webTitle: Banks urged to bail out euro

fields.headline: Banks urged to bail out euro
fields.standfirst:
Single currency has become an embarrassment and intervention inevitable, says IMF
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The world's leading financial institution yesterday said it appeared inevitable that US and European central banks would intervene on the money markets to halt the slide in the value of the euro.
fields.body:
The world's leading financial institution yesterday said it appeared inevitable that US and European central banks would intervene on the money markets to halt the slide in the value of the euro.

The International Monetary Fund's chief economist, Michael Mussa, said that it was now a question not of "if, but when" central bankers should act.

"Circumstances in which major countries would want to use intervention to attempt to influence exchange rates are relatively rare, but they do arise," said Mr Mussa, who was speaking in Prague at the beginning of the IMF/World Bank annual meeting. "One has to ask 'If not now, when?'"

The relentless fall in the euro's value continued yesterday after reports that Denmark's voters may reject the single currency and traders sent its value tumbling to below 85 cents against the dollar for the first time.

The remarks by the IMF drew an angry response from the German government. "Michael Mussa should concentrate on his job instead of giving his advice to the European Central Bank," said a source.

Finance ministers from the world's leading economies, who are gathering in the Czech capital for a G7 meeting this weekend, are being placed under mounting pressure to coordinate a buying spree on the foreign exchanges in support of the euro.

Central banks intervene in foreign exchange markets when they want to strengthen a currency. By buying euro and selling dollars they would reduce the supply of euro in the market and give the currency some support as it hovers at record lows.

But there has been no concerted central bank action to support the euro, which has tumbled more than 25% against the dollar since it was launched in January 1999.

Traders agreed that the euro was in dire straits. "I think the market has decided that until there's actual intervention or some other means by the (European Central Bank), any rally in the euro will be unsustainable," said Jeffrey Yu, a currency trader at Sanwa Bank.

The markets are worried that divisions between Europe and the US may prevent the G7 from agreeing a rescue package this weekend.

US policymakers are unlikely to back any moves to lower the dollar, which is helping keep the American economy from overheating by suppressing inflationary pressures, and analysts do not believe that the European Central Bank can win a fight with the markets without US backing.

Mr Mussa said that the euro's weakness had originally been "an embarrassment rather than a problem" for European policymakers. But he said it was now becoming a problem not just for Europe but for the world economy.

While the US was benefiting from lower inflation, Mr Mussa said the dollar was "not sustainable at its present level" which could exacerbate the record American current account deficit.

Mr Mussa also used the Prague meeting yesterday to urge the EU to set a credible timetable to bring in new members from eastern Europe, but said the newcomers might face problems if they introduced the euro too quickly.

"Full economic convergence with the income levels of western Europe will take years, well beyond any prospective timetable for the adoption of the euro."

fields.headline: James Turrell Skyspace
fields.standfirst: Kielder, Northumberland  *****
fields.trailText: Kielder, Northumberland *****
fields.body:
Is this shape of the future? A circular structure walled with dry stone stands on Cat Cairn, a rocky outcrop overlooking Kielder Forest, Northumberland, a spot that feels as far from modern urban life as it is possible to get. To enter James Turrell's Skyspace you have to pass through a tunnel in the hillside, like the passages that led into the neolithic barrows once built in places like this. Crossing this threshold, you are invited to worship the sky.

The Skyspace is a circular white-walled room with a bench round the circumference and a circular hole in the roof. The hole is like the pupil of an eye fixed unblinkingly on the heavens. You can sit, or better still lie, on the bench and watch the sky move across the aperture. Everything speeds up: you realise how fast things change when you concentrate on the same bit of sky. Clouds unravel. For a while - if you're lucky - the sky turns completely blue.

It's impossible to see it as empty space. Instead you experience the illusion that the sky is a dome. This perceptual shift is called "celestial vaulting". Lying here, it makes you feel part of nature. Stumbling out of the Skyspace into a landscape of felled trees and mossy stones, you are more aware of the texture of light, the colours in the sky.

Turrell was part of a group of artists who made installations with light and space in 1960s California. Since the 1970s he has been turning the Roden Crater, an extinct volcano in the Painted Desert outside Flagstaff, Arizona, into a labyrinthine system of Skyspaces receptive to light from different parts of the galaxy. Turrell is the last great American romantic artist, giving the viewer rhapsodic encounters with nature and the mystery of light. He proves that artists can still look at nature afresh.

It's like a new religion - you can imagine a future in which James Turrell is venerated as the prophet of light and every community has its own Skyspace. Turrell has cited Maes Howe in Scotland, constructed 5,000 years ago and aligned to receive the light of the winter solstice, as an influence on the Roden Crater. Seeing his Skyspace in Kielder, you realise that what he really wants to do is take us back to the stone age.

Details: 01434 220643.

fields.headline: Doomed love at the London Coliseum
fields.standfirst:
Manon Lescaut
London Coliseum ****
fields.trailText:
Manon Lescaut
London Coliseum ****
fields.body:
There are nine new productions in English National Opera's Italian Season, its bold and imaginative venture to celebrate both the millennium and the centenary of Verdi's death. Puccini's Manon Lescaut opened the season on Monday, with Monteverdi's The Coronation of Poppea to follow the night after, so the beginning and end of the great Italian lyric tradition were represented from the start.

The key to this massive project lies in the design: without a basic set running throughout the series, managing such a number of shows would be logistically impossible. So Stefanos Lazaridis has come up with an all-purpose setting onto which extra elements will be grafted to define each staging. But this is more than some neutral, background idea. Lazaridis's set confronts the audience as soon as they enter the auditorium; made of old scaffolding lashed together, it encloses the stalls with a walkway running the whole circumference of the auditorium at circle level, with ladders to higher platforms where the boxes would otherwise be and similar galleries surrounding the acting area. A spiral stairway leads upwards from the stage into the flies.

For the opening show, director Keith Warner has used every level to come up with a wonderfully rich, psychologically penetrating and dramatically effective staging of Manon Lescaut that steadily tightens its focus, just as the opera does, on to the pair of doomed lovers. The galleries are thronged with the chorus in the opening act, observing and commenting upon the burgeoning love between Manon and des Grieux, and they follow her downfall in the second with equal relish. In the third the convicted women embarking on the prison ship to America are paraded around the auditorium on the walkway, derided by the chorus all the time. The distinction between audience and action, already blurred by the portrayal of the old roué Edmondo as a chorus figure, becomes hard to sustain, so that the final act played out between Manon and des Grieux in the wreckage of the set is all the more concentrated.

Warner makes telling use of symbolism too. As the prelude is played, a masked figure, representing the corrupt world that will bring Manon's destruction, teases a young girl (Manon herself, presumably) with toys - a horse, a gilded mansion. When she is arrested as a prostitute at the end of the second act, Edmondo brutally stamps upon the house. In the final scene, as the lovers expire in the desert, Manon catches sight of her reflection and sees instead that young girl. They are simple gestures, yet wonderfully effective. The show is full of such careful details, which cumulatively bring this sometimes problematic drama to life.

The main challenge is mapping the personality of Manon herself - an innocent virgin in the first act, transformed into a grasping opportunist in the second, yet changed again into a tragic heroine by the end. Nina Stemme manages that progression pretty convincingly, singing better and better as the evening went on. Martin Thompson's des Grieux is sturdily sung too. David Kempster's Lescaut is nicely ambivalent, Mark Richardson's Geronte an irredeemable old lecher, and John Graham-Hall's Edmondo a wonderful Voltairian portrait of total corruption. The chorus are brilliantly marshalled, and Paul Daniel conducts the score with increasing passion and certainty as the opera homes in on its tragic target. A great start to a fascinating autumn at the Coliseum.

In rep until November 3. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

fields.headline: Theatre  Alcestis
fields.standfirst: Viaduct Theatre, Halifax ***
fields.trailText: Viaduct Theatre, Halifax ***
fields.body:
What drove Ted Hughes to adapt Alcestis, the Euripides play in which a wife dies in order that her husband may live? The temptation is to see it as a deeply personal work hewn out of Hughes's relationship with Sylvia Plath. But one virtue of Barrie Rutter's premiere production for North ern Broadsides is that it allows us to see the play in larger, more visionary terms.

Hughes's version is anything but straight Euripides. He keeps the structure whereby Admetos, the king of Thessaly, accepts his wife's sacrifice of her life for his. He also preserves the magical conclusion in which Heracles resurrects Alcestis. But where Euripides casts his sceptical eye over woman's unequal relationship to man, Hughes makes this a story of struggle and, finally, hope in which death is conquered not just by Heracles but by unswerving love.

Hughes heightens the conflict in several ways; one is by sharpening the exchanges between Admetos and his father who refuses to give up his own life. His chief innovation is to make Heracles a pivotal figure who, while sojourning in Admetos's house, re-enacts his 12 labours. My first reaction was that this clogs the narrative, but Hughes's purpose is twofold: to motivate Heracles's act of human resurrection and to show that all existence is a struggle between death and love.

This spirit informs Hughes's Birthday Letters; it also lurks behind The Winter's Tale. Hughes is consciously tapping into the great Shakespearean reconciliation-myth as the silent Alcestis is restored to her husband. And Rutter's production plays on those links by having Joanne Thirsk's Alcestis preserve a touching statue-like stillness as she awaits her husband's reclamation.

The production has a stark severity - a brick-walled background, shadowy vaults - but given the optimistic ending and the modernity of Hughes's language I wished that the production were lighter in tone. The acting sometimes succumbs to armpit rhetoric and the costumes, making Admetos and his courtiers look like a group of shaven-headed transvestites, are odd.

Despite the gear, Andrew Cryer is a suitably suffering Admetos, David Hounslow is a bluff Heracles and Barrie Rutter himself gets things off to a brisk start as a scene-setting Apollo. But if it is a stirring evening it is largely because of Hughes's moving insistence on the power of memory and passion to triumph over death.

At the Viaduct Theatre until September 23. Box office: 01422 255266. Then touring. This review ran in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: Vegastones
fields.standfirst: Monarch, London ****
fields.trailText: Monarch, London ****
fields.body:
As the infamous Robert De Niro psycho speech from Taxi Driver spills out from the speakers, you wonder what to expect from the Vegastones. Any notions of severe mohicans and combat jackets are dispelled, however, by the picture of glamour that appears from the darkness. The Vegastones blatantly set out to dispel preconceptions: well, a band made up of two Australians and a Bulgarian can't really help it. While singer Tim Van Der Kuil and drummer Damon Wilson look fairly ordinary, it's the peroxide chic of bassist Svetlana Valeninova that sets the stage alight, a vision in tight pink trousers and white feather boa. Then the music begins.

A heady mix of punk, pop and rock'n'roll, the Vegastones create polished chaos for the disenchanted, a slice of Americana romanticised in a way that could only come from outsiders. This is a Kerouac road movie soundtracked by the Stooges with an eye firmly on day-time radio. One blast could blow Britney into the stratosphere.

Disco is introduced by Van Der Kuil as "a song about love, sex and self- destruction", and his sleazy vocals - a corrupted Chris Isaak, telling tales of the big city while serving behind a midwestern bar - suit the subject matter well. As Wilson, more Animal from the Muppets than Beach Boy Dennis, attempts to tear the skins off his drums with his frantic pace, Valeninova shakes her hair furiously. She's like the love child of Nico and John Entwhistle, with clipped yet childlike vocals and hands that hit the frets like a demon.

While the Vegastones' heart lies in rock'n'roll, there's a meaty slice of 60s garage in there too. Sticky is joyfully catchy pure pop, while Drag Queen Eyes maintains a theme of beautiful girls with tragic lives that spins throughout the Vegastones songs. But it's Neko, from upcoming EP Easy Listening Does My Head In, with its thrash punk fuzziness, that is most intoxicating. Van Der Kuil charges towards Valeninova with his guitar, before turning to Wilson, who is still smashing the life out of his drums. Unsurprisingly, they're all smiling.

webTitle: Merope Mills  on MI5 recruiting teachers

fields.headline: Do you promise not to tell?
fields.standfirst:
MI5 wants to recruit teachers - as long as they're prepared to lie about their new career. Merope Mills examines the pressures of having a top secret job

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: MI5 wants to recruit teachers - as long as they're prepared to lie about their new career. Merope Mills examines the pressures of having a top secret job.
fields.body:
It had all the hallmarks of your average job ad - but with one noteworthy difference. Nestling among the higher education classifieds last week was an advertisement offering teachers, healthcare workers and counsellors the chance to do "something completely different" - an invitation from the internal security service MI5 to apply to join its spy-recruiting department. James Bond it might not be, but the small print highlighted a crucial qualification for the job: an almost superhuman degree of self-control. "Please avoid telling your friends about your application," it pleaded. "Discretion is an essential part of working for the security service."

Working for MI5 - like working for the covert wings of government, policing and the armed forces - may sound thrilling, but there are serious psychological downsides to pursuing a top secret career.

"It was really hard, but it was part of the job and you just had to accept that," recalls Oleg Gordievsky, who defected from the KGB to join MI6 in 1985. Even though he never had to sign the Official Secrets Act, he says, he kept his counsel, "based on my own principles and conscience." As a result, even his closest family were kept in the dark on all matters deemed top secret. "I didn't tell them anything. My children were brought up on the crossroads of the cold war, so they didn't want to know, and my sister never asked because she didn't want to put that pressure on me."

In a culture in which work plays such a major role in our daily conversations and personal relationships, some psychologists argue that the strain of conducting a cloak-and-dagger career is one more job stress a wearied labour force does not need.

"It does create additional problems because generally you can only talk to people in the same business," says Noreen Tehrani, now a psychologist specialising in workplace stress but previously a government researcher who was required to sign the Official Secrets Act. "There was a time when I couldn't tell anyone what I was doing and it made my social life quite difficult because when I met new people, they'd always ask: 'What do you do?' And I'd have to say: 'I can't really tell you.' I'm in the same situation now as most of my work is confidential and because we talk about work so much, there's an element of, well, what kind of conversations can you have?"

During the 10 years he served in the SAS, Neil Coleman could give no indication to his family when, where or for how long he'd be gone. "It was stressful," he says. "There were times in my life when nobody knew where I was - and when you went home everything could be hunky-dory or your wife could have left you."

In a career marked by extreme danger - including helping to end the Iranian embassy siege in 1980 - the strain of not talking about work often manifested itself indirectly in his personal relationships, which suffered as a result. "The nature of the job and the lack of communication obviously caused pressures with your wife, so in my job there was a high divorce rate." He even attributes part of the post-traumatic stress from which he still suffers to that specific job requirement.

But there are things to be gained from an embargo on work-oriented coversation, argues Guy Fielding, a lecturer at Oxford University who has researched secrets, lies and interpersonal relationships. "The flipside of this kind of secrecy is that these people could get some separation between the various aspects of their life," he says. "They have to divide work life from family life and social life, which can give psychological benefit."

Perhaps it is for this reason that Commander David Perfect had no qualms about being restrained from talking shop with family and friends during his 31-year career in the Royal Navy's submarine service. "There were lots of times we couldn't talk about the job, but I didn't find it particularly hard. In fairness to the system, it was explained to everyone what you could or could not say, and everybody knew the ground rules. I could say, I'm going away at this time, I'm likely to be back at this time and this is the sort of area I'll be in."

Navy bases provided an essential support network for his family in his absence, Perfect says. "There were a lot of wives living together and they all had their own ideas about what we were up to. It didn't really matter whether they were right or wrong - it just helped."

But by no means everyone who takes a vow of secrecy manages to muster so much self-control - and the consequences can be devastating, as history demonstrates, from the intrigues of Imperial Rome to the Profumo affair and beyond. Gordievsky admits it is a temptation to which even the most cunning of double agents is subject. "I had a British lady friend and it was difficult not to share the circumstances of my job with someone I was that close to. We talked about her work more, but sometimes I did open up to her, which was a bit against the rules."

Nevertheless, Gordievsky says, the secretiveness imposed by a career in espionage may be equalled by the pressures towards confidentiality of the modern business world. "It was hard, but sometimes I think it wasn't as hard as some of the pressures people have in business today," he says. "They have obligations to the deals they strike - a lot feel they can't turn to anyone when they think things are wrong or corrupt. Things are hanging over their heads, too."

My children were brought up on the crossroads of the cold war, so they didn't want to know, and my sister never asked because she didn't want to put that pressure on me." In a culture in which work plays such a major role in our daily conversations and personal relationships, some psychologists argue that the strain of conducting a cloak-and-dagger career is one more job stress a wearied labour force does not need. "It does create additional problems because generally you can only talk to people in the same business," says Noreen Tehrani, now a psychologist specialising in workplace stress but previously a government researcher who was required to sign the Official Secrets Act. "There was a time when I couldn't tell anyone what I was doing and it made my social life quite difficult because when I met new people, they'd always ask: 'What do you do?' And I'd have to say: 'I can't really tell you.' I'm in the same situation now as most of my work is confidential and because we talk about work so much, there's an element of, well, what kind of conversations can you have?" During the 10 years he served in the SAS, Neil Coleman could give no indication to his family when, where or for how long he'd be gone. "It was stressful," he says. "There were times in my life when nobody knew where I was - and when you went home everything could be hunky-dory or your wife could have left you." In a career marked by extreme danger - including helping to end the Iranian embassy siege in 1980 - the strain of not talking about work often manifested itself indirectly in his personal relationships, which suffered as a result. "The nature of the job and the lack of communication obviously caused pressures with your wife, so in my job there was a high divorce rate." He even attributes part of the post-traumatic stress from which he still suffers to that specific job requirement. But there are things to be gained from an embargo on work-oriented coversation, argues Guy Fielding, a lecturer at Oxford University who has researched secrets, lies and interpersonal relationships. "The flipside of this kind of secrecy is that these people could get some separation between the various aspects of their life," he says. "They have to divide work life from family life and social life, which can give psychological benefit." Perhaps it is for this reason that Commander David Perfect had no qualms about being restrained from talking shop with family and friends during his 31-year career in the Royal Navy's submarine service. "There were lots of times we couldn't talk about the job, but I didn't find it particularly hard. In fairness to the system, it was explained to everyone what you could or could not say, and everybody knew the ground rules. I could say, I'm going away at this time, I'm likely to be back at this time and this is the sort of area I'll be in." Navy bases provided an essential support network for his family in his absence, Perfect says. "There were a lot of wives living together and they all had their own ideas about what we were up to. It didn't really matter whether they were right or wrong - it just helped." But by no means everyone who takes a vow of secrecy manages to muster so much self-control - and the consequences can be devastating, as history demonstrates, from the intrigues of Imperial Rome to the Profumo affair and beyond. Gordievsky admits it is a temptation to which even the most cunning of double agents is subject. "I had a British lady friend and it was difficult not to share the circumstances of my job with someone I was that close to. We talked about her work more, but sometimes I did open up to her, which was a bit against the rules." Nevertheless, Gordievsky says, the secretiveness imposed by a career in espionage may be equalled by the pressures towards confidentiality of the modern business world. "It was hard, but sometimes I think it wasn't as hard as some of the pressures people have in business today," he says. "They have obligations to the deals they strike - a lot feel they can't turn to anyone when they think things are wrong or corrupt. Things are hanging over their heads, too."

fields.headline: Yahoo! and Amazon part
fields.standfirst: E-merchant loses most favoured bookseller status
fields.trailText: Surfers using the internet's most popular portal, Yahoo!, will no longer be advised to buy books at Amazon.com after a parting of the ways between the two big-name hi-tech companies.
fields.body:
Surfers using the internet's most popular portal, Yahoo!, will no longer be advised to buy books at Amazon.com after a parting of the ways between the two big-name hi-tech companies.

Amazon walked away from its partnership with Yahoo! after the end of a three-year agreement on Monday.

Under the tie-up, anyone entering a query on Yahoo! was offered the chance to buy books on the subject at Amazon.

The end of the agreement was seen as a blow to California-based Yahoo! Analysts said several internet vendors had renegotiated agreements with web portals after deciding that the number of customers generated was disappointing.

Yahoo said the partnership had been ended "mutually". It moved swiftly to fill the gap, naming Barnesandnoble.com, as its "preferred bookseller" in the US. On other national sites such as Yahoo.co.uk, Amazon will still be recommended in the short term, although there was speculation that agreements elsewhere were likely to be re-examined.

Yahoo's president, Jeff Mallett, put a brave face on the news, stressing the potential of the deal with Barnesandnoble.com, even though it has only a third as many customers as Amazon. "This displays our continued commitment to offering convenient, quality resources and services to our millions of users," he said.

Barnesandnoble.com is a joint venture between Barnes & Noble, the US chain of "bricks and mortar" bookshops, and Mannesmann, the telecoms company owned by Vodafone. Barnesandnoble shares surged 30% on hopes the tie-up would raise the profile of the business.

Amazon said it intended to concentrate on an alternative agreement with America Online. A spokeswoman said: "This was more compelling to us for a variety of reasons."

Amazon is thought likely to have been impressed by AOL's merger with Time Warner, which could offer more opportunities for co-promotion.

The online bookseller has been making an effort to cut marketing costs recently, following concerns about its business model.

Amazon is often cited as an example of the trend for markets to generate sky-high valuations for dot.com companies with few assets and no record of profits.

In addition to being the number one bookseller on the net, Amazon is the leader in selling videos, compact discs and DVDs.

AOL's president, Bob Pittman, said: "Amazon.com is one of the best known online retailers in the world and I'm pleased to extend a relationship that has clearly been successful for both of us."

Amazon's top selling lists are seen as a bellwether for the popularity of books and music. Among its latest bestsellers are JK Rowling's novel Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire and the Barenaked Ladies' album Maroon.

fields.headline: Jimi Teno
fields.standfirst: Barbican, London ***
fields.trailText: Barbican, London ***
fields.body:
During Spell (the new single), Jimi Tenor said: "I've been trying to keep my cool." It's hard to take this comment seriously when the performer is dressed like an Indo-Jazz Snow Queen, in a wedge-shaped helmet, with yards of net tumbling from harem pants and a midriff- revealing silver top. Previously he had been wearing a red kaftan with flapping flares. For sheer ambition and audacity, you've got to hand it to Tenor.

It's not just the outfits: in his bid for megastar domination, he sold out the Barbican Hall for two sets largely taken from his album Out of Nowhere, accompanied by two guitarists, bass guitar and drums, sitar and tamboura, plus Mike Kearsy, Tenor's regular trombonist, conducting the 60-strong Trinity College of Music Orchestra. They managed the funkier phrases with precision and added welcome colour and performance detail: sparkling celesta, punchy marimba and rasping bass trombone. Tenor was always busy, whether on flute, tenor sax, organ or Moog, while his urgent, fragile falsetto is effective and disorienting - like seeing Warhol singing Bowie in Elton John drag.

Tenor's sound is indebted to a whole generation of half- forgotten soundtrack composers, the studio-tanned pros who routinely "rescued" films by splicing and spicing big ensembles and boogaloo grooves with exotica and electronics. He and Kearsy have briefly resurrected this Frankenstein monster of contemporary music, once relegated to Oxfam vinyl bins and late-night TV. Close your eyes and you can see sex and violence, bad fashion and continuity errors. Open them and there's the more appealing sight of Tenor's two accompanying vocalists (Nicole Willis and Wanda Pittman), adding a nicely pitched soulfulness to songs such as Backbone of Night, Sugardaddy and the anthemic Better Than Ever.

webTitle: Net bank targets the new rich

fields.headline: Net bank targets the new rich
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking group, yesterday set its sights on a new breed of affluent British investors by introducing a pan-European online investment and banking service. The internet-based venture will go live in Britain and Germany next month.
fields.body:
Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking group, yesterday set its sights on a new breed of affluent British investors by introducing a pan-European online investment and banking service. The internet-based venture will go live in Britain and Germany next month.

The bank also plans to open a number of branches, dubbed "investment centres", in Britain. It has set itself a target of signing up 1m customers across Europe over five years.

The online service, Global Investor Portfolio, will allow customers to deal in shares on 15 stock markets including London, Frankfurt and New York, and hold their cash in four currencies: sterling, US dollars, Swiss francs and euros.

There will also be an "investment supermarket" offering products from companies such as Schroder, Merrill Lynch, Mercury Asset Management, HSBC and ABN Amro as well as its own Credit Suisse Asset Management arm. Personal financial advice will be added next year.

The service, which will be rolled out across the European Union, puts Credit Suisse in head-to-head competition with HSBC and Merrill Lynch, whose online joint venture targeting affluent investors in Britain goes live later this year.

Credit Suisse hopes the idea of having an account with a well-known Swiss bank will attract British investors. It declined to disclose how much it was spending on the venture other than to say it was "a significant investment".

A spokesman said that, while the service was an online facility with telephone back-up, it would take bricks and mortar form with the opening of hi-tech centres in major areas. It is trialling a centre in Milan.

Thomas Wellauer, chief executive of Credit Suisse Financial Services, said the new service was targeting the 40m people identified as "Europe's 'new affluents' ".

"These are the people who have gained most from the years of economic growth, rising incomes and rising stock markets, but feel the investment services they receive have not improved in line with their new-found affluence."

These individuals' total invested assets are typically in the region of £30,000-plus.

A spokesman said the service was not aiming to be the cheapest and would not be competing with the net's discount brokers, but it is starting with a special offer of a flat fee of £15 per trade.

Credit Suisse aims to have more than £20bn under management within five years. It is planned that the service will be available via digital television and Wap mobile phones.

Credit Suisse First Boston, the group's investment banking arm, plans a similar online private banking service in the US through its recent acquisition Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette.

The move comes amid predictions that the number of online banking and investment accounts in Europe will top 14m by 2004.

The number of households in Europe, the Far East, Japan and Latin America which are on the net and contain active investors is expected to grow more than fourfold over the next 10 years to 50m.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
How do you convince your boss that you are right?

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How do you convince your boss that you are right?
fields.body:
Katie James, 43 project manager

In a previous job, I had to manage a colleague who used to be my boss. He refused to take my leadership, so I drew up a contract for him because I wanted to keep tabs on what he was up to. He took this as an insult and resigned. At a meeting to tie up loose ends, he told me he was willing to stay on under a compromise, but I said no and offered my own resignation instead. This wasn't accepted and he had to leave. I won out because I believed I was doing the right thing for the organisation and once I'd convinced myself of that, it was easy to convince my boss.

Alison Parker, 39 chief executive

I once had a boss who refused to travel second class, even though it was company policy. He used to ask me to book his tickets and would complain because I wouldn't travel in first class with him. It came to a head when we travelled to London by train and he wanted a meeting on board. As usual I refused to travel first class, he refused to travel second and even on the train neither of us budged. From then on, we made separate arrangements. I won't go against company policy because I think if you feel strongly about something, no matter how petty, you must stick to your guns.

Patrick Shingler, 48 business development director

I once argued that investing in a certain factory was not a good idea but I was against a group of people at work who thought it was. The key to standing your ground is to find the most influential person in the group and persuade them you are right. They, in turn, can persuade everyone else. I knew this major investment decision wasn't going to work, so, armed with the facts, I went to my chief executive and convinced him it was a bad idea. It's hard work, though, because not only do you have to convince people your idea is right, you've also got to show why the initial idea was wrong.

Jane Ross, 38 chief executive

When you stand your ground, first you've got to work out why people are against your ideas. I once spent six months with my team, putting together a proposal for a project. We had a meeting with a valuable client who wanted to change most of it. This had happened before and people had accepted his changes, but I stopped him mid-sentence to ask why and what better ideas he had. He was shocked at my audacity and didn't really have an answer. If you've put a lot of work into a project, you have to fight to keep it and that means not allowing some big ego to stamp on your ideas.

Chrissy Lewis, 47 publisher

A couple of years ago, my team was relocated. We were in a tiny room with inadequate resources and morale was low. I brought up the subject at virtually every meeting with my boss because I felt I had a responsibility to make my staff happy. Eventually he got so fed up that he referred me to his boss. I had all my arguments prepared, he was sympathetic and we were relocated. If you have a problem, don't be afraid to chip away at your boss, because while he may not be able to sort it out, he may be able to put you in touch with someone who can.

webTitle: Captain Alleyne takes the A train

fields.headline: Captain Alleyne takes the A train
fields.trailText: Mark Alleyne, who captained Gloucestershire to an unprecedented treble of one-day competitions this summer, will lead the England A party for the second winter running. Mike Selvey reviews the squad.
fields.body:
Mark Alleyne, who captained Gloucestershire to an unprecedented treble of one-day competitions this summer, will lead the England A party for the second winter running. Alleyne was one of 16 players, half of them aged 22 or under, six with Test experience and three who have tasted one-day international cricket, who will visit West Indies early next year to play in the Busta Cup, their domestic competition.

In a surprise move, the selectors have named John Crawley as Alleyne's deputy. The Lancashire captain has not played Test cricket for two years since an indifferent tour of Australia, although his capacity to play spin made him a candidate for the main tour of Sri Lanka in February.

Youngest of the squad is Jamie Foster, the 20-year-old Essex wicketkeeper, who played for England Under-19 against Australia this year. There are grounds for optimism for the Test players Chris Schofield, the Lancashire leg-spinner who was given a central contract and played two Tests this summer, Aftab Habib, who played two Tests against New Zealand last year, Chris Read, Alex Tudor and Chris Silverwood, all of whom might have wondered if international cricket was not passing them by.

The New Zealand spin bowler Daniel Vettori is heading home after his back problems resurfaced during the first Test against Zimbabwe in Bulawayo, and will be replaced by the all-rounder Glen Sulzberger.

Grant Flower, who was called three times for throwing on Saturday, has had his bowling action cleared by Zimbabwe's cricket authorities and is likely to play in the second Test against New Zealand starting today.

A commission investigating corruption in South African cricket yesterday sought India's assistance in obtaining a copy of a crucial tape recording and access to bookmakers accused of match fixing.

Shamila Batohi, chief prosecutor of the South African commission, met police officials to seek a copy of tape recordings made by Delhi police of South Africa's captain Hansie Cronje in conversation with an Indian bookmaker earlier this year.

England A squad: M W Alleyne (Gloucs, capt), J P Crawley (Lancs, vice-capt), I J Ward (Surrey), V S Solanki (Worcs), U Afzaal (Notts), A Habib (Leics), D J G Sales (Northants), C M W Read (Notts, wkt), J S Foster (Essex, wkt), P J Franks (Notts), A J Tudor (Surrey), C E W Silverwood (Yorks), R J Sidebottom (Yorks), S J Harmison (Durham), J F Brown (Northants), C P Schofield (Lancs).

England Under-19 squad (for winter tour of India): I R Bell (Warks, capt), M A Wallace (Glam, wkt), N Peng (Durham), K Ali (Worcs), G Pratt (Durham), M S Panesar (Northants), I Pattison (Durham), J Sadler (Yorks), J E Bishop (Essex), C Tremlett (Hants), G Muchall (Durham), A C McGarry (Essex), R Ferley (Kent), K Hogg (Lancs), A Suppiah (Somerset).

webTitle: Cricket: Mike Selvey reviews the season

fields.headline: Golden summer needs gilding this winter
fields.standfirst: Vibrant season ends with England still in dire need of quality spinners
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey reviews a vibrant season that has ended with England still in dire need of quality spinners.
fields.body:
It is hard to believe now but 12 months ago English cricket was lying in a tattered heap. A desperate World Cup, preceded by an undermining shabby scuffling over money, was followed by a humiliating defeat by a modest New Zealand side. England, unofficially anyway, were deemed to be the worst international team on earth.

In that year since then the change round has been astonishing and when, on a gorgeous early autumn day, Nasser Hussain lifted the Wisden Trophy aloft on the Oval balcony it put the cap on the most compelling international season that this country has seen since the Ashes were turned round in 1981.

How rosy is the garden really though, and in particular, are England beginning to achieve in spite of still, rather than because of, the system? Much has been made this season of the revamped two-divisional county championship and there is no question that August blues, where cricketers with nothing to play for wish their lives away, have been replaced by some admirable relegation and promotion scraps. Yet there is something imperfect in a championship that will see a third of each division promoted and relegated each year (imagine football's Premiership like that).

Whatever the competitive edge, however, the standard of cricket remains disappointingly the same and will do so until a way is found of concentrating talent into fewer sides, so that the transition between domestic and international cricket is as seamless as possible. Regional cricket - six sides with county cricket providing the next tier equivalent to Australian grade cricket - has to be investigated.

The standard of pitches both domestic and international remains at an all-time low, too. There is something wrong when matches are consistently finishing inside three days and in the case of Headingley in less than two.

Then there is the dearth of spin bowling and the capacity to play it which will hold England back as a top-flight Test nation. They will be facing the three best spinners in the world - Saqlain Mushtaq, Muttiah Muralitharan and Shane Warne - in the course of the next year and the difference between success and failure as a side could hinge on how well they are handled. England need to encourage youngsters to visit the academies of the subcontinent as part of their education.

Yet England fortunes were nonetheless turned around with dramatic effect. Three series, Tests and one-day, were all won. Zimbabwe, a team of limited resource but resourceful, were no walkover. But at Lord's in their first Test in England they got stage fright and, although in the second Test they punched their weight and gave England a late scare, they had missed an opportunity.

Next came the first two Tests against West Indies. In the opener, on yet another inferior Test strip at Edgbaston, England were trounced in three days and, in the eyes of the public, all the old doubts resurfaced. These were put firmly in their place by a stunning performance at Lord's where imminent defeat was transposed to victory in one of the most scintillating Tests seen.

More success came in the triangular series and the wagon was rolling. Since then, when team uncertainties began to be eliminated, the side has not looked back and there is genuine hope of a successful winter in Pakistan and Sri Lanka and of a real tilt at the Ashes next summer.

So why the transformation? The appointment of Hussain as captain, and then of the dispassionate Zimbabwean Duncan Fletcher as coach, has proved inspirational. Hussain is authoritative and up front, Fletcher the quiet, firm, understated bedrock to the England cause. Together, in South Africa last winter, they set out to identify the best players, not just technically but temperamentally, and to give them the best conditions in which to flourish.

There was a nucleus to the side: Atherton, Alec Stewart, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick. Out of the South African winter had come Michael Vaughan's unflappable batting and, by chance, Craig White's genuine pace and swing. Dominic Cork returned for West Indies and immediately announced himself once more as a match-winner, while Marcus Trescothick justified Fletcher's judgment of his ability.

Central contracts, while requiring review, ensured Gough, the player of the summer, and Caddick stayed fit and it was the controlled and continuous aggression of the pace quartet that won the summer.

webTitle: Uefa turns down Red Star appeal

fields.headline: Uefa turns down Red Star appeal
fields.trailText: Uefa has turned down an appeal by Red Star Belgrade to allow them to play the second leg of their first-round Uefa Cup tie against Leicester City at home.
fields.body:
Uefa has turned down an appeal by Red Star Belgrade to allow them to play the second leg of their first-round Uefa Cup tie against Leicester City at home.

Uefa ordered the game to be staged at a neutral venue because the Serbs could not provide acceptable guarantees of City's safety in Belgrade. Subsequently, the increasing unrest in Yugoslavia before next week s general election gave Red Star's appeal less chance of succeeding.

But City still do not know where the game, scheduled to be played on Thursday week, will take place. Red Star had been given an extension on yesterday's deadline to come up with an acceptable neutral venue. Red Star having failed to meet that deadline yesterday evening, Uefa will choose the venue to settle the tie, which stands at 1-1 after the first leg at Filbert Street.

A likely solution is the Bulgarian capital Sofia, where Red Star played the home leg of their first-round Uefa Cup tie against Montpellier last season.

Dennis Bergkamp, whose contract at Highbury runs out at the end of the season, said that his agent would meet Arsenal to discuss a two-year extension with the Gunners.

"This is going to be my last contract, so that means it is a very important one," said Bergkamp, who believes that his decision to retire from international football will be to his and Arsenal's advantage.

Newcastle and Rangers are fighting to sign the 19-year-old Colchester winger Lomano Lua-Lua, who is valued at £2m, and Ipswich have signed a 27-year-old Slovenian international, Amir Karic, from NK Maribor on a four-year contract for £700,000.

Charlton may hit a £445,000 jackpot if the 15-year-old midfielder Owen Price turns professional for Tottenham Hotspur, who offered £4,000 for him last year. A Football League tribunal has ruled that Spurs must pay £10,000 to Charlton immediately and up to £100,000 for every 10 senior games Price plays.

webTitle: Michael Owen's top tip... pick me for every England game

fields.headline: Michael Owen's top tip... pick me for every England game
fields.trailText: Using the time honoured TV question to record a voice level and relax a subject before the cameras rolled, the interviewer asked Michael Owen what he had eaten for breakfast.
fields.body:
Using the time honoured TV question to record a voice level and relax a subject before the cameras rolled, the interviewer asked Michael Owen what he had eaten for breakfast.

"Breakfast?" he replied, "I was up too early for that. I was on the Big Breakfast this morning but I certainly haven't had time to eat any." Nor was there now as he flitted from chair to chair in a conference room at London's Langham Hilton to answer much the same questions about his latest book from interviewers as diverse as Gabby Yorath and Charlie Brooks, from Sky to terrestrial through more cable companies than he probably knew existed.

There was even a reporter from one of those kids' TV shows who insisted that Owen begin all his answers with the words "My top tip for ... is ..." Thus we learned that his top tip for having fun is "scoring goals" and his top tip for scoring goals was "don't panic." And his top tip for dealing with daft questions was to break a chair over his interrogator's head.

No, of course he did not. He remained charming and down to earth throughout three hours of this, and the following afternoon signing session for his new book at WH Smith in Oxford Street, where the queues were longer than at the petrol pumps. He is so natural that even his admission that, despite writing two books, he has never read one and has sat through only one full film in Cool Runnings - can you imagine the ridicule David Beckham would have received by committing such a confession to print? - served only to make him appear more touchingly unpretentious.

But then he does redeem himself by reporting that the worst abuse he has ever had was from his local bin man after England's 0-0 draw in Poland last year and his unofficial top tip for life is not to believe your own publicity He says: "When you score a hat-trick, people say you are as good as Pele and when you miss three sitters, they say you are the worst player in the world. But you are neither of those things."

Owen does admits to selfishness, saying: "You would never get in the team or get to play up front if you weren't a selfish person" and to the vice of envy - "if David Beckham, Paul Scholes and the Neville brothers gave me a look in their trophy cabinets, I would be more than jealous." He also covets the automatic striking role in the England team vacated by Alan Shearer.

He says: "I believe I am good enough to play regularly for England and I was disappointed when Kevin Keegan told me before the France game that he was putting me on the bench because he wanted to play with one striker in Andy Cole and use Paul Scholes. He also told me not to read anything into it for the future.

"When I came on, I didn't have enough time alongside Andy Cole to judge whether he would be a better partner for me than Emile Heskey, my Liverpool club mate. But you should be able to play with anybody and Andy is a terrific player at the top of his form.

"So is Emile. He gets lots of stick from the fans and the press but he would be the last person to get stick from the manager or the other players. You cannot know how good it is to play with him and if you analyse Liverpool's goals this season, he has probably played a part in every one."

His book, Michael Owen In Person, is his second so far. And he is still three months short of his 21st birthday, which suggests he might have overtaken Jeffrey Archer for prodigiousness by the time he reaches 30. The full blown autobiography in two years time will be the next in the series.

He is also showing growing skills before the camera, answering a question about next months' World Cup qualifier against Germany by saying: "I'm confident we can win because unlike a lot of players, I have got a 100 per cent record against them - played one, won one."

fields.headline: Larsson on the spot
fields.trailText: Dunfermline 1 - 2 Celtic
fields.body:
The ghost of the old Celtic reappeared briefly yesterday, but it was banished by the revived version at East End Park last night.

First they learned that Kenny Dalglish was suing the club for wrongful dismissal, then Dunfermline threatened to ruin their perfect league record. But Henrik Larsson escaped from the individual attention he was receiving from Scott Thomson to score twice, gain their 11th successive victory and go back to the top of the league.

Dunfermline applied themselves positively to the formidable task of stopping Martin O'Neill's bandwagon and took the lead with a Stevie Crawford penalty in the second half. Celtic hit back with a penalty of their own within two minutes and then claimed all the points when Larsson was allowed more space than he needed to put away the winner.

Dunfermline do not much resemble the stereotype of a new entrant in the hammerthrowers' league. Their manager Jimmy Calderwood, who has long experience in the Netherlands, has reshaped them into a Dutch pattern, with man-marking defenders and a sweeper and a willing adherence to a passing game. Even the goalkeeper favours the dragback.

Calderwood also introduced a wild card in Junior Mendes, who he hoped could surprise a Celtic defender or two with his unrestrained quickness.

For a while this formula threatened to undo the Glasgow giants. In the space of just over a minute in the middle of the first half, Mendes twice penetrated the left flank of the Celtic defence and Lee Bullen had two chances in front of goal but just could not make telling contact.

On the first occasion, Andrius Skirla, a Lithuanian international defender who has played for PSV Eindhoven, played the ball through for the striker to run on to. The ball sat up obligingly on the edge of the area, but Johan Mjallby came across to snuff out the threat.

Dalglish, the former director of football operations, was offered substantial compensation when he left the Glasgow club but rejected the offer.

"There is a potential litigation. We received notice that he intends going after us for compensation," the chairman Brian Quinn told the club's annual general meeting yesterday.

fields.headline: Dynamo Kiev 0 - 0 Manchester United
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Dynamo Kiev: 1-Olexander Shovkovsky, 2-Alexander Khatskevich, 4-Olexander Holovko, 5-Vladislav Vaschuk, 6-Yuri Dmitrulin, 7-Kakha Kaladze, 26-Andriy Nesmachny, 8-Valentin Bialkevich, 10-Maxim Shatskikh, 11-Georgi Demetradze, 14-Andriy Husin.

Manchester United: 17-Raimond Van Der Gouw, 2-Gary Neville, 3-Denis Irwin, 5-Ronny Johnsen, 27-Mickael Silvestre, 7-David Beckham, 8-Nicky Butt, 9-Andy Cole, 11-Ryan Giggs, 16-Roy Keane, 19-Dwight Yorke.

Referee: Kim Milton Nielsen (Denmark)

1 Kiev kick-off in a chilly stadium as United seek to build on their excellent start to this season's campaign.
2 Silvestre lobs the ball up the left flank as United seek to get an early advantage. Kiev reply with a run by Khatskevitch through midfield; he finds Bialkevich outside the area but Van Der Gouw gets there first.
4 Khaladze is brought down by Irwin 30 yards out on the right for a Kiev free-kick but it comes to nothing.
5 Referee Nielsen has a word with Demetradze after a late challenge on Silvestre.
7 United free-kick; Beckham takes from deep in midfield straight into the Kiev area, Kiev counter and United are caught short at the back when Shatskikh gets into the area. Good work by Giggs works the ball out into safety.
8 Almost a goal for United when Giggs plays in Yorke on the edge of the area, but the striker drags his shot wide of the right stick.
10 Kiev lob the ball over the United back line but are caught offside.
12 Giggs finds Silvestre deep in the left, but his cross is into space and easy for Kiev keeper Shovkovsky.
13 A very lively start to the game with Kiev dong a good job of closing United down and forcing them to give away possession. The surface looks heavy and both teams appear to have decided that a quick passing game is the key to a result.
15 Some space for United as Giggs cuts in from the left, but Kiev clear again as he tries to find Yorke.
19 Cole on the left area cuts the ball back for Beckham to rifle in a shot - blocked.
20 Corner to United on the right, but it comes to nothing. Corner to United on the left and Shovkovsky loses sight of the ball before it is cleared.
24 The quick passing game seems to be failing on the dodgy surface and Kiev both sides are finding it hard to hang on to possession.
25 Free-kick to United just over the half-way line. The ball is worked quickly down the right and back for Cole to shoot from the edge of the area. The ball loops up from a deflection and Keane clashes with the keeper as tries to pick up the rebound.
27 Shatskikh tries a shot from distance and is unlucky to see it go narrowly wide.
29 Bialkevich comes close for Kiev when he gets away on the left, cuts inside and works the ball on to his right foot before shooting from just outside the area - Van Der Gouw does well to turn it wide of the far post.
33 United enjoying the best of the possession and still look the more likely to score despite a couple of good chances from Kiev.
35 United in control as Kiev are caught offside yet again.
37 And caught again, although it lookd as though Irwin was playing him on. Lucky, as Irwin then went on to bring down the Kiev player inside the area.
40 Giggs races away through midfield on the counter and finds Cole on the right. He crosses for Beckham on the left but his chip into the area findds no-one.
41 United corner on the right, Beckham takes and Kiev clear.
42 Beckham finds G Neville on the right but the defender over-hits his cross and the move breaks down. Still very much a game of attack and counter-attack.
45 One extra minute to play as the first half draws to a close. Neither team choses to make much use of it. Half-time. Difficult conditions, but will be pleased with their performance so far.

46 Andy Cole shoots from 25 yards when he should not have been allowed the space - not enough purchase and it is saved easily.
48 Dmitrulin plays in Shatskikh just inside the area and his great first touch sees the ball fly off the crossbar - a lucky escape for United.
49 Strong start to the second half for Kiev as Shatskikh agains is the danger when he gets on the end of a deep cross into the six-yard box, but his header is way off the mark.
51 Shatskikh again as he gets away on the right, but his hopeful cross towards towards lone man Demetradze is hopelessly off target.
53 United yet to attack in this half,but now Beckham gets involved. He threads the ball through midfield to Cole on the left; he in turn lays it back for Butt to shoot wide from 25 yards.
58 A lovely flick by Giggs on the edge of the Kiev area just fails to give Cole a shooting chance, Kiev break and United have their work cut out as the Ukrainians flood forward.
60 United caught short as Kiev break, with Shatskikh agains the inspiration. United shut the door just in front of the area.
64 Giggs tries to exploit space on the left; Silvestre gets away to the by-line and his cross is held by keeper Shovkovsky to deny Cole a point-blank header.
67 Substitution Sheringham on for Yorke.
69 Kuzmichev on for Demetradze. Shatskikh has the best chance of the half; after a great run through midfield, he unleashes a shot from 20 yards that Van Der Gouw is at full stretch to turn away via the upright.
71 Van Der Gouw almost blows it for United when he kicks the ball straight to Kiev sub Kuzmichev. He is so surprised by the good fortune that United immediately win it back.
76 The game is still being played at a frantic and somewhat scrappy pace, very much end to end.
78 Substitution Solskjaer on for Cole.
82 Lots going on, but not a lot happening. Keane blasts in a shot from distance, straight at the goalkeeper.
83 SubstitutionThe Hungarian Bodnar on for Dmitrulin.
86 This is not a pretty game as Kiev come forward again. Nesmchney makes a run on the left and crosses into the six-yard box; Husin gets up for the header but he should have done better and fails to find a way through the crowd.
87 Substitution Fedorov on for Husin.
89 Kiev comes close agaim as Nesmachney fires ion a cross from the left - Johnsen the man to make a nuisance of himself and deny the scoring chance.
90 Two minutes extra to play. A job well done by United, who have been well-organised and coped with pretty much everything that Kiev have thrown at them, which hasn't been a great deal. Full-time.

The ball loops up from a deflection and Keane clashes with the keeper as tries to pick up the rebound. 27 Shatskikh tries a shot from distance and is unlucky to see it go narrowly wide. 29 Bialkevich comes close for Kiev when he gets away on the left, cuts inside and works the ball on to his right foot before shooting from just outside the area - Van Der Gouw does well to turn it wide of the far post. 33 United enjoying the best of the possession and still look the more likely to score despite a couple of good chances from Kiev. 35 United in control as Kiev are caught offside yet again. 37 And caught again, although it lookd as though Irwin was playing him on. Lucky, as Irwin then went on to bring down the Kiev player inside the area. 40 Giggs races away through midfield on the counter and finds Cole on the right. He crosses for Beckham on the left but his chip into the area findds no-one. 41 United corner on the right, Beckham takes and Kiev clear. 42 Beckham finds G Neville on the right but the defender over-hits his cross and the move breaks down. Still very much a game of attack and counter-attack. 45 One extra minute to play as the first half draws to a close. Neither team choses to make much use of it. Half-time. Difficult conditions, but will be pleased with their performance so far. 46 Andy Cole shoots from 25 yards when he should not have been allowed the space - not enough purchase and it is saved easily. 48 Dmitrulin plays in Shatskikh just inside the area and his great first touch sees the ball fly off the crossbar - a lucky escape for United. 49 Strong start to the second half for Kiev as Shatskikh agains is the danger when he gets on the end of a deep cross into the six-yard box, but his header is way off the mark. 51 Shatskikh again as he gets away on the right, but his hopeful cross towards towards lone man Demetradze is hopelessly off target. 53 United yet to attack in this half,but now Beckham gets involved. Shatskikh has the best chance of the half; after a great run through midfield, he unleashes a shot from 20 yards that Van Der Gouw is at full stretch to turn away via the upright. 71 Van Der Gouw almost blows it for United when he kicks the ball straight to Kiev sub Kuzmichev. He is so surprised by the good fortune that United immediately win it back. 76 The game is still being played at a frantic and somewhat scrappy pace, very much end to end. 78 Substitution Solskjaer on for Cole. 82 Lots going on, but not a lot happening. fields.headline: Book trade news
fields.standfirst: Fuel crisis hits bookshops, Fay Weldon and Stephen King discover the ups and downs of online publishing, Terry Pratchett scorns the internet, and WH Smith seeks synergy with Booker
fields.trailText: Fuel crisis hits bookshops, Fay Weldon and Stephen King discover the ups and downs of online publishing, Terry Pratchett scorns the internet, and WH Smith seeks synergy with Booker
fields.body:
Fuel blockade hits bookshops

If you go down to your local bookshop this week you may be in for a surprise. For bookshops are running out of books. The book trade's supply chain, hardly the swiftest animal on the planet, has been hit by the petrol blockades with a number of book distributors having to suspend their services in the wake of dwindling fuel supplies. Even with the blockades now over it has been reported that it could take up to three weeks for the situation to return to normal, meaning that long-forgotten backlist titles could soon be making an unexpected appearance at the front of bookshops. Students in particular could be affected by shortages, with local campus bookstores lacking the textbooks required to start the new term.

For the book trade, which once paid a firm of consultants £100,000 to inform it that it was wasting £150m each year shifting books from one location to another, a product blockage during one of its peak selling seasons is the last thing it needs. Voices at trade body the Booksellers Association have been urging publishers to "consider other methods of delivery". Quite what they have in mind is anyone's guess.

The ups and downs of online publishing

This tangible tribulation could be yet another fillip for the virtual world, which has already been boosted by the news that Fay Weldon is publishing her latest book in digital format only, and that Agatha Christie's oeuvre is going online.

Ms Weldon's book, entitled Woodworm or Love Among the Scientists, is being published in serial form weekly on the government website www.YouGov.com. According to the site, Weldon's book is the first work to be serialised on the net as it is written: "Others have published books on the internet, but this is being created exclusively for this site and published immediately each chapter is finished." Readers are also encouraged to send their comments to Weldon. The novel itself, which revolves around the scientific aspirations and jealousies of a female cosmologist, her husband who breeds "sheep from the stem cells of unborn lambs" and his friend who is "involved with the genetic modification of tomatoes," kicked off this week.

Meanwhile, Chorion, which owns the rights to Agatha Christie's vast body of work, has granted Penguin US the licence to publish 10 of her books in electronic format. Chorion, which also owns the rights to Enid Blyton's writing, believes this could be a significant future revenue stream. But it ain't necessarily so, not at least if the latest update on Stephen King's e-book experiment is to be believed. For King, the pioneering e-book advocate and sometime writer of horror books, appears to have run into trouble with his own e-book experiment. The writer, who has been selling his latest novel The Plant for $1 an episode on his website www.stephenking.com, has reported a "widening disparity between downloads and payments" and has suggested that there has "undoubtedly" been some "thievery and bootlegging going on". He also suggests that readers have been downloading more than one version of the text to accommodate their different computer systems or e-books but paying for only one. According to King, this is like book buyers going to a bookstore to ask for free copies of a paperback or audio version of a book because they bought the hardcover. "As simply as I can put it, you must pay for what you take every time you take it or this won't work," King admonishes. King has already stated that if fewer than 75% of downloads were paid for he would desist with the series. Whatever the merits of King's e-book experiment this is now a real possibility, and King risks disappointing his unusually devoted readers - a situation few authors could afford.

Terry Pratchett scorns the internet revolution

Another blow has been dealt to the e-book revolution by fantasy writer Terry Pratchett who, according to the trade website www.theBookseller.com, will not be going digital any time soon.

Likening the internet to a "whining Californian mall rat, forever demanding that the real world be redefined to suit its whims", Mr Pratchett said that "as things stand" he would not be doing a Stephen King. Pratchett's latest novel, The Truth, is being published in November. It is to be hoped that book distributors have managed to refuel before then or the author of the Discworld series of books could find himself in for a road to Damascus-style digital reawakening.

WH Smith seeks synergy with Booker

One thing not worrying Pratchett is the Booker shortlist, due to be announced on October 5. Rumours over the identity of those authors who are likely to make it onto the shortlist have been in shorter supply than usual, but perhaps the field has become much wider than in previous years. Suggestions that the Booker could be dumbing down appear to have been confirmed with the news that WH Smith, purveyor of newspapers, sweets and airport fiction, is "getting behind" the prize like never before. The newsagent is to run its first ever in-store promotion for the award this year, with newly designed point-of-sale material.

Perhaps WH Smith is hoping for a double whammy from the prize and believes that one of the books chosen for the shortlist could be from its own publisher, Hodder Headline. Indeed, this could be just the kind of synergistic link between the publisher and its parent that WHS chief executive Richard Handover might have hoped for when he paid £185m for it more than a year ago. Such synergies have been scarce so far within the group, leading some commentators to wonder about the logic behind the original purchase. Those dissenters may well have been joined this week by WH Smiths' new finance director John Warren. Earlier in the week Mr Warren attended a publishing party held by Hodder Headline, only to find that rival bookseller Waterstone's had been contracted to handle the event's book sales. Mr Warren might also like to take a look at Hodder Headline's new consumer website, www.madaboutbooks.com, which prompts would-be book buyers to purchase their titles from two online bookshops, neither of which is www.whsmith.co.uk.

webTitle: Turning universities into a training ground for industry has its drawback

fields.headline: Servants of the economy
fields.standfirst: Turning universities into a training ground for industry has its drawback
fields.trailText: Turning universities into a training ground for industry has its drawback
fields.body:
The huge growth in postgraduate degrees over the past decade has been accompanied by a shift towards vocational training, with courses and skills now much more focused on the needs of business. But there are increasing concerns that universities are being turned into training grounds for industry.

Postgraduate education bears little resemblance to what it was 20 years ago. In that time there has been a 400% rise in student numbers and a radical change in the type of people engaged in postgraduate study, with much more part-time study and mature and overseas students. Major changes are taking place which will alter the postgraduate experience and reshape higher education.

Postgraduate numbers have risen as people seek to gain further specific training and differentiate themselves in the job market. This means that postgraduate education now has a much more vocational slant to it. The changes are even impacting on research courses, with research and funding councils increasingly stressing the training elements of postgraduate life.

Recent reviews by the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) and the Higher Education Funding Council for England (Hefce) both of which have expanded or made explicit reference to training in postgraduate education. It is no longer seen as sufficient for someone to work on a specific piece of research; they must finish with a set of transferrable skills which can be applied not only in an academic context but in any work situation.

The student progress files initiative takes this a stage further by introducing greater comparability and consistency into a student's record of achievement. These take the form of individual transcripts which are set to become much more comprehensive. This will enable students and employers to access a more detailed record of achievement which more fully reflects their educational experience. But a more significant part of this initiative for students will be the implementation of personal development plans. These will enable students at all levels to maintain a record of their achievements, goals and experience throughout their courses, and be a major contribution to empowering students in their education.

Details of the Progress Files initiative are at www.qaa.ac.uk/

Yet there are worrying aspects to the vocational trends within higher education. Universities are under pressure to make their research, teaching and services more relevant to the broader society and economy.

Although this is to be welcomed in principle, many fear that it would be counterproductive to turn universities into mere training grounds for business, industry and the economy. Universities serve a much broader range of functions than this, acting as reserves of knowledge and drivers of initiative, imagination and analysis for society as a whole.

Faced with an ever more competitive environment, and persistent funding reductions, the sector is having to fight for its place in society as more than an education factory producing products for consumption by the economy.

Proposals from the Conservative party in the past week to free universities by endowing them with funds and removing direct state funding seem to reinforce the idea of universities as no more than servants to the economy. The Conservative proposals say Britain's best universities used to be the best in the world. This is a disingenuous swipe at higher education in Britain as many of us still believe that British universities are the best in the world. Ideas such as these threaten to enhance elitism and reduce opportunity for the population which universities serve as public institutions.

For those wishing to pursue an academic career the prospects are often bleak. Salary levels are depressed and for new lecturing staff the pressures to publish and take on extensive teaching responsibilities very quickly are immense. Universities have generally colluded with the funding agencies to push professional development for their new staff back into the years a person takes to complete a PhD. This has meant that current postgraduates are under great pressure to meet ever-increasing demands on their time for training and publishing, while at the same time providing a considerable amount of undergraduate teaching for departments.

Students are not products but individuals and if the government's policies of lifelong learning and widening access in higher education are to be more than empty rhetoric, universities must change to be more open and accessible and less elitist in their attitudes.

 Jeremy Hoad is general secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee.

fields.headline: Pop goes the weasel
fields.standfirst: Treading a fine line between courageous exposés and scurrilous tittle-tattle, website Pop Bitch is proving a painful thorn in the side to the nation's celebrities.  Clark Collis spoke to its (anonymous) mastermind
fields.trailText: Treading a fine line between courageous exposés and scurrilous tittle-tattle, website Pop Bitch is proving a painful thorn in the side to the nation's celebrities. Clark Collis spoke to its (anonymous) mastermind
fields.body:
All things considered, it has to be said that 21st-century society is not badly served when it comes to pop gossip. Indeed, if the energy that was spent writing stories about chart stars could somehow be recalibrated for automotive use, then the current oil crisis would be over with a single "I'm ' still ' not a lesbian" announcement from Mel C. There are some stories, however, that fall between the cracks - largely because libel-obsessed legal departments drop them down there. Now, thanks to a weekly e-newsletter called Pop Bitch, more and more of these stories are seeing the light of day. Or at least the glow of a computer screen.

"It's for adults who like pop music," says Pop Bitch's 30-year-old co-writer who - at present - prefers to remain anonymous. "I mean, I love pop music. The only difference about us, as opposed to magazines or newspapers, is that we don't want to follow pop stars' agendas. But we genuinely do like these people. We just feel that if they're running around out of their mind on drugs, sleeping with everyone - well, that's fantastic too."

Of course, the internet is not short of places where people can read scuttlebutt about pop stars. The big difference with Pop Bitch is that many of its contributors are proper journalists who have stumbled across tales just a tad too fruity for their respective publications.

"Well, I guess that's true," says Mr X. "I mean I'm a journalist. And a lot of stories come from journalists. But the other person that writes Pop Bitch isn't a journalist, and we now have a message board which lets people post stuff up. Working in the media, there's very much this atmosphere that the readers are just braindead idiots. But, actually, I find that non-journalists' stories can be just as good. The Pop Bitch philosophy is that it's outside the whole process of PRs and parties and journalists. I like to think of it as a communal thing, really."

It is true, however, that Pop Bitch's stories - like those of America's Drudge Report - have increasingly been picked up by the mainstream press.

"Yeah, that's happened quite a lot," agrees the site's mastermind. "We've seen things explicitly ripped off by the tabloid papers and the music press. But you can't be that precious about it. It's gossip after all. It's supposed to be spread. Probably our best scoop, though, was that we had the name of Madonna's baby 10 days before the birth. The funny thing was that nobody picked it up. They just assumed there was no way we could have known that.

Or maybe they just thought we were mucking around. Who would call their kid Rocco?"

The first Pop Bitch, which appeared at the end of last year, featured stories on everything from Ginger Spice's pubic hair to Kenny Rogers' frisbee-throwing, while also printing the midweek chart ("Why wait until Sunday to find out who's number one?") Since then, there have been 40 more editions, each one with a bigger readership.

"We've got about 6,000 subscribers now. But what's interesting is the growth curve - we're adding anther 10 per cent every week. It took us about 27 weeks to reach a thousand. But now it only takes 10 days to add another. It's also growing internationally. For some reason we've got a lot of readers in Portugal."

At present, though, Pop Bitch remains a non-profit-making business ("You can't really sell hot, steaming gossip by the pound") without even any kind of legal war chest in case one of its stories ends up in the libel courts. Not that such a scenario overly worries its creator.

"We've never posted anything which we didn't think was true. Also, we try to guard against libel by using blind items - which blonde songstress has a problem with the white powder? That kind of thing. The only thing we do which is really libellous is a thing on celebrities who have large penises - but we kind of assume no one would sue about that."

Indeed, Mr X claims that, far from complaining about the site, celebrities are more likely to be subscribing to it.

"Yeah, I don't want to name them because I think that would be a breach of trust. But there are a couple of comedians and authors. There's also this manager of a couple of very high-profile pop bands who subscribes, which always makes us wince slightly. Because when we write something about his acts, we know that two hours later he'll be reading it. You've just got to hope that people take it in good humour. That it doesn't come across like a bitter, nasty gossip sheet."

How, then, would he like it to come across?

"Like an affectionate, nasty, gossip sheet."
