webTitle: Israel calls off talks with Palestinians

fields.headline: Israel calls off talks with Palestinians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the middle east
fields.trailText: Israel has called an indefinite "timeout" in peace talks with the Palestinians with the explanation that Yasser Arafat has hardened his  position on the unsettled issues, an Israeli official said today.
fields.body:
Israel has called an indefinite "timeout" in peace talks with the Palestinians with the explanation that Yasser Arafat has hardened his position on the unsettled issues, an Israeli official said today.

Aides to Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak were not immediately available for comment. Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat said he had been scheduled to hold talks today with his Israeli counterpart, Gilead Sher.

Mr Erekat said Mr Sher informed him before the start of the meeting that Israel decided to suspend talks until further notice.

"They told me there would be no meeting tomorrow, or the day after, or the day after," Mr Erekat said.

Mr Erekat said he informed Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat of the decision which he called regrettable. "It is obvious that the Israeli government is trying to assign blame to us, but on the other hand, they are closing all the doors to any progress," he said.

In New York, US secretary of state Madeleine Albright yesterday pledged continued support to bring Israeli-Palestinian negotiations to a successful conclusion, saying peace was the "only path; to a prosperous and safe Middle East.

She made the remarks at a dinner honouring former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres. Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami earlier yesterday said the parties needed to come to agreement by mid-October "at the latest" - a date spurred by US presidential elections in November and the reconvening of Israel's parliament in late October.

Mr Barak is expected to try to shore up his coalition government after recent defections to protest his sweeping concessions to Mr Arafat. The Israeli leader promised delivery of virtually all of the West Bank and Gaza for a Palestinian state.

Israeli-Palestinian negotiations have been hung up because of a sovereignty dispute over Jerusalem holy sites. Gaps remain on other issues, including the future borders of a Palestinian state and the fate of Palestinian refugees.

However, negotiators have expressed confidence that they could conclude a treaty once the Jerusalem dispute is solved. The US is drafting bridging proposals that are to be presented to both sides in a few days.

fields.headline: Havas to buy Hudson Sandler controlling stake
fields.trailText: French ad conglomerate Havas is to acquire a 60% share in London-based financial PR firm Hudson Sandler, says Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
French advertising conglomerate Havas is to acquire a 60% share in London-based financial PR firm Hudson Sandler.

Hudson Sandler will join the Havas Diversified Agencies Group and work with Paris-based W&Cie, which Havas bought last year, to form an investor and financial public relations consultancy.

Havas has not disclosed financial details of the deal.

"We believe that the growth [potential] for financial public relations is in Europe and that European companies now appreciate that they have to talk to their shareholders a lot more," said Hudson Sandler chairman Michael Sandler. "We in Europe are becoming one big integrated market."

Havas is this month expected to complete its $2.1bn (£1.5bn) purchase of US-based Snyder Communications. Last week, it announced it had acquired Canadian agency Vickers & Benson.

fields.headline: Clark joins race for Speaker
fields.trailText: David Clark, the former cabinet minister sacked by Tony Blair, announced yesterday that he is to stand as Commons Speaker with a pledge to abandon the wig and breeches traditionally worn by male holders of the office.
fields.body:
David Clark, the former cabinet minister sacked by Tony Blair, announced yesterday that he is to stand as Commons Speaker with a pledge to abandon the wig and breeches traditionally worn by male holders of the office.

A popular figure among backbenchers on all sides of the house, Dr Clark is the most senior MP to throw his hat into the ring to succeed Betty Boothroyd, who will stand down next month.

Dr Clark, who served as chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster for a year until he was sacked by the prime minister in 1998, won widespread admiration when he stood up to the lord chancellor during a cabinet row over freedom of information.

His stand against Lord Irvine, who was seen as a bully during Labour's first months in office, has led MPs from both sides of the Commons to pledge their support for the MP for South Shields.

Dr Clark, 60, pledged to be a modernising Speaker who would support an end to all-night sittings and a beefing up of the role of select committees.

"The days have gone, except for high days and holidays, when the Speaker should wear breeches, buckled shoes and a wig," he said yesterday. "We have to show the country we are business-like which is difficult when the Speaker is dressed in a medieval fashion."

fields.headline: Labour slump puts Tories ahead
fields.standfirst: Exclusive  Poll shows government trailing by four points and prime minister's popularity in free fall
fields.trailText: The latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today gives the Tories a shock four-point lead and indicates that last week's petrol crisis has plunged Tony Blair into a deeper political hole than even the weekend polls suggested.
fields.body:
The latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today gives the Tories a shock four-point lead and indicates that last week's petrol crisis has plunged Tony Blair into a deeper political hole than even the weekend polls suggested.

It puts the Conservatives on 38% - up four points - and Labour on 34%, its lowest ICM rating since January 1992.

The massive slide in Labour's fortunes - down 10 points on last month's 44% - is a bitter blow to the prime minister who might have expected to see some kind of recovery as the petrol began to flow back to the pumps over the weekend when the survey's fieldwork was done. But the detailed survey findings show that the government completely lost the argument over fuel prices.

The poll also shows that the surprising political winners out of the fuel crisis are proving to be the Liberal Democrats who have made up as much ground as the Tories. The five point rise in their fortunes - from a static 17% - indicates that as many disaffected Labour voters regard Charles Kennedy's party as the next best thing to Labour as those who see the Conservatives as a credible alternative. It means the Liberal Democrats this week face their biggest political opportunity for more than a decade.

The shock for Mr Blair is that the two polls published on Sunday - carried out by Mori and NOP - were taken towards the end of the storm on Thursday and Friday and he could have reasonably expected an almost instant recovery in his party's fortunes.

But this third poll shows that Labour support fell further during the weekend as people reflected on the impact of the crisis on their lives.

Even more worrying for Mr Blair is the fact that the details of the poll results show that the disaffection of former Labour voters is not confined to the petrol issue alone.

Mr Blair's own personal rating has taken an even sharper dive. His approval rating as prime minister stood at plus two in July in the immediate aftermath of Gordon Brown's announcement of massive extra funds for health and education. But in the last week, it has gone into freefall and now stands at minus 34 - the lowest for a Labour party leader since Neil Kinnock in 1989. More than 70% of voters do not believe ministers' claims to be a "listening government".

While Mr Blair's popularity once transcended party loyalties, it is now found only among core Labour voters - 69% of whom say he is doing a good job.

The 10 point drop in government support will reawaken one of the most traumatic memories in recent Labour history: the winter of discontent in 1978/79 when the party's poll rating plunged from 48% in November 1978 to 33% in February 1979. James Callaghan did stage an eight point recovery in the polls in the three months left before the May 1979 election but there was not enough time to prevent Mrs Thatcher ushering in 18 years of Tory rule.

The ICM poll must now place a question mark over whether a general election next May is too soon to stage a full recovery.

The movement on the ICM poll - a swing of 7% to the Conservatives - represents a smaller shift in opinion than the Mori poll published at the weekend. The August Mori poll for the Times gave Labour a lead of 22 points and the Mori survey published in the News of the World last Sunday gave the Conservatives a lead of two points - a swing of 11% from Labour to the Conservatives. A Times/Mori poll is expected to be carried out this weekend.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,055 adults aged 18 plus by telephone between 15 -17 September. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Under attack:  Fungi plague threatens terracotta army
fields.trailText: One of China's most famous tourist attractions, the 2,200 year old terracotta army, is facing a new enemy - 40 types of fungi.
fields.body:
One of China's most famous tourist attractions, the 2,200 year old terracotta army, is facing a new enemy - 40 types of fungi.

More than 1,400 of the lifesize soldiers and horses, built to protect China's first emperor, Qin Shihuang (259-210BC), are infected with mould, the state-run China Daily reported yesterday.

The authorities in the north-western city of Xian have called in a Belgian company which specialises in treating fungi to stop the rot before it spreads to all the 7,000 terracotta warriors unearthed since they were discovered in 1976.

"It is difficult to kill all of the species without professional help," said Wu Yongqi, curator of the museum where the statues of archers, infantrymen, charioteers, horses, and even acrobats are housed in an underground vault.

It was not immediately clear to what extent China's growing air pollution has contributed to the spread of the fungi. Nine of the world's 10 most polluted cities are in China, and much of Xian is a grimy industrial sprawl.

"It is difficult to kill all of the species without professional help," said Wu Yongqi, curator of the museum where the statues of archers, infantrymen, charioteers, horses, and even acrobats are housed in an underground vault. It was not immediately clear to what extent China's growing air pollution has contributed to the spread of the fungi. Nine of the world's 10 most polluted cities are in China, and much of Xian is a grimy industrial sprawl.

webTitle: When no tests are better than bad tests

fields.headline: When no tests are better than bad tests
fields.standfirst:
As the government unveils plans to boost NHS dentistry, Guardian health expert Dr Ann Robinson examines the case for and against preventative testing
£100m boost for dentistry on NHS
fields.trailText: As the government unveils plans to boost NHS dentistry, Guardian health expert Dr Ann Robinson examines the case for and against preventative testing.
fields.body:
A £100m government scheme is published today to ensure that everyone has access to an NHS dentist by next year.

Dentists will be offered new incentives to see NHS patients rather than carry out more lucrative private work. Around four million people in the UK do not have access to an NHS dentist, the British Dental Association claims.

NHS dentists have become like gold dust around the country since dentists voted with their feet some years ago.

Many opted to offer private services only while some offered to see young children on the NHS-on condition that their parents were seen privately.

Some stalwarts continued to offer dental services on the NHS, but bemoaned the paperwork and, more worryingly, the inferior materials that they had to use when filling NHS teeth as opposed to private cavities.

Now the government has woken up to the inevitable consequences; the nation's teeth are rotting, as those with the poorest dental hygiene struggle to find dental care they can afford.

Four million people don't have access to a dentist at present and you can bet your bottom dollar that those are the four million who need it most.

Dental checkups save expensive fillings and dental work; they are cost effective for the taxpayer and most of us would far rather let the dentist look in our mouths twice a year and have a quick scrape and polish, than have to suffer the drill.

Preventive dentistry is a good thing, as are free, regular eye checks to screen for glaucoma in over 50s.

But are all health checks worthwhile? You can definitely have too much of a good thing with some tests raising more anxiety than they are worth.

An increasing number of companies now pay for their employees to have private health checks. And all GP surgeries offer a health check when you join a new practice.

Pharmacies and health food shops offer all sorts of testing opportunities - instant pulse checks, blood pressure, cholesterol, diabetes and bowel cancer kits.

You can even send your hair off to private labs that claim to check for vitamin and mineral deficiencies.

There is seemingly no end to the number of practitioners willing to take your money to check your health.

But health checks that offer a standardised battery of tests may be ignoring the problems that you are most at risk of developing while offering other tests that don't give you useful information.

To be useful to you, preventive tests and health checks need to be targeted to you as an individual.

Everyone over the age of 20 benefits from a blood pressure check every five years; women on the pill or HRT and anyone whose blood pressure has been raised in the past or has a family history of heart disease should have it checked more regularly-say, annually.

Blood tests for diabetes, high cholesterol, raised PSA indicating possible prostate cancer don't need to be carried out on everyone - the need and frequency of testing will depend on individual susceptibility to a condition.

Specific screening for breast, cervical and bowel cancer is a good idea if you are at risk.

The National Screening programmes offering breast and cervical cancer at regular intervals for all, regardless of their level of risk, are fairly crude ways of trying to pick up these diseases at a very early stage. In time, we are likely to be offered screening at intervals that reflect our level of risk.

In all probability, low-risk women will be offered a smear every 10 years, and high-risk women every year.

So yes, preventive tests can be useful but you need to ask your GP or medical adviser some specific questions; with my history, which tests should I have done and when?

The ideal preventive medicine package is like a well made suit - all your measurements and requirements should be fully discussed, your vital statistics should be carefully recorded, and it should be tailor made to fit you and your needs.

The worst sort of testing gives you meaningless results, false reassurance and unnecessary anxiety. No testing is better than bad testing.

fields.headline: Time Out launches online shopping channel
fields.trailText: 2.15 update: Time Out enters phase two of its online expansion with the launch of its shopping channel, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Time Out has launched its first in a growing list of new channels, part of a new online strategy to migrate more printed content onto the website and develop more online-only content.

Five years after the launch of timeout.com, the company is now looking to boost its digital presence with the launch of more online guides, a Wapsite, a presence on NTL's interactive TV platform and a new-look website.

"It's a fairly obvious strategy - we're putting everything we do in print online. We've always wanted to go this route but there were concerns that it would impact upon sales of the magazine, which have now been allayed," said Pete Fiennes, editorial director at Time Out.

This week Time Out launches a dedicated shopping guide, timeout.com/shopping, which is an extension of its annual A4-sized Time Out Shopping Guide. The online guide aims to provide the most comprehensive shopping guide of London by listing more than 10,000 shops and highlighting the best 250 shops and services online.

The launch of the new section is backed by Time Out's first online advertising campaign, as well as offline activity that takes in taxi sides, bus backs and flyposting.

Fiennes added that the next new section would be an eating guide with more to follow in the coming months. "The main problem was getting a database up and running, but now we've got that we can take all of our print products onto the web," he said, adding that a Wap service will also be developed in the near future.

TimeOut.com recently recruited Ros Atkins, former editor of Carlton.com, as editor of the site, replacing Sarah Dallas who left to be cities editor of the Economist's website in June. The site claims to receive more than 3m page impressions per month with 180,000 unique users.

fields.headline: EMI and Warner offer formal merger concessions
fields.standfirst: Last chance for EMI/Warner merger
fields.trailText: EMI and Warner Music are today hoping to save their proposed merger by formally submitting concessions to the European Commission.
fields.body:
Record companies EMI and Warner Music are today hoping to save their proposed merger as they formally submit concessions to the European Commission.

The £14bn deal has come under intense scrutiny because of the £89m merger of Warner Music parent Time Warner with AOL, which has sparked fears that the new music group will dominate the web downloads market.

Competition commissioner Mario Monti also objects to the combined company's control of music publishing and recorded music. A successful merger would reduce the number of powerful record companies in Europe to four big players.

"The formal remedies presented by the two companies are intended to increase competition across the European music industry," said an EMI statement.

The proposals are expected to include the disposal of publishing and local record labels, with analysts suggesting the internet issue will be the easiest to resolve.

EMI shares fell 1.5p to 552.5p in early trading.

webTitle: Excite Chello plans expansion in wake of merger approval

fields.headline: Excite Chello gears up for merger approval
fields.trailText: Excite Chello expects its merger to be approved within the month and is gearing up to expand into new markets and IPO, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Excite Chello expects its merger to be approved within the month and is gearing up to expand into new markets and IPO early next year.

A war chest of around E100,000 has been set aside for acquisitions and strategic stakes, adding to those Excite @ Home already has in electronic greetings card firm BlueMountain Arts and desktop art firm Webshots.

Evan Rudowski, managing director, media at Excite Chello, said a number of acquisitions and stakes would be made once the £3.6bn merger inked earlier this year between broadband giants Excite @ Home and Chello receives regulatory approval. Rudowski declined to go into details of which companies Excite @ Home was looking at, but it is thought that music download sites and sports broadcasting would be on the list.

Excite @ Home has yet to unveil its plans for the UK market having come up against a conflict of shareholder interest in the UK. The UK arm of Excite was, until recently, 50% owned by Excite @ Home and 50% owned by BT. Excite @ Home has now bought effective control of Excite UK by buying 7% of BT's stake for an undisclosed sum, and in the longer term, could take full ownership of the offshoot. However, Rudowski said there were a number of benefits that being partnered with BT offered.

Excite Chello has remained quiet about how it plans to roll out broadband services in the UK - one of the only European countries where it hasn't yet got a footprint. While Chello parent company UPC recently bought a 25% stake in Telewest, it is not certain whether Excite Chello will use the Telewest cable networks, along with NTL networks, to enable it to move into the UK. Rudowski also said that Excite Chello was talking to BT about leasing local DSL loops and hadn't yet ruled out either broadband option.

The deal combines Dutch company Chello's broadband Internet access services - available to 30m homes in 15 countries - with the American Excite @ Home's Internet content covering 10 countries throughout Europe and Asia-Pacific. An IPO on the Amsterdam Stock exchange and Nasdaq is expected early within the next six months.

fields.headline: M&C Saatchi wins £10m Move.com launch push
fields.trailText: Move.com has appointed M&C Saatchi to handle its £10m UK launch campaign, says Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
US online property service Move.com has appointed M&C Saatchi to create a £10m campaign for its UK launch.

The company, which claims to be the second-biggest property site in the US, will compete with UK rivals Assertahome.co.uk and Rightmove.co.uk. It launches this week with a database of 100,000 properties.

Move.co.uk has secured distribution deals with Lycos and Excite and is close to announcing two more. It will work with independent estate agents and chains across the UK, including Bradford & Bingley, Foxtons, Winkworth and the Home Sale Network.

Mike Simon, manager director of Move in Europe, told Netimperative: "Move will bring a new focus to what happens before and during, but also after, the move. This site is about holding your hand, getting you educated, giving you the services and tools to find your new home.

"We not only act as an entry point to home buying, we take you through the front door." The £10m campaign will kick off in January with a series of television, print and radio ads.

webTitle: New row breaks out as Savio stays at Madrid

fields.headline: New row breaks out as Savio stays at Madrid
fields.trailText: New Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri has failed in his bid to bring Real Madrid winger Savio to Stamford Bridge - with both sides claiming they pulled the plug on the deal.
fields.body:
New Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri has failed in his bid to bring Real Madrid winger Savio to Stamford Bridge - with both sides claiming they pulled the plug on the deal.

This morning, Savio announced he had decided to stay at the Bernabeu Stadium after taking the advice of several of his team-mates, as well as Chelsea's former Real defender Christian Panucci, who was quoted as telling the Brazilian he would be "mad to come".

"I have listened to the words of Roberto Carlos, Flavio Conceicao and even Panucci, and they have made me think better of moving," Savio insisted. "I don't want to leave Real. I just wanted to listen to an interesting offer but now I have decided to carry on and see out my contract for three years."

But the Brazilian's statement was dismissed out of hand by Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson, who insisted that his club pulled out of the deal when Real raised their initial asking price of £9m.

Talking to London's Evening Standard, he explained: "The deal broke down last night and it was us who decided to pull out. We had agreed a fee of £9m for the player but then the new Real Madrid president Fiorentino Peres informed us that he wanted another $4m - more than £2m.

"That was unacceptable to us, especially as the player had appeared against Sporting Lisbon in the Champions League last week which if anything lowered his valuation to us because he would have been unable to play for us in the Uefa Cup this season."

Hutchinson also had words of support for Panucci. When asked if the defender had urged Savio to stay away from the Bridge, Hutchison said: "The opposite is true. Christian has in fact been trying to persuade Savio to come."

Nevertheless, the Italian's commitment to the Chelsea cause is sure to be questioned again. The former Internazionale player reportedly did not want to come to the club because he considered it "too small", and was involved in a very public on-field row with team-mate Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink during Chelsea's home defeat at the hands of Leicester on Sunday.

webTitle: Lua Lua lured to St James' Park

fields.headline: Lua Lua lured to St James' Park
fields.trailText: After weeks of waiting, Newcastle United look set to complete the signing of Zairean forward Lomana Tresor Lua Lua from Colchester United. The Second Division side finally accepted a £2.5m offer from United this morning, paving the way for the 19 year old to move to Tyneside.
fields.body:
After weeks of waiting, Newcastle United look set to complete the signing of Zairean forward Lomana Tresor Lua Lua from Colchester United. The Second Division side finally accepted a £2.5m offer from United this morning, paving the way for the 19 year old to move to Tyneside.

Colchester chairman Peter Heard said: "We were anxious not to lose Lomana but we had to respect the strong wishes of the player and his family.

"Although he was happy at Colchester, it is perfectly understandable that he would want to play at a Premier club.

"The transfer fee gives us the opportunity to establish financial security for the club and will assist with the cost of the new ground. We all wish Lomana every success for the future."

Lua Lua has scored five goals in nine appearances for the U's this season, including a hat-trick in their Worthington Cup success over Queens Park Rangers. Newcastle have fought off late competition from Rangers and West Ham to sign the player they have been watching for the past year.

webTitle: AOL launches unmetered access in UK

fields.headline: AOL launches unmetered access in UK
fields.trailText: AOL UK has launched an unmetered internet access service in the UK.
fields.body:
AOL UK has launched an unmetered internet access service in the UK.

The flat-rate service, which costs £14.99 a month all in, is currently limited to AOL's longest-standing members.

Those who have joined the service more recently will be allowed to sign up "in subsequent weeks", while everyone else goes to the back of the queue.

The service uses Friaco - a telecoms deal for ISPs that allows them to buy wholesale unmetered connections direct from BT.

In the past year, Friaco has been beset by difficulties, culminating in a revised deal being offered this summer. The slow take-up rate of Friaco has been blamed for the slow roll-out of unmetered access.

fields.headline: £100m boost for dentistry on NHS
fields.trailText: A £100m government strategy for ensuring everyone has access to an NHS dentist was published today.
fields.body:
A £100m government strategy for ensuring everyone has access to an NHS dentist was published today.

The plan includes an £18m reward scheme to encourage dentists away from lucrative private work and into more NHS sessions. But dentists' leaders were critical of the announcement, saying there was "nothing very new" in the strategy and that £40m of the cash was, in fact, old money.

About 4m people in the UK do not have access to an NHS dentist, according to the British Dental Association.

The huge rise in the numbers of dentists who do private work, means a third of health authorities have reported problems finding NHS practices.

The new strategy, which also includes plans for a £35m revamp of dental surgeries, pledges that by September 2001 "everyone can get NHS dentistry if and when they need it".

Dental access centres will be set up in areas where there are shortages of NHS practices to provide people with treatment. Patients will have better access to information setting out exactly what they can expect to pay for under an NHS dentist.

And dentists who work primarily for the NHS will be given financial rewards that could see their pay go up to almost £60,000 a year. A statement from the British Dental Association said: "We are disappointed there is nothing very new in the strategy and that our long-standing concerns about inadequate funding of all sectors of NHS dentistry have not been fully addressed.

"The £100m announced for NHS dentistry over two years includes £40m already announced earlier this year."

Dr John Renshaw, chairman of the BDA's Executive Board, said: "We will be pleased if the new strategy helps to improve access for some patients. However, unless the government addresses the grave funding crisis in NHS dentistry, dentists will continue to leave the NHS and there will be no hope of a permanent recovery."

Health minister Lord Hunt acknowledged that patients have had a "raw deal" in finding NHS dentists but claimed the proposals would improve access and quality of care.

With the additional £18m annual fund for loyalty payments, dentists will receive around an extra £4,500 on their salary, he said.

"We do want to attract more dentists back to the profession ... particularly women," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"We have also introduced a £35m modernisation scheme which will update dental premises and kit. We are showing our faith in dentists who are sticking to the NHS.

"By ringing NHS Direct ... people will be told the nearest dentist who can provide NHS treatment to them," he added.

fields.headline: Frederick Forsyth
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the thriller writer and Europhobe, and why his latest work won't be in the bookshops.
fields.body:
All you need to know about the thriller writer and Europhobe, and why his latest work won't be in the bookshops

1. Frederick Forsyth, still best known after 29 years for writing The Day of the Jackal, is embracing the new technology.

2. His latest book, a collection of stories called Quintet, will be published on the internet by Online Originals.

3. In the world of books, this is known as doing a Stephen King.

4. Earlier this year, King cyberpublished Riding the Bullet. Sadly, it was much pirated.

5. He has had much greater success with his more recent part-work The Plant, which is available a chapter at a time, for a dollar a throw. More than 150,000 readers have forked out, and the third chapter is about to appear.

6. Back to Fred, as he is never known: He's 62, has knocked around a bit, but judging by his views on Europe and on mercenaries, he's not terribly keen on foreigners.

7. Forsyth, once the youngest pilot in RAF, worked as a journalist in Berlin and Paris, before turning out the Jackal book and famously having it rejected by a slew of publishers before it became a bestseller.

8. That's another thing he has in common with S King, who threw the manuscript of his first book, Carrie, into the trash can. It was rescued by his wife Tabitha, and went on to sell 2.5m copies.

9. King's latest three-book contract is said to be worth $48m. That's something he doesn't have in common with F Forsyth.

10. Nor is King terribly interested in politics. Forsyth is. He's a leading light of the Congress for Democracy (sic), and something called the Democratic Party which is headquartered, fittingly enough, in the Enigma Business Park in Malvern.

webTitle: Lib Dem conference: MP derides Tory leaders beer exploits

fields.headline: Pouring scorn on plonker Hague
fields.standfirst:
MP derides Tory leaders beer exploits
Special report: Liberal Democrat Conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague s much-derided 14 pints a day drinking claim was mocked yesterday when a Liberal Democrat MP branded the Tory an utter plonker for consuming so much drink.
fields.body:
William Hague s much-derided 14 pints a day drinking claim was mocked yesterday when a Liberal Democrat MP branded the Tory an utter plonker for consuming so much drink.

In a debate on the future of village pubs, Nigel Jones, MP for Cheltenham, described Mr Hague as a skinhead with a skinful. His tirade even drew in the prime minister,as Mr Jones talked of doing a Euan"  a reference to the recent drinking antics of Mr Blairs 16-year-old son, Euan, found drunk and incapable after finishing his GCSEs.

Mr Jones  who was injured by a man wielding a samurai sword in his constituency office during an attack in which a Lib Dem party worker was killed  said of Mr Hague: I have to tell you that anybody who drinks 14 pints of beer a day is a complete and utter plonker."

The chairman of the parliamentary beer group added: I just wonder if the Tories used this tactic at their bonding meetings.Can you imagine bogus Billy going out on a 14 pint bender with say, (shadow chancellor) Michael Portillo, or (Tory ex-prime minister) Edward Heath, or speeding Ann Widdecombe? She must be something else after 14 pints."

But he told party members: If you ever find bogus Billy Hague face down in the gutter performing what I understand these days is called doing a Euan, please resist the temptation to attach a notice to him saying DNR do not resusci- tate. We want him (Mr Hague) leading the Tories into the next election so that people can compare him and his deadbeat crowd and his kneejerk policies with Charles Kennedy and our sensible, well thought-out, properly costed policies.

Delegates later voted to call on the government to introduce progressive beer duty, a measure to assist small brewers that exists in the US and most European markets.

fields.headline: Serendipity is our favourite word
fields.standfirst: Nominate your favourite word on our talkboards
fields.trailText: Serendipity, that mellifluously long and happy noun has emerged as the nation's favourite word. The 18th century term, coined by the writer Horace Walpole for "the faculty of    making fortunate discoveries by accident" - he had just read the Persian fairy tale, The Three Princes of Serendip - came top in a poll devised by the Word Festival of Literature, which starts next week at the Globe theatre, Bankside,   London. fields.body:
Serendipity, that mellifluously long and happy noun has emerged as the nation's favourite word. The 18th century term, coined by the writer Horace Walpole for "the faculty of making fortunate discoveries by accident" - he had just read the Persian fairy tale, The Three Princes of Serendip - came top in a poll devised by the Word Festival of Literature, which starts next week at the Globe theatre, Bankside, London. The "part parlour game, part Domesday survey", launched several months ago by Bob Geldof, drew 15,000 emails and postcards in the search for Britain's best words.

In second place came quidditch, a word from the modern fairy tale of Harry Potter. This is the game played by the wizards and witches; it is similar to two existing English words, quiddity and quidnunc - but these never caught on.

Between them, Walpole and JK Rowling pushed love into third place. The words peace and why tied for fourth place.

A Greek-derived word cherished from school English lessons, onomatopoeia - an even longer tongue-twister than serendipity - took fifth place. It means words like hiss, buzz or bang whose sound imitates the action they describe. Its high placing will briefly lift the morale of teachers and school inspectors.

Hope and faith were fifth and sixth, with charity nowhere.

But it is perhaps the nine words at the bottom of yesterday's top words list that most tersely catch the mass millennial national mood. They are football, muggle, hello, family, bollocks, compassion, fuck, home, Jesus, money.

Among other also-rans in the competition was a nomination by the Men Behaving Badly scripwriter, Simon Nye, that appears to be dripping with the frustrations of a 1960s single-sex public school education: nipples.

Barbara Windsor, the actress, failed to score with darling - meaning, she said, "I can't for the life of me remember your name". Kermit the Frog suggested Hi Ho for the same reason.

The satirist and cartoonist Ralph Steadman lobbied for his new word entwangled, "Combining entangled and entwined which suggests an amorous embrace between," he wrote.

The most erudite celebrity nomination was forwarded by the pop singer Sting for the word laconic, "an adjective derived from the Greek that originally described the people of Sparta who were famously taciturn and given to short pithy phrases. Cocktail banter was not big in Sparta".

The top 10 words chosen were:

1 serendipity
2 quidditch
3 love
4 peace
= why
5 onomatopoeia
6 hope
7 faith
8 football
= muggle
= hello
= family
9 bollocks
= compassion
= fuck
= home
10 jesus
= money

 The Word Festival of Literature runs from September 23 at the Globe Theatre, Bankside, SE1.

webTitle: Clock ticks down to Prague's IMF timebomb

fields.headline: Clock ticks down to Prague's IMF timebomb
fields.standfirst: This week's annual meeting of the World Bank and the IMF will probably be the target of many anti-capitalism activists. As Kate Connolly reports from the Czech capital, the police are taking no chances
fields.trailText: This week's annual meeting of the World Bank and the IMF will probably be the target of many anti-capitalism activists. As Kate Connolly reports from the Czech capital, the police are taking no chances.
fields.body:
As tens of thousands of anti-globalisation protesters begin descending on the Czech capital for the International Monetary Fund/World Bank annual meeting which opens later this week, city officials say they feel as if they are preparing for war.

Tear-gas equipment has been procured from Germany and water cannons that have not been used since the Velvet Revolution of 1989 have been brought out of the store-cupboard.

Schools are to be closed, hospitals are stocking up with medicines to treat chemical weapon injuries and the post office says it cannot guarantee deliveries.

Many of Prague's 1.2m citizens are planning to up and leave the city during the gathering, which takes place from September 19 to 28.

Theatres that have only just reopened after the summer break are being forced to close, and staff at banks in the city have been warned to dress in casual attire so that they do not make themselves potential protest targets.

''We hope,'' said the 30-year old Czech Interior Minister Stanislav Gross, whose political future is dependent on the success or failure of the summit, ''that the biggest criticism they can levy at us is that we went over the top with our preparation.

''Only we'd rather be safe than sorry.''

But as hundreds of protesters - up to 25,000 are expected - found themselves being turned away at the border in the past few days, a spokesman for the Initiative Against Economic Globalisation (INPEG), an organisation preparing many of the protests, said the police approach reminded him of the communist era.

''This shows that police practices are getting back to how they used to be 15 years ago,'' Viktor Piorecky said.

The Communist Party of Bohemia and Moravia announced its ''disgust'' that protesters were being banned from entering the country.

''Our party will ask the interior ministry to explain how Prague will secure people's freedom to speak out on the IMF,'' said a spokesman.

A newspaper editorial ran: ''By limiting the freedom of other people, we are limiting our own freedom and this is the cost of our fear.''

Police say that they are well prepared for the planned mass demonstrations, marches, and plans to barricade state offices and high-profile businesses.

''Our main aim is to ensure that the conference can go on without delegates being affected by what's happening outside,'' said police president Jiri Kolar, who is coordinating the operation.

Various "hotspots" have been identified by police where protesters are expected to gather in force. All of Prague's 22 branches of McDonald's are being viewed as prime targets for the demonstrators' wrath.

Mr Kolar said that the police are prepared to tolerate non-violent protests, but he admitted that they had imposed tough document checks and car searches to keep ''undesirables'' out.

This weekend, they face the added headache of having to keep an eye on protests against the activation of Temelin, an internationally-condemned, Soviet-designed nuclear power station in southern Bohemia, as well as the arrival of 15,000 music lovers for Prague's first WOMAD world music festival.

The Czech police has faced criticism in recent years for the way in which it has handled May Day riots in Prague, during which windows of fast food restaurants and butchers' were smashed and several people were injured.

To ensure they appear more accountable and responsible, they have accepted the presence of 100 volunteer legal observers who will report back to superiors if they violate human rights.

A hotline has also been set up where people can report incidents of abuse of power. INPEG plans two non-violent counter summits on September 24 and 26. The latter, known in activist-speak as "S26", will be by far the biggest.

Protesters will march from Prague's Namesti Miru (or Peace Square), to the summit's venue, the Congress Centre in the south of Prague. Under communism the centre was the Palace of Culture, and has been renamed and renovated at a cost of millions of dollars for this month's event.

INPEG insists that it has nothing to do with a movement calling itself Destroy IMF, which tells protesters how to say ''Fuck off you fascist pig'' and ''where's the nearest McDonald's?'' in Czech.

But the police say that the real ''acid test'' for them will be the first major protests on September 23.

Then, Ludowik Zifcak, a former secret police officer who was jailed for 18 months in 1989 for abuse of public office during the protests in the run-up to the Velvet Revolution, will lead his extremist group, United Front.

Zifcak represents one end of the spectrum of the extremists who will come to Prague. He has expressed his extraordinarily ambitious aim to bring together all sides in a common alliance against IMF and WB policies.

''We have started talks with Czech anarchists, skinheads and patriotic associations whose opinions are similar to ours,'' he said. He plans to hold demonstrations everyday between September 23 and 29.

On the same day, Czech president Vaclav Havel will also attempt to unite all sides for a discussion group at Prague Castle.

The man who has optimistically described the summit as ''a unique opportunity in the history of our country, and one that will possibly never be repeated,'' has invited 300 people from government, the IMF, World Bank and NGOs to discuss the issues of world poverty and globalisation.

The discussion will be chaired by the UN commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, and will be attended by IMF executive director Horst Koehler, World Bank president James Wolfensohn and Ann Pettifor, director of the British organisation Jubilee 2000.

It will be carried live, in Czech, on the internet at Praha 2000.

Mr Havel's spokesman, Vladislav Spacek, also announced that the president was to take the bold step of delivering a speech at the opening of S26, thus endorsing what could turn into a full-scale riot, after protesters said that Prague 2000 would become "Seattle 2".

Czech white supremicist groups have actually expressed their fear that they will become targets of violence for rival anarchist groups, whom they say will greatly outnumber them.

Some far-right groups have even asked for police protection. Officials at the US Embassy in Prague, however, have expressed their private fear that better-resourced far-right groups from neighbouring countries, particularly Germany, could make a bee-line for Prague in the coming days.

Czech-based skin-head groups such as National Resistance, National Alliance, the Patriotic Republican Party and Defence of the Nation, have lodged an application to hold a demonstration on September 23, on Letna Plain, in the north of the city.

But already some of the 215 protest applications that have been lodged with the City Hall in Prague, look to be under threat.

Miroslava Studenovska, the major of the Prague 4 Nusle district, where the summit venue is located, said that she had had no choice but to ban protests in the district and block off green areas.

''Instead we have established a coordination centre which will be in operation from now until early October. A free telephone number has also been made available to provide citizens with necessary information,'' she said.

Those arriving in Prague yesterday from all over Europe were being given flyers in Czech, English, French, German and Spanish. "Read before demonstrations'", the leaflets said.

The flyers list protesters' rights according to Czech law, inform them about the status of foreigners and offer useful telephone numbers.

Fifteen thousand camping places have been made available for protesters at Strahov Stadium, a huge former communist monstrosity big enough to fit five football pitches, which, these days, is normally just home to a drive-in cinema.

So far, 5,000 people have booked places for the temporary tent city via the internet. Others will stay at Dzuban campground in the north east of the city or in various squats dotted around Prague.

On Saturday, journalists were informed just two hours before of the location outside Prague where demonstration management techniques were being practised.

The boot camp, on a rundown farm, 30 miles outside Prague, has been home for the past few days of 250 activists, who have been taught how to behave in demonstrations, as well as the techniques of tree-climbing and samba.

On Tuesday they will move to a secret location in Prague.

fields.headline: Fraud inquiry into dome contract
fields.trailText: Fraud squad detectives were today investigating allegations of malpractice relating to a contract at the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Fraud squad detectives were today investigating allegations of malpractice relating to a contract at the Millennium Dome.

The inquiry centres on a contractor who worked for the dome's operators, the New Millennium Experience Company, a spokesman for the firm said.

Scotland Yard's fraud squad said it was investigating one contractor and one contract.

A spokesman for NMEC said that the contractor in question was responsible for services within the dome rather than the actual structure or the attractions. The NMEC said: "The dome's rigorous internal audit system identified a possible irregularity relating to one contractor earlier this year. The police have been kept informed since June. " A Metropolitan Police spokeswoman said today: "Police are considering an allegation in connection with a procurement of a contract by a company in south-east London. It is an allegation that the contract was awarded inappropriately. A matter is being considered by the Metropolitan Police's fraud squad."

The claims of irregularities are believed to be related to an alleged failure to follow guidelines and were handed over to the fraud squad by local police.

The news comes a week after the Japanese bank Nomura withdrew its £105m offer to buy the ailing attraction in Greenwich.

In February, the Millennium Commission pumped an extra £60m into the dome when its chief executive Jennie Page resigned, and another £29m was invested in May when chairman Bob Ayling stood down.

Last month the commission announced the dome would be getting a £43m advance payment from the planned sale at the end of the year to a consortium backed by Nomura.

Two weeks ago a further £47m was agreed in National Lottery funds to keep the attraction open until the end of the year, while at the same time it was announced non-executive dome chairman David Quarmby would be replaced with an executive chairman, businessman David James.

fields.headline: AOL launches unmetered internet access
fields.trailText: AOL is to finally roll out an unmetered internet service, Amy Vickers writes.
fields.body:
More than a year after AOL pledged to "stop the clock on metered internet telephone costs", it has finally launched an unmetered service.

The move, which comes in the wake of disastrous attempts by AltaVista and Lineone, has been welcomed by the internet industry, despite the service being £5 per month more expensive than nearest flat-rate rival Freeserve.

The service is being rolled out only to existing AOL subscribers at a cost £14.99 per month (including all internet calls). This price matches BT's Surftime package.

The AOL Flat Rate is based on Flat Rate Internet Access Call Origination (FRIACO) - BT's unmetered wholesale internet access product that allows internet service providers to offer unmetered services to subscribers.

So as not to encounter the same problems as beleaguered unmetered services, AOL plans to give longer-standing users priority during the service's roll-out. However, all AOL users will have been offered the service by the end of November, according to Matt Peacock, director of corporate communications at AOL UK.

"It's going to be a fast roll-out. Now it all depends on BT to deliver its FRIACO promises. What happens from here on is down to BT," he said.

The AOL Flat Rate is being offered as an alternative to AOL's £9.99 subscription service, which does not include any free internet calls.

It is thought that customers of CompuServe, the AOL-owned ISP aimed at businessmen, will be offered a similar FRIACO service in the near future.

AOL would not provide figures for how many subscribers it expects to sign up to the service, or how many UK subscribers AOL has. However, the company said it would be able to connect "hundreds of thousands" to the Flat Rate service.

webTitle: Flagging Bush sets sights on middle class vote

fields.headline: Flagging Bush sets sights on middle class vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush changed his tack and his tone in the US presidential election campaign yesterday, seeking to revive his flagging fortunes with an issues-based drive for middle-class votes in the battleground states.
fields.body:
George W Bush changed his tack and his tone in the US presidential election campaign yesterday, seeking to revive his flagging fortunes with an issues-based drive for middle-class votes in the battleground states.

The Republican candidate began a 12-city tour with a visit to an Arkansas maternity ward, where he waxed lyrical on the joys of fatherhood at the start of a week in which he aims to highlight his "cradle-to-grave" domestic policy agenda and ditch his reputation for negative campaigning.

It was the start of "an important week in this campaign", he admitted in a speech in Little Rock, "a week that speaks to the aspirations and hopes of middle-class families all across the nation."

The visit to the maternity ward kicked off a determined effort by the Republicans to regain control of the election agenda from Vice-President Al Gore, the Democratic candidate, who continues to extend his recent lead in the opinion polls, not just nationally but in many of the states that will decide the election.

"This is a very focused, more aggressive effort to let voters know where Governor Bush stands on the major issues of the day," his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, told reporters before the start of the latest campaign swing.

Each day of the week would feature "metaphor" visits to enable Mr Bush to set out his stall on issues such as education, welfare, taxes and pensions, Mr Fleischer said.

Mr Bush will end the week with another visit to Florida, where he will talk about his plans for the elderly. The visit to the state where his brother Jeb is governor, and which most strategists originally put in the Republican camp, shows how strongly Mr Gore is doing in the battleground states.

With some polls showing Mr Gore threatening to take a dominant lead, Mr Bush launched a "Blueprint for the Middle Class", a 16-page summary of his policy proposals, and began highlighting his new slogan: "Real Plans for Real People."

"It's a real plan. It isn't one of those things with a lot of fine print in it. It's a real plan to help families help themselves," he said before going on to Missouri and Illinois.

The move is a calculated risk, since the polls that show Mr Gore leading also show him well ahead on most of the issues the Republicans want to highlight. But Mr Bush has come under fierce pressure from within his party to focus on themes that the voters repeatedly say matter most to them.

The most recent polls differ about the extent of Mr Gore's lead, but there is no disagreement about the fact that, after months of seeming to be on course for victory, Mr Bush is struggling to prevent the vice-president succeeding Bill Clinton on November 7.

The latest Newsweek poll shows Mr Gore with a 50% to 38% lead among registered voters, and a 52% to 38% advantage among likely voters - the biggest leads he has had in any national poll since the candidates began their campaigns for the White House more than two years ago.

Other polls show Mr Gore with only a single-figure lead, but all demonstrate that he is widening the gap. A new Harris Interactive survey gives Mr Gore a 46% to 43% lead, while the latest Gallup three-day tracking poll shows him at 49%, against Mr Bush's 41%. The Green candidate, Ralph Nader, is on 3%, and Pat Buchanan of the Reform Party has 1%.

As well as reining back Mr Gore, Mr Bush particularly needs to stop the erosion of his lead among male voters. The latest Gallup figures show that this lead among men has fallen from 20 points two weeks ago to just three points. Mr Gore leads strongly among women voters.

Gore advisers dismissed the Bush relaunch as "pictures and no substance, reflective of a campaign that's all imagery and no ideas". So confident are they, they issued a cheeky rebuttal yesterday of part of Mr Bush's agenda. Under the heading "Bush's child care and pre-school proposals", the press release from the Gore campaign consisted of a blank sheet of paper.

fields.headline: Books for boys
fields.trailText: Here is a selection of six books - all paperbacks - to tempt the lads, none of which would fail to tempt the girls either.
fields.body:
I'm proud to be a Reading Champion for the National Reading Campaign as one of a number of writers, sports people, entertainers, fathers, grandads, big brothers and friends who promote books for unstruck boys. Sexist? Yes - but let's be charitable and think of it as positive discrimination. Here is a selection of six books - some new, some older favourites, all paperbacks - to tempt the lads, none of which would fail to tempt the girls either.

Gene Kemp's The Turbulent Term of Tyke Tiler (Puffin Modern Classics, £4.99) is rebel Tyke's own account of helping underdog Danny Price to overcome his problems. It's got heart, it's fast and it's funny - with an edge-of-the-seat climax and a smack of a surprise waiting at the end.

Anyone into bikes and laughs and satisfying plots will enjoy Chris Powing's The Mustang Machine (Barn Owl Books, £3.99). Despite its sharp realistic edge, the story's big "grip" is a fantasy bike with a stallion's mind. But who tames it? Tim, a flushed, fever-eyed, serious hospital case. An exciting read, with depths.

The Killer Underpants by Michael Lawrence (Orchard Books, £3.99) needs to be read by kids themselves because no adult will get the words out for laughing. Jiggy's new underpants have a power of their own; they control him, chasing their own devil plans. But like Tim, Jiggy lives in our world of home and school. Fantastic and real - and very funny.

Kara May's Yeti Boy (Collins, £3.99) is Fenn, who lives with the abominable snowmen in the Sanaskar Mountains. In saving them from disaster he gets to grips with the tragedy in his own life. This is a thrilling and moving "other world" story that bears upon us all.

If you're hooked on Friends, Jonathan Meres' Yo! Diary! 2 (Piccadilly Press, £5.99) is a must. Six teenagers in their individual styles spill their deepest secrets about themselves and reveal their views of each other. And we discover that we're not alone, that others have the same shames and fears and minor joys as we do.

super.activ Football by Clive Gifford (Hodder, £3.99) is worth a season's training - a book packed with diagrams, drawings and insider writing on how to improve your game. Essential reading for every Premiership player.

 Bernard Ashley's recent novel Little Soldier was shortlisted for the Guardian Children's Book Award and the Carnegie Medal. His latest book for teenagers is Playing Against the Odds, published by Barrington Stoke. The book charity Reading Is Fundamental is seeking role models who can get boys into the reading habit - not just well-known names, but fathers, grandfathers, brothers, teachers, librarians or anyone else who champions reading. If you want to nominate a Reading Champion, contact the campaign on 020 7828 2435, email: gen.clarke@mcmail.com or look at the website at: literacytrust.org.uk

fields.headline: Prague-bound
fields.standfirst: Protestor Gideon Burrows explains why he is going to Prague
fields.trailText: Five months of preparation, press speculation and propaganda and Prague S26 is here. A motley crew of anarchists, socialists, deep ecologists, tree climbers, animal liberators, pacifists, Christians, street reclaimers, politicians, and everything in between, will gather on the cobbled streets of the Czech capital for what promises to be the biggest anti-capitalist protest Europe has ever seen.
fields.body:
Five months of preparation, press speculation and propaganda and Prague S26 is here. A motley crew of anarchists, socialists, deep ecologists, tree climbers, animal liberators, pacifists, Christians, street reclaimers, politicians, and everything in between, will gather on the cobbled streets of the Czech capital for what promises to be the biggest anti-capitalist protest Europe has ever seen.

I am going to Prague because, for me, the blind pursuit of liberalised trade, advocated by the World Bank, the IMF and the WTO, has proven to be more harmful to developing nations than beneficial. Though the institutions aim to alleviate poverty, they have failed badly. The forced imposition of Western financial ideals on states without the economic, social or natural environment to cope with them has led only to increased profits for Western businesses and increased degradation, poverty and death for the poorest people in the developing world.

The World Bank and the IMF are profoundly undemocratic. The affluent powers dominate the voting - together wielding enough power to make or break any resolution by themselves. Executives and employees of the Bank and IMF are not elected, their work is not open to public scrutiny, and their policies need no approval by governments. The Bank frequently imposes policies on states against the will of its government and people. I hope peaceful resistance will prevent private deals being struck, deal which might further damage the developing world.

The question of revolution versus reform in is one which splits activist and academic alike. The World Bank and the IMF aren't working, but there is room for reform as well as revolution. Structures for distribution of loans are in place, and the bank has plentiful resources that would be wasteful to discard. The biggest overhaul must come in ethos not structure.

The abolition of the "one dollar - one vote" system is an essential starting point. Only when Zambia has the same voice as the United States, will the World Bank listen to what the developing world is saying about its needs. The Bank must abandon the pursuit of international free trade, instead engaging with grass roots native communities in loan recipient countries to discover what will help them most. The activities of the Bank must become transparent and accountable.

There is an immense feeling of frustration among protestors. The Okinawa G8 Summit in July cost Gambia's total debt twice over, but still failed to agree any new commitments to alleviate world poverty. Campaigners feel cheated and ignored, violence is the ultimately unacceptable result. When a hundred or more protesters become violent, they disenfranchise thousands of others who have come to make their point forcefully but peacefully. High ideals of anti-hierarchy and grass roots democracy are sacrificed, media and public sympathy is lost. The activist movement must learn to re-channel their anger. Civil disobedience is more powerful than civil unrest.

Gideon Burrows is a journalist and activist. He is news editor of Red Pepper magazine. He writes as an individual, not a spokesperson.

webTitle: Big Breakfast reaches new audience low

fields.headline: Big Breakfast becomes small fry
fields.trailText: Channel 4's Big Breakfast reached a new low yesterday when it scored the lowest viewing figures of all five channels, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Channel 4's Big Breakfast reached a new low yesterday when it scored the lowest viewing figures of all five channels.

Just 500,000 people were watching the Big Breakfast at the peak early-morning time of 8am yesterday, giving the channel 100,000 fewer viewers than Channel 5's children's programmes and 200,000 fewer than BBC2's Breakfast 24. At 8am the once-popular show had a share of just 9% of the viewers compared with 24% for BBC1's Olympic Grandstand and 29% for ITV's GMTV. The figures will prove an embarrassment to Channel 4, which had been hoping for better things from its return to the star line-up of Johnny Vaughan and Denise Van Outen. And it rather begs the question of how low the ratings will drop when the pair leave at the end of this year.

Elsewhere, the BBC's increasingly odd scheduling of Castaway continues to baffle and deter viewers in equal measure. BBC1 broadcast the show for just 20 minutes last night at 8.40pm, putting it up against ITV's smash hit Who Wants to be a Millionaire. No prizes for guessing who won. Castaway attracted just 6.4m viewers while nearly twice that number (11.4m) were watching ITV.

A special 40-minute episode of EastEnders also suffered from a clash with ITV. The much-vaunted arrival of the Slater family to Albert Square gave the show a ratings fillip, with 11.9m people tuning in to give BBC1 a 49% share. But the figures tailed off in the final 10 minutes, as the show went head to head against Who Wants to be a Millionaire.

It was a good night all round for ITV. Almost all the 9.4m people who watched the first part of its thriller, My Fragile Heart, stuck with it for last night's conclusion, which attracted 9.2m viewers to give it a 41% share.

The BBC's Olympic Games coverage continues to prove popular in spite of scheduling difficulties caused by the time difference. The Day Downunder, an hour-long round-up of the day's sporting highlights, attracted 4.8m viewers when it was broadcast at 7pm to give BBC1 a very respectable 22% share. And the late-night Olympic Grandstand attracted 2.1m viewers, to give BBC1 a 39% share of the viewing - by far the best performance of all five channels at that time.

fields.headline: Testigo
fields.standfirst: Mohamed Meni talks about living in Spain as a refugee from Western Sahara
fields.trailText: Mohamed Meni talks about living in Spain as a refugee from Western Sahara
fields.body:
Me llamo Mohamed Meni y soy saharaui. Nací en Dajla, un campo de refugiados en el desierto de Argelia. Cuando sea mayor lucharé por mi país, el Sáhara Occidental. Estamos en guerra con Marruecos porque nos quitaron nuestra tierra.

Yo llegué a España con un grupo de niños saharauis. Veníamos a pasar las vacaciones con familias españolas. Yo me quedé porque sufro alergia al trigo. Desde hace cinco años vivo en Hospitalet, Barcelona. Ahora tengo dos familias: mis padres y mi hermano en Dajla y mis padres y hermanas en Barcelona.

Del campo de refugiados echo en falta a mi familia y a mis amigos. Ahora mis amigos de catorce años ya no van a la escuela. Trabajan de albañil y ayudan a construir casas. También echo en falta a mis camellos. Con mi familia nos escribimos cartas y a veces me llaman por teléfono desde unas cabinas. Allí no hay Internet ni ordenadores porque no hay electricidad. Una vez cada dos años voy a visitarles. Y entonces me gusta hablarles de la televisión y del cine. Recuerdo que es lo que más me fascinó cuando llegué hace cinco años, además de la ducha.

Dajla, el campo de refugiados, está en un desierto de arena. Dajla es también el nombre del pueblo de pescadores en Sáhara Occidental donde vivían mis padres. Ellos me explican que desde nuestra casa se veía el Océano Atlántico. Mis padres tenían allí un barco. Esperamos que las Naciones Unidas organicen un referéndum y así poder volver a nuestra tierra. Y si no iremos a la guerra.

Eulàlia Furriol was talking to Mohamed Meni.

Glosario/Glossary

un albañil a building worker

una cabina de teléfonos a telephone box

la ducha the shower

echar en falta a to miss

hablar de to talk about

un ordenador a computer

un pueblo de pescadores a fishing village

el trigo wheat

las vacaciones holidays

una vez cada dos años once every two years

fields.headline: Decision on UKTV flotation 'early next year'
fields.trailText: A decision on whether to float the BBC/Telewest joint-venture, UKTV - raising up to £200m for the BBC - is likely to be made in the first quarter of next year, the deputy chief executive of BBC Worldwide has said.
fields.body:
A decision on whether to float the BBC/Telewest joint-venture, UKTV - raising up to £200m for the BBC - is likely to be made in the first quarter of next year, the deputy chief executive of BBC Worldwide has said.

Peter Teague told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "By quarter one next year, we will be in a better position to assess the value of a flotation to BBC Worldwide".

It is the first time that BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, has admitted that flotation was a possible option for the channel, after the chief executive of Telewest, Adam Singer, raised the possibility at the Edinburgh TV Festival last month.

Teague would not be drawn on any specific details about the value to BBC Worldwide or Telewest of floating the joint-venture. Singer estimated at the time that an initial public offering of 40% of UKTV, estimated to be worth between £700m and £1.48bn, could generate £200m for each of the parties.

Teague said UKTV had around £200m of debt to pay off, which would need to be factored in to the value.

A UKTV float, covering the six channels UK Gold, UK Gold 2, UK Horizons, UK Play, UK Style and UK Drama, would represent the first public offering of a BBC asset. The BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, has told BBC Worldwide it needs to find £1.1bn in revenue by 2006. Last month the corporation announced the sale of a stake in internet site beeb.com to a US firm for £32.5m.

webTitle: French Connection to raise ad spend

fields.headline: French Connection to boost ad spend
fields.trailText: French Connection Group chief executive Stephen Marks has pledged to increase the company's ad budget following profits rise.
fields.body:
Stephen Marks, chairman and chief executive of the French Connection Group, has pledged to increase the company's advertising budget following the success of its "Everyone's talking FCUK" campaign.

French Connection today unveiled a 15.4% increase in first-half pre-tax profits to £7.5m, on turnover up 24.7% to £87.4m.

Its performance for the year as a whole is expected to be even better, with like-for-like retail sales up 12% in the first six weeks of the second half of this year.

"Advertising and marketing are a very important part of driving the business forward and supporting the brands," said Marks.

"The 'Everyone's talking FCUK' ad campaign has been a resounding success and we have just launched a TV ad campaign in the UK.

"We believe that the continued increase in advertising, balanced with credible product, a great shopping environment and excellent customer service, will help us maintain our growth in the future, both in the UK and US."

Marks added the TV ad drive has been a hit with shoppers, as the coats and T-shirts featured are best-sellers in French Connection shops.

The results are a rare success in a retail sector that has been hit by the rainy summer and aggressive discounting.

Marks put it down to the strength of the brand. The FCUK logo is constantly imitated, with the Young Conservatives landing themselves in hot water last year when they used the slogan for an ill-fated recruitment drive.

"FCUK has got into people's language and minds. There a sense of fun about what we do, and the product lives up to customers' expectations. But the clothing market is much more demanding now, as the public knows far more about what is right and what is wrong," Marks said.

French Connection is expected to continue to expand during the second half of this year, with the opening of its biggest store on the corner of Oxford Street and Duke Street in London.

The company also plans to launch a men's grooming range and has signed an exclusive licensing deal with Boots to launch 20 products in 1,300 stores.

webTitle: Why Bradman should do a Freeman

fields.headline: Why Bradman should do a Freeman
fields.trailText: Raelene Boyle to Betty Cuthbert to Shirley Strickland to Shane Gould to Dawn Fraser to Debbie Flintoff-King to Cathy Freeman. It was a spectacular call of honour for a spectacular ceremony.
fields.body:
Raelene Boyle to Betty Cuthbert to Shirley Strickland to Shane Gould to Dawn Fraser to Debbie Flintoff-King to Cathy Freeman. It was a spectacular call of honour for a spectacular ceremony.

When Freeman climbed those shimmering steps to light the Olympic flame in Sydney, some saw her as representing the hopes of the aboriginal people. Some saw a miracle - why didn't she drown or burn when she was standing in a fountain and surrounded by flames? Some saw a fashion statement - where did she get that all-in-one white catsuit?

Others saw it as tokenism. A last ditch attempt by a nation still dominated by beer-swigging, dunny-inhabiting, singlet-wearing white boys to change its image in the eyes of the world. To blot over the hundreds of years of aboriginal oppression and shirtiness to sheilas.

But a celebration of 100 years of female participation in the Olympics was just that, a celebration. A celebration of women's involvement in the most unifying event on the planet. It wasn't a half-arsed political statement. And even if it was meant to be, or people saw it as one, women athletes circa 2000 AD don't need that sort of patronising.

Cathy Freeman is Australia's golden girl (if she were a swimmer, Australia would have no doubt voted for a republic and she, ensconced as President, wouldn't have looked quite as nervous as the Governor General did at the opening ceremony). She is their most famous athlete full stop, and a hot favourite for the 400m gold.

Her chief rival is Marie-Jose Perec, the double-Olympic 400m champion, who has the highest profile of any athlete in any sport in France. Controversial misery-guts she may be but it doesn't stop her visage being plastered all over the billboards and magazines from Calais to Cannes.

Marion Jones isn't particularly well-loved by her countrymen but she still steals the limelight from America's somewhat faceless conveyor belt of male sprinters. And it's not just sprinters - the US viewing audience for Olympic women's ice skating in 1996 was beaten only by that for the Super Bowl.

Even in Britain where the deeds of male athletes - Cram, Coe, Ovett, Black, Christie - have traditionally dominated the sports pages, there are signs of a breakthrough. Jonathan Edwards may have broken the World Record and made the pages of the Church Times, but Denise Lewis is the more instantly recognisable.

And if, as Colette Dowling suggests in her new book The Frailty Myth, there is no reason that women cannot eventually run as fast as men, the attention paid to women athletes during the Olympics can only grow.

Unfortunately England's women cricketers are unlikely to be able to participate. Cricket was last an Olympic Sport in 1900, when Great Britain - well, the Devon County Wanderers - beat France. And if the Australians can't sneak it in as an exhibition sport, nobody can.

We should be grateful at least that the Women's World Cup isn't being held in our country. Our last opening ceremony didn't exactly wow those punters who bothered to turn up. Tony Blair cut the ribbon on a drizzly grey day in May. Well at least he was a cricket fan. Well, at least his microphone worked. Well at least the fireworks went off. Well ...

And maybe the world's women cricketers will have the ultimate honour. Australia wouldn't or couldn't persuade Don Bradman out of retirement to light the Olympic flame. But perhaps he can be tempted by a lower profile, but less commercial, gig. It would instantly transfer the eyes of the cricket world to New Zealand. Women's cricket would never have had it so good. Go on Don, do the decent thing. Light our fire.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous column, on how England's women struck it rich on the lottery, click here

webTitle: Asda to hold senior citizens' singles night

fields.headline: Asda targets elderly with singles night
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Asda's latest marketing stunt is aimed at the elderly in its first senior citizens' singles night. By Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
Asda's latest marketing stunt to draw shoppers is aimed at the elderly in its first senior citizens' singles night.

In a move designed to attract the elderly population of Broadstairs, Kent, of whom 37% live alone and 1 in 10 admit to feeling lonely, Asda will help senior citizens find love over bingo games, wine tasting and tea dances. Tombolas and raffles will raise funds for charities such as Help the Aged.

Sally Hopson, Asda's customer services director, said: "Older people are some of our most loyal customers, so we wanted to be able to hold an evening which gave them the opportunity to get out and about, meet new people, make friends and maybe check out the chance of romance."

If tomorrow's event is a success, Asda hopes to launch them throughout the country.

webTitle: Firebox.com hires top marketer from Unilever

fields.headline: Firebox.com poaches top Unilever marketer
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Firebox.com has poached Shaun Harris from Unilever to be its marketing director. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Lads gadget site Firebox.com has secured a coup by pulling in a top marketer from Unilever. The electronic retailer has poached Shaun Harris from Unilever's food division, Ven den Bergh, to be its marketing director.

Harris, who has worked at Unilever for 11 years, was responsible for household brands such as Magnum, Solero, Carte D'or and Viennetta. At Firebox.com he will assist in the planned European expansion and oversee brand development.

"Passing on a top level job in Unilever was a hard decision, but Firebox is emerging as one of the leaders in the etail sector. I look forward to translating the brand and its values to foreign markets and building on Firebox's success to date," said Harris.

Firebox.com already has operations in London and Sweden and plans to launch in Germany within the next 12 months. Last month Dennis Publishing took at 5% equity stake in the retailer in return for offline and online marketing in magazines such as men's lifestyle magazine Maxim.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: The transfer talk: more interesting than the Olympics
fields.trailText: Sources at Panathinaikos have told onefootball.com that Manchester United are preparing a £10m offer for 25-year-old striker Nikos Liberopoulos. United fans can be forgiven for getting excited about this one - the left-sided Greek international has been compared to a certain Monsieur E Cantona.
fields.body:
Sources at Panathinaikos have told onefootball.com that Manchester United are preparing a £10m offer for 25-year-old striker Nikos Liberopoulos. United fans can be forgiven for getting excited about this one - the left-sided Greek international has been compared to a certain Monsieur E Cantona.

Newcastle have asked Chelsea about their under-fire defender Frank Leboeuf, according to the Daily Mail. Bobby Robson wants the 32-year-old World Cup winner to bolster his defence, but may bridle at Chelsea's £4m asking price and the Frenchman's £25,000-a-week wages.

Meanwhile, the Mirror reports that Chelsea defender Christian Panucci advised Claudio Ranieri's first transfer target - the Real Madrid winger Savio - to stay well away from Stamford Bridge. Savio, who has decided to stay at Real, said: "I have listened to the words of my Real team-mates Roberto Carlos and Flavio Conceicao and Panucci and they have made me think better of it."

Teamtalk claim Liverpool are keeping tabs on Sheffield Wednesday's Owen Morrison. The left-sided midfielder has apparently impressed Gerard Houllier, who has had the youngster watched in a number of reserve-team fixtures.

Rangers are the latest club to join the race for Colchester striker Lomana Lua Lua. The 19 year old also interests West Ham - but fellow suitors Newcastle are threatening to withdraw their £2m offer if a deal is not completed soon.

Wimbledon are to make yet another £3m bid for Richard Dunne. The Everton defender failed to agree terms with the First Division club two weeks ago, but Dons boss Terry Burton is not giving up yet.

Charlton striker Andy Hunt could win an international cap for Austria. Hunt has an Austrian grandparent and the Austrian FA have been watching his progress - they may name him in their squad for their World Cup match against Liechtenstein next month. "There has been no indication he would not want to play for us," said a spokesman for the AFA.

Wolves will up their bid for Stockport midfielder Tony Dinning. They've already offered £500,000 - but County want £1.5m.

Millwall, who sacked joint-managers Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary at the weekend, want Joe Kinnear or Ray Wilkins to take over at the New Den.

Meanwhile, former Barnsley and Charlton midfielder Neil Redfearn is in line for the player-manager's post at Halifax.
