fields.headline: Urlaubsparadies Deutschland
fields.standfirst: The summer didn't live up to expectations in Germany. How did youngsters make the most of it?
fields.trailText: The summer didn't live up to expectations in Germany. How did youngsters make the most of it?
fields.body:
Rudi Carell, deutscher Schlagersänger und Entertainer, hat es schon vor Jahren gewußt. "Wann wird's mal wieder richtig Sommer?" hat er damals in einer Schnulze gefragt. Tja Rudi, gute Frage - auch Jahre später noch. Denn irgendwie hat sich eine Hitzewelle auch heuer wieder nicht so recht einstellen wollen. Und das, obwohl man sie uns eigentlich versprochen hatte.

"Deutsche schwitzen im Jahrhundertsommer" titelte eine große Boulevardzeitung noch im Frühjahr. Au fein, haben wir uns gedacht und schon mal neue Bademode eingekauft. Aber ausführen konnten wir sie nur ganz selten, weil es ständig wie am Schnürchen geregnet hat.

Aber mal abgesehen davon: Das Wetter hat uns auch sonst ziemlich übel mitgespielt. So mancher Ferienausflug fiel buchstäblich ins Wasser. Und so kam es, daß einige Jugendliche eher in ihren eigenen vier Wänden als im Freibad untertauchten. Was aus den Sommerplänen im ersten Jahr des neuen Millenniums geworden ist? Wir haben uns umgehört.

Dieser Sommer war uns als Jahrhundertsommer angekündigt worden. Hattet Ihr deshalb besondere Pläne? Anita (15):

Ehrlich gesagt: nein. Ich glaube sowieso nicht an das, was die Meteorologen über das Wetter sagen. Die täuschen sich einfach zu oft.

Karel (17): Naja, das mit dem Jahrhundertsommer war ja wohl eher ein PR-Gag der Wetterfrösche. Heuer neigte ja sowieso jeder dazu, alles als etwas ganz Besonderes hinzustellen, nur weil zufällig das Jahr 2000 ist.

Helga (19): Besondere Pläne, ja, die hatte ich. Und ich habe sie auch umgesetzt: Ich war mit meinem Freund in Deutschland unterwegs; mit dem eigenen Auto. Das haben wir uns nach dem Abitur gegönnt.

Ein Sprichwort sagt: "Erstens kommt es anders und zweitens als man denkt ..." Hat Euch der häufige Regen im Juli einen Strich durch Eure Urlaubsvorhaben gemacht? Helga:

Kommt darauf an, wie man es sieht: Natürlich war unser Trip zum Teil ziemlich verregnet. Einmal mußten wir sogar unter einer Brücke essen. Wir hatten an diesem Tag ein Picknick vorgesehen, aber es wollte nicht aufhören zu regnen. Und da haben wir eben an einem kleinen Bach gehalten und uns unter dieser Brücke verschanzt. Das war zwar ungewöhnlich, aber irgendwie auch sehr witzig.

Thomas (16): Das Wetter in den Ferien ist mir grundsätzlich egal. Der August war ja auch ganz schön, da konnte man sogar einige Male ins Freibad gehen. Ein bißchen nervig war der Juli. Da ist in der Schule nicht mehr so viel los. Trotzdem konnte man die freien Nachmittage nie nutzen, um draußen irgendwas zu unternehmen. Ich denke nur an meine Inline-Skates. Mit denen war ich heuer gerade mal an drei oder vier Tagen unterwegs.

Regina (20): Eher im Gegenteil. Weil es bei uns so mies war, bin ich mit Freunden kurz entschlossen nach Italien gefahren. Dort war es ziemlich angenehm. Auch nicht so heiß wie sonst, aber zum Wandern und Radeln hat es gereicht.

Anita: Meine Eltern waren ziemlich stinkig. Wir sind letztes Jahr im Winter umgezogen und heuer wollten sie zum erstenmal den Urlaub im eigenen Garten genießen. Klar, das ist schon schade. Aber Sonnenschein und Hitze sind doch auch nicht alles, oder? Ich finde, man kann sich auch amüsieren, wenn das Wetter nicht mitspielt.

Karel: Ich weiß nicht, ob das anderen auch so geht, aber manchmal finde ich es sogar ganz schön, wenn es regnet und man nicht raus muß. Ich verziehe mich dann mit einem guten Buch in mein Zimmer und lese den ganzen Tag über. Das ist für mich auch Entspannung. Vielleicht sogar mehr, als irgendwo am Baggersee in der Sonne zu brutzeln.

Urlaub in Deutschland ist ein Urlaub ohne Wettergarantie. Würdet ihr es trotzdem machen? Helga:

Klar, habe ich heuer ja bewiesen. Und ich würde das auch jederzeit wieder machen. Deutschland hat so viele schöne Ecken. Die sind auch super, wenn es mal regnet. Und so schlimm war es in diesem Jahr doch auch nicht. Klar, man erinnert sich an den nassen Juli. Aber der August hat doch alles wieder herausgerissen.

Regina: Ich denke schon. Man fährt ja zum Beispiel auch nach England oder Schweden, obwohl man genau weiß, daß dort nicht immer die Sonne vom Himmel brennt. Aber darauf kommt es im Urlaub ja auch gar nicht an. Wenn ich wegfahre, will ich etwas sehen, will mich amüsieren und mich erholen. Und das kann man in Deutschland genauso, wie in einem anderen Land. Wenn man natürlich nur am Strand liegen will, muß man sich das vorher überlegen . . .

Thomas: Logisch. Ist eigentlich ohnehin schade, daß man sich in fremden Ländern oft weniger auskennt als in der eigenen Heimat. Ich habe mir vorgenommen, in den nächsten Jahren ein Bundesland nach dem anderen abzuklappern und mir mal anzuschauen, wie es dort so ist. Außerdem habe ich bei Urlaub in Deutschland den absoluten Vorteil, daß mich jeder versteht und ich mich nicht in einer anderen Sprache zurechtfinden muß.

Anita (15): Ehrlich gesagt: nein. Ich glaube sowieso nicht an das, was die Meteorologen über das Wetter sagen. Die täuschen sich einfach zu oft. Karel (17): Naja, das mit dem Jahrhundertsommer war ja wohl eher ein PR-Gag der Wetterfrösche. Heuer neigte ja sowieso jeder dazu, alles als etwas ganz Besonderes hinzustellen, nur weil zufällig das Jahr 2000 ist. Helga (19): Besondere Pläne, ja, die hatte ich. Und ich habe sie auch umgesetzt: Ich war mit meinem Freund in Deutschland unterwegs; mit dem eigenen Auto. Das haben wir uns nach dem Abitur gegönnt. Ein Sprichwort sagt: "Erstens kommt es anders und zweitens als man denkt ..." Hat Euch der häufige Regen im Juli einen Strich durch Eure Urlaubsvorhaben gemacht? Helga: Kommt darauf an, wie man es sieht: Natürlich war unser Trip zum Teil ziemlich verregnet. Einmal mußten wir sogar unter einer Brücke essen. Wir hatten an diesem Tag ein Picknick vorgesehen, aber es wollte nicht aufhören zu regnen. Und da haben wir eben an einem kleinen Bach gehalten und uns unter dieser Brücke verschanzt. Das war zwar ungewöhnlich, aber irgendwie auch sehr witzig. Thomas (16): Das Wetter in den Ferien ist mir grundsätzlich egal. Der August war ja auch ganz schön, da konnte man sogar einige Male ins Freibad gehen. Ein bißchen nervig war der Juli. Da ist in der Schule nicht mehr so viel los. Trotzdem konnte man die freien Nachmittage nie nutzen, um draußen irgendwas zu unternehmen. Ich denke nur an meine Inline-Skates. Mit denen war ich heuer gerade mal an drei oder vier Tagen unterwegs. Regina (20): Eher im Gegenteil. Weil es bei uns so mies war, bin ich mit Freunden kurz entschlossen nach Italien gefahren. Dort war es ziemlich angenehm. Auch nicht so heiß wie sonst, aber zum Wandern und Radeln hat es gereicht. Anita: Meine Eltern waren ziemlich stinkig. Wir sind letztes Jahr im Winter umgezogen und heuer wollten sie zum erstenmal den Urlaub im eigenen Garten genießen. Klar, das ist schon schade. Aber Sonnenschein und Hitze sind doch auch nicht alles, oder? Ich finde, man kann sich auch amüsieren, wenn das Wetter nicht mitspielt. Karel: Ich weiß nicht, ob das anderen auch so geht, aber manchmal finde ich es sogar ganz schön, wenn es regnet und man nicht raus muß. Ich verziehe mich dann mit einem guten Buch in mein Zimmer und lese den ganzen Tag über. Das ist für mich auch Entspannung. Vielleicht sogar mehr, als irgendwo am Baggersee in der Sonne zu brutzeln. Urlaub in Deutschland ist ein Urlaub ohne Wettergarantie. Würdet ihr es trotzdem machen? Helga: Klar, habe ich heuer ja bewiesen. Und ich würde das auch jederzeit wieder machen. Deutschland hat so viele schöne Ecken. Die sind auch super, wenn es mal regnet. Und so schlimm war es in diesem Jahr doch auch nicht. Klar, man erinnert sich an den nassen Juli. Aber der August hat doch alles wieder herausgerissen. Regina: Ich denke schon. Man fährt ja zum Beispiel auch nach England oder Schweden, obwohl man genau weiß, daß dort nicht immer die Sonne vom Himmel brennt. Aber darauf kommt es im Urlaub ja auch gar nicht an. Wenn ich wegfahre, will ich etwas sehen, will mich amüsieren und mich erholen. Und das kann man in Deutschland genauso, wie in einem anderen Land. Wenn man natürlich nur am Strand liegen will, muß man sich das vorher überlegen . . . Thomas: Logisch. Ist eigentlich ohnehin schade, daß man sich in fremden Ländern oft weniger auskennt als in der eigenen Heimat. Ich habe mir vorgenommen, in den nächsten Jahren ein Bundesland nach dem anderen abzuklappern und mir mal anzuschauen, wie es dort so ist. Außerdem habe ich bei Urlaub in Deutschland den absoluten Vorteil, daß mich jeder versteht und ich mich nicht in einer anderen Sprache zurechtfinden muß. webTitle: Champions League: Dynamo Kiev v Man Utd

fields.headline: Beckham the dynamo driving United's cause
fields.trailText: David Beckham was welcomed by hordes of supporters at Boryspil airport yesterday and the defenders of Dynamo Kiev are sure to stick as close to him tonight after his commanding display at Goodison Park on Saturday.
fields.body:
David Beckham was welcomed by hordes of supporters at Boryspil airport yesterday and the defenders of Dynamo Kiev are sure to stick as close to him tonight.

Anyone who saw him spraying 70-yard passes around Goodison Park on Saturday with a simplicity that suggested he might have been shelling peas would be willing to subscribe to the theory he is playing some of the best football of his career.

Sir Alex Ferguson volunteered the opinion last night that Beckham "was playing as well as I can remember", and from someone usually prone to keeping anything Beckham-related in-house such high praise is not proffered lightly.

Any journalist displaying the temerity to mention Beckham's name within Ferguson's earshot over the past two years has usually been shot down with the type of impenetrable stare that could make mice jump into a trap. But, as United prepared for their first match inside the imposing Respublikanski stadium, his willingness to speak about Fleet Street's favourite play-thing is perhaps evidence that, after more indiscretions than he would care to remember, the Scot finally regards Beckham as having come of age.

"There comes a time when you reach an age of maturity and that's the period when you really look for players to shine. David is doing just that," he said. "I can remember from my playing days that, when you reach that stage, when you feel in control, then everything is that much easier.

"David knows he can score more goals but he's already got three this season and, if he continues at this rate, he will be up around the 14 or 15 mark, which is what he is capable of.

"His hunger has always been there but it is not just that. He is very fit. Some players need more rest than others, but not him. He has a natural stamina to go with everything else."

Dynamo, however, have a few star players of their own. Their midfielder Andrii Husin was last season's Ukraine player of the year and the Uzbek striker Maxim Shatskikh won Ukraine's golden boot and was named newcomer of the year.

Since beating Arsenal two seasons ago they have sold arguably their two finest assets, Andrei Shevchencko to Milan and Sergei Rebrov to Tottenham, but Ferguson is adamant that Ukraine's flagship team will provide United's sternest examination of this first group stage.

"Kiev always seem to produce a great player who no one has heard of," he said. "They are something of an unknown quantity and that's to our disadvantage. We don't know their players like we do with, say, Barcelona, Real Madrid or Juventus. That could work against us."

Dynamo are certainly taking it seriously. Having won vischa liga by a record 18 points last season, scoring 85 goals while conceding only 18, they have been given special dispensation by the Ukraine Football Federation to postpone their league matches until October so that they can get a good start in the Champions League.

Paradoxically, however, the lack of competitive action seemed to work against them last week when they led against PSV Eindhoven in the Netherlands before succumbing to tired legs and losing 2-1.

That result makes their need for victory here all the stronger and, judging by the number of ticket touts milling around yesterday, there should not be many empty spaces in their 83,500-capacity stadium.

A back injury to Fabien Barthez, suffered against Everton on Saturday, saw Mark Bosnich reunited with United's first-team squad yesterday, although it will be Raimond van der Gouw who replaces the Frenchman in goal. Teddy Sheringham is likely to resume his partnership up front with Andy Cole.

webTitle: Wanted: an ordinary guy to be bigtime movie star

fields.headline: Wanted: an ordinary guy to be bigtime movie star
fields.standfirst: It is not often that an auteur holds open auditions for a leading role, but that is Polanski's latest ploy
fields.trailText: It is not every day Roman Polanski, maker of Chinatown and Rosemary's Baby, throws the door open to an amateur to anchor a £25m movie.
fields.body:
Small ad: Prominent film director seeks "ordinary bloke" to play the lead in his next film. No experience necessary.

It is not every day Roman Polanski, maker of Chinatown and Rosemary's Baby, throws the door open to an amateur to anchor a £25m movie.

The classified advertisement in yesterday's Guardian was not quite that bald, but not far off. "Acting experience not essential," it said, but the right person "needs to be sensitive, vulnerable and charismatic".

The Actors Centre in Covent Garden, London, where the open auditions for the part of the Polish composer Wladyslaw Szpilman in The Pianist will be held on Saturday week, is already wondering whether it should order crash barriers.

But then this is no ordinary film. For Polanski, 67, who has spawned more than his fair share of myths and horror stories, is confronting his past for the first time.

He was born in Paris in 1933, and his Polish parents moved back to their homeland just as war clouds gathered. As Jews, they were the first to be rounded up and Polanski's formative years were spent amid the horrors of the Krakow ghetto. He survived liquidation by the Nazis only because his father pushed him through a hole in the barbed-wire fence.

While his mother perished in Auschwitz he was sheltered by farmers until he managed to find his uncles. His traumas did not end there. They beat him, and they only thing that kept him sane, he later admitted, were the Nazi propaganda films he sneaked into cinemas to see. He was reunited with his father in 1945.

For most of his adult life Polanski has been obsessed with The Pianist, the harrowing autobiography of Szpilman, who like him narrowly escaped the camps.

The book, published in 1946, tells how he was saved by a German officer who admired his music and his playing.

Alex Johnson, from casting agents Celestia Fox, said because the story was "so close to Polanski's own experience, he has a very clear idea of what he wants. He feels there is someone out there, and not necessarily an actor, who embodies what he feels about Szpilman. Obviously, the ability to play the piano would help, but he is looking at this in a very broad way."

Polanski will not able to attend auditions himself. There is the matter of possible extradition to the US to worry about. The director has not visited Britain since 1978 and is still wanted in Los Angeles in connection with the alleged rape of a 13-year-old girl during a party at Jack Nicholson's mansion in 1977.

Polanski's second wife, the actor Sharon Tate, was murdered by Charles Manson and his gang in California in 1969.

He is now married to the French actor Emmanuelle Seigner, 33 years his junior. They have two children.

webTitle: Taylor & Francis reports hike in profits

fields.headline: Profits spur Taylor & Francis on acquisition hunt
fields.trailText: Publishing group Taylor & Francis is on the prowl for acquisitions after reporting a rise in half-year profits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
High-brow publishing group Taylor & Francis is on the prowl for acquisitions after reporting a rise in half-year profits.

The academic and scientific publisher, which produces over 500 journals and over 1,500 new books every year, said pre-tax profits had climbed from £2.95m to £3.6m.

Taylor & Francis wants to repeat the success of its £4.33m acquisition of the Scandinavian Journals Business in January this year, which added 61 titles to the group's roster.

Chief executive, Anthony Selvey, said: "The group's strategy remains to grow the business through both well planned organic development and earnings enhancing acquisitions in markets that we know and understand."

The group managed to spice up its bookish profile in July when it announced a joint venture with e- publisher Versaware, which will make the group's catalogue of 17,000 titles available on e-books. Another strand of the Taylor & Francis e-commerce strategy is SARA, a popular online service for journal subscribers which has 90,000 users.

The shares rose 6.5p to 611.5p.

webTitle: Restructure looms for Budweiser marketing team

fields.headline: Budweiser marketing department set for revamp
fields.trailText: Budweiser is poised for a significant overhaul of its UK marketing department. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Budweiser is poised for a significant overhaul of its UK marketing department following the departure of James Lousada, the European marketing director on Budweiser.

Lousada, who has already left the company, is replaced by Kerry Bebe who is promoted from marketing manager.

Michelle Norman, a senior spokesperson at Budweiser, confirmed Lousada's departure but declined to comment further on the reorganisation of the department or the reasons behind Lousada's move.

Lousada joined the Anheuser-Busch owned brand as marketing manager in 1996 and was responsible for the ongoing review of Budweiser's advertising account. A pitch was called in June for a second UK agency to handle the brewer's £15m account alongside the incumbent, BMP DDB.

Goodby Silverstein & Partners in the US created a series of ads that continue to run in the UK starring Louie the Lizard. The company is said to be increasing its UK marketing budget from £29m to £33m in 2000 following the success of the series.

fields.headline: Guinness builds ice pub to promote brand
fields.trailText: Guinness has created a pub entirely made from ice as a stunt to promote its Extra Cold beer, reports Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
Guinness has struck upon a novel solution to the age-old problem of warm beer - funding a pub entirely made from ice as a stunt to promote its Extra Cold beer.

The 9sq metre pub, made from 20 tonnes of ice in conditions of minus 18 degrees Celsius, is licensed to sell real pints to punters and will be on display at the Broadgate Centre in central London today.

Ice sculptor Jonathan Lloyd is unconcerned that within five hours his creation will be reduced to water: "The fact that it melts is part of the magic."

Guinness will use the £250,000 ice-pub - equipped with ice stools, an ice dart board and an ice pool table - to advertise its draught Extra Cold beer.

A Guinness spokeswoman said today that if technology developed, Britons could one day see ice pubs around the country promoting the beer.

fields.headline: 4imprint's profits tumble
fields.trailText: Promotional products group 4imprint has reported massive losses, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Promotional products group 4imprint has reported massive losses in its first set of results since undergoing a radical transformation.

The group, formally known as the Bemrose Corporation, blamed the reorganisation for half-year pre-tax losses of £45.3m, against a £1.15m profit for the same period last year.

Earlier this year, it sold off its print businesses for £40m to concentrate on selling promotional goods, such as company T-shirts and coffee mugs, through catalogues and over the internet.

The group has seen US sales rise from £14.68m to £17.34m following a lucrative link-up with US catalogue retailer Lands' End. The deal allows 4imprint to market its products to Lands' End's client base of 100,000 companies, which generates £95m annual sales.

4imprint chairman Roger Booth said: "Current trading is on plan and we have substantial financial resources to invest in the development of both our existing operations and new opportunities."

The group's shares tumbled 20p to 485p in early morning trading.

webTitle: The women on top in the BBC

fields.headline: Women on top at Dyke's BBC
fields.standfirst: With Greg Dyke at the helm, an increasing number of women are making their mark in the higher echelons of the BBC
fields.trailText: With Greg Dyke at the helm, an increasing number of women are making their mark in the higher echelons of the BBC. By Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
The feminisation of the BBC seems to be accelerating under director general Greg Dyke. The appointment of Lorraine Heggessey as controller of BBC1, the first woman to hold such a coveted and powerful post, is an obvious breakthrough. For the first time both BBC1 and BBC2 (Jane Root) have women controllers, while BBC Knowledge, the network to be revamped as a serious BBC4, is also run by Liz Cleaver.

But women are also well represented among the powerful new layer of genre commissioners, who will advise channel controllers this autumn on which new dramas, entertainment, factual, and specialist programming and arts to back.

They include Danielle Lux (entertainment), Nicola Moody (factual), Glenwyn Benson (specialist), and probably, Jane Tranter (drama). Roly Keating is the new arts supremo, while Nigel Pickard runs all children's programming and scheduling. They have real power because there is a "dual key" system: both commissioner and controller must agree. Also, with new quotas due to be announced for BBC producers, they wield power over what is made in-house as well as by independents.These executives have development funds for new projects on all networks, a key spending area.

Also, within the past nine months, two of the three national regions have passed into the control of women, Menna Richards at BBC Wales (headhunted from HTV) and Anna Carragher, BBC Northern Ireland. Both are high profile leadership roles. In Wales Richards has already shaken up the structure and now has to revitalise production, especially for BBC1 which has been in the doldrums. In Northern Ireland there are continual political tensions requiring a trusted pair of hands.

The national regions have been invited by Dyke to bid for extra funds made available by the slashing of bureaucracy: for example, to provide programmes for new regional digital services.

In radio the tide turned with the appointment of Jenny Abramsky as director two years ago, but has continued with the decision to make Helen Boaden controller of Radio 4, another highly visible and coveted post. Kate Rowlands, as head of radio drama, has been charged with developing drama for both Radio 4 and Radio 3, as well as planning the forthcoming fiftieth anniversary of The Archers.

It's a far cry from the last big shake up in 1996, when John Birt famously overlooked talented women, having previously driven away Liz Forgan. Only a year ago the dying days of the Birtist era favoured corporate bruisers such as Matthew Bannister, and drove away Jana Bennett, the executive who championed Walking with Dinosaurs, to the Discovery networks.

Both are high profile leadership roles. In Wales Richards has already shaken up the structure and now has to revitalise production, especially for BBC1 which has been in the doldrums. In Northern Ireland there are continual political tensions requiring a trusted pair of hands. The national regions have been invited by Dyke to bid for extra funds made available by the slashing of bureaucracy: for example, to provide programmes for new regional digital services. In radio the tide turned with the appointment of Jenny Abramsky as director two years ago, but has continued with the decision to make Helen Boaden controller of Radio 4, another highly visible and coveted post. Kate Rowlands, as head of radio drama, has been charged with developing drama for both Radio 4 and Radio 3, as well as planning the forthcoming fiftieth anniversary of The Archers. It's a far cry from the last big shake up in 1996, when John Birt famously overlooked talented women, having previously driven away Liz Forgan. Only a year ago the dying days of the Birtist era favoured corporate bruisers such as Matthew Bannister, and drove away Jana Bennett, the executive who championed Walking with Dinosaurs, to the Discovery networks.

webTitle: French Connection to up ad spend

fields.headline: Profit rise leads French Connection to up ad spend
fields.trailText: Stephen Marks, chairman and chief executive of the French Connection Group, has pledged to increase the company's advertising budget following the success of its "Everyone's Talking FCUK" campaign.
fields.body:
Stephen Marks, chairman and chief executive of the French Connection Group, has pledged to increase the company's advertising budget following the success of its "Everyone's Talking FCUK" campaign.

French Connection today unveiled a 15.4% increase in pre-tax profits to £7.5m for the first six months of the year on turnover up 24.7% to £87.4m. Performance for the year as a whole is expected to be even better, with like-for-like retail sales up 12% in the first six weeks.

"Advertising and marketing are a very important part of driving the business forward and supporting the brands," said Marks. "The 'Everyone's talking FCUK' advertising campaign has been a resounding success and we have just launched a new TV advertising campaign in the UK.

"We believe that the continued increase in advertising, balanced with credible product, a great shopping environment and excellent customer service, will help us maintain our growth for the future, both in the UK and the USA."

French Connection will continue to expand during the second half of the year, with the opening of its biggest store on the corner of London's Oxford Street and Duke Street. The company also plans to launch a men's grooming range and has signed an exclusive licensing deal with Boots to launch 20 products in 1,300 stores.

fields.headline: Publicis and Cordiant agree to merge Zenith stakes
fields.trailText: The Publicis Group has reached a verbal agreement with the Cordiant Communications Group to merge their stakes Zenith Media, Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
The Publicis Group has reached a verbal agreement with the Cordiant Communications Group to merge their stakes in media buyer Zenith Media.

Publicis chairman Maurice Levy confirmed the two companies have reached an "agreement in principle".

As part of the merger, the companies are negotiating the creation of a holding company that would group the media buying activities of Publicis, including media arm Optimedia and its 50% stake in Zenith, with Cordiant's Zenith share.

Publicis acquired a 50% stake in Zenith as part of its buyout of London-based Saatchi & Saatchi, which was last week cleared by the High Court. Publicis has also expressed an interest in acquiring Cordiant's 50% stake in Zenith. Should this happen, Publicis could consolidate Zenith with Optimedia to create an international media buying giant and fulfil one of the main aims of the Saatchi merger.

The finer details of the merger have yet to be negotiated and no timetable for completion is available.

David Lister sticks up for Andrew Marr, the BBC's new political editor and former Independent editor. (p.9)
Mario Monti, the European Competition Commissioner, yesterday said that rapid consolidation among media companies could mean that regulators have to change the definition of market dominance. In other words, the EMI and Time Warner merger might go through. (p.15)

THE GUARDIAN
Ashank Desai, an Indian computer pioneer, said British business must be more enthusiastic about e-commerce or risk being left behind by other industrial nations. (p.24)
Joe Sinyor, head of Sony UK, has been appointed chief executive, newspapers at Trinity Mirror. (p23)
Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group said the relaunch of Talk Radio as TalkSport had proved a success despite rising losses. (p24)
Ulster TV, buoyed by an Irish economic boom, said it should ride out any fall in ITV ad revenues. (p26)

Former Sun-editor Kelvin MacKenzie has turned his £1.5m investment in broadcaster the Wireless Group into a £13m stake, thanks to a soaring share price.(p.32)

The European Commission will block the huge merger between AOL and Time Warner unless the companies offer more concessions. (p.1) US company RSL Communications has accused telecoms regulator Oftel of suffocating internet growth in Britain. (p.2)

DAILY EXPRESS
German company Teekanne has signed up Sean Connery for a tea advertising campaign. The plan is to make the drink "erotic" and "adventurous." (p.24)
Jailbreak, Channel 5's riposte to Big Brother, garnered only 1m viewers for its first episode. (p.31)

THE SUN
Aspiring writers Cass Pennant and Neil Bowers say director Guy Ritchie stole their ideas and used them in his new movie, Snatch. (p.1)

THE MIRROR
Directors at Channel 4 and production company Bazal, the people behind Big Brother, have given £70,000 to Joanne Harris, the Down's Syndrome teenager who received the same amount from winner Craig Philips. (p.7)
Viewers will be able to see Alan Titchmarsh lose his rag in TV show Ground Force next month. (p.8)

And Finally...

THE DAILY STAR
"Fed up Gary Lineker is quitting They Think it's All Over because of joker Jonathan Ross poking fun at him". He doesn't like being called Big Ears. (p1)

webTitle: Ground Force team 'came close to blows'

fields.headline: Ground Force team 'came close to blows'
fields.trailText: Alan Titchmarsh and fellow TV gardener Tommy Walsh came close to blows while filming the new series of BBC1's Ground Force, according to an interview in this week's Radio Times.
fields.body:
Alan Titchmarsh and fellow TV gardener Tommy Walsh came close to blows while filming the new series of BBC1's Ground Force, according to an interview in this week's Radio Times.

The usually mild-mannered Titchmarsh reportedly lost his rag while planting beds in a garden in Pitsea, Essex, after Walsh inadvertently covered the flower beds in sawdust when he was sawing timber. "Call me picky if you like but I like my Ground Force gardens to be pristine when we finish them," he said. "I do not get a thrill from seeing them covered in dandruff."

Walsh added: "For a while it did get a bit hairy. But when we'd both calmed down we actually kissed (yes) and made up. What made me cross was that I was working flat out to get everything ready and here was Alan moaning about a bit of stray sawdust."

The only good thing about the incident was, according to Titchmarsh, that it silenced his fellow presenter Charlie Dimmock. "She just kept her head down and fiddled with her water feature," he said.

webTitle: Ulster TV buoyed by Irish economic boom

fields.headline: Ulster TV buoyed by Irish economic boom
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Ulster TV, the Northern Ireland commercial television broadcaster, said yesterday that the strength of the Irish economy should help it ride out any fall in ITV network advertising revenues.
fields.body:
Ulster TV, the Northern Ireland commercial television broadcaster, said yesterday that the strength of the Irish economy should help it ride out any fall in ITV network advertising revenues.

The company's half-year operating profits rose 24% to £6.7m. An exceptional gain of £13m from the sale of its stake in satellite group Société Européene des Satellites pushed the pre-tax figure up to £20.4m.

Ulster said advertising revenues in the half-year had jumped by 12%, in line with the rest of the ITV network excluding the high-growth London area.

It has seen signs of a fall-off in advertising across the ITV network in the three months since June.

But the company said that it expected its share of ITV advertising revenues would continue to improve, because its performance is linked to Ulster TV's programming and penetration across Ireland and not to the rise and fall of dot.com companies which has been a factor in the fluctuating advertising revenues for companies in England.

John McGuckian, the Ulster TV chairman, said: "The nature of our market, with its strong regional focus, should ensure that the effects of the downturn in the second half at network level are mitigated by the continuing strong growth in the economy in Ireland."

Ulster TV's sales, consisting almost entirely of advertising revenue, climbed 11% to £20.4m. Its sales house, TSMS, has been sold to Granada Media group and it is expecting to conclude a deal with the new owner about contractual arrangements in respect of airtime sales.

Its internet acquisition, currently operating at a loss, is seen as a long-term area for growth. Begun in June, it has built up subscribers using the Ulster TV brand name. It has 20,000 subscribers but the aim is to achieve 60,000 by June next year.

Turnover for the internet business reached £347,000, resulting in a loss of £342,000 as Ulster TV builds up the operation. It has a marketing budget of around £1.2m for the first year of operations. Initially it is targeting its all-Ireland ISP at the consumer market. But the plan is to offer a business version later this year. Ulster TV's share price closed at 355p, down 15p, more than 4%, yesterday. For the six months to June, the company announced a dividend of 3.6p, 16% higher than last year's figure.

webTitle: Talked out: Sport beats chat any day, says MacKenzie

fields.headline: Talked out: Sport beats chat any day, says MacKenzie
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Wireless Group, the radio business run by former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, yesterday said the relaunch of Talk Radio as an all-sport station had proved a success.
fields.body:
Wireless Group, the radio business run by former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, yesterday said the relaunch of Talk Radio as an all-sport station had proved a success.

The station, which rebranded as Talksport at the start of the year, generated a 21% increase in revenues during the first six months to £5.1m. The company said male listeners now accounted for 75% of the total compared with 55% at the same time last year under the previous format.

More than £4m spent on advertising the relaunch contributed to losses for the station widening during the first half from £2.9m to £6.5m. That figure was also inflated by £2.2m spent on the acquisition of sports rights, a figure which may raise a wry smile after the station was rebuked for pretending that commentators watching Euro 2000 on a television in a Dutch hotel bedroom were broadcasting live from the games.

In its maiden results as a quoted company, Wireless Group reported revenues of £13.8m up from £4.2m after the acquisition of the Radio Partnership and Independent Radio Group during the second half.

Group operating losses more than doubled to £7.6m due to the cost of relaunching Talksport. Shares in the company slipped 3p to 263.5p against their peak of 289p in July.

Wireless Group, which is the fourth largest radio business in the UK, raised £36m through its flotation in May although much of that cash was used to reduce debt and provide working capital.

The local radio assets moved into the black with a £600,000 operating profit against a £300,000 loss last year.

webTitle: Lib Dem conference: Delegates want Queen to give up church role

fields.headline: Call to end royal supremacy
fields.standfirst:
Delegates want Queen to give up church role
Special report: Liberal Democrat Conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday voted to remove the Queen as head of the established Church of England in a package of sweeping constitutional reforms that would go much further than Labour.Special report: Liberal Democrat Conference 2000
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats yesterday voted to remove the Queen as head of the established Church of England in a package of sweeping constitutional reforms that would go much further than Labour.

On the first full day of their annual conference delegates repeatedly invoked the extraparliamentary pressure exerted by fuel protesters last week to justify demands for Labour to be more radical and less secretive.The constitutional measures adopted include old Lib Dem favourites like electoral reform and an elected senate as well as further devolution to the regions  especially in England  and much more scrutiny of government policy in Whitehall.

The conference unanimously accepted an amendment which would bar the head of state from holding any position of high authority in any church and would also amend the 1701 Act of Settlement which requires the monarch to belong to the Church of England.

The Lib Dem treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, had earlier warned that the fuel protest represented the shape of politics to come  much scarier, energetic, in your face, fast, awkward, difficult, high tech".

In the new climate voters could no longer be deceived by stealth taxes or by William Hagues new stealth charges" for students,pensions and the sick. The Truro MP, who reminded delegates that in rural areas like his people need their cars  making car tax a poll tax" which hurts the poor most.

 In a later debate the Lib Dem foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, called for the lifting of non-military sanctions against Iraq. The ordinary people of Iraq are the oppressed, not the oppressors. Their suffering is not caused by sanctions, it is caused by the evil exploitation of those sanctions by Saddam Hussein," he told delegates.

webTitle: Guardian debate: Labour lecture angers activists

fields.headline: Minister jeered for 'populist' attack
fields.standfirst:
Labour lecture angers activists
Special report: Liberal Democrat Conference 2000
fields.trailText: A Labour minister yesterday  infuriated Liberal Democrat  activists by turning up at their  party conference to lecture  them on the need to abandon  oppositionist tactics and populist soundbites in favour of  constructive policy engagement with the Blair government.
fields.body:
A Labour minister yesterday infuriated Liberal Democrat activists by turning up at their party conference to lecture them on the need to abandon oppositionist tactics and populist soundbites in favour of constructive policy engagement with the Blair government.

The home office minister, Charles Clarke, was heckled and lectured in his turn over Labour s failings in office across a range of policies, from reactionary penal reforms and stealth taxes to constitutional timidity.

Mr Clarkes attack was launched after he accepted an invitation from Simon Hughes MP, his old friend in radical student politics at Cambridge, to speak at the Guardian s an- nual debate on the conference fringe, the first Labour minis- ter to do so.

We were on the same side in Cambridge, for the people and against the system. Its inter- esting to see which side we are on now, joked Mr Hughes be- fore he rattled off a list of Labour shortcomings  its re- jection of electoral reform, its hostility to freedom of information and its extraordinary  reluctance to impose a higher tax rate on incomes of £100,000 a year than paid by those on £25,000.

But Mr Clarke, former chief of staff to Neil Kinnock, and now MP for Norwich South, stood his ground in exchanges which were repeatedly interrupted with cries of rubbish and other abuse  not least when he said he did not believe there was a fundamental difference between Labour and the Liberal Democrats on most basic issues.He cited the tackling of poverty and the need for better public services as examples of common interest,along with better environmental policies.All of them showed differences of emphasis between the two parties rather than of principle.

The minister argued that what you do, not what you say" was the real test for the kind of radical changes wanted by himself and fellow panelists  Mr Hughes, Lady Nicholson MEP and grassroots activist, Tony (now Lord) Greaves. Lady Nicholson, an ex-Tory MP, predicted that the future of politics will lie in Europe and in cooperation,not the knock-down trench warfare of Westminster. Undeterred, Mr Clarke claimed that whatever the government put forward the Liberal Democrats adopted an oppositionist position, even when difficult reforms on health, tax or education were proposed. The Liberal Democrats nationally tend to snipe at the edges rather than adopt constructive policies," he said.

His audiences indignation rose still further when the minister complained of their assembly of populist soundbites appealing to different audiences 2in recent policy statements and said they should choose constructive engagement rather than oppositionism and cheap soundbites".

Angered by Labour failures and by its refusal to accept electoral reform for Westminster, some delegates called on Mr Kennedy to abandon the joint consultative committee with Tony Blair. On that point Mr Hughes and Mr Clarke agreed: they thought it a use- ful forum worth keeping.

fields.headline: Anti-euro trend gains in Denmark
fields.trailText: Anti-euro campaigners surged ahead in Denmark yesterday, a Gallup poll giving them an 11-point lead over the increasingly gloomy Yes camp, at 48% to 37%.
fields.body:
Anti-euro campaigners surged ahead in Denmark yesterday, a Gallup poll giving them an 11-point lead over the increasingly gloomy Yes camp, at 48% to 37%.

But 10 days before the referendum on whether to join the single currency, the difficulty of predicting the result was underlined by a Vilstrup poll, which put the Nos at 43% and the pro-euro camp at 42%.

The Gallup poll in the newspaper Berlingske Tidende found that 15% of voters were undecided, as did the Vilstrup poll in the rival daily Politiken.

The latest findings came after the Social Democrat prime minster, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, promised at the weekend that Denmark's high-spending welfare state would remain unchanged if it abolished the krone.

Women working in the public sector are said to be especially susceptible to this argument, which is likely to be heard increasingly loudly in the campaign's final days.

But a claim by Mr Rasmussen and the economics minister, Marianne Jelved, that pensions would be safe in the euro zone came under fire from No campaigners, who said it was a sign of panic by the pro-euro camp.

As the political temperature rose, a labour movement report warned that skilled and unskilled workers would bear the main costs of rejecting the single currency.

According to the analysis, said the Berlingske Tidende, a No vote would lead to 21,000 lost jobs within the next five years and interest rates would rise by 0.6%.

The pro-euro campaign, launched in March, has been undermined by suggestions that the advantages of membership are uncertain, and more recently by the euro's slide against the dollar.

webTitle: Cabinet split over fuel price deal

fields.headline: Cabinet split over fuel price deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Treasury ministers are privately considering offering a rebate on diesel duty to road hauliers, but not to the ordinary motorist, to quell the petrol price rebellion which has sent the government into a tailspin.
fields.body:
Treasury ministers are privately considering offering a rebate on diesel duty to road hauliers, but not to the ordinary motorist, to quell the petrol price rebellion which has sent the government into a tailspin.

In interviews yesterday the chancellor, Gordon Brown, refused to back down on his hardline stance last week. He insisted he would not give in to short-term demands or return to the era of boom and bust.

However, Blairite cabinet ministers are determined to face the Treasury down and insist on a general cut in petrol duties. One said: "Rebates for road hauliers would only be tinkering at the edges. People feel a genuine grievance over the price of petrol and that needs to be addressed. The chancellor has made his views plain, but so will other ministers."

The minister said only a big fall in oil prices could prevent the government from making concessions on petrol duties. However, oil prices were continuing to rise last night to more than $34 a barrel.

An unexpected go-ahead for a freeze, or even cut, in petrol duties came from the environment minister, Michael Meacher, yesterday. He said the big rise in petrol duties had been environmentally necessary at a time of falling oil prices, but in the past 10 months the price of oil had risen from $10 to $34. He added that improvements in engine technology would be more than twice as effective in cutting carbon emissions than rises in petrol duty.

Downing Street is hoping to rebalance the political atmosphere with a string of high profile spending announcements at the Labour conference next week.

Mr Brown feels strongly that the rise in petrol duties were necessary to remove the budget deficit and store up the surpluses necessary to fund the big increases in spending on education and health.

However, Treasury officials have been in private talks with the Road Haulage Association since the Budget about plans for "an essential users' rebate" on petrol duties.

The RHA is due to meet the unofficial organisers of last week's "leaderless protest" tomorrow to discuss the next moves in their campaign.

webTitle: Drivers urged not to panic over new blockade rumours

fields.headline: Drivers urged not to panic over new blockade rumours
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Motorists were today urged not to panic-buy fuel after rumours of fresh blockades led to queues at petrol stations in parts of the country.
fields.body:
Motorists were today urged not to panic-buy fuel after rumours of fresh blockades led to queues at petrol stations in parts of the country.

The rumours, which started in south Wales, spread to other parts of the country, including south-west England and the home counties, leading to fears that fuel will be in short supply again.

The Association of Chief Police Officers (Acpo) said panic-buying was based on "utterly unfounded rumours", while the Petrol Retailers Association (PRA) warned that the situation could become "extremely serious".

In a statement, an Acpo spokesman said: "The fuel situation is returning to normal and 80% of stations are supplied. We are hearing reports of renewed panic-buying in parts of Wales and the south-west.

"These are based on utterly unfounded rumours and there's no cause for anyone to return to panic buying.

"It is based on a misinterpretation and misunderstanding of something that was said on a local radio station, who have since retracted what was put out. This is a totally unnecessary reaction."

The PRA said there was no evidence of any action taking place at any fuel terminal, so there was no need for motorists to panic buy.

"If these stories are circulating and are causing panic buying it is extremely serious and could lead to a re-emergence of the problems of last week.

"This obviously would cause a severe problem for the emergency services and we would urge consumers not to panic buy."

The Transport and General Workers Union said none of its tanker driver members was taking official industrial action and there were no reports of any unofficial strikes.

Tankers were continuing to drive out of Avonmouth Docks, near Bristol, with no sign of any problems.

But huge queues built up at service stations across the city following rumours that drivers were about to strike.

Queues outside the Esso station just a few hundred yards from the dock gate quickly reached a quarter-of-a-mile and caused traffic congestion in the area.

A Texaco garage in Cardiff also reported panic-buying.

"People are telling us that blockades are going ahead and they've come to fill up. They think that something is going on," an attendant said.

Supermarkets in the city said customers were not panic-buying food, but petrol.

Senior duty manager Matthew Bennett at Sainsbury's Colchester Avenue petrol station said: "There is a queue of cars waiting for petrol which stretches back a mile and a half."

Managers have enforced a £10 petrol limit to get the queue moving faster.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for Cheshire police also appealed to motorists to stop panic-buying fuel in response to what he called "malicious rumours" about new protests.

He said: "Cheshire police have a patrol at Stanlow (distribution centre). There is no picket there and we have no knowledge of pickets anywhere in the county."

He added that officers were looking at internet sites on the fuel crisis to see whether they had been used to publicise the latest panic.

webTitle: Protesters accuse Brown of provocation over fuel

fields.headline: Protesters accuse Brown of provocation over fuel
fields.trailText: The farmer who spearheaded the first fuel tax protest today accused the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of trying to provoke further demonstrations.
fields.body:
The farmer who spearheaded the first fuel tax protest today accused the chancellor, Gordon Brown, of trying to provoke further demonstrations.

Brynle Williams, who headed the six-day stand-off outside the Stanlow oil refinery in Cheshire, was reacting to the chancellor's rejection of the deadline imposed by protesters.

The 51-year-old farmer described the chancellor's comments as "antagonistic" while a spokesman for the hauliers who blockaded the Shell terminal, at Jarrow, Tyne and Wear, said Mr Brown would be committing "political suicide" should he fail to act within 60 days.

Mr Brown's defiant stance came as members of the government's new fuel task force sat down again to try to thrash out an agreement on how to secure supplies of petrol - and as a new poll showed Labour's support on the slide.

Mr Williams said from his sheep and cattle farm in Cilcain, near Mold, north Wales: "Gordon Brown is a very very silly man for making such an antagonistic public statement.

"The chancellor is trying to provoke a confrontation by saying he won't stick to our 60-day deadline. He wants to discredit us by provoking us into action before the 60 days is up and then turn round and say 'I told you so'. But I would appeal to the British public to maintain calm and give the man the benefit of the doubt."

Mr Williams, vice-chairman of the Farmers' Union of Wales, added: "I hope at the end of the 60 days he will show he has listened and responded. Mr Brown is like a cornered animal at the moment and is very dangerous; let's ensure he still has an escape route."

Len Johnson, a spokesman for the hauliers who blockaded the Shell terminal at Jarrow, criticised Mr Brown for rejecting the protesters' deadline.

"It is political suicide if he does not do anything within the 60 days. It was a serious gesture and it was well thought about before it was made," he said. "I am sure action will be taken if nothing happens. It would be different if he said 'let's get round the table and talk about it' and explain why he can't do anything within the 60 days."

Mr Johnson expressed scepticism at the chancellor's claims that he was listening to the farmers and hauliers. "He said he was listening to us years ago, but we have been demonstrating for the past two years now," he said. They have been trying to keep us sweet but we are not going to stand for it any more. We are wise to them now."

The chancellor reiterated his hardline stance in an interview with the Times published today, in which he said: "We are not going to make decisions on the basis of deadlines such as this. We have a process that works: the pre-Budget report and then the Budget."

In an apparent rebuke to those colleagues calling for the government to be more responsive, he added: "People do not want governments taking decisions because of something that has happened one week and changing their mind the next week."

Three sub-committees were today trying again to determine how to keep petrol and diesel supplies flowing after yesterday's first full meeting of the government's fuel task force failed to reach agreement on either threatened new legislation to compel oil companies to keep supplies moving or a "memorandum of understanding".

The toll the fuel crisis has taken on the government was underlined by a Guardian ICM poll which showed the Tories pulling further ahead of Labour.

According to the survey, two-thirds of people blame the government for petrol price rises, and nearly three quarters say Labour is not a listening government.

Mr Blair's personal satisfaction rating has plummeted from plus two in July to minus 34 now - the lowest rating for a Labour leader since Neil Kinnock's nadir of popularity in March 1989.

webTitle: Saddam oils the wheels of fuel chaos

fields.headline: Saddam oils the wheels of fuel chaos
fields.standfirst:
As threatening sounds emanate from Baghdad once again, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker examines the Iraqi leader's role in the continuing global oil crisis
Special report: the petrol war
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: As threatening sounds emanate from Baghdad once again, Middle East editor Brian Whitaker examines the Iraqi leader's role in the continuing global oil crisis.
fields.body:
The bellicose noises from Baghdad are chillingly familiar. Saddam Hussein's verbal onslaught against his southern neighbours is almost a word-for-word replay of what we heard 10 years ago, shortly before Iraq invaded Kuwait.

Iraq has now accused Kuwait of stealing its oil (supposedly by drilling sideways under the border), just as it did in July 1990. And, for the first time in more than a decade, an Iraqi military aircraft has intruded into Saudi airspace.

Nobody knows for certain what lies behind this, and no doubt it serves Saddam's purpose to keep the world guessing.

It is particularly baffling because, up to now, Iraq has been winning the public relations war over sanctions, and UN Security Council Resolution 1284 holds out a reasonably short and straightforward route to ending them once and for all.

With most of the world ready to help Iraq out of its predicament, a conciliatory approach from Baghdad would be the obvious course at present.

But Saddam rarely does the obvious. He distrusts resolution 1284 and wants to end sanctions on his own terms, not those of the UN. He is also troubled by the compulsory one-third deductions from Iraqi oil sales that are used to pay compensation to victims of the 1990 Gulf war.

The total amount of compensation is likely to run to hundred of billions of dollars, and the UN has made clear that these payments must continue, even if sanctions are lifted.

The noises from Baghdad certainly sound like the prelude to armed conflict, although the consensus among experts is that his army is in no state to fight another war.

Of course, in the absence of UN inspectors, there is no way of knowing if Saddam has replenished his weapons of mass destruction, but it seems unlikely.

As the US Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright, confidently asserted the other day, Saddam "is in a box... [we] have kept him contained".

Conceivably the latest threats are not really for external consumption, but are intended to mask an unseen power struggle within Iraq.

The report last weekend that Saddam's wayward son, Uday, had attempted suicide is interesting but unconfirmed. A few weeks earlier, there were claims that Saddam himself has terminal cancer. Could the disease be affecting his brain?

In the absence of any firm evidence on the state of Saddam's health and his family relations, it is wise to suppose that he remains as powerful as ever and in full command of his faculties. We should look for another motive that makes sense, at least in Saddam's own terms.

The oil markets are in a delicate state and depend, more than at any other time, on the continuity of supplies from Iraq.

Iraq's two local enemies - Saudi Arabia and Kuwait - are among those endeavouring to bring prices down. For each $1 drop in the price of a barrel of oil, the value of Iraq's production falls by around $2.5m a day.

By engineering an atmosphere of crisis in the Gulf, Iraq can create jitters in the market and keep prices high. It's easy to do and, unless Saddam actually resorts to military force, there's no risk to Iraq.

Iraq, just like Saudi Arabia, is in a position to move markets, and there have even been suggestions in the past - which are difficult to prove - that it has used this to profit from insider trading.

Manipulating the oil price by means of a largely fictitious crisis would bring economic benefits to Iraq, but there may be scope to exploit the current situation further.

One way would be to contrive an interruption in the supply of Iraqi oil (on which the US particularly depends).

Saddam is often attracted by politically symbolic gestures, and the idea of imposing his own sanctions on the west, as retribution for the events of the last 10 years, would certainly appeal to him.

It would also strike a chord with popular opinion in many parts of the Arab and Islamic world.

Such a move would cause oil prices to soar even further, wreaking havoc in much of the industrialised world, and especially in the United States in the midst of a presidential election.

At the moment, the world does not have enough readily-available spare production capacity to compensate for the loss of Iraqi oil, which currently amounts to about 2.5m barrels a day.

But if Saddam wanted to do that he would have to do it soon: there is only a small window of opportunity before increased production from elsewhere replenishes the stockpiles.

It would certainly be a huge gamble by Iraq, and western analysts have generally discounted the idea on the grounds that Saddam would simply be punishing himself by cutting off his only source of real income.

It might not, however, be as costly for Saddam as it looks. The high oil prices of the last few months have given Iraq an unexpected cash windfall - possibly enough to see the country through two or three months of zero revenue without abnormal hardship.

A second factor to bear in mind is that the Iraqi regime receives only about half of the total revenue from its oil production.

Apart from the deductions for compensation, a further 13 per cent of the money goes directly to the Kurdish areas, and some towards covering UN administration costs.

If Iraq announced that it was imposing oil "sanctions" against the US and others, but was prepared to supply to friendly countries directly (outside the oil-for-food programme), it would therefore only need to sell half of its current production to break even.

It might not succeed in that, but any oil that it did sell directly would be worth twice as much as normal.

There would certainly be supply difficulties because this would break the UN embargo, but countries desperate for oil might not take kindly to US attempts to intercept the tankers. The political effect would be to create further rifts in what remains of the international consensus over Iraq.

If the ploy succeeded, sanctions and the oil-for-food programme would be shot to smithereens. There is no certainty that Iraq will try it, and Saddam may judge that the risks outweigh his frustration over sanctions.

But he would be missing a trick if he did not think about it seriously, and so would the west, if it did not consider how it might respond.

fields.standfirst: Chancellor defiant over protesters' 60-day deadline
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has insisted the government will not give in to petrol protesters and rejected demands for a quick cut in fuel duties.

The toll of the fuel crisis on the government's standing was underlined by a new survey showing the Tories pulling further ahead of Labour. The results come after two weekend polls, one showing the Tories ahead by 2% and another putting the parties neck and neck.

The Guardian poll shows nearly two thirds of people blame the government for petrol price rises and nearly three quarters say Labour is not a listening government.

Ministers have said they expect the government's poll rating to improve within the next four to six weeks. However, Conservative leader William Hague said the fuel crisis and the polls showed the people have had enough with the government that had not listened and had not acted to prevent the crisis.

fields.headline: Oil price surges to 10-year high
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Oil prices surged to a 10-year high on the global markets yesterday as tensions in the Middle East and a cautious statement from Saudi Arabia about the chances of further output increases dashed hopes in the west of an early fall in energy costs.
fields.body:
Oil prices surged to a 10-year high on the global markets yesterday as tensions in the Middle East and a cautious statement from Saudi Arabia about the chances of further output increases dashed hopes in the west of an early fall in energy costs.

Share s fell sharply in New York in response to oil prices rising more than a dollar to just under $37 a barrel. Brent crude was up by 89 cents on the day to $34.87, continuing to shrug off last week's com mitment by the oil cartel, Opec, to pump 800,000 extra barrels a day. Both the blue-chip Dow Jones index and the technology-based Nasdaq were heavily down in morning trading.

Markets were also unsettled by a new wave of selling of the euro, which fell to its lowest ever level of just over 85 cents against the dollar in Tokyo yesterday and ended the day in London only marginally higher at $0.8527.

Dealers said they were sceptical about the prospects of this weekend's meeting of G7 finance ministers and central bank governors coming up with a rescue package for the single currency.

French conglomerate Vivendi said yesterday its three-way merger with Seagram and Canal Plus would cost 10% more than the original $30bn because of the euro's fall.

US group Gillette said the weak euro would reduce its sales by 6% when earnings were translated into dollars.

Analysts were also disappointed by Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi Naimi's statement that his country would assess impact of the production rise before taking further action.

webTitle: Few motorists ran dry, but ministers' talk rang hollow

fields.headline: Few motorists ran dry, but ministers' talk rang hollow
fields.standfirst:
Blair's main problem is that dissatisfaction runs deep
Special report: the petrol war
Latest ICM polls
fields.trailText: More than 70% of all motorists had enough petrol to keep on driving throughout last week's fuel crisis, today's Guardian/ ICM poll reveals.
fields.body:
More than 70% of all motorists had enough petrol to keep on driving throughout last week's fuel crisis, today's Guardian/ ICM poll reveals.

It shows that 29% of motorists - or about 23% of the adult population, when those who do not have a car are included - ran so low on petrol that they had to give up using their car.

The ICM poll findings suggest that Tony Blair's real political problem is that the dissatisfaction among the key swing voters is not confined to the issue of petrol prices but runs much deeper.

Some 71% now say they do not believe ministers when they claim to be a "listening" government and Tony Blair's own approval rating as prime minister has taken an even sharper dive that the 10-point slide in New Labour's share of the vote, with his personal ratings slumping from plus two in the early summer to minus 34 points now.

In July, in the immediate aftermath of Gordon Brown's injection of extra funds for health and education, Mr Blair had a positive approval rating, with 44% saying he was doing a good job compared with 42% dissatisfied with his performance as prime minister.

The survey shows that the petrol crisis has triggered a massive loss of personal confidence in Mr Blair.

Only 29% of voters think he is doing a good job - the lowest for a Labour leader since Neil Kinnock in March 1989 - and 63% are unhappy with his performance in Downing Street.

The only group to retain faith in Mr Blair's abilities are Labour voters - some 69% of whom say they think he is doing a good job. A majority of Labour voters do think Mr Blair's is a listening govern ment - but even one third of Mr Blair's loyal supporters disagree with this.

The detail of the poll shows that the government has lost nearly every key argument during the petrol crisis. The attempts of ministers to explain the role of Opec and the oil companies in the petrol price rises completely failed to convince voters.

Some 63% firmly blamed the government, 17% blamed Opec, and only 12% blamed the petrol companies.

The argument that petrol prices should be high to encourage drivers to leave their cars at home for environmental reasons has also completely failed to have any impact. Only 20% agree with the idea of such anti-pollution taxes, and 76% say petrol prices should be cut because they need their cars.

The findings about how many people had to give up using their cars during the last week because they did not have any petrol show that 23% of all adults had to stop using their car, 56% said they carried on driving, and the remaining 21% said they did not have a car.

When those who do not have a car are excluded, the results show that 29% of motorists had to stop driving because they did not have petrol, but 71% were able to carry on motoring.

However, the real anxiety for Mr Blair must be that this poll - the third in the last three days showing that the Labour lead has disappeared overnight - could indicate the beginning of the kind of seismic shift in the political landscape that crippled the Tories eight years ago when the pound was forced out of the European exchange rate mechanism.

It might have been expected that Labour's recovery would have started as soon as the petrol began to be delivered to the pumps once again. That has not proved to be the case. Mr Blair is now in a bigger electoral hole than even the weekend polls indicated.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,055 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between September 15 and 17. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Morris demands inquiry into 'collusion'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers' Union, yesterday called for a public inquiry into why oil companies and the police appeared to collude with protesters during last week's fuel blockades, warning the government against any knee-jerk resort to new legislation.
fields.body:
Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers' Union, yesterday called for a public inquiry into why oil companies and the police appeared to collude with protesters during last week's fuel blockades, warning the government against any knee-jerk resort to new legislation.

The TGWU, which represents the majority of employed tanker drivers and played a key role in helping to bring the blockades to an end, is preparing a dossier of evidence for Tony Blair, detailing company and police inaction or connivance with the anti-fuel tax protests.

But Mr Morris, responding to suggestions that the government is planning legislation requiring oil companies to maintain fuel supplies, made clear that he had not been consulted and that his union would not tolerate any move to restrict the right to strike for tanker drivers.

"The government should investigate why existing legislation was not effective before they rush to implement new laws," he said. His members would be at the "sharp end" of the proposed legislation, which raised questions of civil rights and practicability.

"The roles of the police, the oil companies and the protesters all need to be investigated if we are to avoid blockades of this sort," he said, citing the failure of police to use "their considerable public order powers to restore safety to the roads".

Reports from the union's tanker drivers' representatives, Mr Morris said, raised a questions about the blockades by owner drivers and farmers, including:

 Why had protesters been given the run of restricted areas at Immingham depot near Hull when unions had been refused access, as they had at Fawley, to represent members?

 Why, when protesters first appeared at the Stanlow depot in Cheshire and TGWU members working for P&O told managers they would work normally if they were given police escorts, was no such support given?

 Why did police take no action over film of drivers being threatened at Stanlow - some were told by demonstrators that their pictures would be posted on the internet.

Mr Morris said BP had instructed TGWU drivers last week not to take tankers out - this in an industry ruthlessly quick to make wage deductions if drivers failed to carry out their contractual obligations.

"Why did the companies not invoke their contractual rights in getting deliveries out?

"Why didn't they take out injunctions? Why did the police not invoke the law of obstruction? Why was a convoy of trucks allowed to occupy all three lanes of the M11 travelling at less than 10mph?"

The TGWU is in a strong position to press its case with the government, not least because of the success of two of its officials, Danny Bryan, national officer for road transport, and Andy Smith, TGWU president, in persuading Grangemouth tanker drivers to resume supplies last Wednesday which helped to bring the blockades to an end.

webTitle: Drivers and firms resist petrol supply plan

fields.headline: Drivers and firms resist petrol supply plan
fields.standfirst:
Ministers tell unions legal duty to deliver would fall on oil companies
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Government plans to respond to last week's sudden petrol drought by imposing a new legal duty on oil companies to maintain supplies met fierce resistance from the companies and unions last night.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour,  Michael White  and  Raekha Prasad
fields.body:
Government plans to respond to last week's sudden petrol drought by imposing a new legal duty on oil companies to maintain supplies met fierce resistance from the companies and unions last night.

In an effort to quell union protests about a possible removal of the right to strike, the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, wrote to the TUC to reassure the unions that any legal duty to ensure continuous supply of petrol would be imposed on employers, and not on the tankers drivers or their unions.

The petrol companies said the scheme was probably unworkable, adding they would not instruct their workforce to cross the protest lines if there was any perceived threat to their safety. They added many of the tanker drivers were not in their direct employment.

The controversy arose after the first meeting of a task force of ministers, police and oil firms set up to prevent a repetition of last week's crisis.

When asked if the fuel crisis will ever happen again, Jack Straw, the home secretary, replied: "It is a very rash minister who says something will never happen again but what we are working on is a very significant reduction of the risk of this kind of disruptive action."

Ministers have said they want to extend the powers in the Energy Act 1976 which gives the government the right to order or regulate the supply of crude liquid petroleum, gas and electricity. Under this act ministers can ask the courts to impose unlimited fines on gas and electricity companies that fail to meet requirements to maintain supplies.

Cabinet ministers said the oil companies were being much more constructive than expected, but added a general legal duty would put extra pressure to rearrange the supply chain.

However, some of the oil companies pointed out that if no legal duty is placed on tanker drivers to work, there is no effective leverage on the companies to supply petrol.

A legal duty already exists on oil companies to keep a fixed level of oil reserves in Britain, or abroad under bilateral agreements with foreign governments.

Mr Straw said prior to any legislation, likely to be included in the Queen's speech, the government and oil firms would draw up a non-legal memorandum of understanding setting out each side's duties and responsibilities.

The task force is in the short term to be split into three sub-committees - the first covering the potential legal duties on petrol suppliers, a second covering the degree of coordination between the oil firms, the police and Whitehall, and a third ensuring that Whitehall is able to respond to any emergency better by guaranteeing supply to essential users.

Ministers also want the task force to look at redistributing petrol supplies into local depots, ending the concentration of the entire reserves in a small number of refineries. The companies are also to be asked to look at bringing tanker drivers back into direct employment. At present many are sub-contracted, or self-employed.

Mr Straw said he had received detailed reports from the task force about the level of intimidation received by the truck drivers. "What is incontrovertible is the truck drivers did feel intimidated and that the oil companies themselves logged a series of incidents of intimidation."

Downing Street admitted that it will not seek to impose its new laws before the 60-day deadline imposed by the hauliers for a cut in fuel duty. Ministers have been told the overspill session is already so full it could not contemplate introducing emergency legislation this autumn.

Some of the leading figures in last week's ad hoc protest are expected to meet with the Road Haulage Association on Thursday to discuss tactics.

Roger King, chief executive of the RHA, warned the government was very foolish to signal plans for emergency powers. It was setting a deadline to road hauliers by which they would have to take further action.

The Liberal Democrats' leader Charles Kennedy accused the government of a lack of candour during the crisis which had undermined public confidence and challenged it to create a new fuel policy which is both fair and "upfront" about its environmental goals.

In an emergency statement at the start of the Liberal Democrats' annual conference he urged ministers to freeze fuel taxes in real terms for five years; to use the VAT windfall gained through higher world prices to improve public transport; to ensure that the oil companies "recognise their social responsibilities both in respect of pricing and security of supply" or face punitive tax penalties; and to provide special help for car-dependent rural areas though tax breaks on petrol stations or better community transport.

Mr Kennedy told delegates in Bournemouth that the mutual consent necessary to the workings of a "fundamentally decent country" like Britain's had come close to breaking down last week.

Oil companies said that petrol was being delivered to almost all of their stations but panic buying had forced several to close again.

An estimated 12 Jet stations had been forced to close a spokesman said. "Everyone's running very hard to catch up and queues have certainly calmed down. Buying patterns are now edgy to normal."

BP said it had opened 90% of its 1,500 stations but anticipated that several would be forced to shut again because deliveries were not meeting demand. However, a spokeswoman said that stations are now quieter than at the weekend.It estimated that stations would return to normal within two weeks.

Shell expects to have all its 1,044 stations open today. Stationsreported "extensive queuing" despite 230 more trucks delivering fuel yesterday than is usual for a Monday, a spokesman said.

Two thirds of Esso stations - the company with the most garages - are open. A spokeswoman said petrol was delivered at 140% of the normal rate over the weekend."Some sites are going to be running lower but we are trying to ensure that the spread is even."

About 200 schools in England were closed yesterday as a result of fuel shortages, the Department for Education and Employment said. The department stressed that fewer than 1% of schools were affected.

webTitle: Bin Laden link derided by court

fields.headline: Bin Laden link derided by court
fields.trailText: Six men alleged to have links to the international terrorist Osama bin Laden were sentenced to death in Jordan yesterday for plotting to kill US and Israeli tourists.
fields.body:
Six men alleged to have links to the international terrorist Osama bin Laden were sentenced to death in Jordan yesterday for plotting to kill US and Israeli tourists.

Another sixteen, including a man living in Britain, were given sentences ranging from seven and a half years to life; six others were aquitted. Most are of Palestinian origin. They deny the charges and say their confessions were given under duress,

Jordan's practice is to commute death sentences for political crimes. Even so, defence lawyers were reported to be surprised by the many tough sentences.

The three-man Amman tribunal rejected the prosecution's claim that all 28 defendents - including 12 at large and tried in absentia - were tied to an extremist group called al-Qaeda, allegedly led by Mr Bin Laden. The men "had no organisational affiliations", the court said.

The charges concern a plot to attack tourists during millenium celebrations in December at Mount Nebo, where tradition says Moses saw the promised land, and at a Christian settlement beside the river Jordan.

A Jordanian living in Britain, Omar Abu Omar, also known as Abu Kutaida, was sentenced in absentia to 15 years for financing the plotters.

Mr Bin Laden, a Saudi exiled in Afghanistan, is wanted by the US for the bombing of two African embassies in 1998 in which 224 people died.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Tarsem Singh
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Tarsem Singh
fields.body:
Full Name:
Tarsem Singh Dhandwar

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

I change my name according to which country I'm in. Americans can't pronounce Dhandwar so I dropped my surname for the release.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?
Never.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?
I'm a really boring to guy to go out with, a guy who loves rubbish TV.

What was the last illegal thing you did?
I haven't but my accountant probably has for me.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?
I can't think of anything, so that tells you what sort of person I am.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
Marianne Jean-Baptiste - she's a funny, accommodating person.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?
TP - she was a B.

Has a critic ever made you cry?
No, and never will.

What would you advertise without a fee?
UNICEF, Family Planning... hey, I'm from India.

What would you never advertise?
Religion, patriotism, anti- abortion.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?
I have a clean conscience, nothing to confess.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
Sitting on the toilet.
