fields.headline: Peruvian secret police chief 'arrested'
fields.trailText: Peru's most vilified man and one of its most powerful, the intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos, was detained yesterday by soldiers acting on the orders of the armed forces commander, according to news reports.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos, and agencies in Lima
fields.body:
Peru's most vilified man and one of its most powerful, the intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos, was detained yesterday by soldiers acting on the orders of the armed forces commander, according to news reports.

The development came after opposition leaders met into the pre-dawn hours and called on President Alberto Fujimori to order Mr Montesinos' detention, the independent radio station CPN reported.

On Saturday Mr Fujimori said that a videotape allegedly showing Mr Montesinos bribing an opposition MP to defect to the president's congressional bloc had damaged the stability of his government and the country.

He said he was deactivating the national intelligence service and calling elections at which he would not be a candidate, ending his 10 years in power.

Miguel Gutierrez, an investigative reporter for the opposition paper La Republica, said senior officers had confirmed Mr Montesinos' detention. He said navy commandos loyal to Mr Fujimori entered the Las Palmas air force base, where Mr Montesinos has his headquarters, and detained him.

The mayor of Lima, Alberto Andrade, said earlier that Mr Montesinos was still running the intelligence service and was at his headquarters. Unconfirmed reports said he was destroying documents that would incriminate him.

Government officials did not confirm Mr Montesinos' detention, which the radio station said was ordered by his close associate General Jose Villanueva Ruesta, commander of the armed forces.

It said Mr Montesinos' sister had asked a court to order his release.

webTitle: Flagging Bush sets sights on middle class vote

fields.headline: Flagging Bush sets sights on middle class vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush changed his tack and his tone in the US presidential election campaign yesterday, seeking to revive his flagging fortunes with an issues-based drive for middle-class votes in the battleground states.
fields.body:
George W Bush changed his tack and his tone in the US presidential election campaign yesterday, seeking to revive his flagging fortunes with an issues-based drive for middle-class votes in the battleground states.

The Republican candidate began a 12-city tour with a visit to an Arkansas maternity ward, where he waxed lyrical on the joys of fatherhood at the start of a week in which he aims to highlight his "cradle-to-grave" domestic policy agenda and ditch his reputation for negative campaigning.

It was the start of "an important week in this campaign", he admitted in a speech in Little Rock, "a week that speaks to the aspirations and hopes of middle-class families all across the nation."

The visit to the maternity ward kicked off a determined effort by the Republicans to regain control of the election agenda from Vice-President Al Gore, the Democratic candidate, who continues to extend his recent lead in the opinion polls, not just nationally but in many of the states that will decide the election.

"This is a very focused, more aggressive effort to let voters know where Governor Bush stands on the major issues of the day," his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, told reporters before the start of the latest campaign swing.

Each day of the week would feature "metaphor" visits to enable Mr Bush to set out his stall on issues such as education, welfare, taxes and pensions, Mr Fleischer said.

Mr Bush will end the week with another visit to Florida, where he will talk about his plans for the elderly. The visit to the state where his brother Jeb is governor, and which most strategists originally put in the Republican camp, shows how strongly Mr Gore is doing in the battleground states.

With some polls showing Mr Gore threatening to take a dominant lead, Mr Bush launched a "Blueprint for the Middle Class", a 16-page summary of his policy proposals, and began highlighting his new slogan: "Real Plans for Real People."

"It's a real plan. It isn't one of those things with a lot of fine print in it. It's a real plan to help families help themselves," he said before going on to Missouri and Illinois.

The move is a calculated risk, since the polls that show Mr Gore leading also show him well ahead on most of the issues the Republicans want to highlight. But Mr Bush has come under fierce pressure from within his party to focus on themes that the voters repeatedly say matter most to them.

The most recent polls differ about the extent of Mr Gore's lead, but there is no disagreement about the fact that, after months of seeming to be on course for victory, Mr Bush is struggling to prevent the vice-president succeeding Bill Clinton on November 7.

The latest Newsweek poll shows Mr Gore with a 50% to 38% lead among registered voters, and a 52% to 38% advantage among likely voters - the biggest leads he has had in any national poll since the candidates began their campaigns for the White House more than two years ago.

Other polls show Mr Gore with only a single-figure lead, but all demonstrate that he is widening the gap. A new Harris Interactive survey gives Mr Gore a 46% to 43% lead, while the latest Gallup three-day tracking poll shows him at 49%, against Mr Bush's 41%. The Green candidate, Ralph Nader, is on 3%, and Pat Buchanan of the Reform Party has 1%.

As well as reining back Mr Gore, Mr Bush particularly needs to stop the erosion of his lead among male voters. The latest Gallup figures show that this lead among men has fallen from 20 points two weeks ago to just three points. Mr Gore leads strongly among women voters.

Gore advisers dismissed the Bush relaunch as "pictures and no substance, reflective of a campaign that's all imagery and no ideas". So confident are they, they issued a cheeky rebuttal yesterday of part of Mr Bush's agenda. Under the heading "Bush's child care and pre-school proposals", the press release from the Gore campaign consisted of a blank sheet of paper.

fields.headline: Lib Dems back gay couples
fields.standfirst:
Party conference rules out marriages but votes to give equal legal benefits to homosexual couples

Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Party conference rules out marriages but votes to give equal legal benefits to homosexual couples
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats voted overwhelmingly for a change in the law to recognise gay partnerships yesterday - but sought to quench middle England fears by denying that they were advocating gay marriages.

With a clear eye on wooing disillusioned Tory voters, Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrats' unsuccessful London mayoral candidate, told delegates at the party's conference in Bournemouth: "I do stress this is not a proposal for gay marriage. That is another debate."

What the party was proposing was a "civil partnership" as applicable to heterosexual couples who chose to live together but not marry, as to gay and lesbian couples.

Ms Kramer said the proposal would allow any two unrelated people over 16 in England and Wales the legal benefits afforded to married people in areas such as pensions, inheritance, tax and social security.

She had met with initial opposition, but had cited the example of the gay partner of one of the Soho nailbomber's victims, who received no compensation , unlike the husband of another victim.

People who "call themselves middle England" and who would not normally be advocates of gay rights had told her it was not fair.

Other delegates sought to repair the potential damage to their courtship of the Tory vote - which saw them win the Romsey byelection in May - by headlines on "gay marriages".

Baroness Sarah Ludford, MEP for London and head of the Liberal Democrat group in the European parliament, said it was right the "landmark motion" should not refer to gay marriages since it was important to recognise the "genuine sensitivities" of those who felt marriage was an institution which must have a "reserved status".

Dr Evan Harris, MP for Oxford West and Abingdon, insisted the move was not about forcing, or even asking, Christians to marry somebody of the same sex.

"We are just asking them to allow other people the sort of equality and freedom that they would expect for themselves," he said.

The motion - which was carried almost unanimously - calls for ministers to consult on a scheme for civil partnerships and makes the Liberal Democrats the first mainstream British party to advocate such a policy.

William Hague emphatically rejected the idea of gay marriages last month after the Tory vice-chairman, Steven Norris, backed the deal. Labour has "no firm proposals on this issue", a spokesman said last night.

But, while it may have appeared radical, one delegate, Sue Vincent from Reigate, condemned the motion for not going far enough.

"It entrenches discrimination against gay couples by not offering them the option of civil marriage.

"Heterosexuals have three options: marriage, cohabitation or civil partnership. Lesbian and gay couples will only have two options."

But the vote was welcomed by the gay pressure group Stonewall, which said it hoped other parties would take note.

Spokesman Sebastian Sands said he was "very pleased" the party had shied away from the phrase "gay marriage". "We don't think the word marriage is helpful. It has connotations that are not appropriate.

"It's not the religious aspect that we think is important, it's the practical aspects - inheritance, pensions, succession of tenancy, and the credibility that relationships are given."

webTitle: Comment, Hugo Young: Political substance should replace spin

fields.headline: Message of the polls: the age of froth is over
fields.standfirst: Hugo Young says that direct action is a call for political substance to replace spin
fields.trailText: Hugo Young says that direct action is a call for political substance to replace spin
fields.body:
The emptiest demand this weekend was for the recall of parliament. Parliament would appear to be the problem not the solution. This should not be so, but it is so. Two thousand people decided they had a more potent voice from their strategically positioned lorry-cabs and deck-chairs than a dozen Gladstones, were there any to be heard, could have delivered in the Commons. They were right. Recalling parliament would have been, I regret to say, an exercise in sentiment not pragmatism, the whinnying of asses after the stable had burned down.

Some of the reasons for this may be transient. A government with a huge majority does not need to pay attention. Only small majorities bring big listening. This was as true of Thatcher 1983 as it is of Blair 2000. But other features of parliament's recession are systemic to modern British democratic politics: the intransigent whipping, the scorn for independence, the power of machines, the near-impossible task facing a backbench MP who wants to influence a government decision. Few if any MPs are seen as speaking fearlessly for their people. If collections of them purport to do so, they're cast into the salon of those self-excluded from serious society.

This neutering of the elected politician, which gets more not less severe, has happened in parallel with changes in the electorate. They reinforce the process, deepening alienation from the system in which parliamentary politicians operate. Voters are better educated than they were. They know more, as media outlets proliferate. They're harder to fob off with fancy claims. They're less deferential to leaders of all kinds, less willing to believe in anyone or anything, less chained by prior ideological allegiance. Their impatience grows as their loyalties diminish.

Modern technology, moreover, offers them alternatives to mere cynicism. They don't need parties in order to mobilise. The mobile phone is stronger than a thousand envelopes. Before long, internet polling could be producing a critical mass of uncontrollable energy, putting millions of voters behind causes that conventional politicians prefer to bury. Here we have the makings of an era of direct democracy, last week being the most pointed British shot so far.

It was an ugly beginning. The absence of violence against the person doesn't mean there was no violence against the system. Who the hell are these people to give the government 60 days? Why should a bunch of farmers, already cushioned to the last gallon of diesel against the realities of the market, hold a gun to the country's head? Haulier hubris had a fascist undertone. If direct democracy is the coming thing, let it at least have more representative origins than this.

On the other hand, it should force politicians to come cleaner. The act of violence against the system posed questions more starkly than the blurry mediations of representative democracy. Fleeting though Labour's plummet may prove to be, the popular response confirmed by today's Guardian opinion poll registers how wide the impatience runs. What voters want, as they empower themselves directly, is action more than promises, substance more than tone, alertness to their present mood not just the five-yearly test of it at the ballot box.

I n a recent book, The New Prince, Dick Morris, Clinton's one-time lead consultant, proposes a major lesson to be taken from this shift, which in America is further advanced than here. The day of spin is done, says Morris, who was one of spin's creators. What voters want are issues, on which politicians must take positions. Attack ads, personality stuff, feel-good images: all these, he says, will fail to build durable support among an informed, watchful, demanding electorate which distrusts all intermediaries with a severity unimaginable 20 years ago.

"A political leader should take the temperature and monitor the pulse of the times in which he lives," Morris concedes. He must align his style with the public mood. But the update Morris now gives on 15 years of such manipulation on Clinton's behalf is that the new voters want choices between measures rather than men. They now care more about issues than froth, about policy not morality. "When a candidate takes an issue position in the thick of controversy, voters feel that is the most reliable indicator they have of his true essence." George W Bush is suddenly trying to make the switch, away from the politics of cuteness, to retrieve his lagging campaign. It has relevance to post-blockade Britain. Voters alienated from the charades of parliament are saying by their discontent that they want less spin, less dissembling, more honesty, more principle.

Labour stood up for principle by not caving in to haulier menaces. This clear position may yet reap benefits, as the petrol crisis fades and more people understand what was at stake. But Mr Blair seems determined not to make much of it. Even during the blockade he was anxious to define no one as an enemy. He has discovered how few friends he made by such restraint. We see that the magic of his personality is no longer his matchless political weapon. Though he remains irreplaceable in the leadership, in the country he must now depend on more than shallow charisma.

This is a good not a bad development. Charisma was always the least of it. The shock of last week should take Labour to the honest heart of its political argument. Of the follies committed by ministers, none was more absurd than the pretence that Britain did not have a high tax on petrol. Cut such nonsense, says the voter. Defend your strategy. Come clean about the society you want, high tax and all. Make the case for the fuel tax, and for the public services it pays for. Respect the public's mood, and understand their lives. But doing things by stealth finishes up insulting a well-informed electorate.

If direct action awakens that kind of apprehension, it will have been a therapy. Can it do the same for William Hague? Though the Conservatives have momentarily benefited from the crisis, their predicament is deeper. They've appeared to have no principles as regards democracy. Though Hague called for parliament to come back, he also called the enemies of elected democrats "fine upstanding people". The opportunism of a desperate man has seldom been more obvious.

That's only the beginning. If Labour's taxes are stealthy, the Tories' cuts skulk in clandestine mendacity. Their low-tax society, trumpeted again yesterday, builds on what they see as these new seismic signals. But all they dare talk about is waste, the last refuge of the oppositionist scoundrel. They daren't describe honestly the society they want, falling back instead on the politics of Mr Blair's personality. In the post-parliamentary era, people demand more than that. It's the only good lesson from the barricades.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

 Dick Morris, The New Prince, is published by Renaissance Books, Los Angeles

webTitle: Oftel accused of local loop favouritism

fields.headline: Oftel accused of local loop favouritism
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The telecoms regulator was under fire last night after a potential bidder to connect homes and businesses to the telecoms network pulled out, alleging the process favoured BT.
fields.body:
The telecoms regulator was under fire last night after a potential bidder to connect homes and businesses to the telecoms network pulled out, alleging the process favoured BT.

Nasdaq-listed RSL Communications said "local loop" connections in prime residential and business markets were being reserved for BT's high-speed broadband internet technology while rivals competed over the least populated exchanges.

"Oftel had the chance to create real competition to BT in local exchanges but it has wasted the opportunity," said RSL, which last month announced plans to move its headquarters from New York to London. But its complaints were rejected by the regulator.

An Oftel spokeswoman said the regulator had been responsible only for setting the timetable for unbundling the "local loop", the last mile or so of copper wires connecting homes to the network.

"The process whereby the allocations take place as they do is a process that has been agreed by the telcos themselves. We have been sitting in on the meetings but it is something the telephone companies have agreed on."

Oftel has set a target of July 2001 for rival operators to be able to install digital subscriber line (DSL) technology at local exchanges.

As RSL backed out, data communications group KPNQwest announced it had signed a deal with BT to roll out its high-speed internet services at local level.

BT's share price closed at 795p but had risen by nearly 3% in early trading as the market reacted positively to merger talks with AT&T. The British group said in a weekend statement that it was "exploring ways of broadening and strengthening the scope of the relationship between BT and AT&T in business services".

Further details were not given but analysts believe negotiations centre on combining business services into a standalone unit and then working on a separate merger of their respective wireless operations.

The two companies already have joint ventures in the two areas, trading respectively under the names Concert and Advance.

BT and AT&T would be left to concentrate on their traditional domestic consumer interests in a move designed to salvage both companies' sagging share prices.

webTitle: Hi-tech pioneer accuses British of resisting change

fields.headline: Hi-tech pioneer accuses British of resisting change
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: British business must embrace e-commerce more strongly or run the risk of being left behind other leading industrial nations, according to one of the pioneers of India's computer industry.
fields.body:
British business must embrace e-commerce more strongly or run the risk of being left behind other leading industrial nations, according to one of the pioneers of India's computer industry.

Ashank Desai, chairman of global e-consultancy Mastek, told delegates at the Commonwealth Business Forum: "A certain complacency and resistance to change in IT advancement have been visible in the attitudes of many of the chief executives in the UK."

Mastek advises companies as diverse as Lex Vehicle leasing and bookstore Barnes & Noble.

Mr Desai claimed that the corporate culture in Britain was not conducive to IT. Technological advancement, he said, is restricted partly because IT managers do not sit on the board of directors of British companies.

That often meant firms failed to spot the potential of "e-opportunities".

Mr Desai, who founded the e-business consultancy in 1982 with two friends in a bedroom in Mumbai, also claimed that there was an "alarming dearth of skills in Britain".

"If organisations are not responding properly they will have problems," he told the Guardian. "Whole industries such as financial services and the travel industry are going to change completely the way they do business."

The warning came as western governments vie to recruit computer programmers from around the globe and especially the Indian subcontinent. Earlier in the year German chancellor Gerhard Schröder said he would relax immigration laws to let in highly trained IT staff.

Britain is set to follow. Last week Home Office minister Barbara Roche called for a "debate" on immigration to plug the skills gap.

Mastek, which is now worth almost $500m, has a division in Britain which is run by a "local chief executive" but is staffed by Indian programmers. "We bring people from India for the software development," Mr Desai said.

A spokesman for Mastek UK said that often the mathematical ability of Indian graduates was far higher than comparable British workers.

However, there is hope. Mr Desai said: "The knowledge and expertise are both available in Britain, but little is being done to use it to its full potential."

SSI announced yesterday the largest cross-border takeover by an Indian technology firm, through its plan to buy US-based AlbionOrion for $63.65m in a cash-and-stock deal.

Software company SSI said it would pay $20m in cash and issue 6.5m global depositary shares as a consideration for the remaining $43.65m.

webTitle: Business: Dimension debut is a flop

fields.headline: Dimension debut is a flop
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: One broker's view of the performance of Dimension Data on its first day as a FTSE 100 stock was: "Trades of this nature make a mockery of the system. Surely there must be a stewards' inquiry."
fields.body:
One broker's view of the performance of Dimension Data on its first day as a FTSE 100 stock was: "Trades of this nature make a mockery of the system. Surely there must be a stewards' inquiry."

Shares in the South African-based IT group plunged 312p, or 31.20%, to 688p yesterday in heavy volume as Friday's incredible closing price was unravelled.

Once again the finger of blame was being pointed at the closing auction process, which the London Stock Exchange uses to match as many "buy" and "sell" orders as possible at the close of trading each day.

In Friday's closing auction, Dimension shares shot through £10 as a single tracker fund, determined to increase its weighting in the stock ahead of its promotion to the FTSE 100, placed an "at best" order for a massive 24.3m shares into the system. To put things in perspective, the shares had been trading at 672p before the closing auction and the previous closing high for the stock was 689p.

Because the order had no limit, the auction process, which uses a complex set of algorithms, automatically set about trying to execute as many trades as it possibly could. The outcome was that the index fund picked up the required shares at £10 each. Almost inevitably the stock opened sharply lower this morning as dealers realised what had happened.

Friday's incident is the latest problem with the auction process, which was introduced to bring London in line with European markets.

Back in August Mid-cap health group Smith & Nephew, down 3.5p to 279.5p, appeared to have lost more than a third of its market value after its closing price had been inflated in the previous day's auction period.

But dealers are also questioning the behaviour of the tracker funds. "How badly are these tracker funds managed and administered?" asked broker Cantor Fitzgerald in a note to clients today.

Dealers pointed out that FTSE International, the body that compiles the FTSE indices, flagged up Dimension's promotion to the FTSE 100 weeks ago and asked why tracker funds had to leave their reweighting to the last possible minute.

But Dimension was not the only stock to experience volatile trading yesterday. Both Halifax, up 36p to 519, and BAE Systems, 22.75p better at 349p, ended sharply higher after closing at artificially low levels on Friday as a number of program trades hit the market during the auction period.

Leading shares meanwhile, slipped to their lowest close in five weeks after a choppy trading session that saw the FTSE 100 trade as low as 6,371.4 and as high as 6,464.3.

But with Nasdaq unable to hold opening gains and the oil price causing inflationary jitters, the blue chip index slipped away towards the end of the session and closed down 7.1 points at 6,410.2.

The heavyweight telecoms sector did most of the damage. Vodafone fell 5.5p to 264.5p, while Cable & Wireless plunged 90p to £10.10 as one American investor set about lightening its holding.

Elsewhere HSBC, down 25p to 973p, was sent into a tailspin by events in the currency market. Investors are starting to get twitchy about the earnings of companies that are adversely affected by the strong dollar. HSBC reports it figures in dollars.

Lower down the market the picture was not much better. The FTSE 250 closed off 53.4 points at 6,901.8, with engineering and aerospace outfit Smiths Industries among the worst performers.

It shares fell 100p to 735p after it unveiled a shock merger with TI Group, unchanged at 374.75p that appeared to please no one. For TI shareholders the takeover offered little premium and for Smiths shareholders analysts said the deal destroyed its niche appeal.

On AIM, Tertiary Minerals, up 6p to 23.5p, benefited from a tip on Channel 4 investment programme Show Me The Money.

webTitle: Makeover artists aim to set tills ringing

fields.headline: Makeover artists aim to set tills ringing
fields.trailText: Young mother Caroline Andrews, is just the kind of shopper Marks & Spencer wants to get back through its doors. Aged 29 and with two young sons, the attitude of customers like this former accountant, now stay-at-home mum, will prove crucial in the retailer's battle to restore its status.
fields.body:
Young mother Caroline Andrews, is just the kind of shopper Marks & Spencer wants to get back through its doors. Aged 29 and with two young sons, the attitude of customers like this former accountant, now stay-at-home mum, will prove crucial in the retailer's battle to restore its status.

An occasional visitor to M&S, she is one of the first to receive the "personal shopping" treatment. An M&S assistant devotes two hours to finding just the items of clothing Ms Andrews wants to complete her makeover from suit-wearing accountant to fashionable mother-of-two.

The assistant, Sam Toma, is freed from the constraints of her staid navy uniform and sports a green tailored zipped top and knee-length A-line skirt, which has become a big seller in the High Street Kensington store.

This personal shopping experience is one of the gimmicks M&S is trying out at its new store in one of London's premier shopping streets with a more affluent customer base, largely female, than most.

Along with Fosse Park in Leicester and Sutton in Surrey, the "concept" store in Kensington has registered a 16% improvement in sales. In these crucial stores, the lights are brighter, the rack upon rack of clothes replaced by trendy arrangements.

For no extra cost, no hard sell and no compulsory purchase, Ms Toma spends two hours with Ms Andrews, trying to gauge what she wants from her wardrobe and when she needs to be able to wear it.

Ms Soma, a shop assistant at M&S for six years, is one of a handful of personal shoppers employed by M&S. The service, more usually associated with high-class stores such as Harvey Nichols, is, M&S insists, a chance to be guided around the store by a trained assistant who knows all the ranges, all the styles and all the colours.

For Ms Andrews it has two advantages. She has left her children at home and is able to avoid lengthy queues in changing rooms. Being with her personal shopper means she has her own changing room and can take in as many items as she wants. Ms Toma races back and forth to the sales floor for different sizes, colours and designs for Ms Andrews, who spends two hours searching for casual outfits as well as some smarter items which could be worn for evenings out and the odd Sunday lunch. This involves more than 30 items being tried on, cast aside, and tried again.

By the end Ms Andrews walks away with an armful of new clothes, including a sleek black dress, smart for evenings out but useful for daywear too, and a casual skirt. Later on she returns to splash out £199 on one of the new M&S leather coats.

This is just the kind of till ringing M&S needs to inspire in all its 297 stores.

fields.headline: At this price?  Novara
fields.trailText: Novara, which supplies educational equipment to schools, has been getting poor marks from the City for some time.
fields.body:
Novara, which supplies educational equipment to schools, has been getting poor marks from the City for some time.

In May the company issued a profit warning and the chief executive, David Newcombe, stepped down. Two months later it had sold its stake in education website DialNET, once hailed as the jewel in the company's crown, at a loss of £2.5m.

Last week's half-year results were dismal. Almost three years after Novara was created through the merger of Nottingham group and Philip Harris, the strains of the link-up are still showing.

It has centralised operations in Ashby de la Zouch, leading to the loss of a whole generation of experienced sales staff. Introduction of a new computer system led to lost orders and late production of the all-important sales catalogues.

Changes are being made by Rod Stoyel, the company doctor turned chief executive, who joined after a career in logistics. Those executives responsible for the mess have left and Stoyel has set about making the computer system work and restructuring the group along brand lines.

For all its woes, Novara's NES Arnold and Philip Harris brands are leaders in their respective segments of the educational supply market, and a sales recovery since the half-year end demonstrates that Novara is starting to benefit from increased government spending on education.

It is also targeting PFI projects and has completed fitting out Parrs Wood, a new school in Manchester. It is contacting holiday companies about supplying its pre-school products for creches.

But even a strong second-half will not make much of a dent in the £5.9m pre-tax loss, after exceptional costs, which the group clocked up in the first half. House broker HSBC is looking for a smart recovery to profits of £4.8m pre-tax and further growth the following year.

At a lowly 27.5p, Novara shares remain a bet on Stoyel's ability to deliver profits as successfully as he used to deliver parcels.

fields.headline: Lottery licence decision 'bizarre'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Camelot, operator of the national lottery, yesterday described the decision to exclude it from making a final bid to run the game for the next seven years as bizarre and grossly unfair.
fields.body:
Camelot, operator of the national lottery, yesterday described the decision to exclude it from making a final bid to run the game for the next seven years as bizarre and grossly unfair.

The company was seeking a high court injunction to prevent the national lottery commission from awarding the next licence without giving it a last chance to amend its bid.

After months of deliberation, the commission said at the end of August that neither Camelot nor Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery were fit to win the licence as their bids stood. The People's Lottery was given an extra month to allay outstanding misgivings.

David Pannick QC, acting for Camelot in the judicial review, yesterday asked for the commission's decision to be declared unlawful.

Camelot also alleged that the commission had been giving the People's Lottery coaching on what it would need to do to win the competition.

Mr Pannick told Mr Justice Richards: "It will not help the legal process to describe the decision as grossly or manifestly unfair - but that is what it is. We can find no precedent for such behaviour." He argued that Camelot should also be given an extra month to answer the commission's concerns.

"This is as if at the end of the football World Cup final the score is 0-0 and the match has to be decided by a penalty shoot-out," he said. "But the ref decides only one team should be able to take the penalties."

Camelot contends the commission "very badly misled" it on the extent of its concerns over US technology firm GTech, its chief software supplier.

Jonathan Crow, representing the commission had a metaphor of his own to defend the decision taken. "This was an evaluation process more like an architectural competition for a new building. One was very nearly there, the other wasn't. We are not saying to the also-ran you should go back and design us a new building."

He contended the People's Lottery would have won even if Camelot had answered the issues of GTech's propriety.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Four injured in loyalist bomb attack

fields.headline: Four injured in loyalist bomb attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Loyalist terrorists linked to Northern Ireland's burgeoning drugs trade were last night suspected of a mid-morning van bomb attack in the resort of Bangor, Co Down, which left a workman fighting for his life. The attack further fuelled tensions between rival groups of paramilitaries.
fields.body:
Loyalist terrorists linked to Northern Ireland's burgeoning drugs trade were last night suspected of a mid-morning van bomb attack in the resort of Bangor, Co Down, which left a workman fighting for his life. The attack further fuelled tensions between rival groups of paramilitaries.

The victim, named locally as Sandy Rice, a father of three, collapsed from his Ford Transit van after the device, attached to the underside of the van, partially exploded as he drove along the seaside town's high street. Three other men were hurt, none of them seriously.

Although the incident in Bangor came less than nine hours after an explosion rocked a loyalist prisoners' centre on the Shankill Road in west Belfast, an explicit link to the ongoing loyalist feud there was being played down. Police said it was too early to speculate.

Mr Rice, head of security at a local nightclub and in his mid-forties, was said recently to have evicted from the premises he works at several drug dealers, believed to be linked to the Loyalist Volunteer Force. Detectives suspect the van bombing was a revenge attack.

Mr Rice is a former internee with links to the Ulster Volunteer Force, engaged in a feud with the UDA and the Ulster Freedom Fighters. They have close links in many areas to the renegade LVF.

Mr Rice, who lived for 20 years in London, is a friend of David Ervine, one of the Progressive Unionist Party's two assembly members. The PUP is the political voice of the UVF.

Mr Ervine said: "This man was under serious threat of losing his life because of his stand against the drugs dealers. He has evicted these people and this is the price paid. It had nothing to do with the Shankill."

The van bombing came less than nine hours after a bomb attack on a UDA prisoners' centre on the Shankill Road in west Belfast, where the feud began last month. The UVF was being blamed for that operation, as tensions continued to rise.

The prisoners' centre was badly damaged. Police last night put on display material they subsequently recovered from the premises, including component parts for pipe bombs, the tail fin of a mortar bomb, balaclavas and combat clothing.

Billy Hutchinson, assembly member for the PUP, close to the UVF, blamed the UDA for resorting first to explosives. It left a pipe bomb at his home on the Shankill Road last week in one of several attacks.

A further 11 families from the Shankill Road, long seen as the bastion of loyalism, applied for re-housing over the weekend. That brings to 187 the number of families forced from their homes in the past month. That represents about 500 people, and is the biggest mass movement of families since the early days of The Troubles.

This time, though, Protestants are fighting with Protestants, with loyalism in disarray. The loyalist feud has claimed the lives of three men and left scores injured.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's move last month to return UFF commander Johnny Adair to jail appeared to have curbed the violence, but it flared again last week.

Black taxis, operated by the UVF, took the surprising step of completing journeys via the republican Falls Road rather than risk driving through the Lower Shankill, stronghold of Mr Adair's C company. Several were wrecked last week in concerted attacks.

Some politicians have even suggested peace lines might be erected. They would be the first to separate Protestants from each other.

webTitle: £700m of new trains wait in safety sidings

fields.headline: £700m of new trains wait in safety sidings
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: More than £700m of new rail rolling stock is lying around unused waiting for safety approval while Britain's railways are overcrowded and dirty.
fields.body:
More than £700m of new rail rolling stock is lying around unused waiting for safety approval while Britain's railways are overcrowded and dirty.

That position was highlighted by Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, yesterday when he told train suppliers: "Your trains do not work straight off the assembly line."

In a keynote speech to the industry in London, he blamed it for letting down passengers and for not having the right strategy. He lamented the lack of any partnership.

Sir Alastair also criticised Railtrack for passing the buck. It had to live up to its public service obligation by bringing down the safety risks of new rolling stock to a reasonable level. "Britain's privatised railway is seen as the greatest market opportunity for new train sales in Europe, and perhaps the world, but this glass is half-empty," he said.

The SSRA confirmed later that since privatisation more than 2,250 train units had been ordered but only 293 were in use. A further 600 should have been delivered and half of these should be in operation by the end of the year.

It said the main reasons for the backlog were Railtrack's delays in approvals, defective or unreliable units supplied by manufacturers - which has incurred the wrath of transport secretary John Prescott - and poor project management.

Railtrack said: "We accept that the process is detailed and that many strict rules have to be followed. But the processes have to be strict to maintain safety on the railway, and we have set up weekly meetings with the rail companies to identify solutions to problems."

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday called on the train and bus operator National Express to remedy competition concerns following its acquisition of Prism Rail.

He said the proposed purchase raised concerns about rail and coach services between London and Stansted airport. If the purchase goes ahead, the company would have a monopoly "which may allow it to raise prices and reduce the quality of coach services on the route", My Byers said.

He stressed that he had asked the director general of fair trading to obtain undertakings from the company by October. National Express is planning to add Stansted to its Gatwick rail services in a partnership with the BAA, Britain's airports operator.

fields.headline: EMI gives ground
fields.trailText: EMI and Warner Music yesterday made a last ditch attempt to save their £14bn merger from the regulatory scrap heap by making further concessions to the European commission.
fields.body:
EMI and Warner Music yesterday made a last ditch attempt to save their £14bn merger from the regulatory scrap heap by making further concessions to the European commission.

The potential breakthrough came at a meeting in Brussels between Mario Monti and senior executives from the two companies. The EU competition commissioner has already made clear that the deal is unlikely to succeed unless modified.

The commission will put the concessions to the companies' rivals to see whether they go far enough to permit the deal.

EU officials said yesterday that they expected EMI and Time Warner to make the concessions binding. The companies could, in exceptional circumstances, still offer concessions after today's deadline.

"We need to examine these proposals and they need to be formalised by the parties," said Mr Monti's spokeswoman, Amelia Torres.

EMI said as recently as Friday that it remained confident that regulators would approve the deal, and its most senior executives have been working flat out for months to make it a success.

Yesterday's meeting was attended by EMI chairman Eric Nicoli, Warner Music chairman Roger Ames and Time Warner chairman Richard Parsons.

It emerged last week that the commission had already drafted a decision to block the deal because it feared that the merged company would monopolise the market for downloading music from the internet.

fields.headline: Call centre boost for Dundee
fields.trailText: One2One, the Mobile phone company, yesterday brought some sunshine to the Scottish unemployment blackspot of Dundee with the creation of 1,000 new call centre jobs.
fields.body:
One2One, the Mobile phone company, yesterday brought some sunshine to the Scottish unemployment blackspot of Dundee with the creation of 1,000 new call centre jobs.

The telecoms group is building a new customer contact centre in Dundee, once renowned for "jute, jam and journalism", but now suffering from high unemployment as well as a shrinking population.

The new state-of-the-art call centre, which will include an employee training campus, will be sited at the Dundee Technology Park and is due to open next summer.

One2One already has a strong presence in Scotland, with more than 1,000 employees in its call centre in Greenock on the west coast of the country.

Henry McLeish, the Scottish enterprise minister, said: "Today's announcement is excellent news for Dundee and for Scotland. The creation of 1,000 jobs further enhances Scotland's reputation as one of Europe's foremost call centre locations."

Harris Jones, managing director at One2One, said: "With a customer base now approaching seven million, and as we move rapidly forward towards the sophistication of third generation mobile communications, it is essential that customer care remains a vital business imperative for our company.

"Our announcement is a clear demonstration of this commitment."

webTitle: Ford shop stewards raise Dagenham stakes

fields.headline: Ford shop stewards raise Dagenham stakes
fields.trailText: Shop stewards at Ford's Dagenham car plant yesterday raised the stakes in their battle to keep the threatened assembly line open by unanimously calling for a ballot on strike action among the factory's entire workforce.
fields.body:
Shop stewards at Ford's Dagenham car plant yesterday raised the stakes in their battle to keep the threatened assembly line open by unanimously calling for a ballot on strike action among the factory's entire workforce.

Reporting a mood of "determined resistance" among the plant's 6,000 employees, Duncan Simpson, a senior AEEU engineering union official, warned that action could spread to Ford's other British plants.

The Dagenham stewards went beyond their original plans of balloting 4,500 workers in the body and paint shops and on the assembly-line by spreading the proposed action to union members in other parts of the plant. This followed an unofficial walk-out on Sunday night and yesterday morning by workers in the trim shop and on the assembly line.

Formally, the stewards' demand for a ballot has to be approved by the unions' leadership but Mr Simpson said a ballot was inevitable "unless the company changes its position, and there's no indication that they will".

He added: "If the stewards' unanimous recommendation is a reflection of the mood at the plant I'm sure we'll get a positive response."

The world's second largest car maker wants to end production of the Fiesta at Dagenham in early 2002 and build a new Fiesta in Cologne, Germany. The unofficial walk-outs came amid suspicions that Ford wants to close the line sooner and had begun trying to shift staff to the engine plant. Ford said it had no plans to change the timetable.

The group has tried to sugar the pill of closing the assembly line at its biggest British plant after 80 years by investing $600m in its engine plant and creating 500 jobs. Ford UK lost £119m before tax last year and its Dagenham plans are seen as a test of its determination to tackle chronic over-capacity in the European car industry.

Sir Ken Jackson, AEEU leader and protagonist of no-strike agreements, has failed to persuade Ford executives to rescind their plans by switching production of Volvos from Belgium to Dagenham and Mr Simpson said the company's decision was "unnecessary, unjustified and totally outside our written agreements [of 1997] with Ford to build a new Fiesta at Dagenham."

fields.headline: Notebook
fields.trailText:
Vacuum at unloved retailer

What a twist the knicker-seller to the nation has once again found itself in. Another round of chaotic managerial change at Marks & Spencer might have sparked another round of takeovers but for the fact that no one can find a suitable predator.
fields.body:
Vacuum at unloved retailer

What a twist the knicker-seller to the nation has once again found itself in. Another round of chaotic managerial change at Marks & Spencer might have sparked another round of takeovers but for the fact that no one can find a suitable predator.

While Philip Green, the Monaco-based tough nut, was sorely tempted nine months ago, even if his ability to finance the transaction always looked a bit fantastical, now it looks as though he has his hands full with Bhs.

Few domestic rivals are likely to have the appetite - or the money, which might stretch to £10bn. They have enough problems of their own. And men like Terry Leahy at Tesco are just not reckless enough to have a go. Across the Atlantic, hot money favourites such as Gap have gone cold. They are facing their own competitive pressures.

So, where does this leave M&S? Rather than a bid, the main problem facing the newly empowered chairman and chief executive, Luc Vandevelde, is moving quickly enough to pre-empt the City comparing him with Sir Richard Greenbury, the last M&S executive to hold both top management roles.

A fresher look and a new image is a start, but Mr Vandevelde knows only too well that shoppers will only start streaming through his doors if the products are worth buying.

As he said himself, "the clock is ticking".

Plastic explosive

Figures out this week showing the dramatic rise in plastic card fraud will no doubt trigger fresh technophobic fears about buying goods and services over the internet. Card fraud losses rose by a whopping 53% in the year to May 2000 to reach a total of £226m, according to Card Watch, the banks' fraud prevention programme.

The two growth areas are in counterfeit fraud, where card details are "skimmed" by unscrupulous staff at the point of sale and used to produce forgeries, and in fraud on mail order, phone or internet transactions where the card is not physically presented.

"Card-not-present" fraud has surged 146% over the past year, prompting the immediate assumption that a growth in internet transactions must be to blame. In fact, the bulk of the £40m card-not- present fraud losses is down to mail order and phone transactions, with internet usage accounting for a tiny percentage.

Where online card fraud does take place, it is likely to be perpetrated by the same petty criminals simply applying the same old techniques to the internet - namely, employing devious means to acquire card details which they use to pay for goods and services .

Until the banks bring in measures to prevent card-not-present fraud, it is down to card holders themselves to guard their plastic from prying eyes. If anything, technology simply makes it easier to catch the fraudsters.

Tower v column

We can assume a state close to clinical depression descended on Stock Exchange Tower yesterday morning. The iX presentation packs have gone in the recycling bin, but for what purpose no one knows. Staff morale has been blown to bits, yet they still have Europe's largest equity market to run - and the systems are creaking.

Friday night saw shares in a new entrant to the mighty FTSE 100 index, computing group Dimension Data, jump by a third - a move provoked by the liquidity problems associated with the Sets order-driven trading system.

Yesterday, the shares fell by a third as the technicality was corrected. But when the price of an £7bn entity goes up and down by a third in the space of 24 trading hours without any real "news," it suggests there is something badly wrong somewhere.

So who is going to fix things? Who has the experience and the energy to cut through the vested interests and find some sort of coherent future for this organisation - a job which the previous chief executive, Gavin Casey, barely started?

Hats so far in the ring include Phillip Thorpe, of the financial services authority, who is seen as a tough, modern regulator, and Hugh Freedberg, chief executive at the Liffe futures market.

Meanwhile, Brian Winterflood, boss of market makers Winterflood Securities, has come up with his own candidate: Edmond Warner, chief executive of Old Mutual Securities. His candidature is said to be strengthened by a knowledge of "bulge bracket" banking (through the likes of Bankers Trust), while also knowing the mood among smaller and regional stockbrokers through Old Mutual. What is more, the man is a good bit under 40.

But Mr Winterflood should know his idea is a non-starter. Warner has just resumed his weekly column in the Guardian (appearing each Saturday). And we will keep him to his contract.

fields.headline:
£28m for Byers constituency
Tyneside plant
fields.standfirst: Minister denies being compromised as US company gets grant to open mothballed Siemens factory
fields.trailText: The Department of Trade and Industry yesterday awarded £28m of public money to a semi-conductor plant in the constituency of embattled industry secretary Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry yesterday awarded £28m of public money to a semi-conductor plant in the constituency of embattled industry secretary Stephen Byers.

The money was crucial to clinch a deal under which a US chip manufacturer has agreed to take over a north Tyneside plant closed by Siemens of Germany and create up to 1,500 jobs. The industry secretary said high quality employment would be created with additional spin-off benefits, adding: "I am confident that Atmel's arrival will give fresh impetus to the north-east."

Mr Byers denied that he was compromised saying he was aware of the sensitivity of the issue and had handed over responsibility for the decision to the minister for trade and the regions, Richard Caborn. The Department of Trade said the government agreed the aid package only after advice from an independent panel of experts.

Siemens mothballed the £1bn facility in September 1998 and made 1,100 workers redundant just 15 months after it was opened by the Queen. The closure was a personal blow to Tony Blair as the prime minister's constituency is less than 40 miles away.

Atmel Corporation of San José in California said it would start operations on site from April 2001.

George Perlegos, chief executive of Nasdaq-listed Atmel, explained it would help create a springboard for Europe and complement the work of another plant it had opened in the south of France.

Some of the chips produced on Tyneside will be sold on to Siemens under a £1bn deal signed by the two companies to run over four years. The rest of the micro controllers and other chips for mobile phones and other hi-tech equipment would be sold in Britain and worldwide.

Controversially Atmel has not actually obtained ownership of the north east plant but has taken it under a sale and lease-back arrangement.

An Atmel spokesman insisted this did not show any lack of commitment to Britain, but reflected the country's unfriendly tax structure.

He insisted there was three years of growth ahead for the market and said the deal with Siemens for forward orders showed that engineering companies were concerned about future supply shortages. Atmel added that it was not discouraged by the value of the pound or shaken by last week's fuel crisis.

fields.headline: Mild mannered Monti seeks superpowers
fields.standfirst: Competition chief flexes muscles to take on the mega-corporations
fields.trailText: "The most powerful man in Europe" is how Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner, describes his sparky predecessor, Karel van Miert. And the mild-mannered Italian academic believes this is not time to shrink from the mantle he inherited.
fields.body:
"The most powerful man in Europe" is how Mario Monti, the European competition commissioner, describes his sparky predecessor, Karel van Miert. And the mild-mannered Italian academic believes this is not time to shrink from the mantle he inherited.

Mr Monti is poised to launch a series of sweeping reforms to strengthen the commission's anti-cartel powers, a move that will see him acquire unprecedented authority to conduct investigations.

The one-time professor of monetary theory at Bocconi university is also turning his attention to the internet and yesterday served notice that, as one of the world's most powerful regulators, he would be more and more involved in ensuring the sector does not become the preserve of a few mega-corporations such as Microsoft. A "wait and see approach" cuts no ice with him and he intends to regulate the sector "on the basis of what we know now".

Ensuring that no one company controls the internet's infrastructure, be it global backbone networks or more modest local networks, is to be one of his top priorities. The danger, he believes, is that such control can be used to gain an unfair advantage in related markets.

Telecoms groups MCI/Worldcom and Sprint, which this year planned the mother of all tie-ups, discovered Mr Monti's views on the subject the hard way. The multi-billion dollar deal spectacularly collapsed after he gave it the thumbs down and yesterday he spelled out why: "It is a truism to say that the more users there are connected to telecoms networks, the more valuable that network becomes. The corollary of this, however, is that the more important the network becomes, the greater the risk that competition problems will emerge."

The restricted nature of set-top TV boxes, Microsoft's alleged refusal to dis close vital information about its PC operating systems and online business exchanges are other issues Mr Monti is carefully tracking.

In all three cases, he said yesterday, there is a risk that a handful of companies will gain too dominant a position.

The quiet Italian has shown he is ready to get tough with the world's mega-corporations. He said no last year to a merger between Airtours and First Choice Holidays and he has blocked a merger between truck makers Volvo and Scania. He is good at getting his own way as Fifa and Uefa have discovered to their cost regarding football transfer rules.

Despite his sober demeanour, Mr Monti has a taste for a catchy phrase as befits a former columnist for Corriere della Sera. So he peppers his speeches with talk of "hardcore cartels" and "cancers on the open market economy" to justify his view that his powers are inadequate.

In future, and provided Mr Monti's reforms are approved by EU governments, the EC will work far more closely with national competition authorities and create a powerful network that will allow evidence of cartels to be freely exchanged across borders. Brussels will concentrate on sniffing out the really serious cartels and spend less time looking into small-scale anti-competitive behaviour.

Its powers of investigation will also be strengthened. At the moment Mr Monti's investigators only have the power to search companies' premises but in future they will, for the first time, be authorised to search private homes.

"Cartels are cancers on the open market economy, which forms the very basis of our community," he said recently. "Moreover, since by nature cartels are secret and therefore difficult to uncover, it is likely that what we are seeing is only the tip of the iceberg. In the words of Adam Smith there is a tendency for competitors to conspire. I am determined to strengthen our fight against cartels."

Brussels's powers to levy fines against companies that drag their feet are also set to increase dramatically and Mr Monti is pushing for "substantial" fines based on a percentage of annual turnover rather than the current system of relatively small fixed amounts. In short, Mr Monti, who has acquired a reputation for being a tough operator, is just about to get even tougher.

He has also announced that he intends to step up cooperation with anti-trust bodies across the world and make "second generation" agreements with the United States and others. His team of competition experts in Brussels, which numbers about 80 people and is widely regarded as understaffed, will also be increased.

Unsurprisingly, Mr Monti, who is still remembered for killing off duty-free shopping in his last job in charge of the EU's single market, is making few friends among those who fear a more powerful regulator with almost limitless powers.

webTitle: RSC casts black actor as English king for first time

fields.headline: RSC casts black actor as English king for first time
fields.trailText: The Royal Shakespeare Company last night claimed to have broken the mould by casting a black actor in the role of an English monarch for the first time in its history.
fields.body:
The Royal Shakespeare Company last night claimed to have broken the mould by casting a black actor in the role of an English monarch for the first time in its history.

David Oyelowo, whose family came originally from Nigeria, will play the title role in Henry VI Parts I, II and III, when the company continues its monumental two-year run through Shakespeare's Histories - entitled This England - during the autumn.

His casting comes as the black British actor Adrian Lester prepares to play Hamlet, the most coveted classical role of all, for the director Peter Brook in Paris. Lester famously moved to America because of the dearth of roles for black actors in Britain.

Michael Boyd, who will direct Henry VI for the RSC, insisted he had not set out to make theatre history. "David really is a bit of a genius. It is colour-blind casting, his son will be white and there is no hint of illegitimacy."

But Hugh Quarshie, who became the first black Hotspur on a British stage when he took over from Timothy Dalton in Henry IV nearly 20 years ago for the RSC, said al though he was thrilled for Oyelowo, it was hardly revolutionary.

"This is not a defining moment for black actors," he said. "It is a lot easier to have non-traditional casting with Shakespeare. In fact, this seems only possible in the classics at all these days. The real problems for black actors come with modern plays and the cinema."

Quarshie, who starred in the recent Star Wars prequel, said that only when black actors routinely play Hamlet and Henry V will casting have become truly colour blind.

Oyelowo, 24, who joined the RSC last year, and is about to begin eight weeks of rehearsal, said he was delighted to land the role.

"Hopefully, it will pave the way for other actors. The more barriers come down, the better," he said.

The production will open at the Swan Theatre in Stratford in November and will move to the Young Vic in London next April.

webTitle: Geldof to care for Tiger Lily

fields.headline: Geldof to care for Tiger Lily
fields.standfirst: Geldof given temporary care of orphan Tiger Lily
fields.trailText: Bob Geldof was yesterday awarded temporary care of the orphaned daughter of his former wife, Paula Yates, as the investigation into the television presenter's death continued.
fields.body:
Bob Geldof was yesterday awarded temporary care of the orphaned daughter of his former wife, Paula Yates, as the investigation into the television presenter's death continued.

Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily Hutchence, four, was made a ward of court at a high court hearing following an application by Geldof, and was last night staying with her three half-sisters.

Yates, 40, was found dead in bed at her London home on Sunday morning. Yesterday a postmortem was unable to determine how she died, though friends dismiss suicide, believing she may have overdosed.

Further toxicology and blood tests will be carried out to pinpoint what role, if any, drugs or alcohol played in her death.

At the high court hearing Mrs Justice Hogg appointed the official solicitor to represent the interests of Tiger Lily, whose father, the Australian rock star Michael Hutchence, committed suicide in November 1997.

Geldof and Yates had three daughters from their marriage, which ended in divorce after she left the former Boomtown Rats' frontman for Hutchence.

A spokesman for the official solicitor said: "Sir Bob Geldof has been awarded interim care of the child [Tiger Lily], until such time as further proceedings direct otherwise."

If Geldof or anyone else applied for the right to bring her up, the official solicitor would investigate who would be best suited to care for her.

The fact that courts are reluctant to move young children from their current carers and to split siblings will strengthen Geldof's hand if he applies to look after Tiger Lily permanently.

Police confirmed that scientists were examining substances taken from the mews home in west London where Yates and Tiger Lily had lived for the past year.

Scotland Yard refused to comment on reports that pills, vodka bottles and heroin were found in the house.

The alarm was raised after a friend, Josephine Fairley, rang Yates on Sunday morning. It is believed Tiger Lily picked up the phone, prompt ing Ms Fairley to go round to the house. When she arrived, she found the front door had been opened, it is believed by the child.

Police said Tiger Lily had been in the house on Saturday evening, but refused to say whether they would talk to her to see if she could shed any light on her mother's last hours.

Hutchence's father, Kell, said he believed Tiger Lily was in "good hands" with Geldof.

Speaking from his home in Australia, Mr Hutchence, 67, said: "My heart goes out to Bob Geldof and to my little granddaughter, Tiger Lily, who I feel for so much at this tragic hour, but certainly we will see how things proceed and I will be guided by many factors in this matter."

Mr Hutchence had tried to gain custody of Tiger Lily after newspaper reports that Yates was dating a one-time heroin addict, but yesterday he said: "I only ever tried to get a temporary custody, if you can call it custody, which would just have been looking after Tiger when her mother was not well.

"I know that Paula had her ways and often we didn't agree, but God bless her, I never really thought it would come to this. She was a good mother, she loved her kids."

Mr Hutchence said he would like to come to the UK, but had recently been in hospital. "The doctors don't want me to fly yet, but I'm hoping to get a clearance from them tomorrow and I think there's every likelihood of coming over and spending some time with Tiger.

"I would like to do that so much. She's just so close to my heart, and I feel so terribly sorry for this little girl."

Yates first became famous as the co-presenter of Channel 4 music show The Tube, and had four children - Fifi Trixibelle, 17, Peaches, 11, and Pixie, 10, with Geldof, and Tiger Lily with Hutchence.

She had been suffering from bouts of depression since the INXS frontman was found dead, hanging in a Sydney hotel room after consuming a cocktail of drugs and alcohol.

fields.headline: Lord Erroll
fields.standfirst: Popular Tory exercising varied talents in Whitehall and industry
fields.trailText: Very tall and burly, Baron Erroll of Hale, who has died aged 86, was among the most successful and popular engineer-politician-industrialists of his generation.
fields.body:
Very tall and burly, Baron Erroll of Hale, who has died aged 86, was among the most successful and popular engineer-politician-industrialists of his generation. Although he reached his political peak under Harold Macmillan, as president of the Board of Trade (1961-63), he thought he did better as minister for power (1963-64), to which post Sir Alec Douglas-Home demoted him. There, he rushed through the Continental Shelf Bill to allow the oil companies speedily to explore the North Sea and thus "dish Labour".

When the Tories were defeated in 1964, he was rewarded with a hereditary barony. After that, he led the Tories in little-reported Lords economic, industrial and foreign trade debates. Last year he was one of the 92 elected by fellow hereditaries to survive as life peers in the transitional House of Lords.

Outside politics, Erroll was an even greater success as an industrialist. He was chairman of Bowater, Consolidated Gold Fields and Whessoe and a leading figure in the CBI, the Institute of Directors and the London Chamber of Commerce. He led successful trade delegations to south-east Asia and Latin America, and penetrated the Iron Curtain, meeting Nikita Krushchev and Chou En-lai.

A complex background enabled Erroll to bridge the class gap. Born in London, he was the son of mechanical engineer George Erroll, who had come south from Glasgow and shed his German-sounding name of Bergmans. Earlier family roots were in Rotterdam. Freddy's father also managed to send him to Oundle. After that, in 1931, he was apprenticed at Metropolitan-Vickers, then an engineering giant in the Manchester suburbs. His public schoolboy polish helped him become chairman of the largely leftwing apprentices association, and he obtained a mechanical sciences degree at Trinity College, Cambridge.

Already in the Territorials, he was commissioned in the 4th County of London Yeomanry at the outbreak of war in 1939, transferring to the tank division of the Ministry of Supply in 1940. He wound up a full colonel in Mountbatten's Southeast Asia Command, as technical adviser on armoured fighting vehicles, and took part in SEAC's first amphibious operations.

Labour's 1945 tidal wave did not touch him as the safe Tory candidate for Altrincham and Sale, and, once in the Commons, he became a militant voice for business and Tory virtues, attacking nationalisation and food subsidies. He also wanted better pay for industrial brains, so that senior executives could think in the evenings rather than wash dishes.

Having turned down previous offers after the Tories' comeback in 1951 in favour of more remunerative directorships, Erroll's first ministerial job was as parliamentary secretary for supply in Eden's 1955 government, and he held the same rank at the Board of Trade (1956-58), before becoming economic secretary to the Treasury (1958-59). Transferred to the Board of Trade under Reginald Maudling in 1959, he took over command in 1961. He survived Macmillan's 1962 purge, but did not shine, mainly because he was caught in the Tory party struggle between big business and smaller entrepreneurs.

Sir Alec Douglas-Home made him minister for power, although Erroll had conspired with Enoch Powell and Iain Macleod to block Home's selection as leader by the Tory inner circle. After the 1964 Tory defeat, Erroll, who had been warned by his doctor to take things easy, turned over his safe seat to Anthony Barber.

After his recovery, he was much sought after by big business. As chairman of Bowater's, the paper giant, he battled with Harold Wilson over his industries bill. As chairman of Consolidated Gold Fields, he fought off takeover attempts by South African billionaire Harry Oppenheimer. As chairman of a Home Office committee (1970-72), he urged more flexible licensing hours and a lower drinking age of 17.

He never lost his sense of humour; until the end, editors loved to reproduce his brief, jokey letters, usually in answer to others' gripes.

He married Elizabeth Barrow in 1950. Since there were no children, the barony lapses.

Frederick James Erroll, Baron Erroll of Hale, politician and industrialist, born May 27 1914; died September 14 2000

fields.headline: Jerzy Giedroyc
fields.standfirst: Prolific emigré publisher who kept the spirit of a free Poland alive through the long years of communist rule
fields.trailText: It has been said of the publisher Jerzy Giedroyc, who has died aged 94, that he saved Polish literature from extinction during his country's long night of communism, and even if the claim is a little exaggerated, few Poles would quibble.
fields.body:
It has been said of the publisher Jerzy Giedroyc, who has died aged 94, that he saved Polish literature from extinction during his country's long night of communism, and even if the claim is a little exaggerated, few Poles would quibble.

He was born in a town known as Minsk Litewski when it was part of Poland, and as Mensk, now that it is the capital of Belarus. But he was educated in Warsaw, where his father was a functionary in the city courts, attending the Jan Zamoyski lycée and then Warsaw University, where he read law. On graduating in 1929, he took a job in the Polish ministry of agriculture, moving, in 1935, to trade and industry. He continued his intellectual interests, taking a university history course in his spare time.

Giedroyc had tried his hand at publishing a student magazine, and in 1930, while still a civil servant, launched a periodical called The Rebellion Of Youth, which in 1936 changed its name to Polityka. It was a left-of-centre, anti-communist publication, which stirred up controversy with pieces by extremists of various hues, and showing an unfashionable interest in events in countries such as Lithuania and the Ukraine.

When the Germans invaded Poland in September 1939, Giedroyc escaped to Romania, where he offered his services as private secretary to the Polish ambassador, and then as agent for Polish affairs at the British embassy. In March 1941, he left Bucharest for the Middle East, where he joined the Polish army, serving with the Highland Rifle Brigade in Libya and fighting at Tobruk.

When his unit moved to Palestine, Giedroyc was given the job of publishing the Polish 2nd Corps journal. After a brief stint in the ministry of information of the Polish government in London, he returned to Rome, where, at the beginning of 1946, he embarked on a course that was to turn him into a living institution.

Unlike many of his colleagues, who believed that tensions between the Soviet Union and the United States would lead to another war and liberate eastern Europe, Giedroyc was convinced that a long period of exile lay ahead. In the belief that Polish emigrés would need literary and ideological sustenance, he opened a publishing house, which, in its first year, produced more than 30 books, mostly classics. In June 1947, he also launched a periodical, Kultura, which became the most important Polish publication of its kind - and remained so until his death.

Later that year, Giedroyc moved the whole enterprise to Maisons-Laffitte, near Paris, where an aristocratic wellwisher had helped him acquire a large, and once handsome, suburban villa. In this improbable setting, Giedroyc got down to work in earnest on Kultura, a thick monthly packed with essays, narrative and polemic. He was assisted by Zygmunt Hertz and his wife, Zofia - he a sensible Sancho Panza to the quixotic Giedroyc, she the tireless copy editor and cook - and supported by the bohemian aristocratic painter, Jozef Czapski. Early editorial meetings tended to be held in the kitchen, the only warm room in the house, but the literary results were astonishing.

Kultura provided a forum for the many Polish writers whom the war, or subsequent political events, had left stranded around the world, cut off from their readership and their raison d'etre. It thus gave back a voice to the likes of Witold Gombrowicz, Czeslaw Milosz and Gustaw Herling-Grudzinski. Giedroyc also kept in touch with writers still in Poland, printing works they could not get past the communist censors. Maisons-Laffitte soon became an international nerve-centre through which Polish literary life pulsated.

Given Giedroyc's long-standing interest in areas east of Poland, and his sense of solidarity with the peoples of other countries under Soviet domination, it was not long before he began publishing the works of Russian and other east European writers, and his imprint began to sneak its way into the Soviet Union.

In 1953, Giedroyc began publishing books again, producing some 500 titles over the next four decades; these tended to be new works by living authors, including Siniavsky and Solzhenitsyn, as well as major Polish writers. In 1962, he launched the twice-yearly Historical Notebooks, devoted to publishing source material and testimonial accounts of events in eastern Europe, which proved a vital source of information on what was going on.

Life at Maisons-Laffitte was a daily struggle against bankruptcy. The quest for funds was not helped by Giedroyc's almost obsessive independence. He would not espouse any single literary set, and frequently annoyed his contributors by publishing material by writers of opposing literary cliques. Nor would he toe any political line, and his contacts with writers living in communist Poland annoyed the London government in exile, which boycotted everything from behind the Iron Curtain.

But the quality of his publications spoke for him, as did his dedication to the cause, and a steady trickle of donations, most of them pathetically small sums eked out of desultory pensions, helped to keep the enterprise afloat. This, in itself, was an extraordinary achievement; many other emigré publishing ventures collapsed in heaps of heavily-accented newsprint.

Loathed and denounced by the Polish and Soviet governments, which even leaned on the French authorities to close down his venture, Giedroyc was idolised by the Polish intelligentsia, and by many Russians, Byelorussians, Ukrainians and Lithuanians. He was a member of the editorial committee of the Russian dissident publication Kontinent, and an adviser to other groups, who treasured his experience and judgment.
