fields.headline: David Wilson
fields.trailText: The role of science correspondent for BBC News was effectively established by David Wilson, who has died aged 73. His pipe-smoking affability, and sometimes pedantic precision, accompanied a lifelong journalistic inquisitiveness and an enthusiasm for clear explanation of science and technology. For many years, he was a familiar presence on radio and television, while his biography of the nuclear physicist Ernest Rutherford received critical recognition.
fields.body:
The role of science correspondent for BBC News was effectively established by David Wilson, who has died aged 73. His pipe-smoking affability, and sometimes pedantic precision, accompanied a lifelong journalistic inquisitiveness and an enthusiasm for clear explanation of science and technology. For many years, he was a familiar presence on radio and television, while his biography of the nuclear physicist Ernest Rutherford received critical recognition.

Though born in Rugby, where his father was an engineer, Wilson was a determined and very recognisable Yorkshireman. One of six children, he was educated at Ampleforth, and briefly read mathematics at Pembroke College, Cambridge, before doing national service with the Royal Artillery in Sri Lanka. Returning to Cambridge to complete a degree in history, his journalistic interest was whetted by the student newspaper, Varsity. He opted to start work in a power station, but soon switched to journalism on the Yorkshire Post and Wakefield Guardian, before moving to the Birmingham Post and Mail. On January 1 1956, he joined the BBC, together with another young reporter, David Coleman.

At the time, the corporation had few resources dedicated to science coverage, a criticism reinforced in the 1962 Pilkington report on broadcasting (to which the BBC responded by increasing the number of science talks producers from one to two). Extraordinarily, there was no science correspondent at all in the news division. The World Service science specialist was eventually moved across, but this was not successful, and Wilson, by then a reporter in London, took over in 1963.

He rescued the role and built it into a major strand of BBC coverage, pioneering subjects which are today meat and drink to a range of correspondents. The space race, advances in medical treatment and the history of the nuclear programme were topics which most absorbed him, and received his typically thorough research treatment.

He worked closely with Reginald Turnill, the aerospace correspondent, and an arrangement was arrived at whereby Turnill covered manned flight and Wilson unmanned. More to the point, Turnill did most of the location reporting, while Wilson anchored events in the studio, notably the Apollo 13 saga. It was not long before Wilson had enough material for a science reporter to assist him.

His solid attention to detail and respect for fact won confidence from scientists and members of the medical profession, and he was awarded a Glaxo travelling scholarship. During the 1970s, he backed his broadcasting with a steady flow of books on carbon dating, immunisation and the discovery of penicillin, and, in 1983, produced Rutherford: Simple Genius.

A heartfelt Catholic, Wilson was accustomed to arguing about the compatibility of faith and science, although, on one occasion, he burst into the editor's office to complain about the line of questioning being employed by a colleague on Cardinal Basil Hume.

When BBC News split between radio and television, he moved across to Television Centre, where his talents were rather less appreciated, although he remained a source of sound judgment and advice in the correspondents' office.

Other pressures also grew. In 1978, his wife, Elizabeth, died of cancer, while two of their four children were still at school. David, for whom family came first, maintained a welcoming home, and also became increasingly involved in adminstration of the NHS. He was vice-chairman of the Richmond, Twickenham and Roehampton Health Authority in the mid-1980s, and fought volubly against what he saw as party political intervention. In 1985, he moved to manage the Ceefax operation, retiring in the early 1990s.

He continued his community activities and was particularly proud of extracting an unexpectedly high price for charity-owned land at Hampton Hill for supermarket development, which funded new community facilities. In 1996, he settled in the Lake District to be closer to his family and follow environmental interests.

fields.headline: Glyn Colledge
fields.standfirst: A potter at the heart of Denby design, he gave his name to a famous range of tableware
fields.trailText: Glyn Colledge, who was both the heart, and at the heart, of the famous Denby pottery design for almost 50 years, has died aged 78. It was his work that led to the now familiar, and much collected, Glyn Ware pottery. His family connections with the Denby pottery went back to the early 19th century, and Glyn continued the tradition and example of his father, Albert Colledge, who became design director at Denby during one of its most innovative and successful periods.
fields.body:
Glyn Colledge, who was both the heart, and at the heart, of the famous Denby pottery design for almost 50 years, has died aged 78. It was his work that led to the now familiar, and much collected, Glyn Ware pottery. His family connections with the Denby pottery went back to the early 19th century, and Glyn continued the tradition and example of his father, Albert Colledge, who became design director at Denby during one of its most innovative and successful periods.

Glyn joined Denby as a trainee modeller in 1933 and, in the same year, began his studies at the Burslem School of Art, in Stoke-on-Trent, under the legendary Gordon Forsyth, who had previously tutored the ceramic designers Susie Cooper, Clarice Cliff, Charlotte Rhead and Mabel Leigh.

During the second world war, he joined the RAF Sea Rescue Service, serving with distinction in Italy, North Africa, Malta, France and Britain. Later, he returned to Denby as a trainee designer under the guidance of his father, and continued his studies at Derby College of Art, eventually progressing from student to part-time lecturer. He also lectured at Ilkeston College of Further Education.

By the beginning of the 1950s, Glyn had been rewarded with his own design studio at Denby pottery. During this period, the decorating department gradually expanded from five "girls" - as the decorators were known - to 70, and, by the 1960s, Denby was taking a leading role in the development of postwar ceramic design. From his studio, Glyn designed his best known work, Glyn Ware, in which pots were decorated with an infinite variety of leaves, in soft, vibrant colours trailing across gently curving shapes. The diversity of the hand-painted leaves was unified by the coherence of the shapes.

Many of Glyn's designs were rooted in tradition and based on an expertise in all the techniques of the pottery industry. During the 1950s, he had also assimilated the atmosphere and ideas generated in that decade, and his interpretation of these was reflected in a series of unique, contemporary-styled vases. He developed new methods and techniques to maintain and extend the characteristic Denby look.

As head of the design department, Glyn would translate the ideas of freelance designers, such as Tibot Reich and Kenneth Clark, into practice. From the 1960s onwards, he and his colleague Gill Pemberton established the Denby pottery as a major contributor to the tableware market. One of his designs, Ode, was a gold medal winner at the California state fair.

As a recognition of his contribution to Denby's continued success, Glyn was appointed as director and new products manager. His work took him to France, Poland and Portugal. He was acknowledged as an expert in his field by peers and colleagues alike, and was praised for his integrity, his attention to detail and his vast technical knowledge.

Glyn took early retirement in 1983. The new freedom enabled him to create his own studio pottery in the garden of the idyllic country cottage, which he shared with his wife, Val, and his son, Austen. Unhampered by commercial restraints, he was able to throw and decorate pottery that celebrated his love of colour and reflected his artistic ability. His work was already well known because of the early Glyn Ware and, increasingly, collectors from all over Britain - many of whom became personal friends - made their way to his studio. There, they were entertained by his quiet, dry wit, his quirky sense of humour and innumerable cups of tea. Conversation would be interrupted by the chimes from his extensive clock col lection, all set to chime at different intervals.

In recent years, Glyn's knowledge of Denby formed an invaluable source of information for museums, researchers and writers. His links with the Denby pottery were never severed. Today, designers, management and former colleagues speak of him as "their inspiration, their ambassador, their friend".

fields.headline: Mbeki attacked for HIV/Aids doubts
fields.trailText: The South African government's most powerful ally - the country's trade union confederation Cosatu - has accused President Thabo Mbeki of causing confusion and costing lives by questioning the link between HIV and Aids.
fields.body:
The South African government's most powerful ally - the country's trade union confederation Cosatu - has accused President Thabo Mbeki of causing confusion and costing lives by questioning the link between HIV and Aids.

Mr Mbeki was forced to listen impassively yesterday while trade unionists at the annual meeting of the Congress of South African Trade Unions loudly applauded their leader, Willie Madisha, as he condemned the president on an issue that is causing as much friction between the unions and government as economic policy.

"The current public debate on the causal link between HIV and Aids is confusing," said Willie Madisha. "For Cosatu, the link between HIV and Aids is irrefutable and any other approach is unscientific and unfortunately likely to confuse people. As a result, it can undermine the message that all South Africans must take precautions to avoid infection."

When Mr Mbeki spoke immediately afterwards, he made only a fleeting reference to Aids as a cause of people being unable to work.

The unions' criticism comes on the heels of a confidential memorandum written by the ANC's own health committee and addressed to Mr Mbeki and his health minister, saying HIV causes Aids and that they must publicly acknowledge this. The committee said "we do not have the luxury of fiddling whilst the masses are dying".

Mounting anger and dissent within the ruling party, the unions, the medical profession and among large numbers of ordinary black people over Mr Mbeki's questioning of conventional scientific thought has forced the government on to the defensive.

It has moved to quell criticism with a series of adverts "clarifying" the president's views. They say that Mr Mbeki has never denied a link between HIV and Aids but that he does not attribute immune deficiency exclusively to the virus, that poverty is also a primary factor, and that drugs are not the only response.

The president's critics accuse him of playing with words and undermining years of Aids education. His government has used these "doubts" to justify withholding drugs from HIV positive people, including pregnant women, they say, adding that scientists have long recognised that ill-nourished poor people with weak immune systems may succumb to HIV more swiftly but that has little to do with the cause of Aids.

South Africa has the fastest growing rate of Aids infection in the world with about one in 10 of the population is HIV positive. Trade union leaders are particularly disturbed because of the excessively high rate of infection among their members. They accuse the government of playing with lives.

Mr Madisha yesterday launched a direct attack on Mr Mbeki's unwillingness to provide drugs to Aids patients. "Government's unwillingness to provide anti-retrovirals, particularly to prevent mother-to-child transmission, is unfortunate. Concerns around cost are understandable but often exaggerated. In any case, they cannot be used to deny treatment for the millions of victims. This is tantamount to condemning HIV/Aids victims to early deaths," he said.

"We need to put the current controversies behind us and develop strategies to obtain cheap drugs, either through hard negotiations with producers or through parallel importation of gener ics and compulsory licensing."

Last week, a South African newspaper polled all 27 members of Mr Mbeki's government on whether they believe HIV causes Aids. Only one, the labour minister, said he did.

"Yes, of course HIV causes Aids," said Membathisi Mdladlana.

The science minister sidestepped the question by saying that the fact that the government is funding a research vaccine indicated it assumed there was a link.

Most of the remaining ministers failed to answer the question directly or to respond at all, which may reflect just how many doubts there are within Mr Mbeki's cabinet over his policy. His ministers may not have had the courage to dissent but neither were they publicly going to back his controversial position.

Only the office of the health minister, Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, toed the president's line with any enthusiasm.

"The minister is working on the assumption that there is acquired immune deficiency. There is a variety of things that causes the collapse of the immune deficiency and it cannot be attributed solely and exclusively to the virus," it said.

fields.headline: Helicopter 'saved drunken crew'
fields.trailText: Coastguards were forced to launch a hazardous rescue mission to save a group of drunken sailors after they attempted to sail 13 miles back to their ship in force six gales, a tribunal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Coastguards were forced to launch a hazardous rescue mission to save a group of drunken sailors after they attempted to sail 13 miles back to their ship in force six gales, a tribunal heard yesterday.

The captain and three senior crew members of the 100,000 tonne Matco Clyde oil tanker had been drinking for almost five hours in a pub in Macduff, Aberdeenshire, when they attempted to return to their ship.

The tribunal, being held in Eastleigh magistrates court, Hampshire, heard that the group, led by Captain Clive Mottram, 54, from Southampton, had arrived in the Macduff Arms at noon on March 23.

Mottram had anchored 13 miles off the coast of the fishing town and, along with chief engineer John Blamires, from Buxton, Derbyshire, and two other senior crew members, had decided to take a boat into Macduff for an afternoon's drinking session.

The group drank heavily until, shortly before 5pm, they received a call from the tanker urging them to return because of the worsening weather.

Belinda Bucknell QC, representing the maritime and coastguard agency, told the tribunal that Mottram had consumed between six and seven pints and all four crew members were drunk. Despite this, they left Macduff for the tanker while a storm brewed.

"As they attempted to steer their craft from the harbour back to the Matco Clyde, they collided with the east harbour wall, scraping 50ft along the breakwater," Mrs Bucknell said.

While concerned local people looked on, Mrs Bucknell said, the crew smashed their single-engine rig into the wall once more. The bystanders urged the crew to return to the harbour, but they responded with "an obscene gesture".

Fearing for the crew's safety, the Macduff harbourmasters alerted coastguards.

The crew had a 13 mile journey back to the tanker, but within six miles their boat ran out of petrol and was swamped.

At around 7pm, a Royal Navy helicopter managed to locate the stricken boat by the lights on the crew's lifejackets. The helicopter sent down a winch man to airlift the four to safety, but, Mrs Bucknell said, he arrived to find one of the crew slumped drunkenly over the wheel.

The tribunal heard that the semi-conscious crewman was believed to have been the captain - and another crew member was similarly inebriated.

As the crew were thought to be drunk, the helicopter pilots refused to return them to the Matco Clyde and, instead, took them to their base at Lossiemouth. They were questioned by police and Mottram and Blamires were charged with serious negligence and misconduct under the Merchant Shipping Act.

webTitle: Leader: Random rockfalls threaten cosmic chaos

fields.headline: Watch this space
fields.standfirst:
Random rockfalls threaten cosmic chaos

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: As far as anybody knows, nobody has ever died of a direct hit by meteor, asteroid or comet. As far as anybody knows, nobody ever will. The operative words in these statements are, however, "as far as anybody knows." And that, brutally, is not very far. US astronomers think they have identified about 900 or so "near earth objects" of 1km or more across. There could be another 1,000 or so, lurking hazards in the darkness of the cosmos, awful accidents waiting to happen. A direct hit from one of these would make a hole of maybe 30km across, darken the skies, freeze the crops and destroy an area the size of France. If it hit the oceans it would set up a tsunami more than 100 metres high, racing at jet speeds to wash away coastal cities.
fields.body:
As far as anybody knows, nobody has ever died of a direct hit by meteor, asteroid or comet. As far as anybody knows, nobody ever will. The operative words in these statements are, however, "as far as anybody knows." And that, brutally, is not very far. US astronomers think they have identified about 900 or so "near earth objects" of 1km or more across. There could be another 1,000 or so, lurking hazards in the darkness of the cosmos, awful accidents waiting to happen. A direct hit from one of these would make a hole of maybe 30km across, darken the skies, freeze the crops and destroy an area the size of France. If it hit the oceans it would set up a tsunami more than 100 metres high, racing at jet speeds to wash away coastal cities.

The big asteroids may not be the problem. It could be the small asteroids of maybe 300 metres across, travelling at maybe 30km a second, producing, when they hit something, a million megaton explosion, or 6m Hiroshimas, that should worry us. There could be 30,000 of those, or even 300,000. These whack into the earth every few hundreds to few thousands of years. The catch is, you cannot see them coming, unless you look very carefully. A government appointed task force is recommending that Britain takes a lead in looking very carefully, especially in the southern hemisphere (that is because the Americans are already looking quite carefully north of the equator.) The brutes are out there: something a few metres across explodes like an atomic bomb in the upper atmosphere every week. A 400 metres-wide asteroid went sailing past the earth on Sunday afternoon, a "near miss" of 11 lunar distances.

One day, sooner or later, the world is going to see one of these objects coming, in time to do something about it. Spotting these things will certainly be modestly expensive. Not spotting them could be positively ruinous. As the Americans say, if you think education is expensive, try ignorance.

fields.headline: Drug baron who 'earned £640m' gets 20 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A drug baron who amassed an estimated £640m during his "premier league" criminal career was jailed for 20 years yesterday after being convicted of dealing in cocaine and cannabis.
fields.body:
A drug baron who amassed an estimated £640m during his "premier league" criminal career was jailed for 20 years yesterday after being convicted of dealing in cocaine and cannabis.

Andrew Billimore, 34, of Little Downham, Cambridgeshire, dealt "at the very top of the bracket in cannabis and class A drugs" in the "most significant" drug ring seen in eastern England for many years, Judge Paul Downes said at Norwich crown court.

Billimore admitted conspiring to supply cannabis, supplying cannabis and conspiring to pervert the course of justice. He was found guilty of conspiring to supply cocaine.

Detectives estimated his earnings at £640m over six years. Billimore, who is likely to have substantial assets seized, laughed when the figure was suggested in court, and his lawyers said it was way off the mark. But police believe the former Ely cathedral guide has huge amounts stashed away.

"This is a premier league dealer," said a police source. "He has few previous convictions, but successful drugs dealers don't get caught often."

Billimore's half brother and "able lieutenant", former paratrooper Thomas McTaggart, 37, of Meldreth, was jailed for 10 years yesterday. He was said to have made more than £1.2m out of trafficking.

He admitted conspiring to supply cannabis and amphetamines, supplying cannabis, possessing cocaine and conspiring to pervert the course of justice.

fields.headline: Liberal and democratic
fields.standfirst:
Transforming Britain in 90 minutes

Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: In the Rose and Crown and the Safeway, on the high street corner and the village green, and especially in the petrol queue people talked of little else. But the grand forum of the nation - parliament - was extinguished in the late crisis from the debate. Parliament was on two and a half months' holiday. And even if it had not been, it might not have made very much difference.
fields.body:
In the Rose and Crown and the Safeway, on the high street corner and the village green, and especially in the petrol queue people talked of little else. But the grand forum of the nation - parliament - was extinguished in the late crisis from the debate. Parliament was on two and a half months' holiday. And even if it had not been, it might not have made very much difference. Events like last week's make the great buildings on Parliament Square seem like a kind of echoing museum. Politics, the Liberal treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor told the party assembly yesterday, was much scarier, more energetic, in your face, fast, awkward, difficult, hi-tech: frightening and seductive. And instantly responsive, in a way the official system is not. It will have to learn to live with them. So the hour and a half the Liberal Democrats spent yesterday discussing our institutions was no mere backwater issue. Disaffection has always been an engine of political and constitutional change. Maybe it could be again.

The Lib Dems did a lot, in terms of commitments, to change the face of Britain in their 90 minutes. They replaced the Lords with an elected senate, kicking the bishops out. They gave us a real Freedom of Information Bill, strengthened the select committee system, cut the number of ministers, and pushed devolution further. Then gleefully grasping a proffered amendment, they revoked the Act of Settlement to allow the monarch to belong to any religion (or none) and barred the head of state from holding any high position in any particular church, thus disestablishing the Church of England. They did not, however, abolish the monarchy. A party which is not on the verge of government has far more freedom than those in power or close to it to make such sweeping proposals. But the Lib Dems' idealism is much to be preferred to the ultra-caution of their bigger rivals.

In other circumstances there might have been trouble over PR, but there just wasn't time. The leadership says that Lord Jenkins's plans for a not-all-that proportional system called the Alternative Vote Plus are still very much alive, a belief which has now departed from Lord Jenkins himself. One critic from the floor called it "a dead duck". The question now is in what circumstances the duck might be resuscitated. If the next election finished where the polls are now, and Labour needed the Lib Dems for survival - then, perhaps.

webTitle: Top brass cash in on BG split

fields.headline: Top brass cash in on BG split
fields.trailText: The chief executives of the two companies to be formed from gas group BG later this year are in line for hefty pay increases, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The chief executives of the two companies to be formed from gas group BG later this year are in line for hefty pay increases, it emerged yesterday.

Frank Chapman, head of the expanding exploration and production and storage company BG International, will be given a 25% rise, from £360,000 to £450,000, BG said in its demerger document. Phil Nolan, his counterpart at Lattice, the holding company for the rest of BG's activities, including the lucrative but tightly regulated Transco pipelines business, will see his salary upped 18% from £335,000 to £395,000.

The two are also to benefit from new, long-term incentive payment schemes but BG said remuneration packages, including pay-offs for departing directors, had been approved by the Association of British Insurers and the National Association of Pension Funds, the two biggest shareholder lobbying groups.

BG said the salaries had been benchmarked against FTSE-100 practice and while Chapman's was around the median, Nolan's fell short. David Varney, outgoing chief executive of the BG Group, will get a £500,000 golden goodbye, equivalent to a year's salary on his two-year rolling contract.

webTitle: Smiths in charm offensive over £4.5bn TI merger

fields.headline: Smiths in charm offensive over £4.5bn TI merger
fields.trailText: Smiths Industries last night launched a full scale offensive to win over sceptical investors for its surprise £4.5bn merger with fellow engineering business TI Group.
fields.body:
Smiths Industries last night launched a full scale offensive to win over sceptical investors for its surprise £4.5bn merger with fellow engineering business TI Group.

News of the deal sent Smiths' shares tumbling 100p to 735p, a near-12% fall. Alan Thomson, Smiths' finance director, said advisers had warned the deal would be poorly received and yet 15% of the company's shareholders had approved it last Friday before it was sprung on the market early yesterday.

A string of brokers and analysts poured cold water on the deal that would propel two mid-cap companies in what Mr Thomson admitted was the "unloved, downtrodden" engineering sector into around 70th place in the FTSE 100.

Analysts labelled the merger a purely defensive manoeuvre and said that, while Smiths' executives had gained the upper hand in the merged group, TI shareholders had won out. Even Cazenove, Smiths' lead broker on the deal, said a sharp decline in the company's share price could stop the deal going ahead and that there was a possibility that an alternative offer for TI might emerge despite the lack of immediate interest. TI shares closed unchanged at 374p.

Brushing aside these worries, Mr Thomson said: "Part of the problem with the market is that they see this as another Invensys (the merged BTR-Siebe group) which shocked everybody in recent days with its profits warning, or even Rolls-Royce, but it is not. This is about going for growth.

"Our annual results came in today right at the top end of expectations at £266m, up 12%, we're converting 80% of that into cash, and getting on with the strategic moves which everybody had said we had got to get on with and do."

He said the combined group would have debts of just £500m on sales of £3bn and these would be swiftly wiped out with £200m cash inflows a year, leaving it "tremendous firepower" for future acquisitions and growth.

The merger brings to an end the search by Sir Christopher Lewinton, TI's chairman, for deals to bring his company's shares out of the mire and correct what he saw as a basic mismatch between their price and TI's real performance.

Sir Christopher, who had threatened to take TI private, will become non-executive chairman of the enlarged group until he retires in January 2002. Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, chief executive of Smiths and the new entity, said that the deal would double the size of the aerospace business (to £1.1bn sales a year) and add TI's sealing solutions business.

Mr Thomson said both Boeing and Airbus, the two dominant civil and military airplane-makers, wanted bigger suppliers.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The merger of Cambridge vaccine firms Peptide Therapeutics and Cantab Pharmaceuticals has ground to a halt following confirmation from Peptide that it is considering selling a stake to US biotech group Baxter International.
fields.body:
Peptide swayed by Baxter offer

The merger of Cambridge vaccine firms Peptide Therapeutics and Cantab Pharmaceuticals has ground to a halt following confirmation from Peptide that it is considering selling a stake to US biotech group Baxter International.

Peptide and Cantab have been in talks for four months, but delays in the release of merger details had resulted in scepticism from analysts.

The Baxter deal is expected to be formally announced tomorrow with Peptide's half-year results. In a statement yesterday the company confirmed it was looking at a "strategic alliance" with Baxter, focusing on commercial projects.

Baxter would pay Peptide 130p per share for a stake of about 20%. Analysts believe the Cantab deal was pitched at 110p.

Peptide shares closed up 9p at 92p.

Blockade left 35% on brink

Last week's fuel protests could have put a third of Britain's small firms out of business if they had lasted for much longer, according to a survey released yesterday by Dun & Bradstreet.

"The results of this survey point to the fact that small business, who already survive from hand to mouth, would have had severe difficulties had it lasted much longer," said Philip Mellor, senior analyst at D&B.

About 35 % of the 500 small to medium-size companies surveyed said the fuel blockade would have seriously threatened their business if it had continued for a week longer.

Sinyor to join Trinity board

Trinity Mirror plc said yesterday it will appoint Joe Sinyor to the board as chief executive of newspapers, adding that he will take up his position once his contractual negotiations with Sony UK are concluded. Mr Sinyor will have strategic and operational responsibility for all of Trinity Mirror's newspaper operations.

Pensions for small business

Legal & General has signed a deal with the Forum of Private Business (FPB) to offer stakeholder pensions to up to 350,000 employees of small businesses across Britain, it was announced yesterday.

Stakeholder pensions, available from April next year, will be aimed particularly at those who do not have access to a company pension scheme. They will be cheaper and more flexible than traditional personal pensions.

Legal & General said it was joining forces with the FPB to make the new plans available to its 25,000 member firms, most of which are small and medium-sized enterprises.

fields.headline: Granada set for £3bn deal
fields.standfirst: French rival in talks to buy Le Meridien and Posthouse hotels
fields.trailText: Granada Compass, the newly merged catering and hotels group, is understood to be in advanced talks to sell the bulk of its hotels business - which includes the Posthouse and Le Meridien chains - to its French rival Accor for around £3bn.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor , Neil Hume  and Mary O'Hara
fields.body:
Granada Compass, the newly merged catering and hotels group, is understood to be in advanced talks to sell the bulk of its hotels business - which includes the Posthouse and Le Meridien chains - to its French rival Accor for around £3bn.

While agreement on price has still to be reached, both companies are thought to be working to complete the deal before the end of the month. The sale will rid Granada Compass of the rest of the trophy hotels won through the acrimonious takeover of Forte five years ago, but will exclude the budget Travelodge chain, many of which sit inside the motorway service stations run by Granada Compass.

Completion of the deal will be met with relief in the City, where Granada's share price has fallen 20% this month. Ever since the merger between Granada and Compass in May, analysts have been cool towards the continuing presence of a major hotels division within the new group, arguing that it should focus on the faster growing contract cater ing and hospitality business.

The deal will cap an extraordinary run of transactions for chairman Gerry Robinson, who has indicated he will retire soon, leaving the business in the hands of chief executive Francis Mackay. The merger between Granada and Compass was followed almost immediately by the flotation of 20% of Granada Media, the television business which is now being merged with its ITV rival, United News & Media.

The up-market Meridien chain, which includes the London hotels Waldorf on Aldwych, and Le Meridien on Piccadilly, complete with one of Marco Pierre White's restaurants, is thought to be worth around £2bn. It will also be selling the smaller, middle-range Posthouse and Heritage chains, which analysts value at up to £3.5bn.

Accor boasts some 3,400 hotels around the world, including the Ibis and Novotel chains. More than half its business is concentrated at the economy end of the market.

Speculation about the imminent transaction fuelled heavy trading in Granada Compass' shares yesterday, sending the price 17p higher to 707p.

A formal announcement is thought to have been slated for September 27, when Granada Compass is due to issue a trading statement - the same day as Accor is due to publish its annual figures.

Sector specialists said Bass was also interested in the hotels portfolio but was beaten on price.

Travelodge, meanwhile, continues to expand rapidly, with plans for an extra 1,000 rooms each year for the next three years. It is not included in Granada's hotel division, sitting in "roadside" travel operation, which includes the ser vice stations and Little Chef cafes. One source close to the discussions said last night: "The market may have been impatient, but there were reasons for Granada adopting what may seem a complicated process towards a demerger of its media and catering businesses. Tax was one.

"The result will be one clean highly rated media business, with real stature, and one focused catering business with excellent international spread. There was no way Granada was going to go back to being the hotch-potch of businesses it was ten years ago."

The deal will cap an extraordinary run of transactions for chairman Gerry Robinson, who has indicated he will retire soon, leaving the business in the hands of chief executive Francis Mackay. The merger between Granada and Compass was followed almost immediately by the flotation of 20% of Granada Media, the television business which is now being merged with its ITV rival, United News & Media. The up-market Meridien chain, which includes the London hotels Waldorf on Aldwych, and Le Meridien on Piccadilly, complete with one of Marco Pierre White's restaurants, is thought to be worth around £2bn. It will also be selling the smaller, middle-range Posthouse and Heritage chains, which analysts value at up to £3.5bn. Accor boasts some 3,400 hotels around the world, including the Ibis and Novotel chains. More than half its business is concentrated at the economy end of the market. Speculation about the imminent transaction fuelled heavy trading in Granada Compass' shares yesterday, sending the price 17p higher to 707p. A formal announcement is thought to have been slated for September 27, when Granada Compass is due to issue a trading statement - the same day as Accor is due to publish its annual figures. Sector specialists said Bass was also interested in the hotels portfolio but was beaten on price. Travelodge, meanwhile, continues to expand rapidly, with plans for an extra 1,000 rooms each year for the next three years. It is not included in Granada's hotel division, sitting in "roadside" travel operation, which includes the ser vice stations and Little Chef cafes. One source close to the discussions said last night: "The market may have been impatient, but there were reasons for Granada adopting what may seem a complicated process towards a demerger of its media and catering businesses. Tax was one. "The result will be one clean highly rated media business, with real stature, and one focused catering business with excellent international spread. There was no way Granada was going to go back to being the hotch-potch of businesses it was ten years ago."

fields.headline: Labour pays the price
fields.standfirst:
But do keep a sense of perspective

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: For eight long years, the Conservatives have lived with the legacy of Black Wednesday, the day when George Soros and his fellow speculators bundled Britain out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism. With the government's reputation for competence in shreds, John Major's poll rating fell off a cliff, never to recover. Was last week's fuel crisis Tony Blair's Black Wednesday? Have voters lost all faith in the ability of Labour to manage the economy? On the face of it, the signs are not promising.
fields.body:
For eight long years, the Conservatives have lived with the legacy of Black Wednesday, the day when George Soros and his fellow speculators bundled Britain out of the Exchange Rate Mechanism. With the government's reputation for competence in shreds, John Major's poll rating fell off a cliff, never to recover. Was last week's fuel crisis Tony Blair's Black Wednesday? Have voters lost all faith in the ability of Labour to manage the economy? On the face of it, the signs are not promising.

The findings of our ICM poll today make grim reading for ministers, illustrating the depth of public hostility not just to the government's specific handling of the blockade of oil refineries but to its whole approach and demeanour. The polls published at the weekend, undertaken when the petrol stations were running dry last Thursday and Friday, could be shrugged off as blips, but the ICM fieldwork was conducted on Saturday and Sunday when temperatures had cooled and Britain was supposed to be getting back to normal.

For once, those who said Tony Blair had suffered his worst week since becoming leader were absolutely right. Labour's poll rating is its lowest since the aftermath of the 1992 election defeat; 71% of people say that ministers are not listening; 63% blame the government for the rise in oil prices. Perhaps most significantly of all, overall satisfaction with Tony Blair has collapsed to levels not seen since 1989, when Neil Kinnock was leader of the opposition. You don't need to be Philip Gould to know that Labour is in trouble.

Even so, this is not the equivalent of Black Wednesday. Last week's protests may have brought the country close to paralysis, but it was the road hauliers and farmers who blinked first. They packed up and went home because, in the final analysis, they realised that it was a battle they could not win. Back in 1992, it was a completely different story. Then, the financial markets had the power and the will to force the Major administration to abandon the central plank of its economic strategy. In the weeks following Black Wednesday, there was a total policy vacuum while the Treasury and the Bank of England worked out what to do next. George Soros actually did the economy nothing but good, yet Major received no credit for a recovery his government's policies would have hindered.

Nothing remotely comparable has befallen Labour. Inflation is the lowest in the European Union, unemployment is poised to drop below a million during the winter, living standards are rising, billions of extra pounds are being pumped into health and education, the appalling legacy of poverty left behind by the Conservatives is slowly being tackled. Of course, Britain is no nirvana - but it should be possible to persuade voters that Labour has made a difference by the time of the election.

Students of psephology may recall that the last time Labour's poll rating fell as sharply as it did in our poll today was in February 1979, during the winter of discontent. Ministers are right to be concerned about the danger of history repeating itself, but there is no reason why it should. They face an opposition which looks less fit to govern than just about any other in Britain's history, they are reaping the reward for parsimony in the first two years of this parliament with the £43bn increase in public spending, and - in retrospect - they brought the fuel blockades to a reasonably swift end. Easy though it is to say, Labour should avoid panicking.

fields.headline: Attack on Ivory Coast ruler
fields.trailText: The military ruler of Ivory Coast, General Robert Guei, has implicitly accused his rivals in next month's presidential election of making an attempt on his life.
fields.body:
The military ruler of Ivory Coast, General Robert Guei, has implicitly accused his rivals in next month's presidential election of making an attempt on his life.

Two of his bodyguards were killed when disgruntled soldiers attacked his official residence before dawn yesterday.

"Some young military people were more or less invited by certain people who are known to me to make an attempt on my life," he said.

His comment is seen by Ivorians as pointing the finger at opposition politicians, and they fear that the attack will give him an excuse to detain other contenders for the presidency, or call off the ballot.

The attack is further evidence that the army and the country have grown disenchanted with Gen Guei since he backtracked on his promise to hold free elections after he seized power in December.

He has chosen to run for office himself while trying to bar more popular opponents, drawing criticism from France, the former colonial power, and the US.

Gen Guei put himself forward as a presidential candidate in the ballot after rewriting the constitution to try to exclude his main rival, the former prime minister Alassane Ouattara.

fields.headline: 'If you'd said I'd get fired for this, I would have laughed'
fields.standfirst:
Case study

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Terri Seargent's case should be a shining success story for genetic science. The latest breakthroughs in deciphering the human blueprint helped to identify a "misprint" in her genes which made her susceptible to respiratory failure. The discovery will probably save her life, but it has robbed her of her livelihood.
fields.body:
Terri Seargent's case should be a shining success story for genetic science. The latest breakthroughs in deciphering the human blueprint helped to identify a "misprint" in her genes which made her susceptible to respiratory failure. The discovery will probably save her life, but it has robbed her of her livelihood.

Her dismissal from a North Carolina insurance firm last year was one of the first US cases of "genetic discrimination". Although Ms Seargent had an exemplary record at work, her employers decided that she was "flawed" and a liability, on the basis of a genetic test

She had gone to her doctor thinking that she was suffering from allergies that were making it difficult to breathe. Instead, tests revealed that she was suffering from Alpha 1 deficiency, an often fatal disorder thought to be the genetic legacy of distant Viking ancestors. If left unchecked, the disease eats up the lungs and the sufferer gradually suffocates from within.

However, if caught early enough, the disease can be stabilised by a regime of medicines, diet and exercise. So Ms Seargent thought she was lucky to have received an early warning.

"If you'd told me you were going to get fired because of this, I would have laughed at you," she said.

But Ms Seargent worked for a small firm which took care of its own employee insurance needs, and word of her condition quickly spread from the insurance administrator to the management. Days later, she was told that her services were no longer required, despite a string of glowing work reports.

When she challenged her sudden dismissal on the grounds of unfair discrimination, her former employers quickly recast her reputation.

"Suddenly, I was a horrific person, a terrible person. They had to get rid of me as I was destroying the company," she said, adding: "So why did I just receive a 10% raise then?"

Being made redundant was just the start of her problems. Her husband's insurers suddenly announced that they would raise their premiums in view of her condition, and her 23-year-old son is also having problems finding insurance.

"It's real scary what these insurance companies can do," Ms Seargent said.

The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is taking Ms Seargent's story to court - as a test-case on genetic discrimination to find whether it is covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1994.

However, she is not overly optimistic, pointing out that all but 3% of ADA cases are won by the employer.

But if Ms Seargent had to go through it all again she would still go straight to her doctor for her screening. "In the end, my life is more important than a job," she said.

In a more ideal world, of course, it would be better not to have to choose.

fields.headline: Remaining Octuplets fight for life
fields.trailText: A second baby from a set of octuplets died yesterday as her six siblings fought for survival in a Milan hospital.
fields.body:
A second baby from a set of octuplets died yesterday as her six siblings fought for survival in a Milan hospital.

Fear that the babies' vital organs and central nervous systems are fatally under developed intensified after the girl, named Cristina, suffered a haemorrhage.

Doctors had hoped to delay the babies' delivery for two more weeks, but Marinella Mazzara, 31, gave birth to the first, a girl, on Wednesday, three months early.

The other seven, four boys and three girls, arrived on Sunday, the first naturally and the rest by caesarean section. One of the boys died soon afterwards.

The health minister, Umberto Veronesi, led criticism of doctors for turning fertility treatment into a "wild west" without proper regulation.

The surviving babies, each weighing just over 450 grams (1lb) were in incubators at Niguarda hospital last night. Their condition was stable, but the doctors feared neurological and respiratory complications, as well as infections, the hospital spokesman, Stefano Martinelli, said. Experts put their chance of survival at 50%.

Mrs Mazzara, from Ballata in Sicily, was described as well. Her womb had swollen to a volume of 3.5 gallons - twice the normal size for a pregnant woman.

Mr Veronesi criticised doctors' recklessness. "What a tragedy for that woman. Sometimes doctors should recommend adoption."

webTitle: Who's testing our genes - and why?

fields.headline: Who's testing our genes - and why?
fields.standfirst:
Health warning: As DNA screening takes hold, Americans find it can leave them unemployed and uninsured

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The US equal employment opportunities commissioner, Paul Miller, has called for tougher safeguards for workers against genetic discrimination after it emerged that hundreds of people have already lost their jobs or insurance protection as a direct result of advances in genetic screening.
fields.body:
The US equal employment opportunities commissioner, Paul Miller, has called for tougher safeguards for workers against genetic discrimination after it emerged that hundreds of people have already lost their jobs or insurance protection as a direct result of advances in genetic screening.

"Just as it is illegal to refuse to hire an individual because of their race or gender, it should be illegal to make job decisions based solely upon genetic information without considering that person's ability to do the work," Mr Miller wrote in an article in the University of Maryland's Journal of Health Care Law & Policy.

"It is simply bad science for an employer to use the presence of a predictive genetic trait or marker to make workplace decisions, because those traits cannot predict how well that person will succeed in the workplace."

Civil rights activists are growing concerned that if such Orwellian practices develop at the same pace as the race to decipher the human blueprint they could create a "genetic underclass" considered unemployable because of the chemical codes they carry inside them.

'Flaws' cost jobs

In a recent survey carried out by the Shriver centre for public health in Massachusetts, doctors and genetic testing centres reported 582 cases of people who were turned down for jobs or health insurance because of "flaws" discovered in their genes.

Another watchdog organisation, the Council for Responsible Genetics (CRG), says it has documented more than 200 cases of genetic discrimination by employers.

Researchers believe these figures are the tip of an iceberg. In most cases the corporations involved are not keen to publicise their practices, and nor are the victims, anxious to avoid further stigmatisation. In the cases cited by the genetics council the victims are not referred to by their full names.

They include Kim, a social worker, who mentioned at a staff workshop that her mother had died of Huntington's disease, giving her a 50% chance of developing the potentially fatal genetic condition. A week later she was dismissed.

In another case a 40-year-old woman with an exemplary employment record agreed to take part in a genetic research survey and tested positive for BRAC1, a gene linked to some breast and ovarian cancers. Despite having preventive surgery she lost her health insurance and then her job.

Mr Miller is calling for new federal legislation to close the legal loopholes that allow employers and insurance companies to gain access to genetic information on prospective employees and use that information in hiring and firing.

An attempt to get Congress to pass an anti-discrimination law - led by the Democratic leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle - has been blocked by the opposition of the insurance industry and the corporate lobby in Washington.

Watching the bill being shelved until next year at the earliest, the senator warned: "We simply cannot afford to take one step forward in science while taking two steps backwards in civil rights."

The scientists leading the race to decode the human genome - like the physicists before them who first split the atom - also know the dangers that are inherent in their mission.

As the first draft of the human genome map was unveiled to a great fanfare in June one of its principal authors, Francis Collins, director of National Human Genome Research Institute, said: "Already, with but a handful of genetic tests in common use, people have lost their jobs, lost their health insurance and lost their economic well-being due to the unfair and inappropriate use of genetic information."

Records unprotected

Recent research has found that the fear of future discrimination can be as damaging as discrimination itself, as people forgo screening for potentially treatable conditions for fear the information will be used against them in the future.

A study by Georgetown University in Washington found that fear of discrimination has led one in 10 people at risk deciding against testing for genetic traits linked to cystic fibrosis, Huntington's disease, colon cancer and other conditions with a hereditary link.

The US department of labour has found that many women are avoiding breast cancer screening because they believe a positive finding would go on their medical records and become available to employers or insurers.

Their fears are justified in an unregulated market, where medical data are often treated as a tradable commodity, bought and sold by medical centres and insurance companies. In the words of one executive at a medical data company: "There are more controls over the disclosure of your video rentals than your medical records."

webTitle: Call for church to honour Shaker leader

fields.headline: Call for church to honour Shaker leader
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A civic group yesterday called for the charismatic leader of a religious group which flourished in the US for almost 200 years to be honoured in the British city of her birth.
fields.body:
A civic group yesterday called for the charismatic leader of a religious group which flourished in the US for almost 200 years to be honoured in the British city of her birth.

The Manchester civic society wants a commemorative plaque to be put on the walls of Manchester cathedral where Ann Lee, who led the Shakers for 14 years in the 18th century, was baptised and married.

The move could embarrass the church because Lee was thrown out of the cathedral after "wilfully and contemptuously" disrupting a service there in 1773. The illiterate daughter of a Manchester blacksmith who said she was "clothed with the sun and the moon under her feet", Lee claimed she had been born again as the counterpart of Jesus, the female messiah and witness to whom the light of God were revealed.

During the 18th century the Shakers' wild singing and dancing, said to be heard seven miles away from their meetings, and their unconventional beliefs, caused them to be attacked by mobs in Manchester, and New England in the US. The Shakers were founded in Bolton, Greater Manchester, in 1747, but today are better known for their furniture and strict celibacy than their theology.

"I knew little about Ann Lee until I heard a biography serialised on radio," said Tony Wilson, chairman of the civic society. "Manchester appears to have forgotten someone who was a significant figure in the history of religion. Any commemorative plaque would have to be on a building connected with her. The cathedral is the obvious place, controversial though that may be."

The dean of Manchester cathedral, the Very Rev Ken Riley, said: "Lee was a church leader of some standing and a very successful one, even if some of her beliefs were rather extreme. Considerations are likely to be more practical than theological - it's a question of how many plaques we have space for."

Lee left Manchester with a small band of followers and sailed to America in 1774. She spent years wandering New England, stirring controversy wherever she went, not least because of her demand that even married converts should abstain from sex. The idea of a woman leading a religious group was so disturbing that her persecutors subjected her to crude tests of femininity.

Richard Francis, who has written a biography of Lee (and the two funniest novels ever written about Stockport), wonders why no feminist beat him to telling her story.

"I don't think it's an inappropriately modern way of looking at Ann Lee to say that, in making her claims as a woman, she was beginning something that persisted through the next two centuries and helped to change the status of women," he said. "There is a direct cause and effect."

One nice irony is that the cathedral from which Ann was ejected is now often used for the ordination of women.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: I'm very much looking forward to seeing the sensation of the Edinburgh Festival, Puppetry of the Penis, when it opens in London this week.
fields.body:
I'm very much looking forward to seeing the sensation of the Edinburgh Festival, Puppetry of the Penis, when it opens in London this week. But producer David Johnson has run into stiff opposition (I thank you) from some prudish newspaper editors. So far the Daily Telegraph, the Daily Mail and even Rizla Rosie Boycott's thrusting Daily Express have been too unbending to carry an advertisement with the word "penis" in it. Charles Moore, editor of the Torygraph, has had particular problems giving the show access to his columns. "I was told by the advertising department that the editor had given his final decision," says Johnson. "We offered to drop the photograph, but they said the title was the problem. Even the Vagina Monologues didn't have this much trouble." Undeterred by Charles Moore's firm stance, David hopes the show will tour the regions next year. In the meantime there are plenty of tickets for the five-week run at the Whitehall Theatre, on 020 7369 1735.

With the effects of the fuel crisis still being felt, the Home Office has set up a list of essential services getting priority access through the petrol queues. The list is much as you'd expect - police, firefighters, doctors, ice makers _ yes, that's right, ice makers. Category 20 is "manufacture or distribution of ice or dry ice", which comes above prison guards and undertakers on the list. And thank God for that - the crisis would have been unbearable without a decent gin and tonic.

But the crisis did have some dire consequences for residents of Buxton in Derbyshire. A sign posted on the door of the the Queen's Head pub on the High Street warned that beer would be rationed to only 10 pints per customer. Although this may just have been a ploy to keep William Hague away.

Despite his flagging support at home, it's great to know that Tony Blair's winning smile has become an inspiration to the French: "When you cannot brush your teeth," reads the back of the packet, "chew Tonigum." But just like Mr Tony, there's a downside: "Excessive consumption can have laxative effects."

The local police chief in Bochum, Germany, is in trouble with the police union after suggesting that officers should resist shaving their heads in the fashionable David Beckham style - in case they are mistaken for neo-Nazis. The German police union is up in arms over this infringement of their civil liberties, and is threatening to take him to court if he tries to enforce the idea.

For years the Royal Institution has blinkeredly insisted that its prestigious Christmas lecture is given by a highly respected scientist. But in a refreshing change of policy the institution this year has plumped for Professor Kevin Warwick of Reading University - a man who has certainly pushed back the boundaries of science, but in the wrong direction. His sane and rational claim that robots will take over the world and enslave the human race is sadly not borne out by his own research, including a robot to run a half-marathon that broke down after 20 paces. So it looks as if we won't have to submit to our robot overlords just yet - if Kevin is designing them.

There's no room to tell you about what must be one of Las Vegas's most exciting tourist attractions: Cranberry World. Be sure to visit - it's not like there's anything else to do in Las Vegas, after all.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: •In making an award to the Daily Mail for "shameless hypocrisy" in its coverage of royal matters (Diary, Media, page 10, yesterday), we drew attention to the Mail's recent spread to mark the 16th birthday of, we said, Prince William. That was a shameful inaccuracy. Prince Harry's birthday was the one celebrated by the Mail. Prince Harry was 16 on September 15. Prince William is 18. His birthday was on June 21. (Hoist with our own petard? See below.)
fields.body:
In making an award to the Daily Mail for "shameless hypocrisy" in its coverage of royal matters (Diary, Media, page 10, yesterday), we drew attention to the Mail's recent spread to mark the 16th birthday of, we said, Prince William. That was a shameful inaccuracy. Prince Harry's birthday was the one celebrated by the Mail. Prince Harry was 16 on September 15. Prince William is 18. His birthday was on June 21. (Hoist with our own petard? See below.)

We were in error to suggest, page 9, Sport, September 16, that the Manchester listings magazine [City Life] had carried a cover story suggesting that Manchester was ready to take over the 2004 Olympics if Athens failed to prepare in time. The magazine says it has published no such story. The Commonwealth games, referred to in the same piece, are in 2002, not 2003.

Contrary to the suggestion in our Olympic swimming report, page 8, September 16, Alison Sheppard, is no longer a teenager. She swam in the Seoul Olympics in 1988.

Wilson Kipketer, referred to on the front page of Sport, September 16, was an Olympic favourite for the 800 metres, not the 400 metres.

There was a mistake in our clue to 13 across in the quick crossword, page 25, September 16, "Town in Northumberland". The solution was Alston, a town in Cumbria. It used to be in Cumberland.

Alfred Molina, the actor, mentioned in a column in the Guide section, page 17, yesterday, is not Anglo-Italian. He is Anglo-Spanish-Italian. His father was Spanish, his mother Italian, and he was born in England.

English department, from page 8, Weekend, September 16, where we said, "The higher you hoist your petard, the more unequivocal its salute ...", perhaps confusing petard with pennant. The writer is making a distant reference to Shakespeare: Hamlet, III, iv, "...For 'tis sport to have the engineer/ Hoist with his own petard ..." Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase & Fable defines it thus "Beaten with his own weapons, caught in his own trap," and tells us, "The petard was a thick iron engine of war, filled with gunpowder, and fastened to gates, barricades, etc, to blow them up. The danger was lest the engineer who fired the petard should be blown up [into the air = hoist, OED] by the explosion." Petard, probably from the French, péter, break wind.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897.

webTitle: Free-thinkers respond to extra northern exposure

fields.headline: Free-thinkers respond to extra northern exposure
fields.trailText: Jolly nice for the lucky folks up north to get their own edition of the Guardian (Now for the news from Croft, September 18). As a quid pro quo for some of us in the south, could you print cinema listings in G2 for Bournemouth and Poole? We aren't all Telegraph readers down here, you know.
fields.body:
Jolly nice for the lucky folks up north to get their own edition of the Guardian (Now for the news from Croft, September 18). As a quid pro quo for some of us in the south, could you print cinema listings in G2 for Bournemouth and Poole? We aren't all Telegraph readers down here, you know.
Leo Jones
Bournemouth

What have you done to me? Years of post-graduate research down the pan. Your paper's decision to recognise its northern roots has come at a highly inconvenient time for me. The purpose of my work has been to establish that the Guardian rejected its northern heritage. Now look what you have done.

Many readers may not recognise echoes of CP Scott's 80th birthday address in Martin Wainwright's words, but I do. "The paper which has grown up in a great community... in a real sense belongs to it. How else, except in the permanence of that association can it fulfil its duty or repay the benefits and the confidence that it has received."

Welcome back; you may well be about to undermine my conclusion that the loss of the word Manchester from the masthead was of massive cultural significance, but the sight of the Guardian North yesterday morning provided a small frisson of pleasure.
Tessa Hindle
Lytham St. Annes, Lancs w.hindle@btinternet.com

I cannot see how you can claim that Guardian North will "give the north a fair hearing by the nation" as only those in the north will see those articles. I buy what I had thought was a national newspaper to get a wide perspective. I am interested in news and comment from across the whole of Europe and beyond. If I wanted to buy a parochial newspaper I would do so.
John Kirby
Chesterfield, Derbyshire john.kirby@breathemail.net

It appears that I am about to be discriminated against by being excluded from northern news. Is there any way in which I can stipulate delivery of Guardian North to St Albans or is there going to be a new north-south dividing line. Will there be a short résumé of material which is included in the north version so that I can access it via the internet, or do you have no thoughts on this unwelcome deprivation?.
Jack Hill
St Albans

After a week in which regional bias was highlighted again in government and the media, as the south watched the north run on empty, the last thing that we need is a split in one of the few nationals that actually deserves the name. We want to know about world news, national news and regional news in one publication - a feat you have managed well until now.

I would love to see the Manchester Guardian back on the streets again, but I would like to be able to buy it in Camden and Cardiff, as well as in Chorlton.
Pete Simpson
Manchester

fields.headline: How to save the planet
fields.trailText: James Lovelock's argument that nuclear power could save the planet breaks welcome new ground (The whole world in our hands, September 16). Whatever the drawbacks of nuclear power, the issue needs to be discussed. It is the only proven large-scale source of CO2-free power, and there is no certainty that another will be ready in time to mitigate the effects of man-made climate change.
fields.body:
James Lovelock's argument that nuclear power could save the planet breaks welcome new ground (The whole world in our hands, September 16). Whatever the drawbacks of nuclear power, the issue needs to be discussed. It is the only proven large-scale source of CO2-free power, and there is no certainty that another will be ready in time to mitigate the effects of man-made climate change.

The Kyoto protocol programme to reduce emissions by developed countries is under strain, and in any case addresses itself to the optimistic end of forecasts of the speed and severity of global warming. No wonder, given public attitudes to curbing energy use - look at the events of last week. If the other developed countries had followed the French route - 75% nuclear-generated electricity - the numbers would look very different.

The environmental movement has savaged the nuclear establishment, sometimes with just cause. The picture would be transformed if the criticism could turn positive, and the environmentalists could get together with the nuclear industry to look for solutions to the problems of nuclear safety and waste disposal, which are not insuperable. As Lovelock says, the future of the planet may depend on it.
MR Morland
London martinr@morlandm.freeserve.co.uk

Has James Lovelock really checked his calculations? He chooses 2050 as the year by which baking humanity will look back and curse those "damn" Greens who prevented a universal nuclear economy from coming into being. But by 2050 there may well be 10bn people on the planet: at 1 kilowatt per head of installed electric power (the present norm in western Europe), such a programme would require 10,000 widely distributed nuclear power stations; stable non-seismic ground for each of them; stable human societies to manage them; and hundreds of stable waste-repositories on sites somewhat more secure than Mr Lovelock's Devonshire garden. The front-end problems of uranium mining and its wastes, and the tail-end problems posed by the inevitable production of plutonium, would almost certainly be beyond technical and political solution.

Moreover, even if Mr Lovelock's nuclear electricity supply scheme should come safely into being, he still offers no answer to the other, greater, need for fuel for agriculture, homes, industry and transport.

He should think again, pausing perhaps to consider the case for renewably generated hydrogen, which could answer all our needs, at very little risk and with negligible global warming potential.
Mike Koefman
Manchester mike@koefman.u-net.com

James Lovelock is wrong about radioactive pollution. Chernobyl did not kill only a few firemen. The thyroid cancer increase is well known, but the accident was also followed by depressed fertility and a sharp peak in infant leukaemia observed in Greece, Germany, Scotland, Wales and the US.

This cannot be explained by conventional radiation risk models but, as a scientific meeting in London next month will consider, "...the adequacy of accepted theories is increasingly questioned". Nuclear power always entails radioactive emissions. Animals, as Lovelock blithely says, don't know or care about shortened lifespans, and natural selection will "take care of mutations" but people will not accept these costs.
Richard Bramhall
Low Level Radiation Campaign bramhall@llrc.org

fields.headline: For the love of Paula
fields.trailText: I was very glad to read Muriel Gray's appreciation of Paula Yates ('I wish she had been better loved', September 18), as so much which has been said and written since her death has been inaccurate and hypocritical.
fields.body:
I was very glad to read Muriel Gray's appreciation of Paula Yates ('I wish she had been better loved', September 18), as so much which has been said and written since her death has been inaccurate and hypocritical.

It is clear to anyone with an open mind and half a brain that Paula was a great deal more than a fluffy blonde with an entertainingly tragic life. It is so easy to judge people when they are struggling and not adhering to the public perception of dignified grieving.

As for Paula's children, the press should do them a favour and stop calling them "tragic". What they need now is love, support and privacy, not labels from amateur psychologists.

I liked what I saw of Paula. Like Muriel, I wish she had found what she was looking for and had been able to hang on to it.
Sally Beggs
London

The choice of front-page photograph to accompany your report on the death of Paula Yates demonstrated a lack of taste and respect. Most of us understand how bodies are removed. A picture of a body bag hardly adds to the sum of human knowledge.
Tony Parker
Burley in Wharfedale, West Yorkshire

fields.headline: Mud sticks
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey (Earth works, September 11) commends the innovative mud walls of a new building at the Machynlleth Centre for Alternative Technology. Pat Borer, one of the architects, laments the need to protect the new walls with glass and timber because, as your caption states, it is "one thing to build with mud in the heat of Africa, but wet old Wales?"
fields.body:
Jonathan Glancey (Earth works, September 11) commends the innovative mud walls of a new building at the Machynlleth Centre for Alternative Technology. Pat Borer, one of the architects, laments the need to protect the new walls with glass and timber because, as your caption states, it is "one thing to build with mud in the heat of Africa, but wet old Wales?"

In fact mud cottages were once common in Wales. Iorwerth Peate's The Welsh House, published in 1940, describes houses still standing from Anglesey to Pembrokeshire, mud being a cheap and durable material. Mud cottages can still be seen in Dyfed and in the Llyn peninsula. One such, at Bryncroes in Llyn, was inhabited until the 1950s and its mud gable end resists the elements to this day. This is a tribute to its durability as a building material in a climate renowned for rain.

Glancey also mentions Clough Williams-Ellis's "fantasy village of Portmeirion". After the first world war, Williams-Ellis explored the practicalities of building cheap homes for heroes. The material of choice was rammed earth.
Linda Adams
Cowbridge, S Glamorgan

webTitle: That's not art, it's simply Garbage

fields.headline: That's not art, it's simply Garbage
fields.trailText: You report on the posting of illegal MP3s on the internet (Net takes safety away from CDs, September 18) and different musicians' responses to the problem. While I have every sympathy for those whose work is being stolen, that sympathy rapidly diminishes when someone you cite, Shirley Manson of Garbage, refers to her work as "art".
fields.body:
You report on the posting of illegal MP3s on the internet (Net takes safety away from CDs, September 18) and different musicians' responses to the problem. While I have every sympathy for those whose work is being stolen, that sympathy rapidly diminishes when someone you cite, Shirley Manson of Garbage, refers to her work as "art".

Mozart's music is art. Miles Davis's music is art. The Beatles' music is art. Even the Sex Pistols' music, closely tied to the social climate around it, the clothes and graphic design, results in a package that may be described as art. Shirley Manson's music is not art. It is a disposable entertainment with little impact, even within the music buying fraternity. While our cultural heritage would be impoverished by the absence of Mozart, Miles, the Fabs or the Pistols, we would not be impoverished by the non-existence of Garbage records. fields.headline: Dome's troubleshooter is Tory donor
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: David James, the troubleshooter brought in to save the Millennium Dome, yesterday admitted to being a long-term donor to the Conservative party.
fields.body:
David James, the troubleshooter brought in to save the Millennium Dome, yesterday admitted to being a long-term donor to the Conservative party.

The "company doctor", appointed a fortnight ago after the dome was bailed out with an extra £47m of lottery cash, revealed that he contributed £10,000 a year to the party.

Mr James, 61, who is trying to find another buyer for the failing attraction after the Japanese bank Nomura withdrew its £105m bid, volunteered the information about his political links. He insisted it had no bearing on his new job.

"I give about £10,000 a year to the Conservatives and have done for some years," he said. "But I regard this as a completely non-political project. It's just another case for me to attend to and sort out the commercial implications."

William Hague, the Tory leader, sees Labour's handling of the dome as one of his strongest cards and has repeatedly called for it to be shut down, and for the minister responsible, Lord Falconer, to be sacked.

The revelation comes as the leaked PricewaterhouseCoopers report into the dome's finances made it clear that the New Millennium Experience Company had traded while technically insolvent in July.

But Mr James said the dome's directors, who include Lord Falconer, did nothing wrong by continuing to trade and should not be prosecuted. "The 1986 Insolvency Act places a very heavy obligation on directors to trade while insolvent if they believe there's a prospect they can correct that insolvency by introducing new funds." The £47m had corrected the insolvency, he said.

fields.headline: RUC task at Omagh 'was impossible'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Omagh's senior police chief yesterday made an impassioned defence of the RUC's actions as it struggled to clear the centre of the Co Tyrone town when the first of three confused warning calls came less than half an hour before the car bomb blast which killed 29 people.
fields.body:
Omagh's senior police chief yesterday made an impassioned defence of the RUC's actions as it struggled to clear the centre of the Co Tyrone town when the first of three confused warning calls came less than half an hour before the car bomb blast which killed 29 people.

As the inquest into the August 1998 atrocity again heard terrible details of the aftermath of the explosion, Superintendent William Baxter said only the Real IRA, which planted the 500lb car bomb, could have saved any of the victims.

He revealed there had since been 68 hoax bomb alerts in the town.

The last was last Wednesday, when Martha Pope, the same codeword used in the worst massacre of Northern Ireland's conflict, was given.

It had taken officers 42 minutes to clear the town centre last week. They had only 29 minutes to do so two years ago, and the inquest has heard there was confusion about the location of the device, leading officers mistakenly to shepherd people towards it.

Supt Baxter told the inquest: "The only people who could have made any difference were those who planted that car bomb and who made the phone calls relating to it.

"They had the power to say that the bomb was outside Kells's shop in Market Street. They had the power to give the colour of the car, the make and the registration number, but they didn't do that.

"Every one of my officers put their lives at risk to protect this community. But unfortunately it was not to be. The bombers planted their device on the busiest shopping day of the year. The persons who planted this bomb got out of the car and saw women and children on the street and they walked away. They did absolutely nothing to try to prevent people being murdered that day."

Supt Baxter, calling it impossible to check 180 shops, 150 cars, and hundreds of shoppers, in 29 minutes, said the RUC had a code of practice.

But he told Michael Mansfield QC, representing one family, there were no specific procedures for evacuating Omagh.

He said: "I would not give rigid orders to my officers. Terrorists have often planted secondary devices to catch out police officers. If I told my men exactly where they should be every time there was a bomb warning, I could be directing them to their deaths."

An army doctor earlier told the inquest how a medic with him collapsed when he turned over the body of a heavily pregnant woman, only to find her 18-month-old daughter dead underneath.

Samuel Potter told of the unnamed colleague's reaction as he moved Avril Monaghan, 30, pregnant with twin girls, only to find baby Maura underneath. Mrs Monaghan's mother, Mary Grimes, 65, was also among the 29 victims of the Real IRA bomb.

Captain Potter told coroner John Leckey: "I turned the body of the mother over and found the baby. It is totally burned into my memory for ever. It was so shocking that the medic with me collapsed."

Captain Potter said the mother and her baby, one of her four children, were found on the street outside the remains of Kells's drapery shop.

A police officer had earlier suggested the mother and her baby were elsewhere and apart. But Mr Leckey said he was confident after hearing from Captain Potter that his was the correct version.

Under questioning from Barry Fox, for the Monaghan family, Captain Potter described the child he found with Mrs Monaghan as between 15 to 20 months old, and partially clothed.

Mr Fox said: "That is very important because, obviously, the child died with her mother. It is important for the relatives of those killed to know where their loved ones were exactly."

Captain Potter earlier told the inquest he had pronounced life extinct on 20 bodies and one body part at the scene of the explosion over a 40-minute period.

Asked how he came to his findings, Captain Potter said: "I was looking for bodies with injuries that were survivable and obviously if a body had no head, then I didn't check for signs of life."

Robert Bonar, 63, told how he had seen the Monaghans "badly mutilated and covered in muck and debris". He had searched for survivors for more than an hour after the blast.

Mr Bonar said: "I saw one young girl about 14 to 15 sitting on the ground holding the hand of one of the dead girls." When he asked her what she was doing, she had replied: "I'm just holding her hand."

The inquest continues.
