fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: I Am A Fugitive From A Chain Gang | Beloved | The Hit | Trespass
fields.body:
I Am A Fugitive From A Chain Gang
(Mervyn LeRoy, 1932)
9pm, TCM

A classic Warner Bros social conscience-stirrer. Paul Muni stars as the innocent man sentenced to 10 years' well-hard labour on a southern prison farm, and the daily brutalities of the chain gang are faithfully recorded (LeRoy shifted out of the studio to shoot the rock-breaking sequences in a disused quarry). When Muni finally tires of the beatings he blasts his way to brief freedom; but, unusually, the movie stays tough to the bitter end.

Beloved
(Jonathan Demme, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

Demme's ghost story has a malignant spirit on the rampage and a violent, brooding atmosphere: but the real horror is the spectre of slavery in the post-Civil War south. Oprah Winfrey, who co- produced with Demme, also stars in this decent attempt to translate the bitter poetry of Toni Morrison's novel to the screen. Her Sethe is a former slave haunted by a murder; and if her sorrow grows wearisome over nearly three hours, there are affecting performances from Danny Glover, Kimberly Elise and Thandie Newton.

The Hit
(Stephen Frears, 1984)
1.40am, FilmFour

A classy Brit gangster film crossed with a touch of Buñuel. Two hitmen - John Hurt as Braddock and Tim Roth's Myron - are in Spain to kill Terence Stamp's Willie Parker; the grass whose singing sent a gang of hoods down a decade before. It's the perfect Stamp role: part cockney hardnut, part zen philosopher, he's been expecting the hit for years. Sharply clever, with bursts of serious GBH: just watch Myron's mayhem at the bar.

Trespass
(Walter Hill, 1992)
3.15am, Sky Cinema

Firefighting buddies Bill Paxton and William Sadler stumble on a map marking treasure buried in a factory inhabited by Ice T and Ice Cube's drug- hustling killers: easy enough to get in, much harder getting out with the loot. A Ry Cooder soundtrack pumps up the highly combustible action.

fields.headline: Railtrack 'behind on new safety system'
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack's installation of a new train safety system, ordered by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, after the Paddington rail disaster last October, is already falling behind schedule, a public inquiry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Railtrack's installation of a new train safety system, ordered by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, after the Paddington rail disaster last October, is already falling behind schedule, a public inquiry was told yesterday.

More than 700 key signals controlling track junctions should have been fitted with the train warning protection system (TPWS), but only 550 have been completed. The system is designed to stop a train if it passes a signal at red.

Ian Burnett QC, counsel to the inquiry into railway safety, said the latest reports showed that "the accelerated timetable agreed at the end of last year is not being met".

He said: "Whether the slippage is yet sufficient to compromise the accelerated timetable is not clear."

Mr Burnett also told yesterday's opening session of the inquiry that a further 100 passengers would be killed in the next 24 years due to the same errors which triggered the Paddington and Southall crashes in west London.

Railtrack agreed later that the £400m installation programme, to which it has committed £370m, had fallen behind. But it would soon begin to make up the difference and fit 11,000 signals by the end of 2002.

Critics of Railtrack say that its programme is far too ambitious and that it is beginning to admit privately that it cannot keep to this schedule. The fitting may take at least a further three years.

Health and safety executive officials say they are also concerned at Railtrack's slow progress, although they are prepared to wait and see if the fitting of TPWS can be stepped up. The HSE would not hesitate to use statutory powers to enforce the timetable.

The system has been strongly criticised as a cheap alternative, and not very effective for trains travelling at more than 70mph.

Before the inquiry began yesterday, survivors and relatives from both the Paddington and Southall train crashes, in which a total of 38 people died, called for TPWS to be scrapped and replaced with the more efficient, but much more expensive Automatic Train Protection.

Implementation of ATP, which would stop any train at any speed if it passed through a signal at danger, was abandoned by the last government because it would have cost £700m. At today's prices, it would cost almost £2bn, and both the government and the rail industry are hesitant about it.

Louise Christian of the Southall and Ladbroke Grove solicitors' group, which represents a large proportion of those killed in both rail crashes, said: "We will not put up with a second-rate system. Nobody is going to understand when there is another crash and it is learned that ATP was not fitted."

Comparing ATP with TPWS was like comparing a "computer with a manual typewriter. ATP is in operation throughout Europe. Why should we be saddled with a system which is not failsafe?"

The rail unions want the government to back the introduction of ATP but were overruled by Mr Prescott at the Labour national forum and may be banned from speaking on the issue at next week's party conference.

Yesterday's joint inquiry is being chaired by Lord Cullen and Professor John Uff, in charge respectively of the two previous public inquiries into Paddington and Southall. A report will be published early next year.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Aid workers released
fields.body:
Aid workers released

The British aid worker Jonathan Ward, 31, who was kidnapped during a bungled armed robbery at the headquarters of the charity Action Against Hunger in the Somali capital Mogadishu in July was freed yesterday, the Foreign Office has said.

He was handed over with the French charity administrator Francoise Deutsch, 46 who was seized in the same raid. No ransom was paid.

Olympic torch auction on net

The torch from the 1936 Olympics in Berlin - the first games to be opened by relay runners carrying the torch from Olympia in Greece - is expected to fetch around £2,500 at a Sotheby's online auction. Proceeds will benefit Scope, the cerebral palsy charity.

Couple jailed for smuggling

A couple made 77 smuggling trips across the Channel within two years for cheap tobacco and alcohol, Exeter crown court heard yesterday. Peter Jewell, 40 and Caroline Quick of Barnstaple, Devon, who had evaded £150,000 in duty, were jailed for 18 months and six months.

Man charged over death

A restaurant worker has been charged with killing a British tourist, Wendy Sullivan, 25, of Winsford, Cheshire, whose body was found in a forest on Rhodes. Ukranian Denis Pavelenko was also charged with attempted rape.

Mystery illness kills donkeys

Vets are trying to discover why a mystery disease has killed five donkeys in the Bramshaw area of the New Forest. Other donkeys have been taken ill. Sue Westwood, clerk to the verderers, said: "We've got to establish whether it's a problem that's likely to grow."

Public lose faith in police

More than two-thirds of the public have no faith in police protecting their homes, catching burglars or recovering stolen goods, says a survey for the Home Security and Safety Week.

Asda pays extra 2p for milk

Asda is to pay farmers 2p per litre more for milk and promised the increase would not affect the price to consumers. The National Farmers' Union warned that one retailer alone could not reverse the fortunes of dairy farmers.

Olive oil protects against cancer

Olive oil is a greater protection against bowel cancer than fruit and vegetables, according to a study in the Journal of Epidemiology and Public Health. It finds that cancer rates are higher in countries with high meat or meat and fish consumption.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The New Peacemakers | Don't Rain On My Parade - The Jule Styne Story
fields.body:
The Angolan civil war has been going on for 25 years in spite of a massive United Nations intervention. The use of the country's vast mineral resources to meet the cost of the war has reduced the average monthly income from $400 to 70 cents. President Dos Santos funds his forces through oil revenues and Jonas Savimbi's rebels rely on illegal diamond sales. In The New Peacemakers (8pm, Radio 4) Edward Stourton investigates the International Monetary Fund's moves to achieve peace by controlling both sides' income.

At 12 he was told his hands were too small to make a great concert pianist. Stephen Sondheim said he looked like an accountant. It's no wonder Don Black's biographical series is entitled Don't Rain On My Parade - The Jule Styne Story (10pm, Radio 4). Yet adversity never seemed to bother Styne as he turned out a vast string of hit songs, including Everything's Coming Up Roses and Three Coins In The Fountain.

webTitle: Tired drivers as risky as drinkers

fields.headline: Tired drivers as risky as drinkers
fields.trailText: Sleep-deprived drivers are less alert than those who have drunk more than the legal limit of alcohol, according to new research.
fields.body:
Sleep-deprived drivers are less alert than those who have drunk more than the legal limit of alcohol, according to new research.

A study published today in the journal Occupational and Environmental Medicine found that fatigue can reach dangerous levels at a much earlier stage than has been assumed.

The authors, from Australia and New Zealand, tested responses of 39 volunteers after sleep deprivation and after drinking alcohol equivalent to the legal driving limit in Scandinavia.

They found that those who had been up since 6am performed worse in tests between 10.30pm and midnight than those who were tested in the morning with 50mg of alcohol in their bloodstream (the UK limit is 80mg).

The researchers suggest that countries which set drink-driving limits should consider setting restrictions to prevent people who have been awake for more than 18 hours from driving, piloting aircraft, or operating machinery. Tiredness is estimated to play a part in between 16% and 60% of road accidents in the United States, they say, but few attempts have been made to work out at what point in the day or night that tiredness reaches serious levels.

"The implications of fatigue for safe performance are well recognised particularly in road safety, but in other settings as well," write Andrew Williamson of the School of Psychology, University of New South Wales, and Anne-Marie Feyer from the University of Otago, Dunedin.

The volunteers - lorry drivers and members of the transport corps of the Australian army - were put through tests to measure thinking speed and physical reactions, coordination and attention span. They carried out the tests after a day and night of wakefulness and after drinking alcohol.

The researchers found that commonly experienced levels of sleep deprivation - staying awake for 17 to 19 hours - depressed performance in the same way as drinking a couple of glasses of alcohol.

The volunteers - lorry drivers and members of the transport corps of the Australian army - were put through tests to measure thinking speed and physical reactions, coordination and attention span. They carried out the tests after a day and night of wakefulness and after drinking alcohol. The researchers found that commonly experienced levels of sleep deprivation - staying awake for 17 to 19 hours - depressed performance in the same way as drinking a couple of glasses of alcohol.

fields.headline: Squaring up
fields.trailText: EastEnders | Faking It | The Cops
fields.body:
"Ain't it grand to be blooming well dead"

    Music-hall song

The EastEnders (BBC 1) undertaker showed great resilience during the petrol crisis by using a couple of black horses with feathers in their heads to pull Ethel's hearse. (As the long wreath passed, you noticed Ethel was an anagram of Lethe.) The solemnity of her departure was slightly undermined by the simultaneous arrival of a white van containing the Slaters, a family calculated to lower the tone of any funeral.

The Slaters' built-in bounce was timely, as the regulars were looking deflated. Dot was quoting the more dyspeptic prophets ("There shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth"), Frank was bemoaning his blighted life ("I was young once") and you'd be looking at Eddie Skinner for some time before you were reminded of a ray of sunshine ("It makes you wonder who's going to be next.")

The Slater matriarch is Mo ("Wot you gawping at? Naff off!") According to Pat, Mo's so rough you could scratch the bottom of a Thames barge with her. According to Mo, Pat has walked more streets than PC Plod. They are, you will have spotted, acquainted. Ethel would have enjoyed the collision. Which is one argument against euthanasia. You never know when entertainment is going to turn up in a white van.

Faking It (Channel 4) was a tacky idea redeemed by the fundamental decency and genuineness of the people taking part. Alex Geikie (pronounced geeky) had a month to try and pass muster as a night-club bouncer. He was short, slight, sheltered, county and gay. His boyfriend, Clinton, was a nurse. That seemed likely to come in handy. His father was apprehensive. "How do you get on with, sort of, the coloured community?" Alex had not met any.

He arrived in Hackney by taxi. "My God! A launderette. I don't think I've ever seen a launderette. There's a mattress, a mattress on the pavement!" He was staying with Tony Agastini, a kick-boxing champion, on the 15th floor of a tower block. Tony said, "'Ello my son. Welcome!" Secretly, he was not sanguine. "If someone comes in from the country and 'e talks a bit funny, locals pick up on that. They think, "'Ello, victim!' Bottom line is, 'e should not stand aht. They won't 'esitate to kick 'is 'ead in."

The best way to stop your head being kicked in is to shave your hair off. That done, Alex looked like one of those small, bald aliens who used to turn up in Star Trek wearing nighties.

He knew how Caesar conquered Gaul and how to whack a cricket ball but not how to chuck out a drunk. "I've done a lot of rowing." "That'll be 'andy" said Tony drily. "You can 'it 'em with the oars." A kick-boxing bout with Tony's girlfriend, Bernice, did not impress the bookies. "'E's lucky to 'ave 'is testicles."

At RADA, Alex was coached in talking common. "The word fuck is desperately important to all Londoners. Fuck you, fuck me, fuck off! Lengthen the vowel. Let the breath be the impetus. Farkin' 'ell! Don't smile! Mean it." In grammar: "I was, you was, she was, they was." And deportment: "Think monkey."

After a month's training, Alex was one of several bouncers at the Hippodrome on the night of the England v Germany match and the head of security failed to spot the imposter ("Nah! Honestly?") Tony was much moved. "It's like seeing your kid walk and talk for the first time, innit? Very proud. Very proud. But he should be proud of himself too."

The kid, waving goodbye at Paddington, said "I'm not going to cry, because I'm a hard doorman. Five weeks ago I'd have cried because I made good mates here. Very, very, very good mates indeed. I feel very, very deeply moved and privileged to have come across such kind and generous people. Generous with their hospitality and their acceptance of me. I've been completely overwhelmed by it and I'm going to keep in contact with absolutely everybody." You liked the whole farking lot of them.

The Cops (BBC 2) is brilliant drama pretending to be documentary. The camerawork looks epileptic, the dialogue sounds improvised, the acting is extraordinarily ordinary. It makes you work. I follow it like an eager dog, nose turning this way and that, not catching every word. But quivering.

webTitle: G2: Who's in town and why

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Boys who like boys who like...
On Monday, Dennis Cooper will be at Horse Hospital, Colonnade, WC1 plugging his new book, Period. Who? you might just be asking, unless your taste in literature runs to drug-addled, S&M-packed, serial killer-drenched glibly amoral queerlit pitched somewhere between Bret Easton Ellis and Burroughs, and obsessed with late 80s noisepop. In which case, Cooper must be the only author you read. Anyway, Cooper's presence in London is intriguing because his last book, Guide, featured lurid fantasies about (resolutely straight) Blur bassist and occasional Soho barperson Alex James. Which means it would be worth popping along to the reading just in case Alex, whose escalating weight is surely compromising his status as a gay lust-object anyway, decides to make an appearance.

Gross international product...
When your once pioneering brand of stomach-churning cinema has been crudely trumped by pretty much everyone in sight, then perhaps the only thing to do is retreat to the far side of Offa's Dyke. At least, that's one explanation of why Bobby and Peter Farrelly, along with their stars (and paparazzi-magnet celebrity couple) Jim Carrey (pictured) and Renée Zellweger, are making the long slog to Rhyl this Wednesday for the British premiere of the funny-in-places Me, Myself & Irene.

It's your twang...
Yes sir, that mighty grizzled giant of surf guitar Dick Dale is in town. Dale, you might recall, was briefly lifted from two and half decades of obscurity when the then hegemonic Quentin Tarantino used his track Miserlou for the opening credits of Pulp Fiction. But a more venerable advocate of Dale's thunderous riffing has always been John Peel, which is why Dick is here to play for a Peel Session Live at the Royal Festival Hall on Friday, alongside (who else?) The Fall. And that's this week's fun in the bag.

webTitle: Arts: radical political art at the Whitechapel Gallery

fields.headline: Squeaks of protest
fields.standfirst: The Whitechapel Gallery is supposed to be hosting a show of radical political art. It will take a lot more to drive  Jonathan Jones  to the barricades
fields.trailText: The Whitechapel Gallery is supposed to be hosting a show of radical political art. It will take a lot more to drive Jonathan Jones to the barricades
fields.body:
For those too young to remember, "protest and survive" was a slogan that peace campaigners adopted in the 1980s, after the Thatcher government published an absurd pamphlet entitled Protect and Survive advising what to do in a nuclear attack. It was the historian and activist EP Thompson who coined the pun, I seem to remember, for a book of political essays. Protest and Survive is also the title of a new show at London's Whitechapel Gallery about history and its use; the curators say they want to recover "the political voice that is forever glossed over" in art from the 1960s to today.

Thompson was a romantic British socialist, a student of both Marx and William Morris, who argued in books such as The Making of the English Working Class that popular actions in the past, from bread riots to the poetry of William Blake, can be understood as expressions of a common culture of protest. Thompson was trying to find a common thread in the disparate strands of radicalism; in his day this meant finding a link between CND and the working class. In our day it means finding coherence in the diverse protest movements against the global economy. And in this exhibition it means trying to tie together threads of disparate fury in the art of the past 30 years.

So what are they protesting against? What have you got? There's everything here: Gustav Metzger attacking the global economy with his proposal for a monument to the environment composed of rank upon rank of cars, and cartoonist Robert Thompson's flat-capped northerner telling his son as they contemplate smoking factories, "One day son, all this will be art galleries." Then there's 1970s conceptual artist Cosi Fanni Tutti hiring herself out as a model and stripshow dancer in protest against... something, and the Conspiracy Paintings of David MacDermott and Peter MacGough, attacking abstract expressionism as a CIA front and fingering Aids as "a manipulation of information for purposes of genocide and control, using street drugs and pharmaceuticals to murder and steal property".

This is a raggle-taggle collection of relics, featuring an ill-assorted army of 1970s hippies and skinheads. Whatever it was that made the Austrian artist Valie Export lie motionless in the street in 1972, I'm against it. I'll sign a petition against it. Just don't make me look at any more art relics. There's right-wing protest too, with Gilbert and George's picture of a bomber-jacketed Cocky Patriot (1980) standing between two union flags sewn on the buttocks of a pair of jeans. The homoeroticism complicates the far-right politics - but not enough for my liking. Gilbert and George have become so revered as godfathers of the new British art that young artists and curators now think they can see through their explicit hard right affinities to what they imagine is a core of queer radicalism. But G+G are flamboyantly, unrepentantly right-wing. At a recent public appearance at Tate Modern they confirmed that not only do they still love Margaret Thatcher, "we even like William Hague".

What is missing from most of this art is analysis. Protest - what does that mean? It can be utterly incoherent and reactionary. "No Derv for Paediatrician Pervs", "We Want Something or Other and We Want it Now!" as the placards said in Steve Bell's cartoon on the fuel protest in last Thursday's Guardian. Karl Marx pointed out a long time ago that radical romanticism is a waste of time: if you want to change the world, you must first understand it.

The best art here attempts to do that. Richard Hamilton's Treatment Room (1984) is an NHS operating theatre with creepy white and military green walls. There's a sink for the professionals to wash their hands after administering treatment. They work at a glass-windowed booth, flicking switches and watching the dials on an electronic control panel. The patient lies on a thin mattress and looks up at a screen with images of Margaret Thatcher speaking.

This is a great political work of art because it is witty and does more than protest. Hamilton is an ironist with an acute feeling for history. He loves technology, and even in this study in terror there's a perverse enjoyment. As in his famous collage, Just What Is It That Makes Today's Homes So Different, So Appealing? (1956) - made as a poster for the exhibition This Is Tomorrow at this same gallery almost half a century ago - Hamilton uses an interior as an image of modern life. It is a room that exerts power over anyone who enters it. We are helpless before this historical juggernaut. In the end, we all submit to the treatment.

However, while Treatment Room lingers in the mind, much of the art here doesn't. The style of the exhibition is deliberately anti-aesthetic. In a reaction against glitzy contemporary art shows, this one sets out to make you think. So you have to read a lot of words. The conceptual artist Steven Willats's contributions - early 1980s text and archive pieces in which witnesses describe post-punk subcultures - are mostly words. Only when you get to the end of his texts do you realise they weren't worth reading. Jo Spence's remodellings of photo history and medical history were also done largely in words. This is in the tradition of conceptual art, which was born in the late 1960s out of a suspicion of the image: artists who wanted to attack capitalism believed words were more honest than pictures. They thought they were continuing the Dadaist anti-art tradition, but the Dadaists discovered that images could be a form of political power: some of the most powerful images of the 20th century are German Dadaist John Heartfield's anti-Nazi photomontages. I wanted something like that here, something to bite into memory.

Protest and Survive identifies politics in contemporary art with a suspicion of the aesthetic. This reflects the mood of young art in London. Artists and curators emerging in the wake of the Hirst generation are wary of making shiny, visually striking things to go in galleries. They see themselves as infinitely more serious. Politics is suddenly a word to conjure with. Artists want to be conceptual Marxists, like the 1970s group Art&Language.

But art is a symbolic practice. Artists create images, and images have political meanings - ones the artist might not predict. The most potent political works of the past few decades - like the great political art of the past from Goya to Guernica - deploy devastating images. This show could have included Andy Warhol's electric chairs, Ed Keinholz's Portable War Memorial, Chris Burden's Shoot, Joseph Beuys' Tramstop.

Instead we get art whose sense of its own impotence cannot be concealed. Giorgio Sadotti's installation One...Two... (1993), consisting of a set of drums, guitars and amplifiers apparently just left by a band rehearsing in a garage, is melancholic. The catalogue links it to anarcho-skinhead writer Stewart Home's definition of revolution as "one, two, three, four" and it seems intended as an image of action. But it doesn't feel like that: it feels feeble, leftover, marginal. On the wall nearby is a painting by art collective Bank of a dismal factory landscape modelled on LS Lowry. "Would you be worried if one of these northerners ceased to exist?" asks a poster with the same Lowry stick figures. This is a pretty good joke. But it smacks of what political activists used to call defeatism.

I think we are approaching the core of the exhibition's oddness. One of the curators is Matthew Higgs, founder at the age of 14 of a fanzine for Joy Division, a band not noted for their revolutionary optimism. The other is Paul Noble, inventor of Nobson Newtown, a scary imaginary town whose Nobslums and Nobjobclub he draws with meticulous despair. What a pair of miseries. This exhibition claims to revive the art of protest, but it is really an act of mourning. The problem with all the disjointed protests it brings together is that you never feel they are tangible or present. They happened; we pore over the relics.

The curators should have read their EP Thompson. For Thompson there is no future without art. Culture is not the enemy; it is what we need to give us common purpose and strength. Symbols, narratives and argument are the resources Thompson believed were necessary if we were to protest and survive. This exhibition distrusts symbols, repudiates narrative. It contrasts unfavourably with the exhibition that beat all these new political art shows to it and did it better - Unconvention, curated by the artist Jeremy Deller last year at Cardiff's Centre for the Visual Arts (which, incidentally, has just been closed down by Cardiff's city council).

Unconvention had an infectious enthusiasm to it, and a belief in art, culture and the human spirit, whether expressed in pop music, Jackson Pollock (both were in the show), or activism. It made you hopeful. Deller's contribution to Protest and Survive is funny and poignant, too: he shows a series of snapshots of Bozo the Clown, a middle-aged man in full clown makeup, wandering round the futuristic exhibits at Hanover's Expo 2000. The piece is called Has the World Changed, or Have I Changed?

However, the real star of Protest and Survive is the Turner-shortlisted photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, who saves the show which he publicised as guest editor of the Big Issue. At the far end of the highest gallery at the Whitechapel he is given a long wall to create one of his free, collagistic installations of his own pictures mixed up with news headlines, magazine pictures and other stuff. Tillmans is anything but a conceptual artist. He's relaxed with making images, seeming to chance on them without thinking. And yet his montage of momentary glimpses of things, from rock festival crowds to an operating theatre to young soldiers, adds up to an image of living today, trying to protest and survive. It's poetic rather than rational, and all the better for it. At the centre of Tillmans's installation is a huge blown-up colour image of a sandcastle whose foundations are being lapped by the sea. A beautiful green wave flows towards the already tottering turrets. It makes you think of walls crashing down.

 Protest and Survive is at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1 (020-7522 7878), till November 12.

It's poetic rather than rational, and all the better for it. At the centre of Tillmans's installation is a huge blown-up colour image of a sandcastle whose foundations are being lapped by the sea. A beautiful green wave flows towards the already tottering turrets. It makes you think of walls crashing down.  Protest and Survive is at the Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1 (020-7522 7878), till November 12.

webTitle: Arts: Robert Lindsay is starring in his first sitcom since Citizen Smith

fields.headline: Popular front
fields.standfirst: Robert Lindsay is starring in his first sitcom since Citizen Smith. He tells  Michael Billington  why
fields.trailText: Robert Lindsay is starring in his first sitcom since Citizen Smith. He tells Michael Billington why
fields.body:
I rarely watch sitcoms. I was also extremely rude about Robert Lindsay's Richard III two years ago, comparing his performance for the Royal Shakespeare Company to Ken Dodd capering before a Palladium audience. Lindsay was sufficiently irked to go on radio and retaliate, to liken Stratford to a "theme park" and to suggest he would in future forswear the classical stage. So the prospect of meeting him to discuss his new BBC sitcom, My Family, filled me with a certain dread. In the event, he turned out to be an absolute charmer.

Lindsay's theatre career has had some spectacular highs as well as some unforeseen lows. He cut a dash at Manchester's Royal Exchange, not least as Hamlet and D'Artagnan. His three-year stint in Me and My Girl, in the West End and on Broadway, earned him a coveted Tony award; less happily, it led to a disastrous Carl Reiner movie musical, Bert Rigby, You're a Fool, which he claims "was so depressingly awful it almost ruined my life". But on television Lindsay has long been a bankable star, and he has struck up a particularly fruitful association with Alan Bleasdale, starring in GBH, Jake's Progress and, most recently, Oliver Twist.

Why, though, given he is in constant demand, go back to sitcom for the first time since Citizen Smith? Kitted out in naval officer's uniform for a new Hornblower series shooting at Pinewood, Lindsay explained what lured him into six episodes of My Family.

"It all started when Fred Barron, the man behind The Larry Sanders Show and Seinfeld, came to stay over Christmas. I asked him why on earth someone who was a powerhouse of American sitcom should want to do one for the BBC in its decline. Very flatteringly, he said it was because of me: he'd seen me in Me and My Girl and thought I had a great gift for physical comedy.

"I explained why I didn't like British sitcoms - I thought they were caricatured and stereotyped, too quickly rehearsed and over- expansive because of the studio audience. But Fred countered that he wanted to create a real domestic comedy about middle-aged angst and that he'd use the actors' input. We then came up with the idea of Zoe Wanamaker as my partner and I was completely hooked."

What makes My Family unusual is its attempt to apply American expertise to an English situation. The hero, Ben Harper, is a dentist with a tourist-guide wife and three troublesome children ranging in age from 12 to 19; so far, so familiar. But the scripts are the product of a large team headed by Barron himself, an American duo called Steven and James Armogida and an English pair, Ian Brown and James Hendrie. Each episode also takes on a topical issue - from drugs to school bullying - while using the actors' own experiences.

"In sitcom," Lindsay shrewdly observes, "we work from character; Americans work from personality . What Fred does is tailor the script to your qualities. He's not that interested in character. The only given was that Ben should be a dentist because Fred's father was a Boston dentist who smoked during surgery and detested his patients.

"But Fred observes and listens. I told him about an incident this year over my 50th birthday. It went from being a big do at the Ivy to, finally, a small sit-down dinner for 10. I got into a real lather about it but my 13-year-old daughter said, 'For goodness' sake, it's only a party. You're not going to die. Stop over-dramatising.' That kind of attitude - the sane daughter correcting the harebrained father - finds its way into the script."

The personality-driven show is a very American idea, stretching, adventurously, from Larry Sanders and Seinfeld back to the cosier era of Lucille Ball and Mary Tyler Moore. The one English example that comes readily to mind is Hancock's Half Hour. But My Family not only uses the actors' experience - the fact, for instance, that both Lindsay and Wanamaker are guiltily covert smokers - it applies to it the ruthless corporate expertise of American sitcom. The first episode went through 12 different drafts, involving frantic learning and un-learning of lines. "Zoe," says Lindsay, "is very methodical and likes to take her time. I'm the exact opposite: I can have a script and virtually know it by the end of the read-through. But I think the chemistry between us works very well."

Lindsay brims with confidence about the series: he thinks it's the best pre-watershed comedy the BBC has found in years. But he's much more self-critical when it comes to looking at the arc of his own career. Twice he begins a sentence, "If I have a problem..." The first time, it's to say that he's made himself so diverse he can go almost anywhere.The second, it's to suggest he has a split artistic personality: part of him yearns to be taken seriously as a classical actor, another part leans towards comedy and song-and-dance. Actually, it's not a bad problem to have and is perfectly soluble. Thelma Holt has approached him to play Archie Rice in Osborne's The Entertainer, a part that requires both classical discipline and vaudevillian expertise. Lindsay is also developing a project about Morecambe and Wise with the help of the pair's families. It would tap into his instincts as "a bit of a performer".

As for his post-Richard III outburst on radio, he expresses few regrets. "I'd had a terrible first night. There was no rhythm to the show. The set had got stuck at one point. Then I picked up the papers, not least yours, to be told I lacked the necessary demonism. I just vented my spleen. I suppose what I really felt was that I was being used as a commodity, to help bring the coach parties in, rather than as a member of a company. I think I've been forgiven by the RSC, if not by the citizens of Stratford. But, whatever was wrong with the production, we ended up playing nine months in the West End, so in populist terms it worked."

Lindsay bears no visible grudges. He also seems, at 50, justifiably happy with his lot. He lives comfortably in the pretty Buckinghamshire village of Denham, has a 13-year-old daughter by his first partner and a year-old son by his second and can afford to treat his whole family, including his father and sundry siblings, to a summer holiday. If anything still gnaws at him, you feel it is the desire to be taken seriously as a classical actor. If My Family turns into a big hit, it would be good if it bought him time to do a talent-stretching season with one of the national companies. Sitcom requires precise skills and pays the rent. But a great 19th-century critic, GH Lewes, once wrote: "He is greatest who is greatest in the highest reaches of his art." It's a sentiment I recommend to Robert Lindsay and a whole army of British television actors.

 My Family starts tonight at 8.30pm on BBC1.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.body:
 Do you look wondrous in wellies? Then the Countryside Alliance needs you. Campaigners leading the fight to save fox-hunting are apparently seeking a "prettier" image. Supporters are reported to have been emailed the following call to arms: "Youth and Beauty (either or will do) wanted as leaflet distributors." Smart thinking: the prospect of a perter class of animal mangler makes Sidelines rethink its stance on hunting and pretty much every other ethical issue, too.

 Does your partner no longer make you laugh? Do you deliberately not laugh? Perhaps you're suffering from the 14-year itch. New research reveals the divorce rate in the second seven-year period of marriage is three times higher than in the first. Thousands of mid-life marriages are in trouble, says Prof John Gottman. "They are the people you see in a restaurant not talking," he adds. Funny, we assumed people not talking in restaurants were simply waiting for a more attractive person to turn up and convince them of the merits of badger-baiting.

 Norman Tebbit is in a twist about oestrogen. Concerned by reports that otters have been attacking each other and their cubs, he suggests female hormones are to blame. "As more of our drinking water is taken from rivers carrying female hormones," he writes in the Mail on Sunday, "we have to ask not just whether they are causing unnatural behaviour in otters but in humans, too." That'll be the same unnatural behaviour that women, aka Big Bags of Jumping Hormones, have been displaying since time immemorial. Tempted as we are to unravel Mr Tebbit's oestro-phobia, we have an overwhelming impulse to do something bizarre, like the shopping, cooking, childcare...

 Finally, we are thrilled to learn that Australian swimming supremo Ian Thorpe has size 17 feet. You know what they say about men with big feet - they have big hands. Mind you, as our auntie says, all cats look grey in the dark.

webTitle: Milosevic puts Nato leaders on trial

fields.headline: Milosevic puts Nato leaders on trial
fields.standfirst:
Yugoslav leader revives Kosovo war before Sunday's vote

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia began trying western leaders yesterday for their part in the Nato bombing of Yugoslavia last year, accusing them of crimes against humanity and violating the country's territorial sovereignty.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia began trying western leaders yesterday for their part in the Nato bombing of Yugoslavia last year, accusing them of crimes against humanity and violating the country's territorial sovereignty.

The trial is expected to end immediately before Sunday's presidential and general elections with sentences of 15-20 years on Bill Clinton, Tony Blair, the former Nato secretary general Xavier Solana and European commander General Wesley Clarke, among others.

As President Slobodan Milosevic's re-election campaign gathered pace before polling day, his anti-Nato rhetoric found an echo in the trial.

A row of 14 empty chairs was set opposite the panel of judges in Belgrade's palace of justice, each seat labelled with the name of the person charged in absentia.

It took three hours to read the charges accusing them of crimes against humanity, initiating an aggressive war, using illegal weapons such as cluster bombs, and violating the territorial sovereignty of Yugoslavia.

The prosecutor read out the names of 503 civilians, 240 soldiers and 147 police officers whom he said were killed during the bombing.

At the weekend three members of the student-based resistance movement Otpor, were jailed for 10 days for spraying graffiti on walls in the capital.

Their lawyer, Biljana Kajganic, said the trial in the Belgrade police headquarters in was "incorrect" and she would appeal against the verdict.

The latest poll shows Mr Milosevic with 27% and Mr Kostunica with 32% of the vote. But 30% of the electorate have not yet decided or say they will not vote.

In a further sign of jitters, the state newspaper Politika carried a vitriolic attack on the presidential opposition chal lenger Vojislav Kostunica. One analyst in Belgrade said he believed the article, which portrays Mr Kostunica as a serial adulterer and a liar, could sway many voters.

The Nato show trial was dismissed by a western diplomat as "a pre-election stunt". But it plays to a campaign by the Milosevic regime which has exploited the incomprehension and anger felt by many people toward Nato and the west.

State newspapers and television carried long items from the trial and are expected to report vivid testimony and show gruesome pictures of the damage inflicted on civilians.

One of the crimes against civilians with which the western leaders are charged is the bombing of the state television station RTS.

Testimonies were read, including that of a desk editor who spoke of the smell in the building. "I found two men who were completely bloody," he said. "The smell and the smoke was pervasive. I had blood dripping from my legs."

The evidence was accompanied by footage of burned bod ies under collapsed masonry.

The public reaction to the trial will become clear in the coming days.

Zanka Stojanovic, who lost her 26-year-old son Nebojsa in the RTS attack, said she blamed Nato and Mr Milosevic. "We are accusing Nato leaders and domestic politicians as the ones who are responsible for this," she said. "Our people were not good diplomats and to let such a terrible thing happen at the end of the 20th century is a shame for human kind."

But she took no comfort from the trial: "It is a circus theatre. Those people who are behaving as judges and lawyers, those people are clowns, because if they are judging those people who are not here, then they can judge those people who are here."

fields.headline: No: 1723
fields.standfirst: Lady's Slipper Orchid
fields.trailText: Lady's Slipper Orchid
fields.body:
AKA:
Cypripedium calceolus; Britain's rarest wild flower.

How rare exactly?
Even a French chef would be impressed.

What sort of brute would want to destroy such a symbol of innocence and beauty?
It seems those pesky Victorians couldn't keep their plant-collecting fingers off the pretty little flower, and it was declared extinct in 1917.

But on the third day it rose again?
It's not a rose, it's an orchid. Please pay attention.

You know what I mean.
Oh all right. In 1937, a lone Lady's Slipper was found growing in the wild at an undisclosed location in the north of England.

And you're telling me that no stray rambler or rare-orchid collector has felt the urge to pick it during the intervening time?
The lone Lady's Slipper has been in the guardianship of English Nature since its discovery. In the summer months, when it flowers, there has been a round-the-clock watch to protect it from thieving paws.

So what has it been doing for the past 64 years?
Oh, y'know, growing. The Lady's Slipper usually lives for more than 100 years, so it takes its time about these things.

And it didn't feel the urge to "go forth and multiply" at any stage?
Wrong type of bees, apparently. The troops from Kew Gardens were drafted in to do some manual pollination, and a seed was germinated in 1987 and planted in the countryside in 1989.

So what's happened now?
It has flowered.

What? Petals and everything?
Yup.

And how would I recognise this lesser-spotted bloom?
In his book Britain's Wild Flowers, Peter Marren described the flower thus: "A golden clog or slipper held in the grasp of four purple banners... It looks like some archetypal jungle plant, or the sort of thing a Romantic poet might invent after a session on the opium." You can't miss it.

Not to be confused with:
The giant panda.

webTitle: Comment:UK authors are more talked about than their books

fields.headline: Book squirms
fields.standfirst: In the UK authors are more talked about than their books.  Sylvia Brownrigg on the workings of a literary snakepit
fields.trailText: In the UK authors are more talked about than their books. Sylvia Brownrigg on the workings of a literary snakepit
fields.body:
Salman Rushdie, who has relocated to New York, has complained that London is "bitchy and uninspiring" as a literary home. The phrase is relatively mild compared with some I've heard from other writers, particularly those who move between the American and English publishing worlds. "The snakepit" is one friend's moniker for all things venomous and gossipy, those Soho whispers that can slyly suffocate reputations.

I won't forget a meeting I had with a prominent literary agent soon after I'd arrived from the US. "And why have you moved to London?" he asked, rather suspiciously. (You won't find New Yorkers posing this question to newcomers, so sure are they of the universal desire to live in their city; glum Londoners seem always to express surprise, even scepticism, towards new arrivals.) I gave some Pollyannish response to the effect that I thought London must be a good city for a writer, to which the agent promptly responded "Really? But it's so narrow and incestuous".

Rushdie shares this cross-breeding worry as well, describing the scene as "backbiting and incestuous". Certainly in London people publish their lovers, review their exes, review their employers, puff their friends. A book by a friend of mine was widely reviewed by either his friends or his enemies, resulting in a combination of high praise and low blows. The piece that most pleased him was the single (complimentary) review by a writer with whom he had no connection.

Commentators and diarists talk across the broadsheets as if attending a raucously entertaining dinner party, leaving newspaper readers to guess at what private scores they may be settling as they get in their digs. It is a problem when a small elite controls the cultural conversation about books, and punters should know that the reviews they see are often shaped by a crotchety critic's hidden agenda.

Yet overall, I don't think such shenanigans have much impact on common readers, who often buy their books on the basis of that great ineffable, "word of mouth", more than on the say-so of their Sunday paper. Besides, it is also an elite that controls New York publishing, if perhaps a slightly less homogeneous one. The New York Times, it is true, is rigorous about assuring a lack of connection between reviewer and reviewed. And generally, America is a more think-positive place: the guilty pleasure of reading a review that annihilates an author is not one indulged so frequently there. American editors will encourage criticism to be well grounded and are less inclined to allow general character assassination than here.

For anyone new to London's literary conversation, whether it's taking place in print or between two Chardonnay drinkers at a book launch, the obsession with writers' tiffs does seem baffling. Do we hear, in the US, if Toni Morrison has exchanged curt words with Russell Banks in the Princeton faculty lounge? We do not. But when one English novelist falls out with another, acres of news- print are taken up with the row; and as if that isn't enough, the whole thing is rehashed for headlines five years later when a memoir is published.

Surely either of these writers (perhaps especially the one who has retained a dignified silence on the matter) would find such attention more welcome if directed at the fiction itself. In this respect literary chatter does seem decadent. Even the most self-promoting novelist, who works the gossip mill to his own advantage, must hope actually to be read, not merely to be featured saying something witty in Londoners' Diary.

But there's a paradox here, one I've spoken of with American editors and writers, who can get a vicarious pleasure from the latest Booker scandal or spat in print: at least people in London care enough about literary figures to gossip about them. Isn't that a kind of backhanded compliment? In the US, there just isn't the interest to support a diary in every Sunday paper about the week's bookish goings-on, or a network television broadcast of the premier literary prize- giving, or odds given in the national papers on the winners. We save our gossip for Hollywood, or for unsolved murders: Meg and Dennis's divorce, or the latest on JonBenet Ramsay, now that's news.

Some writers I know in the US have a wistful curiosity about the very bitchiness and incestuousness Rushdie deplores - about the "glamour" that attaches to literary figures here, who become recognisable personalities.

Rushdie might find the lack of talk about him a relief; or he might come to crave it. After a time, he might miss the sense of being in a cultural industry that matters and perhaps find himself wondering what all those UK literary diaries are saying.

fields.bodyText: Salman Rushdie, who has relocated to New York, has complained that London is "bitchy and uninspiring" as a literary home. The phrase is relatively mild compared with some I've heard from other writers, particularly those who move between the American and English publishing worlds. "The snakepit" is one friend's moniker for all things venomous and gossipy, those Soho whispers that can slyly suffocate reputations. I won't forget a meeting I had with a prominent literary agent soon after I'd arrived from the US. "And why have you moved to London?" he asked, rather suspiciously. (You won't find New Yorkers posing this question to newcomers, so sure are they of the universal desire to live in their city; glum Londoners seem always to express surprise, even scepticism, towards new arrivals.) I gave some Pollyannish response to the effect that I thought London must be a good city for a writer, to which the agent promptly responded "Really? But it's so narrow and incestuous". Rushdie shares this cross-breeding worry as well, describing the scene as "backbiting and incestuous". Certainly in London people publish their lovers, review their exes, review their employers, puff their friends. A book by a friend of mine was widely reviewed by either his friends or his enemies, resulting in a combination of high praise and low blows. The piece that most pleased him was the single (complimentary) review by a writer with whom he had no connection. Commentators and diarists talk across the broadsheets as if attending a raucously entertaining dinner party, leaving newspaper readers to guess at what private scores they may be settling as they get in their digs. It is a problem when a small elite controls the cultural conversation about books, and punters should know that the reviews they see are often shaped by a crotchety critic's hidden agenda. Yet overall, I don't think such shenanigans have much impact on common readers, who often buy their books on the basis of that great ineffable, "word of mouth", more than on the say-so of their Sunday paper. Besides, it is also an elite that controls New York publishing, if perhaps a slightly less homogeneous one. The New York Times, it is true, is rigorous about assuring a lack of connection between reviewer and reviewed. And generally, America is a more think-positive place: the guilty pleasure of reading a review that annihilates an author is not one indulged so frequently there. Do we hear, in the US, if Toni Morrison has exchanged curt words with Russell Banks in the Princeton faculty lounge? We do not. But when one English novelist falls out with another, acres of news- print are taken up with the row; and as if that isn't enough, the whole thing is rehashed for headlines five years later when a memoir is published. fields.headline: EU carrot for Serbs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: EU sanctions against Serbia will be lifted if next week's elections bring victory for democrats opposed to Slobodan Milosevic, foreign ministers pledged yesterday,  writes Ian Black.
fields.body:
EU sanctions against Serbia will be lifted if next week's elections bring victory for democrats opposed to Slobodan Milosevic, foreign ministers pledged yesterday.

The 15 EU governments promised "radical change" if Serbians responded to the call. They said they were seeking to give maximum encouragement to the Yugoslav president's enemies.

In a "message to the Serbian people", they said: "We reaffirm that a choice leading to democratic change will entail radical change in the EU's policy with regard to Serbia. We will lift the sanctions against the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia; we will support the necessary economic and political reforms by providing Serbia with aid for its reconstruction and support reintegration into the international community."

What the state newspaper Politika says about Mr Milosevic's rival

Everything about Vojislav Kostunica is a lie. The surname Kostunica is derived from the name of the village of Kostunici, the birth place of Vojislav's father Jovan, who, immediately after the communists came to power, was a judge of a court martial and brought death to many families.

His son hid under a false name to escape revenge. Vojislav has been lying to his wife too. He has been cheating on her brutally. Recently, journalists asked him if anything has changed. He might as well have said: "I am still chasing every woman that passes me by. The only condition is that she is younger than 25."

Vojislav is stiff as if he was wearing a bullet-proof vest. He is narrow-minded, hair-splitting, stubborn, a stickler and boring. He is tense inside. Cold. He is a man constantly on his guard not to show his true face.

fields.headline: Portrait of a lady
fields.standfirst: Is the L word OK?  Anita Chaudhuri finds out
fields.trailText: Is the L word OK?  Anita Chaudhuri finds out
fields.body:
The Olympic games are barely a few days old but already sports commentators, not usually at the forefront of feminist semantics, have stumbled upon a hot new buzzword. "Here come the ladies now," announced one pundit at the start of the women's triathlon event on Saturday and the term has continued to flourish.

It goes without saying that, this being sport, the use of the signifier "lady" is hopelessly anachronistic, in much the same way as it is when Peter Stringfellow and other disco dinosaurs offer "Free Admission for Ladies Tonite" or the maitre d' at an Angus Steak House says "Good evening, ladies" to customers unaccompanied by an adult male. In the context of Olympic coverage, the word is also hopelessly out of place. The Collins dictionary definition of lady defines it as: "1 A woman regarded as having the characteristics of a good family and high social position. 2 An informal name for wife. 3 History : A woman with proprietary rights and authority, as over a manor." Without casting aspersions on the qualities of any of the competitors, since they are not being judged on possession of either property or husbands, their status as ladies seems to be entirely questionable.

Let's face it, in the past, being referred to as a "lady" has never been particularly desirable. As words go, it has more than its fair share of unfortunate connotations. Pop music has provided us with some of the most heinous examples. I mean, what woman, no matter how hopelessly in love she may be, has honestly been able to identify with Chris de Burgh's Lady in Red or, worse still, has been able to relate to being the "once, twice, three times a... " of the Commodores dirge? Then there's The Lady, a magazine that celebrates everything we don't want to be. Finally there are the women who bear the title themselves. Lady Godiva didn't do much to boost the status of ladyhood, nor did Lady Chatterley, and Thunderbirds icon Lady Penelope wasn't much better, though she at least demonstrated great taste in cars and a certain steely dominance over her chauffeur, Parker.

In the past, ladylike behaviour has tended to equate with dull, prim and, by association, sexless conduct. Being a lady is the opposite of being a ladette. Even Anita Loos, usually an exponent of gold-digging hedonism, pointed out in Gentlemen Prefer Blondes that "any girl who was a lady would not even think of having such a good time that she did not remember to hang on to her jewellery".

Perhaps it's a backlash against Denise van Outen and Davina McColl but almost without our noticing, "the lady" has been rehabilitated. It started on the New York club scene in the 90s when Lady Miss Kier, singer with the band Deee-Lite, enjoyed a certain amount of fame. Soon, more female American rappers and DJs were adopting the L-word as a prefix that conveyed attitude and a certain "don't mess with me" imperiousness. Lady of Rage, a protegee of Dr Dre, and Lady Mayhem made leaps and bounds in reclaiming the word.

Thanks to them, being called a lady no longer sounds quite so patronising, but it still depends who you're talking to. If I were standing at the bar with a friend and a man came up and asked: "Can I buy you lovely ladies a drink?" I think we can safely predict the likely response.

The word lady is most powerfully used when it implies a level of froideur and distance, as in: "I think this lady was first." It is perfectly embodied by Catherine Deneuve in the film Belle du Jour, in which she plays a bored bourgeois housewife who brings the same level of chilly restraint to the clients she entertains while moonlighting in a brothel.

For the past two seasons, the fashion industry has seized upon Deneuve's portrait of a lady. Vogue and Elle have devoted acres of glossy space to "lady" fashion shoots and "how to" guides about the correct way actually, um, to be a lady. (Carrying a Guerlain powder compact, freshly ironed hankies and sending thank you notes on posh personalised stationery are apparently all essential.)

Much of this madness has been inspired by Prada, the design house that cruelly sent its models down the catwalk in pleated skirts, twinsets and polyester bows. Alas, this has been seized upon with the kind of earnestness only fashion people could employ and now this autumn we are all expected to tiptoe around in tweed knee-length skirts and frumpy blouses done up at the neck.

A word of caution, though. One lady is being mentioned with alarming frequency in connection with this revival, a style icon cited by everyone from American Vogue to the Daily Telegraph. Baroness Thatcher, for it is she, is said to embody the very essence of the new ladylike trend. You have been warned.

webTitle: Police name all 58 of Dover dead

fields.headline: Police name all 58 of Dover dead
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A team of eight police officers travelled to Fujian province in eastern China with pictures of the 58 illegal immigrants who suffocated in the back of a lorry in Dover, an inquest in Folkestone, Kent, heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A team of eight police officers travelled to Fujian province in eastern China with pictures of the 58 illegal immigrants who suffocated in the back of a lorry in Dover, an inquest in Folkestone, Kent, heard yesterday.

The bodies of 54 men and four women aged between 16 and 45 were discovered during a routine search of a refrigerated lorry at Dover's eastern docks in June. Two survivors were found in the back of the vehicle. The inquest, which opened on June 23, found that the group had asphyxiated in the airtight trailer after it had been parked at Zeebrugge, Belgium, for 12 hours in temperatures of 30C (86F).

Detective Chief Superintendent Dennis McGookin said all of the victims came from villages close to one another and that all but five had been formally identified by relatives in China. Two bodies were identified by fingerprints and another three by relatives in England.

"Some individuals were more difficult to identify and it was a very distressing task," he said. "We were dealing with a delicate issue."

The coroner, Richard Sturt, who adjourned the inquest pending criminal proceedings, praised the police for their "formidable achievement" in identifying the bodies which would remain in storage in Kent while negotiations continued to return them to their families.

A lorry driver, Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, the Netherlands, has been charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and smuggling offences.

You Yi, 38, a chef, and Ying Guo, 29, an interpreter, of South Woodford, Essex, are jointly charged with conspiracy to facilitate illegal entry into the UK.

webTitle: City plans to provide free laptops

fields.headline: City plans to provide free laptops
fields.standfirst:
Nottingham's e-learning scheme to promote computer education

Net news
fields.trailText: Hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren could be hooked up to the internet via a free laptop computer, under a initiative announced yesterday by the city of Nottingham.
fields.body:
Hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren could be hooked up to the internet via a free laptop computer, under a initiative announced yesterday by the city of Nottingham. Its proposed e-Learning Foundation will allow laptops to be leased to local people for educational purposes and one-to-one internet access.

Teachers would be able to mark homework via home-school links, while pupils would be able to access curriculum material and communicate with e-pen pals.

The scheme - which centres around a charitable funding vehicle devised by the US software company Microsoft and the accountancy and financial services firm Arthur Andersen - is likely to be a model for similar projects in other parts of the country. Financial help will also be sought from parents, local businesses and the education budget.

The Greater Nottingham Partnership, which is the regeneration body leading the scheme, hopes it will help new and established businesses fill 40,000 IT-related jobs in the area.

Microsoft's president, Bill Gates, said yesterday: "Nottingham's e-Learning Foundation is a world first in bringing the benefits of technology to learners of all ages, as well as addressing the issue of sustainable funding and the digital divide. Nottingham's work stands as one of the most ambitious and visionary initiatives of its kind."

The council leader, Graham Chapman, said: "We confidently expect Nottingham's e-Learning Foundation to become the model for similar projects in other cities and regions across the country."

Delivery of the first computers to around 200 teachers and pupils will be made this month, supplied by a local firm, Ergo Computing UK. Nottingham city council expects to be able to meet all the local demand, although some prospective users may not receive their machines for five years.

Already, 90% of schools in the city have expressed an interest in the scheme. The area has around 42,000 pupils attending 134 primary, secondary and special schools. Parents will have to make a contribution towards the leasing costs, expected to be between 50p and £5.50 a week, but Nottingham council has got business in the area involved. They can make tax-efficient contributions so that a gift of £100 is worth £128.

The details emerged as the government warned that nearly a third of children would be happy to give out their names and addresses on the internet in exchange for gifts or information.

Urging parents not to be left behind in the scramble for internet access, the learning and technology minister, Michael Wills, warned that more parents needed to make an effort to keep up with their children's progress. He announced a Code for Kids to discourage them from giving out their name or address or trying to contact strangers they meet online.

Speaking at the launch of Parents Online Week yesterday, Mr Wills said almost 98% of secondary and 86% of primary schools were now online. Half of all children also used the internet at home, but only a fifth of them were supervised by one of their parents.

Parents who have never used the internet are encouraged to attend one of the sessions at schools around the country this week. A new website at www.parentsonline.gov.uk shows novices how to use a mouse, scroll up and down and find approved resources.

The Internet Watch Foundation, which helped devised the Code for Kids, advised parents to contact the foundation at www.iwf.org.uk if they encountered offensive sites.

Unruly pupils could be persuaded to work harder if they were allowed to take a term off to do voluntary work, according to a report published yesterday.

Sabbaticals and flexi-schooling were two Institute for Public Policy Research suggestions for getting disaffected youngsters more interested in education.

webTitle: Plan to simplify formula for school funding

fields.headline: Plan to simplify formula for school funding
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will today promise to transform the byzantine system of school funding into a formula teachers and parents can understand - and will enable them to hold councils to account.
fields.body:
The government will today promise to transform the byzantine system of school funding into a formula teachers and parents can understand - and will enable them to hold councils to account.

A green paper on local government finance in England will propose that when central government sets council budgets, it will specify the amount it expects each local education authority to spend on administration, and the amount that should be given directly to schools. Under targets set by the David Blunkett, the education secretary, authorities will be expected to hand over at least 90% of their education budget to schools.

But the green paper proposals, to be unveiled by the local government minister Hilary Armstrong, are expected to be received as a "curate's egg" by head teachers.

It falls short of satisfying calls from the National Association of Head Teachers and the Secondary Heads' Association for a national funding formula for schools.

Under the proposals, councils will still be able to switch money between the different elements of the education budget, or out of the budget altogether. But the green paper will hold out the option of ringfencing the money in the future if councils do not obey government guidelines.

The cash each council is expected to spend on education will be calculated on the basis of a simplified formula.

There will be a flat rate, per-pupil spending, and two top-up elements: deprivation, and difficulty in recruiting and retaining teachers.

Ministers believe the formula will enable communities to hold councils to account if they fail to hand over the money expected.

Mr Blunkett has promised that any new formula will involve a "levelling up, not down". It will seek to address the persistent complaints of teachers in about 40 or so council areas which receive significantly less funding per pupil than other similar areas.

But the system would ensure that blame continues to be shared with local councils if schools feel pressure from books shortages, for instance.

Sources familiar with negotiations in Whitehall say Mr Blunkett pressed for a more radical separation of budgets, but was opposed by by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, and by the Treasury.

According to one account, Jack Straw, the home secretary, had a decisive input, persuading Mr Blunkett that it would be politically dangerous to take on more control of school funding by removing the local authority buffer.

webTitle: Rare chess sets to be auctioned

fields.headline: Rare chess sets to be auctioned
fields.trailText: More than 150 of the world's finest chess sets, found in a cabinet where they had lain for 30 years, could fetch up to £160,000 at Christie's in London tomorrow.
fields.body:
More than 150 of the world's finest chess sets, found in a cabinet where they had lain for 30 years, could fetch up to £160,000 at Christie's in London tomorrow.

The sets, made from materials including ivory, electrical wire and volcanic lava, belonged to a New York businessman, Allen Hofrichter, who died in the early 1970s. He bequeathed the sets to his family, who left them in the cabinet until this year.

A chess specialist, Nic McElhatton, said the collection was superior to the Harbeson collection, sold at Sotheby's in 1979 and described as the best of its kind.

Receipts in the boxes show that Mr Hofrichter paid £35 for a carved wooden set modelled on the bears of Berne (expected to fetch £3,500) and £50 for an Italian alabaster set depicting the armies of Mussolini and Haile Selassie, which could go for more than £1,000.

Other sets were bought at "clearance sales" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

The finest is an 18th-century set made in Delhi by the John Company and expected to realise up to £18,000. The Indian king is seated on a 5in elephant, his bishops are mounted on camels, the castles are guarded by armed sentries, and the pawns carry muskets.

JV News Agency

fields.headline: Surgeon stalked by his ex-wife
fields.trailText: The former wife of a leading surgeon was put on probation for three years yesterday after stalking him and his new wife, sending him excrement in the post and distributing malicious posters near his home.
fields.body:
The former wife of a leading surgeon was put on probation for three years yesterday after stalking him and his new wife, sending him excrement in the post and distributing malicious posters near his home.

Julia Dickson, 48, of Stockport, left the crown court at Manchester yesterday after three months on remand.

At an earlier hearing she was convicted of four times breaching a restraining order by contacting the surgeon, Alan Dickson, 50. She was also convicted of common assault for attacking his wife, Heather Dickson, a former nurse aged 39, in their garden in Greater Manchester last December, calling her a "wicked slut".

Passing sentence yesterday, John Corless, assistant recorder, said to Dickson: "It's a very sad day to find you in this dock, particularly given the nature of the offences you've committed."

She had admitted before magistrates in Stockport that she had struggled to come to terms with her divorce from her husband of 20 years. She became upset when he remarried in February last year.

In December a restraining order was imposed on her for "longstanding disgraceful behaviour", but four days later she called at her ex-husband's home.

When Heather Dickson reminded her of the order, Dickson pulled her to the ground, punched her in the head, kicked her, and said: "This is my husband and my children's house, and I want to be here." Mrs Dickson told magistrates: "She said I was sleeping with her husband and that I was a slut. I was in shock." She said that she had met her husband in 1998, "probably four years after his separation".

In court, representing herself, Dickson alleged that her rival's injuries had been caused by the surgeon. She said he liked to beat women.

Magistrates heard how Dickson returned a note to the surgeon in which he had suggested dates for her to have access to their son. It was smeared with excrement and said: "I have wiped the dog's bottom on this missive, which is all it's good for. Do not ever dictate to me again."

Dickson, who spent six years in a psychiatric unit after her marriage collapsed, cross-examined her ex-husband, dismissing the letter as a joke and inquiring whether he had lost his sense of humour. He replied: "I don't recall much laughter in my marriage. I would accept my sense of humour is limited in this family situation." He told magistrates that despite the restraining order his ex-wife had called him on his mobile and launched a barrage of abuse, including a local poster campaign bearing false allegations about his private life.

webTitle: US troops abused civilians in Kosovo

fields.headline: US troops abused civilians in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Soldiers in a US army unit whose motto was "shoot 'em in the face" beat and abused civilians in Kosovo, according to an official army report prepared published yesterday.
fields.body:
Soldiers in a US army unit whose motto was "shoot 'em in the face" beat and abused civilians in Kosovo, according to an official army report prepared published yesterday.

It found that the soldiers had violated the basic standards of decency and humanity because they had not been prepared properly for a peacekeeping role in the area.

The report comes in the wake of the conviction last month of Staff Sergeant Frank Ronghi for rape and murder. Ronghi has been sentenced to life for killing a young girl while he was on peacekeeping duty in Kosovo, and the case has severely damaged the reputation of the US troops in the area.

The army released the 1,100-page report into the behaviour of A company, 3rd battalion, 504th parachute infantry regiment yesterday.

The army said all the main conclusions and findings of the investigation by Colonel John Morgan were being made public. A limited number of details were being withheld for reasons of security or privacy.

The report amounts to a devastating indictment not only of the way in which members of the unit behaved in Kosovo but also of the way in which they were prepared for their assignment.

"Unit members violated the limits and terms of their military assignments by interrogating, abusing and beating Albanians," the report concluded. It suggested that the unit's members had "violated basic standards" of what was expected of soldiers in the US forces.

It concluded that the commanders of the unit should have been aware of what was being done by their troops. The failure of the senior officers to put a brake on the activities of their men meant that they effectively "perpetuated a volatile situation".

At the root of the problem, the report found, was the way in which the men were prepared for their assignment before they left the US in July last year. Many of the men interviewed during the investigation said they had been prepared as though they were about to enter a high-intensity combat zone rather than a peacekeeping role which depended on winning the confidence of a civilian population.

As a result, the report said, the men "experienced difficulties tempering their combat mentality for adapting and transitioning to peacekeeping duties".

The unit's slogan, "shoot 'em in the face", was an indication of the attitude the soldiers took with them on their duties. The soldiers were found to lack the necessary skills for intelligence-gathering and interrogating civilians about the situation, one of the key roles of a peacekeeping force.

Nine other men were disciplined and received administrative punishment after Ronghi's arrest.

The report, which is highly critical of the command structure and training of the unit, could be used as ammunition in the presidential campaign. The Republican candidate, George W Bush, has criticised the Clinton administration, and by implication his rival Al Gore, for supposedly running down the military and allowing it to become demoralised and underfunded.

A report that backs up such accusations could be used in the debate on which party is better equipped to handle the armed forces.

webTitle: Newly outfitted space station awaits first tenants

fields.headline: Newly outfitted space station awaits first tenants
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Atlantis rocketed away from the international space station early Monday, leaving the cosmic outpost fully stocked and freshly outfitted for its first inhabitants.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Atlantis rocketed away from the international space station early Monday, leaving the cosmic outpost fully stocked and freshly outfitted for its first inhabitants.

The spacecraft separated some 240 miles above Russia, a few minutes late because of minor computer trouble. Afterward, pilot Scott Altman flew Atlantis around the station twice while his crewmates took pictures and videotape of the shining outpost.

"Watching the sunrise and sunset, and the way it illuminated the solar arrays on the service module was just phenomenal. It sparkled like a jewel out there against the blue background of the oceans. A very, very beautiful sight for us," Altman said.

The craft flew together for eight days, during which Atlantis' seven-man crew completed all of their assigned tasks and even some planned for later missions.

"This crew has certainly laid out the red carpet for the first crew to come aboard the international space station," space station deputy manager Robert Cabana said. "I think they accomplished everything we asked them to do, everything we wished they could do, and I think about everything we dreamed that they could do."

During their five days inside, the shuttle astronauts outfitted the station with five new batteries, a toilet, oxygen generator and treadmill in the new Russian-built service module Zvezda. During a spacewalk a week ago, they hooked up power, data and TV cables. They also stocked the cabinets with more than 6,000 pounds of food, clothes, toiletries, ear plugs, office supplies, trash bags, vacuum cleaners and other gear.

All of that will be waiting when the first station crew arrives for a four-month stay, scheduled to begin November 1. Shuttle Cmdr. Terrence Wilcutt said astronaut Bill Shepherd, who will lead a crew of two cosmonauts, won't have any trouble making his home inside Zvezda.

"It seemed like a new house, which is exactly what it was. It's ready to go. We tidied it up, left him a couple of notes and I think it's ready for him to move into," Wilcutt said.

Atlantis' crew even warmed up the beds for Shepherd and company: Each of Atlantis' crew tried Zvezda's sleeping accommodations for a night, Wilcutt said.

All that remains for Atlantis' crew is a bit of well-earned relaxation time and landing preparations. Tropical Storm Gordon is not expected in interfere with a scheduled Wednesday return to the Kennedy Space Centre.

"The forecast actually says that behind the storm, it should be pretty favourable weather conditions, so we're looking forward to those," mission operations representative Jeff Bantle said, but cautioned that it is too early to accurately predict.

The storm was expected to stay well north of Cape Canaveral, where space shuttle Discovery is on its launch pad awaiting a planned October 5 departure for a space station construction mission.

Nasa opted to keep Discovery on its pad because of the storm's path, and was not too concerned that the storm would knock launch preparations off schedule.

"We did lose a little time, but we built in contingency days," Bantle said.
