webTitle: Gospel truth Tavener choral premiere in Pentonville prison

fields.headline: Gospel truth Tavener choral premiere in Pentonville prison
fields.trailText: Twenty prisoners and their prison governor are to sing at the world premiere of a choral work commissioned by a London jail.
fields.body:
Twenty prisoners and their prison governor are to sing at the world premiere of a choral work commissioned by a London jail.

The 10-minute piece by Sir John Tavener, entitled In a Single Moment, will be performed next month at two public concerts in Pentonville prison as part of a festival of the composer's work. Other inmates will see a performance of the work, too. The text of the work is taken from the Greek Orthodox gospel's account of the words Jesus spoke to the good thief at Calvary on Good Friday.

Funded mainly by profits from the prison tuckshop, the commission was the idea of Tabby Bowers-Broadbent, the London Sinfonietta's education manager. "The reaction from all of the inmates has been stunning," she said yesterday. "They have turned up to rehearsals, taken the music away to learn it and shown an astonishing level of dedication and commitment."

The singers will be accompanied by a string quintet and percussion, with the prisoners also playing handbells and using Tibetan prayer bowls as percussion instruments. Terry Edwards, director of the London Sinfonietta Voices and the Royal Opera's chorus, will direct the performance and also lead the choir in Sir John's setting of the Lord's prayer.

"The music is relatively straightforward," said Fraser Trainer, creative director of the Sinfonietta's education programme. "It's slow, gentle and serene - not many semi-quavers. But as it is slow, it's difficult to keep in tune."

Most of the men will be singing in public for the first time, although two have some experience as soul singers.

Gareth Davies, the new governor of Pentonville, has backed the project, begun by his predecessor. "It gives the prisoners a purpose. In rehearsal they were aware of the importance of the work. They know it's a special event."

Ms Bowers-Broadbent said the composer had jumped at the commission. "He is very interested in the spirituality of prisoners and wonders whether they lose it when they go to jail - or find a faith they never had before."

webTitle: Uniform chic puts avant garde into everyday wear

fields.headline: Uniform chic puts avant garde into everyday wear
fields.trailText: The fashion cliche has become the hot new look. Boy scouts, golfer geeks, traffic cops; Miguel Adrover brought the avant garde to the everyday with a collection for spring 2001 in New York on Sunday night which paid homage to uniforms.
fields.body:
The fashion cliche has become the hot new look. Boy scouts, golfer geeks, traffic cops; Miguel Adrover brought the avant garde to the everyday with a collection for spring 2001 in New York on Sunday night which paid homage to uniforms.

Tipped this season to secure his position as fashion's brightest star, Adrover drew the A-list fashion celebs who packed the venue (a marble-pillared bank) to the point that those turned away scaled the walls. The consensus after an hour-long show was that Adrover, with comical disdain for the establishment, had once again sparked the imagination of the fashion crowd.

For Majorca-born Adrover this collection marked his third season in New York. Last season's witty appropriations of midtown status dressing with an inside-out and back-to-front Burberry trench and Louis Vuitton logo'd leather for the back of a coat, could easily have been all style and no content but for the imaginative cuts and elegant construction.

And this season Adrover runs pretty close to form. The signature nose thumbing is clearly evident; schoolboy chic - crisp striped shirts and navy wool micro-shorts; boy scout chic - khaki uniforms complete with triangular scarves knotted about the neck; even newsreader chic- red single-breasted blazers, high but toned silk blouses and A-line mid-calf navy skirts.

But along with the irony came the real expertise which will doubtlessly translate into some key fashion themes for spring. To the sound of a cornet and battle drums came a military look; sharply tailored 40s-style army uniforms with matching shirt and tie; 70s style fatigues complete with khaki caps, aviators and Vietnam badges; even an all-American cop with low slung trousers and a badge. This aggressive masculine theme was then juxtaposed with floating bias cut evening dresses in khaki chiffon and stunning hand painted silk shifts in navy and silver.

Much is expected of Adrover since Pegasus Apparel Group, the new American fashion-investment firm, announced it was backing him. Only a year ago he was struggling to pay his rent. On Sunday, at the end of the show, he knelt on his catwalk and shook the hand of the Pegasus CEO. The irony had to stop somewhere.

webTitle: Admiral to become armed forces chief

fields.headline: Admiral to become armed forces chief
fields.trailText: Britain' s new chief of the defence staff was confirmed yesterday as Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the first navy man to take the post for 12 years.
fields.body:
Britain' s new chief of the defence staff was confirmed yesterday as Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, the first navy man to take the post for 12 years.

The three armed services were involved in a row last year over replacing Sir Charles Guthrie, who retires in February. The navy had been pushing for his successor to come from their ranks.

Sir Michael, who is 57 and married with two children, was appointed first sea lord and chief of naval staff in October 1998. He takes a post that has become increasingly high profile. He is said to be trusted by the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, but has yet to establish with Tony Blair the kind of rapport enjoyed by Sir Charles.

A defence source said he was much quieter than the last, flamboyant, head of the armed forces. "He will not come out juggling balls.He is studious, very intelligent, a precise speaker, not a socialiser."

fields.headline: Rich picketings
fields.standfirst: Typical protesters are young, highly educated and affluent people who are affected by the gap between their expectations and living conditions
fields.trailText: Last week showed the power of an unorthodox type of political participation, at least when the protesters have widespread public support. Protest, however, is not a modern phenomenon. It has been a feature of British politics for centuries
fields.body:
Last week showed the power of an unorthodox type of political participation, at least when the protesters have widespread public support. Protest, however, is not a modern phenomenon. It has been a feature of British politics for centuries, although it tends to get ignored by the writers of constitutional textbooks.

If the man or woman in the street were asked to identify typical protesters, they very likely do not think of people such as themselves. Political activism is a minority occupation in Britain and most people think protesting is something done only by a tiny minority.

But data from our research programme on democracy show this is quite wrong. There is a lot more potential for protest. In July this year we asked a representative sample of the electorate if they were likely to take part in a rally or demonstration in the future. Some 16% responded that they were quite likely to be involved in protest and a further 18% indicated that they might be. In terms of the electorate as a whole that represents about 15m people as possible members of some campaign or another.

If we examine the social profile of likely protesters they tend to be more middle class, younger and more highly educated than their inactive counterparts. Thus 19% of the middle class are quite likely to be protesters, compared with only 15% of the working class. Altogether, 17% of 16- to 25-year-olds are potential protesters com pared with only 9% of the retired. Finally, 21% of people educated beyond the age of 19 are likely protesters compared with only 14% of people who left school at 16. For the most part then, the poor, the uneducated and downtrodden are not likely to be amongst today's protesters.

One of the best explanations why people protest is provided by the theory of "relative deprivation". This argues that people will protest if there is a big gap between what they expect out of life and what they actually are getting. If this gap is growing it can trigger protests. The gap is often measured by income, so that industrial-relations protests are often linked to growing wage differentials and declining real incomes of some workers relative to others. This does seem to be the mechanism that triggered protests by the road hauliers and farmers. Relative deprivation explains why the poor est and most deprived are not usually those who go out and protest, because their expectations are as low as their incomes.

But income is not the only cause of protest. A loss of status or self-esteem can also act as a trigger. Football hooligans who very strongly identify with their team react violently to the loss of a match because they see it as a real blow to their self- esteem. Similarly "not in my back yard" protests over road building and housing developments are usually provoked by the fear of a loss of amenity or a threat of decline in property prices.

An intriguing question is whether or not protest is a symptom of dissatisfaction with the state of British democracy - the system by which we govern ourselves. As the chart shows there is some evidence to back this idea. About 11% of respondents in the survey were not at all satisfied with the state of democracy in Great Britain and of this group some 26% were likely to protest. At the other end of the scale 9% of respondents were very satisfied with the state of democracy and only 15% of them were likely to join the ranks of protesters. Interestingly enough, people who are not very satisfied with the state of democracy are not that different from those who are fairly satisfied, suggesting that discontent has to grow strong before it provokes protest behaviour.

It seems plausible that one source of dissatisfaction with democracy is disillusionment with the electoral process. If so, protesters might be taking action because they think that conventional forms of participation such as putting a cross on a ballot paper are a waste of time. But the evidence does not support this. It turns out that potential protesters are also voters. In our survey, 77% of likely protesters are also likely voters, and 75% of people who are unlikely to vote are also unlikely to protest. Protesting is not an alternative to voting.

Another idea, common at least until the fuel crisis last week, is that protesting is something largely done by left-wingers. The evidence is definitely against. Some 16% of Labour supporters are likely to protest, but this was also true of 12% of Conservatives and 14% of Liberal Democrats - there is not much difference between supporters of the major parties in this respect.

Are we likely to see more protesting in future; will that pool of 15m get mobilised? Relative deprivation theory suggests that rapidly growing inequalities between individu als, together with a decline in the social status and autonomy of some groups compared with others, are likely to trigger future protests. Two recent trends are worth watching. Firstly, there has been a rapid increase in private sector management salaries and perks, compared with those of their employees. Secondly, the income and status of many public sector workers has been declining, teachers for example, compared compared with their private sector counterparts. We should not be surprised if these workers do not bite back at some point in the future.

fields.bodyText: Last week showed the power of an unorthodox type of political participation, at least when the protesters have widespread public support. Protest, however, is not a modern phenomenon. It has been a feature of British politics for centuries, although it tends to get ignored by the writers of constitutional textbooks. If the man or woman in the street were asked to identify typical protesters, they very likely do not think of people such as themselves. Political activism is a minority occupation in Britain and most people think protesting is something done only by a tiny minority. fields.headline: Internet know-how parents online
fields.trailText: Many parents are still unaware of the wealth of high quality educational materials, for children of all ages, that are available for free on the internet.
fields.body:
Many parents are still unaware of the wealth of high quality educational materials, for children of all ages, that are available for free on the internet. With this in mind the DfEE, in association with BT, has launched Parents' Online Week in England, with a website at: www.parentsonline.gov.uk.

Schools, libraries and internet cafes participating in the scheme will open up their computer facilities to the public enabling them to go online. In all these venues, help will be on hand to guide everyone through the world wide web - even those who've never picked up a mouse before.

To encourage schools to take part, the Guardian's educational website at www.learn.co.uk is offering two families the chance of an all-expenses paid trip to London which includes two passes to the Science Museum. The children's news site, MissDorothy.com, is running a competition in which a family of four can win a luxury safari holiday to South Africa.

A huge amount of hype surrounds the internet, worries about unsuitable chat rooms, porn sites and the fear of net fraud, and this makes many parents anxious about allowing their children to go online. To dispel some of these worries, the site includes a Superhighway Safety Pack, where the whole topic of net safety is dealt with, from how to deal with unsuitable sites, through to issues surrounding intellectual property rights and even the correct posture children should adopt when using a computer.

One of the tasks Parents' Online has set itself is to demystify the internet so that adults will feel confident about managing their child's experience online. Even for the experienced computer user, the net can often seem slow and frustrating. To combat this, the designers of the site have created "journeys" around the web suitable for different age groups, which take users on a tour of some of the most exciting and interactive sites available. According to Andrew Atkinson of the DfEE, "We've built the site in such a way that even people with low level connections will be able to access the featured sites. Some of the sites need special software, and there's advice on how to get hold of this in the resources area of the site."

Consultant Alison Lister says, "People have to realise that it does take time to load some sites, it's almost like queuing up at the supermarket. But once you've got there, you've got access to some of the best sites available on the net. It's all about creating communities and making bonds, we want to give parents access to the great wealth of information that's out there. There's no point being on the internet if it's not interactive!"

Parents Online runs from September 18-22; www.parentsonline.gov.uk will remain active for the autumn term.

fields.headline: Samaritan's killing 'reveals flaws in care'
fields.trailText: Deficiencies in community services for the mentally ill were exposed yesterday by an independent inquiry into the killing of a Good Samaritan by the disturbed teenager she befriended.
fields.body:
Deficiencies in community services for the mentally ill were exposed yesterday by an independent inquiry into the killing of a Good Samaritan by the disturbed teenager she befriended.

It found a breakdown of communication between agencies responsible for the care of Daniel Joseph, a deaf 18-year-old, who inflicted 50 injuries on Carla Thompson during a prolonged attack at her home in Tulse Hill, south London, in January 1998.

The inquiry, chaired by the barrister Jane Mishcon, said Joseph was as much a victim of the tragedy as Mrs Thompson and her neighbour Agnes Erume, who was left permanently injured by the attack.

Joseph pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was detained indefinitely at Broadmoor top security hospital.

The report identified special problems for deaf people with mental health problems who cannot be properly assessed without the presence of signing interpreters.

It said the National Deaf Service (NDS) had the main responsibility for planning Joseph's care after he left its psychiatric unit in August 1997. Lack of appropriate contingency plans for his aftercare "fell short of good clinical practice" and the service's lack of resources made it "impotent to go in and assess his mental state in a time of emergency".

Three south London health authorities were also criticised for not working more closely with each other and the NDS.

Addresses where Joseph lived during the years before the attack were within a radius of two miles, but fell into three catchment areas. Contact between teams failed to give the case the priority needed to address his deteriorating condition.

"The system must be improved or the care in the community programme will continue to create apprehension, if not fear, among the general public, and we will continue to fail those dedicated professionals who strive to do their best to help those people with mental health problems live as normal a life as they can, " the report said.

The police gave a lurid account of his attacks on the two women, including battering them with furniture, stamping on them and tying them together by the neck.

"His violent actions bear a striking similarity to those seen in World Wrestling Foundation contests on television," the report said.

Joseph, who was six feet seven inches tall and described as "extremely strong", was obsessed with WWF fights and had dreams of becoming a wrestler.

Ms Mischon said: "I feel that WWF had quite an important part to play in this tragedy. If one considers the particular brutality of the attack, one can see similarities. Some of the extreme actions of the attack did mirror what we know are the choreographed and the not-real actions of the wrestlers. To someone like Daniel, those actions seem very, very real."

The inquiry criticised reports in the media, including the Guardian, for suggesting the homicide was "yet another homicide by a psychiatric patient who had been disturbed and violent for some time." There was "no evidence that the homicide could have been reliably predicted, even the day before it happened."

The teenager did not have a serious mental disorder when he discharged himself from hospital in August 1997. Mrs Thompson took him as a lodger and persuaded him to stop taking his medication and rely on the power of prayer.

Joseph was being "protected from the professionals by well-meaning but misguided friends" who thwarted attempts by the authorities to assess his mental state.

A joint statement by the health authorities and the trust responsible for the NDS said: "We accept the panel's findings that Daniel's care after he moved to Carla Thompson's flat was deficient and that a joint agency aftercare plan, with clear identification of roles and responsibilities, was lacking.

"With the benefit of hindsight we can all see that intervention ... might have prevented the death of Carla Thompson and the severe injuries to Agnes Erume. But hindsight is not the same as prediction."

Joseph's mother Claudette said: "He is very, very sorry for what happened and I am sorry. It is so sad. He loved Carla. He was a very, very sick boy. Carla helped Daniel in all his needs but she stopped him taking his medication because she thought it would zombify his body."

Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of Sane, the mental health charity, said the report confirmed evidence of a confusion of responsibilities.

fields.headline: On the web
fields.standfirst: Interactive sites
fields.trailText: Interactive sites
fields.body:
Health education

*****

Aimed at: key stage 3/GCSE

A superb site where you can view highly entertaining interactive films on all topics to do with health, from the digestive system, with graphic details of how faeces are produced, to fitness and exercise. There's also a special section on the Olympics.

Indian sub-continent

****

Aimed at: A-level

A site dedicated to the history and archaeology of the ancient Indus valley, plus a wealth of photographs, engravings and films on life in the Indian sub-continent during the time of the Raj.

Translation resource

****

Aimed at: key stage 3/GCSE/A-level

An interactive language learning site where you can practise your vocabulary, learn new words, and even translate your emails, documents and web pages into other languages.

Sodaplay

*****

Aimed at: GCSE/A-level

If you played with Meccano as a child you'll love this. Sodaplay models are made out of masses linked by springs and muscles. Grab them with your mouse and pull them around the screen, seeing how gravity and friction affect their shape. Or create and play with your own designs.

New York graffiti

*****

Aimed at: key stge 2

Games, kid's art, projects and stories, all in primary colours, from the site of New York graffiti artist Keith Haring, who died in 1988. A site which brings subway art to life, with a kids colouring book and lesson plans to print out.

Hands-on art

*****

Aimed at: key stage 3

All about art! Hands-on activities include making 3-D architectural models, nature notebooks and abstract portraits. You can add your artwork to the student gallery, and travel back in time with Dr N Ventor to visit Leonardo da Vinci's workshop in 1550.

Virtual art gallery

*****

Aimed at: key stage 2

Take a tour around a virtual art gallery, learning about Vincent Van Gogh along the way. Look at his paintings and take part in an interactive quiz.

Early learners

*****

Aimed at: early years

Over 500 beautifully illustrated interactive games for small children. Learn to count, and practise your mouse skills, by catching fish with your rod.

Population analysis

*****

Aimed at: key stage 3/GCSE/A-level

A site from the Musée de l'Homme in Paris, based on the exhibition entitled Six Billion Human Beings. Type in your age to find out how many people were on Earth when you were born; click on your country to find maps and diagrams on fertility, child mortality, average age of marriage etc. See where you fit in as the world's population explodes!

Nasa online

****

Aimed at: key stage 3/GCSE/A-level

The Nasa site contains a wealth of information - biographies, field journals, activities - for those wanting to explore the reality and excitement of modern science research.

Annabel McLaren, learn.co.uk

You can find more interactive sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

webTitle: Chalk horse at tunnel to hail visitors

fields.headline: Chalk horse at tunnel to hail visitors
fields.trailText: A huge white horse will be carved into the chalk hillside overlooking the Channel Tunnel near Folkestone, Kent, perhaps by Christmas.
fields.body:
A huge white horse will be carved into the chalk hillside overlooking the Channel Tunnel near Folkestone, Kent, perhaps by Christmas.

The artist Charles Newington has designed the 100ft long Celtic white horse, the first landmark travellers will see as they emerge from the tunnel. English Nature had opposed the project as a "man-made folly" after seeing a canvas mock-up, saying it would be detrimental to north downs wildlife.

But last night Shepway district council gave it the go-ahead, subject to the environ- ment secretary's approval. The Conservative MP for Folkestone and Hythe, Michael Howard, supported the plan.

It ends three months of wrangling over the design, which Mr Newington said was one of Britain's oldest symbols. "It could be unveiled in time for Christmas."

The farmer whose land will be host to the horse, Richard Beaugie, said: "It is a worthwhile landmark and certainly won't disrupt my farming. The cattle will ignore it."
Kent News

fields.headline: Salvation Army faces cash crisis
fields.trailText: The Salvation Army yesterday warned that it faces a cash crisis which could threaten its future as the guardian angel of Britain's homeless, poor and needy.
fields.body:
The Salvation Army yesterday warned that it faces a cash crisis which could threaten its future as the guardian angel of Britain's homeless, poor and needy.

A £5m shortfall means that some of its social welfare programmes, including homeless centres, homes for children and the elderly, and substance misuse centres, face closure.

The organisation, which is Britain's largest social welfare provider after the government, was launching its annual fundraising appeal.

"We could be back to the levels of social deprivation seen in the 1950s," warned Commissioner Alex Hughes, the leader of the Salvation Army's UK territory.

He added: "If we cannot increase our funding, either from government sources or from public donations, in the near future, many people who depend on the Army for social care and rehabilitation into the community will simply fall through the net.

"We cannot allow this to happen."

The organisation says it cannot afford to carry out vital work to upgrade facilities and meet the increasing cost of and demand for social services because it is having to compete with other voluntary bodies for cash.

If the organisation is forced to make cuts, the effect on people's lives will be substantial.

Its budget for the current year been set at £5m to cover the running of 50 homeless centres, 20 elderly homes and numerous children's homes. The Salvation Army also runs a family tracing service, counselling services and nearly 900 local church and community centres.
Press Association

fields.headline: The lights fantastic
fields.standfirst: There won't be a better chance of seeing an aurora in Britain for 11 years
fields.trailText: There won't be a better chance of seeing an aurora in Britain for 11 years
fields.body:
The Aurora Borealis, commonly known as the northern lights, is one of the natural world's most spectacular phenomena, featuring large areas of flashing colours, in the direction due north. For a weak aurora, the colour will be very faint and spread out, and may be hard to see. If the aurora intensifies, it may move higher in the sky and develop into a more distinct arc. Brighter patches can develop which turn into ribbons of light which dart around the sky. They are a common sight in the night skies of the far north. At times of intense solar activity, they become visible from lower latitudes. The 11-year solar cycle is now at its peak and the aurora may be visible from Britain from now until well into the next year.

Viewing

The northern lights can be tricky to see in this country, as an individual display may only last for a few minutes, though it may be repeated many times during the course of the night. The best time for viewing is between 10pm and 2am on a cloudless night when the sky is at its darkest. The York University magnetospheric physics group, led by Dr Ian Mann, which monitors activity in space, has just launched a website www.aurorawatch.york.ac.uk to help people understand and see the phenomenon. Predicting exactly when a display will take place is not easy, but those who register at the website will receive an automatic email aurora alert that can be forwarded as text messages to mobile phones.

Climate change

Whilst rises in greenhouses gases have made a significant contribution to global warming, many scientists, such as Dr Mann, are now interested in the possible effects of the solar cycle on the Earth's climate, as there is increasing evidence that the 11-year cycle of solar activity can have significant effects on terrestrial weather.

Between the years of 1645 and 1715, sun spots disappeared almost entirely from the solar surface. During this time the earth experienced a mini-ice age. The global temperature fell considerably, and famously the Thames in London froze over. Through the solar cycle, the amount of light emitted by the sun only changes by around two or three tenths of one per cent. Scientists do not believe that this can account for the observed solar cycle climate changes. However, the changes in the ultraviolet radiation emitted by the sun are much larger. These changes affect the strengths of atmospheric winds, and this may be felt in changes to the weather on the ground. Future research may reveal that the sun affects the climate more than we thought.
fields.bodyText: The Aurora Borealis, commonly known as the northern lights, is one of the natural world's most spectacular phenomena, featuring large areas of flashing colours, in the direction due north. For a weak aurora, the colour will be very faint and spread out, and may be hard to see. If the aurora intensifies, it may move higher in the sky and develop into a more distinct arc. Brighter patches can develop which turn into ribbons of light which dart around the sky. They are a common sight in the night skies of the far north. At times of intense solar activity, they become visible from lower latitudes. The 11-year solar cycle is now at its peak and the aurora may be visible from Britain from now until well into the next year. Viewing The northern lights can be tricky to see in this country, as an individual display may only last for a few minutes, though it may be repeated many times during the course of the night. The best time for viewing is between 10pm and 2am on a cloudless night when the sky is at its darkest. The York University magnetospheric physics group, led by Dr Ian Mann, which monitors activity in space, has just launched a website www.aurorawatch.york.ac.uk to help people understand and see the phenomenon. Predicting exactly when a display will take place is not easy, but those who register at the website will receive an automatic email aurora alert that can be forwarded as text messages to mobile phones. Between the years of 1645 and 1715, sun spots disappeared almost entirely from the solar surface. During this time the earth experienced a mini-ice age. The global temperature fell considerably, and famously the Thames in London froze over. webTitle: Furthermore: Adult illiteracy - it makes you weep!

fields.headline: Adult illiteracy - it makes you weep!
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett on a scourge of our time.
fields.body:
It appears that a special effort is to be made to defeat adult illiteracy, after the shock revelation that one in five adults has poor literacy. And about time too. Adult illiteracy is one of the scourges of our time. Every day teachers are faced with alarming examples like this:

"For potential sources of evidence: schemes of work and policies; lesson plans; Ofsted grades and feedback from observation; presentations given; use of ICT to extend pupil resources/e-mail/internet; active membership of subject associations/ liaison groups/professional association committees; qualifications obtained; command of national curriculum."

A nation where people can grow to adulthood and still write meaningless drivel like this is clearly a nation in desperate need of a campaign against adult illiteracy. This particular example comes from the instructions accompanying the long form that schoolteachers had to fill in if they wished to be considered for "crossing the threshold" and getting paid a little more money. It stood by itself in a box on the page, in bold type, as though it were screaming for help.

A few paragraphs on there was another such box, and then another, each more meaningless and impenetrable than the last.

Worst of all was this injunction to teachers filling in the form: "Bullet points are preferable to extended prose." Bullet points, generally, are nothing more than a means of avoiding the awkward necessity to write coherent prose, and they are used by people who either have nothing to say, or do not have the skill to say it.

Take, for example, this desperate but unsuccessful attempt to communicate: "Key skills can significantly improve a student's

 motivation

 progression

 achievement

 employability."

This comes from a leaflet put out by the government to launch its campaign for key skills, one of which, ironically, is literacy.

This leaflet, rather touchingly, tries to break through the fog of jargon with a section headed "Jargon buster". One of the terms defined is "External assessment" and the definition offered is: "A test set externally to corroborate portfolio evidence." Nowhere is the reader told what it is external to, what a portfolio is, or what evidence it is supposed to corroborate. It is a little like those dreadful books which claim to demystify computers by putting juvenile words among the jargon words - NT@winzip95jpegZLKX for Dummies, that sort of thing.

Perhaps the launch of the adult literacy campaign was an inarticulate cry for help. I rather hope so. You can help people if they know they need help. Politicians, civil servants and education administrators are in great need. They have never been taught that each individual word in a sentence has its own meaning, so they do not write in individual words, but in great prefabricated concrete blocks of words, ponderously manoeuvred from document to document. They desperately need help, and I am glad to know that they are at last going to get it.

webTitle: My son keeps demanding a computer, saying all his classmates have one.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My son keeps demanding a computer, saying all his classmates have one. Do I really need to buy one to help my children with their education? If so, what on earth will I need, and how much will it all cost? Please help - I'm a technophobe and a constantly nagged parent in need of guidance!
fields.trailText: My son keeps demanding a computer, saying all his classmates have one.
fields.body:
Niel McLean, a director of the British Education and Communications Technology Agency, says:

"Substantial amounts of research has shown that access to computers at home can help children do better at school. (However, if we look behind the research a more complicated picture emerges: children of middle class parents are more likely to have a computer at home; these children tend to do better at school anyway).

"As for your fears about your own technophobia, don't let that put you off. Real learning has two aspects, one active, where children explore and try out new things; one reflective where they think about what has happened. Even if you don't understand computers, you can can help by asking children to show them what they are doing, to talk about how and why they did what they did and what they have found out. In this sense computers are no different from books (though, traditionally, reading to children has been seen as a 'female' role - a positive side-effect of home a computer use is that it increases fathers' involvement in education).

"All this means that a computer is best seen as something that the family share, rather than something that parents buy for their children. So why not start by telling your children that you can see the value of a computer, but that you want to learn alongside them. Many schools, libraries and community centres have set up computer clubs that give children access to computers outside the school day. Sometimes these clubs allow parents and children to learn together, helping parents build up their own confidence. Ask your children's schools and the local library whether they offer any 'drop in sessions'. In that way computer use will grow out of a 'learning partnership' between you and your children, and you might begin to lose your technophobia."

Jacquie Disney, director of the Parents Information Network (PIN), which helps parents support their children's education using computers, says:

"Your children are going to be using computers at school and will inevitably benefit from an expertise in this area when they move on to further study and/or a job. Having access to a computer at home can be very beneficial in terms of children's general skill development and in support of their work at school.

"When considering whether or not to buy a computer, clarify why you want one. Is it specifically for your child's education, or will it also be used for games? This will affect the type of computer you need to buy.

"If your family just wants to be able to word process, use a limited range of educational programs and have internet access, then you don't need to pay over £400. You can get a very basic computer for £300 or a second-hand one for even less.

"However, if you want to do all the basics plus use a wider range of educational software, have the facility for desktop publishing (eg producing a leaflet for homework), play most games and have internet access, you should be able to find a computer for between £700 and £1,000. If games are a priority, you need to spend £1,000 plus.

"Finally, even if you are buying it for your children you need to learn some of the basics. Put the computer in a communal area of the house, not your child's bedroom."

Richard Wentik, of The Which? Guide to Computers, says:

"Computer advertising tries to lure novices into spending more than they need to with vague promises of speed and power. In practice, these factors have little to do with long-term usefulness and reliability.

"Choosing your software (the tools or programs) first is the golden rule of computer buying - work out what you want to do, research which software will work best, and then find the hardware (keyboard, screen and main system unit) to match. It can be worth learning the basics of the subject from the many books, magazines and courses that are available - the magazine Parents and Computers might suit you best. Remember that a computer is not so much a one-off purchase as an ongoing investment: like cars, computers cost a lot to run."

 Next week's problem: Midway through their A-levels, two of my son's friends decided to leave school and start work. Although my son says he wouldn't want to do their jobs, he is impressed by their new found wealth and confidence. He behaves as if qualifications are a waste of time. He is clever, and always wanted to go to university. How can I encourage him to stay on and at least finish his A-levels?

webTitle: So you want to learn ... keep fit

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Keep fit
fields.trailText: Keep fit
fields.body:
You're not doing that right. Pardon?

That's not how you do a tricep dip. I know.

You're too close to the bench. Look, I'm not doing a tricep dip. I'm sitting down.

Ah. Sorry, I'm just too enthusiastic. You don't say.

Yes. Keep fit. Can't get enough of it. Right.

I want to be an instructor. What sort of instructor?

Gosh! How many sorts are there? Keep-fit instructing can range from teaching exercise-to-music classes through to circuit training or gym instructing, but one way or another, all are responsible for the overall health and fitness of their clients. They are trained to teach and assess all aspects and levels of fitness safely.

What's the basic method? With individual clients, it's devising specialised programmes. People start off at different fitness levels and with contrasting needs and objectives. All need programmes tailored to specific requirements.

Then they go for it! Yes, under supervision. Instructors have to understand all health and safety ramifications. They've got to make sure their clients don't overwork and do not set about routines and exercise in a harmful manner.

What about group teaching? Safety is still paramount in aerobics, gym or circuit training instruction. Instructors become responsible for their clients' fitness only within that class, but sometimes try to encourage them to improve their health and fitness outside of the sessions.

And job opportunities? Most keep-fit instructors work for themselves or for local health clubs or sports centres. Some solo operators work as personal trainers with just one or two individual clients on a long-term basis.

What about hours and conditions? Hours are at the discretion of the individual, unless they choose to work within a fitness company, when the emphasis may be more on evenings and weekends.

What do fitness instructors need? Plainly, they've got to be physically fit. They need a keen interest in health and fitness, and a knowledge of anatomy and physiology. They will also need a certain amount of co-ordination and must enjoy working with people.

Any entry requirements? There are no specific qualifications required. However, formal training of some kind is essential. It might be a health and fitness diploma course run by a private company or local college. This trains for instruction of all aspects of fitness. Instructors wishing to work in one particular area can rely on a specific qualification in that field, eg for aerobics instructing. The RSA run courses for qualifications recognised within the fitness industry. Courses and qualifications can be checked out through Sprito - the national training organisation for Sport, Recreation and Allied Occupations.

webTitle: Sport is taken seriously "down under" and this is no ordinary sporting event

fields.headline: Olympic ideals
fields.standfirst: First Edition/C4
fields.trailText: Sport is taken seriously "down under" and this is no ordinary sporting event
fields.body:
The Sydney 2000 Olympics are good news for Australian school kids. Their spring holidays have been made a week longer so they can enjoy the excitement free from their studies. Sport is taken seriously "down under" and this is no ordinary sporting event. Those children will be old men and women when an Australian city next hosts "the Games". It was 1948 when they were last held in Britain.

By now the competition is in full swing - 10,200 athletes from 200 countries after 302 gold medals for events in 28 sports. But are the Olympics in good shape?

What are the Olympic Ideals?

The Olympics were first held in Greece in 776 BC. It was a rule that, while The Games were in progress, fighting between rival Greek cities was to stop. "The Sacred Truce" idea was revived by Baron Pierre de Coubertin when he created the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1894. He hoped that the modern Olympics would be a force for good, with sports being practised "in friendship, solidarity and fair play."

Have the Games been taken over by big business?

The linked circles on the Olympic flag represent the five main continents in harmony. It is not only a famous symbol but also an internationally recognised "logo". Big companies will pay for the right to include it on their products' packaging by becoming official sponsors. They hope to share in the prestige that the Games attract and like to be linked to top sporting achievement. The worry is that the IOC is too motivated by money and that some companies such as Coca Cola and McDonalds are the wrong "backers" for something associated with health and fitness.

Who else benefits from the Games?

The other winner is Sydney. 1.3 million tourists are there for the Olympics and a further 22 million people may travel to Australia over the next four years thanks to the current publicity.

Such benefits encourage cities to make huge efforts persuading the IOC that they should host The Games. Suspicions exist that some of the tactics they resort to are unfair. Recently, a scandal involving gift-giving by Salt Lake City in America as part of its bid for the 2002 Winter Olympics led to the resignation of 10 IOC officials.

Is anyone missing out?

Many of the 400,000 Aborigines (2% of Australia's population) feel very excluded. Pride in Aboriginal athletes such as 400m runner Cathy Freeman does not lessen the pain caused by ongoing discrimination. To be an Aborigine is usually a guarantee of poverty, poor health, imprisonment and early death. Up to the 1960s there was a policy of forcibly taking those Aboriginal children with lighter skins away from their parents so they could be raised as "whites".

Should politics be kept out of the Olympics?

Perhaps, but because of their high international profile, the Olympics have often been used politically. This has not always been negative. This year, the teams from North and South Korea - nations at war for the last 50 years - marched under a special unity flag.

What about the drugs problem?

The Olympic motto is "Citus, Altius, Fortius" and to be faster, higher or stronger, some athletes turn to drugs. To stop them, each IOC country tests their athletes. But ensuring all nations apply the same standards is hard - America and Britain have been accused of being too lenient. Doubts also exist about the accuracy of the tests. One of the banned drugs, Nandrolone, occurs naturally in the body and some foods.

Athletes risk their health by taking drugs. Anabolic steroids, which promote muscle development, can cause cancer and heart attacks.

So are the Olympics becoming meaningless?

"Definitely not," says Phillip Pope of the British Olympic Association. "To get to the Olympics at all is a huge achievement and there are dozens of athletes who train doggedly while maintaining other careers and caring for families. Many Olympic sporting heroes never become famous."

 The official Olympics site has an excellent archive of news stories: www.olympics.com

 For a discussion of the treatment of Aboriginal people in Australia, see the article "From The Dreaming to the Dole": www.sydney.indymedia.org

It is transmitted every Tuesday morning at 11.25am and repeated on Wednesday at 11.25am. Go to the First Edition Quiz at: www.4learning.co.uk/first-edition

fields.trailText: Maintaining privilege | Not impressed | Take them out | Part-time at the OU | A matter of fact | Higher teaching
fields.body:
Maintaining privilege

Two advertisements from last week's Guardian Education:

1. University of Cambridge: GEEMA Co-ordinator (Group to Encourage Ethnic Minority Applicants to Cambridge University). Skills: effective communicator with 14- to 18-year-olds, teachers and careers advisers. Application from recent graduates welcome. Salary £13,500 per annum.

2. University of Oxford: Careers Adviser. Skills: ability to relate quickly and effectively with students and employers, to produce material of quality on employment matters, to listen to and counsel students individually and to lead group discussions and training sessions, to liaise with academic staff and participate in management of the service. Graduate with work experience.

Salary £28,725-33,548.

My interpretation: it isn't worth anything to try to increase minority applicants to Oxbridge, but we'll pay a fortune to ensure that our already over-privileged graduates remain privileged. Perhaps the successful applicant for the first job can cite the second in an "equal work for equal pay" application to an employment tribunal.

S Semple
London SW2

Not impressed

Peter Kingston's droll Pulling Power, (Further, September 5), ended with a cliff-hanger. The three air-hostesses, who had joined him in the Arabic class, achieved their aim of learning how to say "welcome" and "good-bye" in the foreign tongue in lesson one. They therefore never came back. Did the class tutor?

Whatever his qualifications and experience, with a drop-out rate of possibly 25% from day one, he was clearly in need of retraining and I trust that, at the very least, his performance-related bonus was withheld!

Frances Gee
Cumbria

Take them out

What a shame that Susan Rees didn't mention the perfectly legal and practical option of home education to the parent whose child was disaffected and truanting (If you ask me, Education, September 12). It was also misleading to say: "You do have a legal duty to send your child to school." It should be pointed out that this is only true if a child's name is on the school register. Parents should know that it is very straightforward to remove a child's name from the register - simply write to the school saying that you, the parent, are going to take full responsibilty for your child's education by teaching them at home.

Susan Godsland
Home Education Advisory Service, PO Box 98, Welwyn Garden City, Herts AL8 6NA

Part-time at the OU

Caroline Ewans said she could not find any part-time PGCE course (Letters, September 5).

I graduated with a PGCE (maths secondary) in 1996 through the Open University, following an 18-month part-time course. It was designed for people with family commitments and people already in work. Caroline should contact the OU to see if the courses are still available. French secondary was definitely available at the time I studied.

I would strongly recommend the OU PGCE to anyone interested in teaching.

Astrid Goldsmith
Hertfordshire

A matter of fact

To the real world it may seem that debates over the nature of history are as relevant as counting angels on pinheads. So when the Guardian treads on the toes of a history professor (Guardian Education, September 5 and 12) little would appear to be gained by entering the fray.

However a few years spent teaching undergraduates reveals that the issue is not just one of theory, but one of quality: quality of teaching as much as the teaching of quality.

When Alun Munslow writes that "history is a narrative-linguistic cultural practice as much as it is an empirical-analytic one", more is in danger of being lost than just the epistolary art form. That a history book is a written text seems fairly incontrovertible, but the question remains as to what to do with that piece of information.

It is, unfortunately, a mere hop, skip and jump from asserting that history is written down as a text to asserting that history is only a text. What is being erased is not only the lives of anyone not currently living, but such old-fashioned concepts as truth and quality.

The pernicious effects of such thinking have already filtered down through the educational system. First year undergraduates are terrified of making value judgements about literature, for fear of reaching outside of the text and into the real world.

The only real effects of departments gazing at their own navels and forgetting the existence of facts is to strip away the possibility of encouraging students to seek out more challenging work. How much easier to sit in an armchair and criticise other historians than to plough through forgotten manuscripts in the British Library. How much easier to study Big Brother than T.S. Eliot.

Quality does matter and when we finally have a whole generation of graduates who cannot read 18th-century poetry or decipher an Elizabethan manuscript, who are we going to turn to so that the next generation can be educated?

Eddie Marcus
postgraduate student, English Faculty, North London University

Higher teaching

While we welcome your report drawing attention to the possible alternatives to voluntary self-regulation by teachers in higher education (You are in my sights, Guardian Education, September 5), there are a number of factual inaccuracies in the final paragraphs that might seriously mislead university teachers contemplating joining the Institute for Learning and Teaching in Higher Education (ILT).

You quote a figure of 2,000 staff holding teaching qualifications out of a pool of 150,000. The ILT does not issue teaching qualifications - it accredits institutions' own programmes and accepts individual members. The number of academic staff holding teaching qualifications is clearly much higher than this. The figure of 2,000 is nearer to that of our current membership, which has now passed 2,000 and is growing rapidly as people are recognising the value of membership both in terms of the benefits they receive and the potential for career advancement.

More seriously, the wording of the following paragraph implies that the Higher Education Funding Council's adverse report refers to the ILT and not the Quality Assurance Agency's procedures. This is most emphatically not the case, and I should be grateful if you would set the record straight.

Dr Paul M. Clark
chief executive, Institute for Learning and Teaching in Higher Education, York

webTitle: Obstructing education inspectors carries a whacking fine

fields.headline: It's criminal
fields.standfirst: Obstructing inspectors carries a whacking fine
fields.trailText: Obstructing inspectors carries a whacking fine
fields.body:
Several days ago, Plymouth further education college lecturer Chris Moiser was flicking through a copy of the new Learning & Skills Act, when he came across Section 57, sub-section 6, which makes it an offence to wilfully obstruct any person exercising functions in relation to an inspection. The offence is punishable by a fine of up to £2,000, which makes it a big league crime, more serious than selling alcohol to under 18s, loitering for the purposes of prostitution or being found drunk and disorderly, and on a par with driving without due care and attention.

"I had no idea the offence existed," says Moiser, "and neither had any of my colleagues. Even the principal didn't know about it. But it's interesting to see that all further education staff have been targeted as potential criminals."

Moiser then started to work his way back through the Further and Higher Education Act of 1992 and the Schools Standards and Framework Act of 1996 to see if the offence was listed there. To his surprise it was, though it was rather more hidden. The Learning & Skills Act at least tables the offence in its list of contents, but you would have to wade through the small print of the two previous acts to ferret it out.

So, with most colleges waiting for the Framework of Inspection report due in the next few weeks to iron out the anomalies between schools and colleges, should lecturers read anything into the fact that the offence is now being given more prominence? Dan Taubman, national official in Natfhe's College's department, believes it's a little early to be pressing the panic button.

"It's still very much a reserve power," he insists, "and I don't know of anyone who has ever been prosecuted under it. There have been instances where lecturers have refused to take part in an inspection as part of their industrial action against a college, but no legal action was taken against them. My guess is that it would be the management who might be at most risk of prosecution if they were to withhold records."

For those who are still worrying about the possibility of picking up an unwanted criminal record, the key word to remember here is "wilful". Wilfulness is almost impossible to define, but Scott Ingram, a criminal lawyer, believes you would would need to prove a state of mind that went beyond the mere careless or negligent, which means that some of the traditional methods lecturers have used to get the better of the inspectors may still hold good.

"I've heard of one lecturer in the midlands who enrolled her son in her class and put him in charge of discipline," says a lecturer who preferred to stay anonymous. "There was also an A-level class that had a royal marine commando whose coursework results were supposed to be linked to the smooth running of the inspection. I don't think that class had problems."

Even if someone does get round to mentioning the word wilful, they've still got to do something about it. The offence is non-arrestable and the inspector would have to report the incident to the police and persuade the Crown Prosecution Service that the case was worth prosecuting. Don't relax too much, though. There's always a first time.

webTitle: Pay and conditions in further education

fields.headline: Big picture
fields.trailText: An attempt to gather the first accurate overall picture of pay and conditions in further education since colleges were incorporated in 1993 is to be launched next week.
fields.body:
An attempt to gather the first accurate overall picture of pay and conditions in further education since colleges were incorporated in 1993 is to be launched next week.

Ministers say they must have a credible analysis of the workforce and its recruitment and retention problems before they can deploy the extra £50m pay initiative to reward high-calibre teachers.

The DfEE is part-paying for an exhaustive 18-page questionnaire drawn up by the sector's employers' organisation, the Association of Colleges, and its five trades unions, to go out to all colleges.

Meanwhile another survey conducted for the Commission for Black Staff in Further Education has found that only around 3% of lecturing staff and just two principals in a sector approaching 450 colleges, are black.

"If you are black and seeking a career in further education, it is hard to get in - and very hard to get on," said a spokeswoman.

Jocelyn Prudence, the AoC's director of employment policy, said: "There is widespread concern about recruitment problems. The survey hopefully will provide urgently needed information."

Among other topics, the questionnaire, to be returned by October 31, asks how many full- and part-time employees, and how much money each college spends on agency staff.

webTitle: How a Russian charity became the world's biggest training organisation

fields.headline: Lifeline
fields.standfirst: How a Russian charity to help Jews survive became the world's biggest training organisation
fields.trailText: How a Russian charity to help Jews survive became the world's biggest training organisation
fields.body:
Last November, at a time when the Buenos Aires spring was turning into summer and the jacaranda trees were in full lilac bloom, I had the good fortune to be paid to go there. My job was to take photographs for a book celebrating the 120th anniversary of a Jewish educational charity called ORT which, despite few people having heard of it, is the largest non-governmental training organisation in the world.

Today it operates in more than 60 countries with 280,000 students - a far cry from humble origins in the tsarist St Petersburg of 1880.

The Russian financier, Baron de Gunzburg, decided to help alleviate the poverty that the country's anti-semitic laws had forced millions of his fellow Jews into. With other leading members of the community, he raised money to set up a number of vocational schools where impoverished Jews could learn the trades that would help them survive. ORT - or the Organisation for the Distribution of Artisanal and Agricultural Skills among Jews - was born, and before long it became an indispensable component of Jewish life in Russia. By the early 20th century it was operating in eastern Europe too.

The 1917 revolution drove fundraising outside the new communist state. Yet ORT continued to provide training to Jews in the Soviet Union until Stalin's purges of 1937 led to it closing its Russian operations for the next 50 odd years. Elsewhere in Europe it carried on in an increasingly dangerous climate. Wherever Jews met with discrimination, the organisation provided them with the means to fend for themselves. Somehow it operated in Berlin right up until the 1940s and remarkably carried on running courses in ghettos and camps in Nazi-occupied territory even as the Holocaust was in full swing.

As European Jews fled to places as far as Shanghai and Santiago, ORT followed, setting up centres where refugees could learn skills that would allow them to earn a living. By the end of the second world war the organisation had become global, shadowing the diaspora to the New World and, of course, to the new state of Israel.

Argentina was just my first stop, before Uruguay, America, France, Russia and Israel, now the main focus of ORTs attentions, with 80,000 students in 140 schools, universities and technical colleges. But it does not just look after its own. In Jaffa I photographed Jewish and Arab pupils learning side by side. In the mountains of northern Israel I visited an ORT-funded school in a Druze village.

And for the last 40 years ORT has been active in the developing world, setting up self-sustaining vocational training programmes. It is a mark of the esteem in which the organisation is held that states as diverse as Bhutan and Bahrain, Bangladesh and Bolivia have all asked it to provide them with technical assistance. More recently it has taken an active part in helping Kosovo and Bosnia get back on the road to normality by establishing education programmes.

As I tripped around the world, I don't think I've ever seen so much technological hardware. From a charity to help a persecuted people simply survive, it has turned into a sophisticated organisation leading the way in preparing people for the hi-tech revolution.

Then there is the sheer scale of it. Moving from country to country, I was overwhelmed by the diversity of this colossus, whose annual budget runs to some $250m. In that one month, I photographed - to name but a few - media studies students in Buenos Aires, trainee aircraft mechanics in Tel Aviv and prospective fashion designers in Moscow. ORT returned to Russia in 1995 and has a technology centre in St Petersburg.

It was the mood that stuck most in my mind: a genuine spirit of collaboration. Most teachers and students I met were no longer bound by the master-pupil relationship of my school days, but were more like partners in a project to ensure future generations' success. The St Petersburg founders would be proud to see just how well their pragmatic philosophy of training people for life has paid off.

 Facing the Future, 120 Years of ORT (£15.99) from ORT House, 126 Albert Street, London NW1 7NE. Telephone: 020-7446 8500

fields.headline: Oxford looks to FE
fields.standfirst: Many further education students are precisely the people Oxford wants
fields.trailText: Many further education students are precisely the people Oxford wants
fields.body:
For too long further education has been the Cinderella of Oxford's admissions system. Last year only 459 candidates from further education colleges applied to Oxford. The figure for the maintained sector as a whole was 4,373, and for the independent sector 3,426. The further education success rate was also much lower than in the other sectors - 30% as against 40% in the entire maintained sector and almost 45% in the independent sector.

Of course, special factors need to be taken into account. Some further education colleges have few A-level students and specialise in vocational and recreational courses.

But that is not a reason for complacency. Students at further education colleges are self-motivated. Sometimes they choose further education because there are no sixth forms where they live. Sometimes they are disenchanted with school. But the crucial point is that they are at college because they made a positive choice to continue their education. They are treated as adults; and they are expected to organise their time and studies themselves. Many of them have exactly the qualities that Oxford looks for.

There is no need to fear that a substantially higher further education intake would mean lower standards or need positive discrimination. It is doubly tragic that so few further education students apply to us - for the nation, because talented young people are failing to develop their potential to the full; for Oxford, because we are missing out on a group which has as much to offer us as we have to offer them.

In two days' time, Mansfield College, Oxford will host a conference, sponsored by the Allied Irish Bank, to explore possible solutions. It is the first conference on this topic to be held at Oxford, but it is only one element in a much broader campaign.

The social and cultural factors that lie behind Oxford's failure to tap the talent in further education colleges are deep-rooted and many-sided.

Lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, negative stereotypes, the Brideshead image and perhaps a perverse, inverted snobbery all help to deter potential further education candidates from applying.

But the crucial point is blindingly straightforward. For whatever reason, too few further education students realise that Oxford might be the university for them. Too few further education students realise this because Oxford hasn't done enough to tell them.

Last year, Mansfield (fully supported by the university) decided that it was time to break down the barriers of habit and ignorance which have kept the application rate down. As a dissenting foundation, originally set up in the wake of Gladstone's legislation breaking the Anglican monopoly of the ancient universities, access is in our blood.

But we soon realised that we couldn't make a significant difference to the problem on our own, so we set up a consortium of seven colleges (Harris, Manchester, Hertford, Keble, New College, St Hugh's and Worcester in addition to ourselves) with the common aim of targeting the sector to encourage more applications from it.

Funding from Higher Education Funding Council for England made it possible to employ a highly effective, but part-time recruitment officer during the summer. The work she started will now be carried forward by a full-time successor - a recent Oxford graduate and former further education student - who has just been appointed with generous support from the Sutton Trust.

The new recruitment officer will be part-missionary and part-saleswoman, not just for Mansfield but for the entire consortium, and indeed for the entire university.

Thursday's conference will be an invaluable building block. We shall hold mock interviews in English and Engineering, explain the mysteries of the admissions process and give current Mansfield students the chance to describe the "Oxford experience".

By the end of the day, we hope to have established an enduring dialogue between the further education sector and the university.

A lot more will have to be done before Cinderella is fully ensconced at the ball. But I hope and believe that she is on her way.

 Professor David Marquand is principal of Mansfield College.

But we soon realised that we couldn't make a significant difference to the problem on our own, so we set up a consortium of seven colleges (Harris, Manchester, Hertford, Keble, New College, St Hugh's and Worcester in addition to ourselves) with the common aim of targeting the sector to encourage more applications from it. Funding from Higher Education Funding Council for England made it possible to employ a highly effective, but part-time recruitment officer during the summer. The work she started will now be carried forward by a full-time successor - a recent Oxford graduate and former further education student - who has just been appointed with generous support from the Sutton Trust. The new recruitment officer will be part-missionary and part-saleswoman, not just for Mansfield but for the entire consortium, and indeed for the entire university. Thursday's conference will be an invaluable building block. We shall hold mock interviews in English and Engineering, explain the mysteries of the admissions process and give current Mansfield students the chance to describe the "Oxford experience". By the end of the day, we hope to have established an enduring dialogue between the further education sector and the university. A lot more will have to be done before Cinderella is fully ensconced at the ball. But I hope and believe that she is on her way.  Professor David Marquand is principal of Mansfield College.

fields.headline: Men at work
fields.standfirst: Most college managers are women, so why haven't they changed the prevailing macho culture of bullying and stress into something softer
fields.trailText: Most college managers are women, so why haven't they changed the prevailing macho culture of bullying and stress into something softer
fields.body:
Those who have had a working knowledge of further education colleges down the years will be aware of just what bastions of male chauvinism many of them have been.

Often led by men who had joined the sector when it was mainly craft and heavy industry based, they have allowed a "Boys' Own culture" to prevail.

"Gentlemanly paternalism" was one apt description of the style of leadership.

Anyone calling foul and claiming this is unfair only needs to be reminded of the first Association of Colleges conference four years ago. This was at a time when women comprised 60% of all staff and 75% of all part-time staff in further education.

The chair of the AoC greeted delegates (some of whom were women) with the words "welcome gentlemen" and closed the conference by telling delegates "to get off home, boys".

That a male club atmosphere was allowed to flourish in the further education sector for so long is strongly linked to its relative invisibility. Whereas the workings of schools have gradually gained higher profile in the media, further education has been regarded as a backwater. Away from media attention, the sector has "witnessed some of the most blatant and rampant examples of 'macho management' to be seen in any sector, public or private, in the UK over the past 10 years."

This is the view of the editors of the summer edition of the Journal of Further and Higher Education, which is devoted to examining the influence that the sharp increase in the number of women managers is having on the further education sector.

This situation, they surmise, has probably arisen because of the reduction of traditional craft industries and the rise of the service sector, which has affected the curriculum in further education colleges. By 1997, women principals in colleges numbered 81 (17%) compared with 13 (3%) in 1990.

So have conditions improved for women staff in colleges as their star has risen in the last decade? If one considers workload the answer has to be a negative. Women managers in the sector are found mainly at the lower levels (e.g. curriculum management, human resources and student services) where they make up some 60% of the workforce.

Since colleges became independent corporations in 1993 it has been at the lower levels of management that the screw has been turned when it has come to making financial savings. There have been roughly 25,000 redundancies from a full-time work force of 135,000 but there has been a huge increase in the numbers of students.

This has boosted workloads and those bearing the brunt of these increases have been the women who have taken up many of these middle management posts.

Farzana Shain of the Department of Education at Keele University believes that middle managers in colleges perform "dirty work". From the statistics on work allocation in colleges Shain concludes: "Middle management emerges as a key site wherein tensions, stress and examples of bullying behaviour proliferate. This suggests that crisis and stress are increasingly being pushed further down the line to where the majority of the women recruited to management positions since 1993 are located."

Stress is being piled on as work like budgeting, planning and auditing is passed down without any commensurate reduction in teaching loads.

The "feminisation" of the sector replicates what has happened in some other professions such as nursing and school teaching. Feminisation takes place when the status of a profession is reduced, there is a decline in pay in real terms, conditions of service get worse and men reject it as an enticing option.

Another factor likely to increase the number of men leaving the sector has been government interference in what is taught in college lecture rooms.

For some people the exodus of male managers from the sector is not necessarily a bad thing, as Pam Cole of the Department of Educational Studies at Sheffield University discovered when interviewing senior men and women managers in colleges.

One male principal found that women staff in their 40s were much more energetic and committed than men. This view was supported by a woman second tier manager who reported that "There are a lot of dynamic women in their 40s, whilst many men feel that they have done it, got the T-shirt and no longer need to make the effort."

So, will the feminisation of management in colleges bring about a change in their culture? The jury is still out on this question, but the omens are not encouraging.

Rosemary Deem of Lancaster University and her colleagues believe that there is no guarantee that further education colleges will become better places in which to work as a result of the increase in women managers. They are of the opinion that some male managers may adopt a more parenting approach and have greater sensitivity to the feelings of employees. On the other hand, after interviewing college managers they believe: "Some female managers may choose to adopt aggressive and status/hierarchy-driven approaches to their work.

"We certainly saw signs of this in a few of our female interviewees, notably those who were particularly willing to embrace enterprise and business cultures and take on macho management."

Farzana Shain echoes this worry as a result of her research findings. "At first sight there would appear to be a shift towards more feminised styles of management. However, a clear analysis reveals that despite being adopted by many women and some men, this way of managing has not replaced the masculine competitive values that underpin policy and practice in the further education sector."

Perhaps in the dog-eat-dog climate that has evolved between colleges since 1993 a masculine approach is needed to ensure survival. The market economy may mean that a feminine approach to management is doomed to failure; which is a pity because, as lecturers will confirm, many of our present day colleges are not pleasant places to work in.

webTitle: The most northern university on the planet

fields.headline: The bear necessities
fields.standfirst: Welcome to the university where you don't lock your doors but never go out without a rifle
fields.trailText: Welcome to the university where you don't lock your doors but never go out without a rifle
fields.body:
It is day one of your university induction course. Take the rifle and learn how to protect yourself against being killed by the local wildlife. In the field the student will need to put tripwires round the tent to set off thunderflashes in case of night attack, and learn how to pack a sledge and signal down a helicopter.

Riding a bike from digs to lecture hall with a £500 university issue hunting rifle slung over your shoulder is routine for students enrolling at the most northerly campus on the planet. It is an outpost of Norway in the high Arctic properly known as Svalbard but better known to most Brits as Spitsbergen. Next to the hooks for coats is a gun rack.

This centre of scientific excellence is closer to the pole than the edge of the Arctic Circle and takes protecting its students very seriously. It is only three years ago that a female student, walking unarmed less than a mile from the centre of the campus, was killed and half eaten by a polar bear. Her companion, another woman student, jumped over a cliff to avoid the same fate and survived, at the cost of two broken legs.

Longyearbyen, the capital of Svalbard, has other claims to fame apart from being 78 degrees north, the haunt of polar bears and the only campus in Europe where the students are routinely armed by the university authorities. There are also local rules about security. No one locks their front door so everyone has a chance to escape into the nearest house if a polar bear is passing.

It has probably the best ratio of professors to students on the planet and an extraordinary list of visiting lecturers in the specialist subjects of Arctic biology, geology, geophysics and technology. Spitsbergen, and the neighbouring islands that make up Svalbard, are dotted with international establishments at the frontiers of space technology, research into climate change and such projects as mapping precisely how fast continents are moving together or apart.

Lasse Loennum, director of UNIS (University Courses on Svalbard) regrets one omission from his extraordinary line-up - British students. Although in 1999 there were 234 students from 22 countries and all of the lectures were in English, not a single UK student was enrolled. "I like British students because their basic maths and physics is so good, but getting them here is very difficult."

UNIS is jointly owned by the four Norwegian Universities and the first students were accepted in 1993 as an integrated part of the Norwegian system. There are no tuition fees and 35 courses are offered for undergraduates with about 50 M.Sc and Ph.D students. This year there are 14 professors on campus, 10 adjunct professors (visitors from other universities) and 170 guest lecturers. Most of the students come from Scandinavia, with half from Norway, but France, Italy and the US also send undergraduates.

Although the campus is only 600 miles from the pole it is one of the warmest places in the Arctic because Svalbard's shores are washed by the most northerly extremity of the Gulf Stream. It is only 20 degrees below centrigrade in winter compared with 40 degrees in Canada much further south. In winter, when it is dark for three months, students are treated to almost daily displays of the northern lights because Svalbard is on the cleft of the magnetic field of the earth.

This makes the nearby mountain an ideal study centre and the home of the two giant dishes which are the eyes and ears of European Incoherent Scatter Radar project which studies the effect of the sun on the earth's magnetic field.

In summer the weather can be warm enough to sunbathe and temperatures can reach 20 degrees C during the four months without a sunset.

Mr Loennum says that while Svalbard is a mecca for winter sports and wildlife enthusiasts, and students spend part of the year getting around on snowmobiles, the university is not an excuse for a "tourist semester".

"This is the smallest university in the world with the largest laboratory, this marvellous almost untouched stretch of the Arctic to study. We study things like permafrost, glaciers, global pollution and how it affects the Arctic and marine biology. The staff-student ratio is unrivalled so we expect people to take full advantage of the opportunity. We want people to be serious."

UNIS has links with the University of Southampton, University of Wales in Cardiff and Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Oxfordshire but so far only at a post-graduate and teaching level.

So far there are no undergraduates but Mr Leonnum hopes that word will filter back. "We are hoping for a British contingent to complete our international flavour. After all, as all the lectures are in English, it seems a shame not to take advantage."

The 35 courses on offer this year are up to one year's duration as part of biology, geology, geophysics or technology degrees. The university year lasts from August to June with the spring semester January to mid-June.

See: www.unis.no
